From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Message-Id: <9309030222.AA04239@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Accompaniment and perfection
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


As a drummer, I seriously enjoy whacking on stuff, and I enjoy hearing
skillful whacking on stuff, but most of what people do at raves with
woodblocks, whistles, etc. isn't skilled at all -- it simply detracts 
from the experience that I get when a perfect drum-groove is interrupted
by some yotz who can't even keep a straight 4.

I enjoy participating, and think that participatory events are excellent
and help crumble the edifice of spectacular society where life is a thing
to be watched and consumed instead of lived -- but unskilled and out-of-time
distractions aren't a contribution, they're an ego-stroke.  I hope, when
I drum in a group, that I am helping to make a beat bigger than myself or
any individual within the gorup could.  If I'm not, I'm just beating off
in public.

The big problem is that we are taught to consume rather than participate, so
we don't often learn the skills that let us participate in group efforts.
It's a tough call, but I think we should accept our limitations while
working to transcend them.  Bring your lightsticks, flashlights, funky
clothes, luv phasers, beanbags, smiles, energy, strength; all make the
world/r*** more interesting than it was -- but don't fuck with the music
unless by doing so you think you can create something better.


Shifting gears --> Most of the beats that get me tweekin' are from live
playing, not straight outa the machine.  Live playing can crust together
that elusive combination of accent, delay, swing, nuance, and reaction
which creates that Beat in a way that is difficult (and certainly non-
intuitive) to program into a sequencer directly.  But can the musicians
keep themselves there?  Rarely.  James Brown rode his bands harder than
just about anyone, and they only got it some of the time.  The machine,
once it gets it, can go on indefinitely with very little skill involved.
The humans have to be greatly skilled, but they can react real-time in
ways that the machine won't.  Anyone who's been to Crash Worship shows
and raves too knows the difference, even though the DJ can mix in ways
that the record makers didn't intend.

// g

>As a drummer, I seriously enjoy whacking on stuff, and I enjoy hearing
>skillful whacking on stuff, but most of what people do at raves with
>woodblocks, whistles, etc. isn't skilled at all -- it simply detracts 
>from the experience that I get when a perfect drum-groove is interrupted
>by some yotz who can't even keep a straight 4.
I am sorry, but not all of us are drummers and can even keep a straight 
4.  I may be the only one, but I enjoy hearing people that are somewhat 
on the beat, banging bongos and wooden blocks and tamborines.  I 
think it adds to the beat rather than detract from it.  
>I enjoy participating, and think that participatory events are excellent
>and help crumble the edifice of spectacular society where life is a thing
>to be watched and consumed instead of lived -- but unskilled and out-of-time
>distractions aren't a contribution, they're an ego-stroke.  I hope, when
>I drum in a group, that I am helping to make a beat bigger than myself or
>any individual within the gorup could.  If I'm not, I'm just beating off
>in public.
I don't think it had anything at all to do with the ego.  I personally 
wish I had a noise maker at times.  It just is enjoyable to make 
noise to the beat that is already going. 

Don't beat off in public you might get in trouble. ;-)
>The big problem is that we are taught to consume rather than participate, so
>we don't often learn the skills that let us participate in group efforts.
>It's a tough call, but I think we should accept our limitations while
>working to transcend them.  Bring your lightsticks, flashlights, funky
>clothes, luv phasers, beanbags, smiles, energy, strength; all make the
>world/r*** more interesting than it was -- but don't fuck with the music
>unless by doing so you think you can create something better.
This is your particular opinion that I tend to disagree with.  You 
can always move to someplace where they are not playing with any 
type of noisemaker. 

Rest deleted. 


Again, just my personal opinion. Hope everyone has a good extended 
weekend. 

:-)
vivianm

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1646      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I'm back in town after 2 weeks of vacation in Italy and Amsterdam
(were I got some cool local music) and I also haven't post a review
in ........ ages so here it is:

			YSH was better than ever

Map point at Cleo on Haight St.
The map was incorrect so it took me (and a bunch of other people) a while
to find the right spot. It was actually kind of fun.
When we finally found it, we also found a police car sending people away from 
what was the entrance: a fence with a hole that was surrounding a private
property of TEXACO I guess.
The person at the door decided to leave the spot so that the police would leave
too. They actually said that they were going to free the dogs.
Unfortunately they didn't leave right away. More people showed up and also
a cab dropped someone.
Anyway the police was looking from far away and after a final check they left 
and we all got in. We still couldn't hear the music so we didn't know for sure 
if there was something going on.
After few minutes of walking on a rough path (we took the wrong one) we
started to see the bonfire and hear the music. 
The place was almost identical to the one were they had it a couple of time 
before (it was just few minutes away from it) but the bonfire made it very very 
cool.
It looked like a small FMR: outdoor (nice breeze), nice people (well actually
nicer than the FMR crowd these days), and almost free (the $5 donation is 
absolutely worth it).
The music was good and more and more people got into the groove dancing (who 
was the DJ around midnight?).
I left during Laura set (who was very impressive) and more people were coming.

	Thanks YSH

					Gianmaria

I went to deep space at the oasis last night with 
a bunch of people- it was very good.

the only negative thing about it was that the door people were
being especially adamant about ID's. It didn't make a 
difference to me, but some of my friends <21 didn't get in.....

at first.

I finally convinced three of my underaged friends to just walk 
back in with me, heads held high. Funnily enough, the cops
were out front talking to the bouncers, providing just the perfect 
amount of distraction for everyone to get in :)

Lots of energy inside- lots of fun!

There were two after parties, but I was tired and had work-
so- I became a pumpkin and nursed the sloppy network of 
dream-seeds inside.

ATTENTION: Massive Culture got their permits back from...
(was it Richmond or Livermore?)- so the party should be going on/off.
Be smart: call the info line!

Peace-

Jocelyn

My definition of 'tribal' may differ somewhat from Mike's.  Since I don't
know much about artists and titles I can't name the names I'd specify as
onna tribal tip, but I've been hearing more and more of it on tapes lately
(maybe that's not the best way to gauge the currency of the scene, of
course).  Nonetheless, I have ulterior motives here, because I think
tribal will go over big-time in the Northwest if anything really gets
moving up here.

----------------------
 what do you mean by tribal?  I realize that your grasp of the "terms"
and the music they refer to may be sketchy-mine sure is, but could you try
to simply describe the music in terms of instrumentation, samples, type
of drumming [simple kick, hats & snare or lots of toms and other drums?],
tempo, etc.?

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep  3 13:04:05 1993

	id AA00763; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:04:03 PDT
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-06/08/93)
	id AA11593; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:04:02 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA11660; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:04:01 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA25020; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:04:00 PDT
Date: Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:04:00 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9309032004.AA25020@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
Subject: Re: Long weekend report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> fred heutte says:
> 
> >One other thing I'm seeing more of in the tribal tradition, and this is
> >a good trend in the scene, is people bringing drums and providing a
> >live counter-component to the records.  I've seen this at Boogie Buffet,
> >YSH and elsewhere, and it works quite well to feather the edges of the
> >relentlessly perfect beats we hear from the records.

Jon answers:
> [...]it drives me
> nuts to hear some lowly HUMAN sitting there with a drum going off in
> his own personal time signature. 

I'm with Jon here.  Although I can enjoy the occasional well-played 
conga (the guy at BB isn't too bad), the dull thuds of off-beat acoustic 
percussion are usually delivered at an energy level far below the super-
human capabilities of our electified friends.  I also find the self-
absorption of live performers to be a bit of a vibe-sink.

> i like that "relentless
> perfection"... we strive for it all the time, in the studio.  jeno
> told my roommate that he really loved the timbale section in "trip
> harder" because it sounded like a live person, but i thought it was a
> failure on my part because i played it rather sloppily and we didn't
> correct all the strikes afterwards. 

Well, the achievement of "perfection" is a pretty subjective thing.  After
all, if everything was quantized down to quarter notes all we'd have is a
horribly mushy metronome.

The Trip's timbale section never sounded completely human to me.  It was 
partially quantized, and the "sloppiness" did not sound like the human feel 
factor one would expect from a professional percussionist.  It was still 
laid over a perfect beat, and I found the timing of the notes to be eclectic 
*and* mechanical, and thankfully nonhuman.  I thought it was great.

For me, raving is largely about the transcendance of our normal everyday
limits.  Sensory overload, unrestricted dancing, sleep deprivation, trance, 
psychedelics, luv phasers, abandonment of ego...  It makes sense that music 
that supports getting us beyond ourselves is music that is created beyond 
the pathetic limits of our physical state.  Just like computers are an 
extension of our physical selves, the music made by computers is an 
extension of our musical and rhythmic sensibilities.  Why rein it in?  We 
don't have to stay in the Stone Age in order to satisfy our tribal yearnings.  
I love playing keyboards along with sequenced tracks, but I would never 
subject anyone at a rave to the horrors of my all-to-human style.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

	id AA05320; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:17:15 -0700
Received: from quark  by portal.unix.portal.com (1.738) 
	id AA17979; Fri, 3 Sep 93 13:17:12 -0700
Received: from nmtvs313.mtvyp by ntmtv.bnr.ca (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA07119; Fri, 3 Sep 93 11:06:06 PDT
Received: by nmtvs313.mtvyp (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA25243; Fri, 3 Sep 93 10:25:45 PDT
Date: Fri, 3 Sep 93 10:25:45 PDT
From: hart@ntmtv.com (Chris Hart)
Message-Id: <9309031725.AA25243@nmtvs313.mtvyp>
To: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  Accompaniment and perfection
Cc: ames!athena.mit.edu!isbell
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


The big problem is that we are taught to consume rather than participate, so
we don't often learn the skills that let us participate in group efforts.
--------

a very good point, one of the most crippling things about popular culture,
IMHO.



It's a tough call, but I think we should accept our limitations while
working to transcend them.  Bring your lightsticks, flashlights, funky
clothes, luv phasers, beanbags, smiles, energy, strength; all make the
world/r*** more interesting than it was -- but don't fuck with the music
unless by doing so you think you can create something better.
----------
I can see this both ways...but I tend to side with the partially or non-
skilled drummer - I am a musician, and I know from personal experience
that all the pissed off people in my past who had to suffer (& I *do* mean
SUFFER) through my early learning stages (some say I'm still there, but
hey, as $hort sez "If ya don't like my raps, don't buy 'em, please")
would have *ended* my development as a musician if I had listened to
their complaints and quit playing...so I try to grin and bear it when
I hear someone struggling.  I admit it might be annoying at times, but
in my experience it doesn't happen *that* much and often the drumming
is pretty good!  Beyond that, to me, to stifle a developing musician
is a far worse crime than kicking a few sloppy of muffed beats...even
giants like coltrane sounded like shit at one point, ya know?  but if
he had been successfully stifled - well, it would certainly have been
*our* loss (this of course applies outside of the jazz scene, I used
coltrane to make a point about the neccessity of playing truly BAD
music during developmental stages - everybody goes through it...).

but of course that's just *my* opinion...as Charles Isbell would say
"what's yours?"

-=jack=-

Subject: Re:  Long weekend report
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Content-Length: 492
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


> what do you mean by tribal?

Lots of organic sounding percussion -- i.e. congas and timbales, rather than
your typical kick/snare/hats sound that most techno uses.

Examples (all are from last year) ---

Jambo: "Drum Attack"
Studio X: "Join the Tribe" (b-side of "Los Kings del Mambo")
808 State: "Reaper Repo" (b-side of "Timebomb")
Ultraviolet Catastrophe: "Trip Harder" (b-side of "The Trip")
Baha Men: "Back to the Island"

And going back further --
Renegade Soundwave: "The Phantom"

i don't know who wrote this (i missed the original) but: i have no
wish to stifle anyone.  i would just love for these developing
musicians to go lock themselves away and FINISH DEVELOPING before
subjecting me to their awkward arrhythmia.

geez, beginning pianists do NOT get to play at carnegie hall, y'know.
you gotta WORK at it first.  i know rave culture has a DIY aspect to
it but, dammit, i pay $20 to get in to these massives to hear boomin'
tunes on a kick ass system and it BOTHERS me when these drummers start
in messing up the beats and ruining my trance.

Jon Drukman                                      jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com

I believe they were... Massive Culture is not entirely a rave (Wicked,

arcade type stuff, a Wicked tent, and other stuff.  It looks like a
rap meets rock meets rave type thingie.  Additionally, going from 2pm
to 2am is kind of wierd wicked hours. 

I've heard enough negative things about it (a lot from the flyer
itself, actually) that I'm going to avoid it at all costs.

The record company that I run is having a sale.  I know that using the net
and sfraves for profit is a no no, but we've greatly reduced our prices for
this sale, and Brian approved this message before I sent it out.


Here's the deal:

All items are $10 each.  Or get any five items for $40.

Details: Minimum order of $20.  (A two-record set counts as one item.  A CD
also counts as one item.)  Prices include postage.  If you want to order by
COD, the UPS COD charge is $4.  Payment must be in the form of check or
money order, made payable to Twitch.  We do not accept credit cards.
These prices are valid for US and Canada customers only.  Sale ends 9/17/93.

Our address: 584 Castro Street, Suite 600, SF, CA  94114.  This address is just
a mailbox, not our actual office.  Also, please do not send me email trying to
arrange a time for me to deliver an order to you in person.  I would prefer to
conduct everything by mail.  And please do not ask us to notify you by email
that we received your order.


Here's what's available (CDs listed first, followed by vinyl) ---

> I've heard enough negative things about it (a lot from the flyer
> itself, actually) that I'm going to avoid it at all costs. 

Like what were some of the bad things you heard? I was planning on
going, just to see how the whole thing went down... but other
considerations have intervened. My attitude towards the flyer
was 'hmm, interesteing. I'll bet this won't come off quite like
they're hoping for, but it's worth checking out for $20'. Of
course I've had misgivings and doubts floating around in my
head... but what are the negative things you heard? Personally
I didn't like the promises of extra-stringent security and
searches...

Still, it's an interesting concept. Like taking Lollapalozza
one step further. I would think that anyone trying to unite
disparate elements of the music scene deserves at least a
chance to show their stuff, rather than dismissing the event
before it's even happened!

-- 
Jim Petersen
chinacat@netcom.com


--

chinacat@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner  Sat Sep  4 08:27:40 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05119; Sat, 4 Sep 93 08:27:40 PDT

	id AA05112; Sat, 4 Sep 93 08:27:38 PDT
Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA06344; Sat, 4 Sep 93 08:27:52 -0700
Date: Sat, 4 Sep 93 08:27:52 -0700
Message-Id: <9309041527.AA06344@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
X-Sender: jsl@netcom.com (Unverified)
Subject: Whatcha gonna do? chill? non!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

This weekend has got to be the weekend of "Well, we tried...".
First the "Massive Confusion" had permits, then lost them, then got them
back.  KQED talked about it.  And I talked to a couple of DJ's about it...
If you want a 15-- event (read "all ages") massive culture is a best bet. 
My morbid curiosity asks (in the back of me head) "How many of the people
on the list will attend this 'all ages, multi-cutural' extravaganza?". 
from the tepid responses the party is getting on the list I would say,
NONE.  Not that I blame anyone mind you, just found it curious.

In any case I ain't goin' to that Circus.  The LAST thing I want to see is
a bunch of teenagers going "yo homie, sup..." or "yo <statement>...".
Arrgh!...

So what the hell esle is up?  BASICS that's what...I guess I'll go to that.
 Ingest some mind-altering stuff.  Hang with a few friends.  Lament about
the ugliness....get into the music.  Tony, Josh, & Jeno are enough to get
me out of the house...Although I generally have not liked the crowd at
BASICS as much as I did in the beginning, they have generally been pretty
cool parties.  Martin does a good job, and the DJ's usually fuck it up. 
Good to go.

The price ain't right?  Wrong.

I talked to P today about the rise in the prices of Boogie.  The $5 is to
cover the additional sound that they put in the dark room.  They are
renting it from JK and $4 would not cover it the cost of the sound so they
raised it 1 buck.  Also the addtl dollar will buy much more than a sound
system.  They will be having, on a more regular basis, special guests. 
That's all I can say for now, but rest assured, Boogie will remain a cool
space for quite awhile with the new sound and the special guests.

I still have problems with the price though, but it won't stop me from
going...at least this week ;)

Peace...
John

"I will not be pushed, filed, stamped, indexed, briefed, de-briefed
or numbered!..." - No. 6
                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com 
=================================================================

Let's cut thru the underbrush and the "healthcare debate."  Hey,
EVERYBODY's for healthcare, etc.  Proposed:  a consitituional
amendment recognizing healthcare as a RIGHT of American persons. 
It should be referenced loosely to the "rights" already in our
mythos, to LIFE, LIBERTY, and the PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS.  (So that
if not staying alive and accepting enforced healthcare is your way
of exercising LIBERTY and PURSUING HAPPINESS, that's okay, you're
constitutional too.)

Who in their right mind (well....make that just WHO....) would or
could oppose a constitutional amendment that recognizes as a right
what everybody except insurance companies and medical profiteers
already THINKS is a right? 


From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep  6 18:07:53 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17651; Mon, 6 Sep 93 18:07:53 PDT
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17644; Mon, 6 Sep 93 18:07:50 PDT
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA08694; Mon, 6 Sep 93 18:08:08 -0700
Date: Mon, 6 Sep 93 18:08:08 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9309070108.AA08694@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Weekend report...  T'was wonderful
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Weekend rave report...

   After attending ConFrancisco Sci-fi convention,   me and a couple friend
from Pennsylvania (Who has never been to a rave before),  headed out to
Basics.    We've heard somewhat bad reports on Masssive Culture,  and 
runours that it was cancelled,  then was actually going to happen.  We
didn;t want to sit in the car for 7 hours driving out to the Burning Man
thang,  so we opted for Basics.    GOOD CHOICE!!,  thanx to those
enlightened folks who advised us on the best one to go to..

  Will be looking forward to reports from those that went.  Basics was 
really GREAT!  especially the outdoors chill out area,  where I can 
ocassionally escape the smoke,  and cool down after dancing.    I saw
the usual crowd there.   As usual,  towards the end,  I pulled out
all the stoppers and got totally wild.   My friends from Pa.  really
dug it,  and now are true total dedicated ravers,  and hope to plug
into the rave scene out PA.  way.   Andy will probably request to 
get on sfraves.   Judy,  his wife was totally wild and almost
un-controllable,  and digging it so much...  Really made me happy to
see her having so much fun.

  After that,  we boogied over to "Boogie" for our traditional coffee
pancakes,  and more dancing.    We brough along "Radion" the Tarot card
reader dude,  and he was tearing up the dance floor over at Boogie.

  Later that afternoon we got word that there was to be a gathering
in GG park,  so we all go over there.   After getting there about 12:30,
we got word that the permits were revoked because the park rangers
didn't want the grass dug up because of the rain.    There was NO rain,
so we all hung out in the park,  gathered around a boom-box,  doing
SOME dancing,   but I was mostly interested in doing my exercises,  yoga,
and relaxing.    I knew that I would have little sleep between Basics
and Deep space nine.

  That evening,  Radion wanted me, Andy and Judy to attend a Pagen Ritual
which I thought was pretty interesting,  very relaxing and I enjoyed myself
drumming and dancing.   Later that evening,  me and Radion headed over to DS-9.

  My freinds went back to Mill valley to my place,  totally hosed and worn
out.    But I was raring to go for another all-nighter (2nd night without
sleep).    I over heard people talking about taking bets as to whether or
not I would show up.   I did....

  Wonderful place,  really comfy chill out area,  done up very nicely 
with the black lights,  foourenscent paint and all.    BUT!!  the PIGS 
came in at about 3 am and shut the place down ... BUMMER!!  and Carlos 
never got to spin.    I was really looking forward to dancing his long 
sets.   So if anyone out there knows why the PIGS shut the place down,
I would really like to know.    The music was GREAT!! dispite the 
interruptions caused by the sound system over-loading the circuit
breakers.    Perhaps that was the reason,   as I saw fire trucks,
pigs,  and massive traffic jam on Columbus St when we left.    Other
people wanted to meet up with us later,  but the pigs wouldn't let us
stay there and find our friends.    Later on, we called the Fluid
Groove info number,   but couldn't find it,  because the recording
was hard to follow,  way too fast to jot down,   but when we got
to the Exploratorium parking lot,  we looked around,  met others also
looking,   but never found it.    Did it come off at that place?

  So,  we left for Mill Valley and called it a night....   WONDERFUL
WEEKEND...

Cheers...

CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep  6 19:05:51 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA18181; Mon, 6 Sep 93 19:05:51 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA18174; Mon, 6 Sep 93 19:05:48 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA12480; Mon, 6 Sep 93 19:05:51 -0700
Date: Mon, 6 Sep 93 19:05:51 -0700
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <9309070205.AA12480@soda.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Fluid Grooviness!!!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


East Coast met West Coast (and a bit of the interior) last night at 
Fluid Grooves.  Bryce's location was good, I'm not going to say exactly
where it was 'cause they're going to use it again in a few months.

Anyway, the sound truck arrived a tiny bit after midnight, and Ethan
and company got things set up pretty quickly.  We had a scare when a
police car turned up, and kept quiet for a while.  Bryce and Ethan went
to talk to the cop, and all was well . . . Lee An got started about 1.00 am,
but as this was the *first* public usage of the Sound Vision system, it took
a few minutes to work out some set-up glitches.  After that Lee went to
town, and the sound system was WONDERFUL.  Big full CLEAR sound, lots of
"feeling" without massive ear-splitting volume.  It was a very good 
combination.

I spun after Lee, and of the 40 or so people at the party about half 
danced to my fave hardcore and hard trance tracks around a fire that
Ethan had set.  It really felt good to play exactly what I wanted, and to
see people enjoying it even though it was so different.  The rest of the
party was sitting talking around a second fire, or walking along the beach
enjoying the not-completely-freezing night.

When I got done SLiP (Ed) got started and made a bunch of people very happy
and tranced-out with his collection of beautifully phat trancey tracks.
During Ed's set Brian and Bryce went to the Safeway and bought us all 
breakfast -- assorted muffins and orange juice.  It was just what a lot
of us needed to keep going.  When Ed was finished my legs hurt from dancing
so long in the sand, but it was MORE than worth it being out doors and
dancing by the fire.  He closed with "Electric Dreams," and it was just so
upbeat and happy that I ran around hugging everyone who was dancing.

Pete Ashdown took over, and played a mix of techno, industrial, ambient,
cyberfunk, and who knows what else.  His set was neat in that it had a lot
of restful parts followed by very energetic oh-my-god-I-gotta-dance parts.
The sun came up during his set (well, it was foggy so we never got any
real sunrise), and at one point about 8 people were standing on the rocks
right along the shore dancing and staring out at the Bay.

Pete finished up at 7.00 am, and then Jon Drukman took to the tables.  Around
this time two seals swam very close to the shore, and stuck their heads
way out of the water to look around at what was going on.  A lot of people
were still dancing, or at least standing up and grooving to the beats.

At about 7.15 the cops came by again and apparantly suggested that it was time
for us to close up shop.  The cop also thanked us in that they did not receive
a single complaint all night from our party.

As we were breaking down a lot of joggers came by our site.  They weren't
too thrilled with the fact that we had the tables in the way of their
jogging path, and one even called us a bunch of motherfuckers.  I think
that guy needs to jog a LONG way to get out a lot of frustrations, no? :-)
Many of us then headed to breakfast, and after espresso, crepes, and eggs
many huggy goodbyes were said and Brian, Jo, and I headed back to Berkeley.

I'd like to thank Lee Fogel for being the seed that got this party started.
He and I were talking in email many weeks ago about "where's the techno" in
San Francisco, and from that I got the idea to approach Bryce and Brian about
throwing a renegade while I was out.  Bryce took the helm from there, and 
put together a party that really worked.  Ethan's sound system was wonderful,
and I'm honored to have been part of the crew that gave it its maiden
voyage.  I'd also like to thank everyone who came, especially Jo who danced
like a REAL Brooklyn Bass-Bin Worshiping girl during the hardcore parts, her 
enthusiasm helped to make me feel like I was doing right by you all.  

But most of all, I thank everyone who came and danced and smiled and
hugged me.  I'd been feeling sort of ambivalent about San Francisco all week,
but you all made me feel like I can be part of the family here if I choose
to be.  No, I'm not moving out soon . . . but I will be back for a visit
in mid-October.  

Love and community,

Laura

P.S.  Thanks for making me promise to come visit San Francisco, Brian.  I
love you!

From: hyland@netcom.com (Tim Hyland)
Message-Id: <9309070651.AA16237@netcom4.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Rhythm at Townsends
To: wicked@netcom.com
Date: Mon, 6 Sep 93 23:51:09 PDT
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves List)
In-Reply-To: <9309050000.AA26689@netcom4.netcom.com>; from "wicked@netcom.com" at Sep 4, 93 5:00 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi Markie, thanks for posting the note about Rhythm.  Don't know why
I'm thanking you, though.  Maybe it's because being a gay raver I
often have to make a choice each evening before going dancing.  Do I
want to go to a rave?  Or do I want to go to a gay club?  It's rare
that an event will fit both categories, but Care*Free in the early
months sure did.  And Rhythm is close.  (The End Up on Sunday
afternoons is a good bet, too, but I digress.)

I guess posts like yours help promote interaction between the two
communities (ravers and gay club kids) so that (hopefully) someday I
won't have to make this kind of decision.  I'm quite comfortable at
most raves, but many of my club-kid friends aren't.

Now, as for Rhythm being Care*Free -- The Sequel, I don't know if I
quite agree with that.  I was at the first couple nights of both
clubs.  Care*Free really felt like a weekly rave thrown by and for
queer and queer-friendly ravers.  It was March of 92, just a couple
months after the big Toon Town craze at Townsend and Quartknee was the
first person to tell me about it.  It kept that rave-y feel for a
couple months until it was "discovered" by the club kids.  After the
gargantuan party Care*Free had the weekend of gay pride that June, it
just wasn't the same any more.

Rhythm, on the other hand, feels like a gay club that quite a few
queer-friendly people come to later in the evening (post-last-call).
The distinction I'm making is probably based in the notion that Rhythm
is being promoted by a person (David?) who, from reports I've heard,
is rooted squarely in the gay club mind-set.  It's only been around
for a couple of weeks, so we'll see how it turns out.

For what it's worth, thanks again Markie.  And I'll see you at Rhythm
next week.

Share and Enjoy,

Tim

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  7 00:03:17 1993

Received: from well.sf.ca.us (well.sf.ca.us [192.132.30.2]) by nkosi.well.sf.ca.us (8.6.beta.4/8.5) with SMTP id AAA26409; Tue, 7 Sep 1993 00:03:10 -0700

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
To: laura@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  Fluid Grooviness!!!!
Message-Id: <93Sep7.000242pdt.14068-4@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Tue, 7 Sep 1993 00:02:37 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I'm sorry I had to miss Fluid Groove, but it sounds like it was a successful
weekend overall for net.raving -- FreeVibe in Seattle, co-produced by our
own Tigger (glenn_fajardo@aldus.com) went off BIGtime in a really nice
rural setting in Issaquah, east of Seattle, in a wooded ravine.  The cops
came, the cops hung around, and the cops left with smiles on their faces,
as 400 ravers including a lot of newbies did our rockin' to a groovee beat.
Sunrise found me in a comfortable spot up in the old growth on the hillside,
amazed once again that this kind of electronically-derived music sounds so
great in the outdoors. Especially good sets from DJs Czech (Vancouver) and
Shocka (Portland).  We had a foggy morning, which only added to the ambience,
making a neat counterpoint to the Get Down3/Get Wicked scene at Sonoma
County Fairgrounds I got off on so much at the end of May.  Finally we
headed back to Glenn's place for an informal after-party that turned into
all day lazing around listening to all kinds of music.

I took the bus back to Portland and dropped in for a while at Mindscape,
an all-nighter at the Depot downtown here.  The advantages: its a three
block walk from my office.  Otherwise, it wasn't much to write to the
world about -- derivative, monochromatic techno (as opposed to fun,
varied, pumping techno) and an OK but fairly vibeless crowd.  The scene
in Portland still awaits its Renaissance . . .

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  7 09:47:41 1993

Received: from gatekeeper.oracle.com (gatekeeper.us.oracle.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Message-Id: <9309071645.AA26833@dlsun87.us.oracle.com>
Date: Tue, 7 Sep 93 09:45:39 PDT
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: weekend update
Reply-To: jdrukman%dlsun87@us.oracle.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

i was going to DJ an early morning slot at MESS, so i slept in friday
night, waking up at 5 AM.  checked the phone message which said "we're
continuing in a new location..."  i feared that the crowd would be
small, and indeed it was.  momentum seemed to be pretty much gone, and
everyone vanished 10 mins into my set.  so i packed it up and went
home.  i don't know how the party was up to that point, obviously.  it
was quite cold in the backup location, and people seemed more into
huddling under blankets than dancing.

so then i missed basics cos i had been hosting a party at my house and
i was really bombed from that...

i was beginning to think that my whole long weekend would be thrown in
the toilet when i heard that fluid groove was happening not ten
minutes from my house!  so i bopped over there, only to get totally
confused by the directions - apparently i wasn't the only one, given
other messages on sfraves this morning.  fortunately, i ran into pete
ashdown who showed me the One True Path to the party :)

and what a party!  vibe to spare, boomin' massive sound system (ethan
is god's personal sound system guy, btw) and a *beautiful* location.
Lee, Laura & Ed all did their best; I finally got to hear the
legendary XDZebra Twin CD attack, and i even got to play 4 records
before the cops suggested (quite politely) that we pull the plug.

too bad, cos the sun was coming up and there was a marvelous view of
the golden gate bridge, top shrouded in fog.  i think the party could
have continued for another hour or so without a hitch.  oh well,
there's always next time!

i left with a big dopey smile on my face and that warm glow inside
that you only get from a truly spiritual encounter.  once again i'm
reminded why i put with the all the bad stuff in the rave scene - cos
the good stuff more than makes up for it.

big smiles to all involved, and an extra special thanks to tamara for
risking life & limb to score my record crates at 6 AM...

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  7 10:16:12 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA22066; Tue, 7 Sep 93 10:16:12 PDT
Received: from orca.es.com (ES.COM) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA22058; Tue, 7 Sep 93 10:16:09 PDT
Received: from slack ([130.187.198.23]) by orca.es.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA16523; Tue, 7 Sep 93 11:16:05 MDT
Received: by slack (4.1/E&S_client-ver1.5/SMI-4.1)
	id AA20760; Tue, 7 Sep 93 11:16:15 MDT
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9309071716.AA20760@slack>
Subject: Groovin' the Fluid
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Tue, 7 Sep 1993 11:16:14 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3428      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I had to go to meet Carlos and Garth to give them their advances at an event
on Columbus.  I'm not sure what it was, but it was fairly cool.  The high end
of the sound disappeared at around midnight, so we left right after that.
There was one track the DJ who played before this happened did that I MUST
HAVE.  It sounds like a drum line or a drum line of plastic bucket drummers,
but it is LOUD.  Any ideas?  Anyway, after that was out of the way, we went
back to my brother's apartment and loaded up my gear.  We then drove around in
touristy confusion until we found the back of the Exploratorium.  I was amused
to get out of the car to find someone (I believe it was Betsy) asking US how
to get to the beach.

Grant and I arrived at the site hearing nothing.  We wandered all over trying
to find it, but kept heading in the general direction.  Eventually we found a
small group of people huddled around turntables and a sound system.  Bryce was
busily engaged talking to an officer.  Amazingly enough, he reasoned with him
and Fluid Grooves was on!

Lee did a cool set, very much in a SF tip.  Then Laura grabbed the tables.
I'd asked her before how hardcore has gone over in SF, and she said she hadn't
done any, but was planning to tonight.  She spun some good stuff, but after
listening to Drukman bitch about the BPMs for an hour, I'm glad she was the
guinea pig.  If I was going to play any hardcore that night, the stuff I would
have dropped would have left several seals and a ton of fish floating in the
bay.  Most of my "hardcore" sounds like Skinny Puppy over a machine gun 4/4.
Ed then took the tables and played some very nice hard trance.  Which
effectively nixed hard trance from my set as well.  I was getting rather
nervous as to what exactly I was going to play.

I went on at about 5:15 and started some funky junk.  There were a couple of
screw-ups in the first half hour (of course, if you didn't notice them, I'm
not going to point them out to you).  Let's just say that using the line/phono
switch to go between the turntable and the CD didn't work as well as I had
planned.  When Ethan came over and pushed down the main volume on a track I
was playing, I realized it was time to go a little bit softer, even though I
had never really ventured beyond 130 bpm.  It was really satisfying to throw
down "Quest" and have Ethan come back and pull the sliders up.  After that
point, I was completely comfortable in the situation and moved through one of
my best sets ever. 

Even though there was a cloud cover, the sunrise was still spectacular.  It
was really fabulous to be behind everyone while they pulsed on the rocks
watching the bay light up.

I was disappointed to see Jon gone from the crowd in the middle of my set.
When he returned with two crates of records, it made it all worth it.  Being
able to hand the baton to Jon was the best possible way I could have thought
of ending my first set in SF.  I'm glad he was prompted to go and grab his
music.  Too bad things had to stop just as he started to move.

Thanks to everyone for the kind comments and warmth I experienced.  I've
recently been really down on the scene here with not many good experiences
while DJing.  Fluid Groove really recharged my batteries.  Say the word on the
next event and I'm down there again (although I'm definitely flying).  Being
able to illuminate the Golden Gate bridge is an experience I will not soon
forget.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  7 10:55:55 1993

From: nrg@netcom.com (Ethan I. Miller)
Message-Id: <9309071756.AA08963@netcom4.netcom.com>
Subject: Fluid Groove
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 7 Sep 93 10:56:11 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Wow What a Night! Fluid Groove fully came off... Many, many thanks to
everyone involved: djs, dancers, pelicans, seals, friendly cops (including
MPs), the list is endless, but especially Bryce for putting a whole lot of
time, energy and money into a great endeavor. Truly a huge payoff on a
whole lot of Positive Energy :)

The Music Was Great! What a nice alternative to our usual SF fare. Lots of
hard trance in a variety of flavors; I truly enjoyed the east coast sound
exemplified by great sets from Laura and Ed (SLiP); XDZebra was killer,
really interesting mix of music from airy slow stuff at dawn to driving,
almost rock and rolly house, he really covers a lot of ground. Lee An
started off the night with an awesome trancy set; Lee you really need to be
headlining; everyone's missing out... which is exactly how I feel about Jon
Drukman as well (Hi Jon) the friendly cops put a quick end to the beginning
of his set which was sounding truly phenomenal. Gold Star to Jon for
putting out the effort despite it being 6am at the time...

Maiden Voyage for my new system was a resounding success if I do say so
myself. To me, a killer sound system is one where rather than feeling like
you're hearing a speaker (or speakers), the air just fills and becomes
saturated with sound, feels kind of liquidy. I think we definitely got
there...with power to spare; it was as loud as any of us wanted it and it
wasn't maxed out!   !) As a note, I wouldn't have got this system if
sfraves didn't exist, so in many ways I think of it as the sfr system; lets
make sure and put it to good use spreading the vibe! Too, I'm calling it
and myself *Sound Vision* so keep your eyes open for:
  Audio by Sound Vision...

Also, myself and Mark Norby from Tilt-a-Whirl are throwing the first of a
series of parties called *Home* on Saturday September 25th. Synergy will be
providing main visuals, confirmed djs are:
  Markie
  Simon (UK)
  Jon Williams
  DRC (YSH)
  Galen
  Jordan (fresno)
This will be a full-scale event in San Francisco; please mark your
calendars and come on out and give us your support, lord knows we need it!
:)

once again, many thanks for a great weekend!
peace always
ethan

Anyone know how the MESS party went down Friday night.  I went to the
location at Aquatic park, danced and chilled for about 1/2 hour, including
with these two homeless ravers out from the mid-west who had been camping
in the bushes where the party was set up.  They had partied and fallen 
asleep when they saw red flashing lights.  Thinking it was cops, they 
snuck through the bushes to spy on what was happening, thinking they might
get busted for camping there, and lo and behold the sound system came on.
Needless to say they were pleasantly surpised.  After about a 1/2 hour the
cops came and told us to shut down.  I told the organizers about the Pt.
Isabel spot that I've been wanting to test, just in case they didn't have
any back-up spots and they decided to go there but I had to get up early
the next day and knew if I went, I'd get trapped their all night so went
home and called it a night.  Does anyone know how or if the party went to
Pt. Isabel?

-Mark

On the gay/straight mix topic:

Check out Corduroy City.  It's being promoted by two great people, each of
whom is well established in their respective scenes:
Stephanie from Together (a weekly "rave" type event)
and Sean from Product (a weekly gay event)

[Just to be clear, I'm not saying that these two are the "main" promoters
of these clubs-- just high-ranking board members  ;)  ]

It has been their intention from the beginning to bring these two crowds
together and so far I think they're doing a great job.

	Tony

okay so im stupid
i was really sick on wednesday and i wasnt feelign much better on friday
when i took off for SF, but i wanted to get to fluid grooves on sunday
so...

being even stupider when i get to SF i say, lets go to MESS
which was a journey in and of itself and scared my friends who took me up
cuz i was now wandering around with a sleeping bag and my stuff
hopign to find some party 

finally finding it, i danced for a bit and then realized i was way too
sick to dance and i should have just gone to the house wiht them
and slept
oh well so i curl up on the parking lot between two cars that provide wind
protection and listen to some good music
(the crowd noticeably going wild over UVC and Freak Chakra)
and then jon D showed up and played a bit but it was just too damn cold
he dropped me an andy off outside streetlight records where inside
was a key to a nice warm apt
after wanderign around and hiking a bit and sleeping
on the hill above that we managed to get the guy who was opening streetlight
to give us the key to said apt (its a friend of andys who left the key for him,
not jsut a key lying around for people to use :)
so i crashed there and then went record shopping and wandered all around SF
and came abck the apt to crash again to get up and catch the bus to
jon and mike and jeffs... which was fun but i was really out of it
and felt god awful ahving to meet people like that
except that wonderful woman from down under who made me tea and stuff

i went back to susie's to crash after much begging and pleading to go somewhere
and sunday i went to GG Park and got really lost looking for a party that wasnt
happening adn ran into someone else looking for said party and
we hung out and talked about stuff and he doesnt like the elmo peoples
and we ran into some of his freinds and they were waiting for someone
to pick them up and i gave them money to go make a phone call
and we got picked up after trying to catch a bus and seeign said people
and then we went over to the party at some guys house on 8th street
and i was feeling worse so i went back to sussies and slept a lot
and it seemed like the plan was to go to fluid grooves
but it just didnt happen

thanks to Susie though for giving me a place to stay and Jon for the ride
from Pt Isabel to somewhere

 ,
dana

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9309072224.AA06082@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: fluid on the beach
Cc: jlf3@attmail.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I was pretty psyched for Elmo's GGPark thing & Fluid Groove so I saved up
my energy for Sunday, passing on Basics which I feared would be a repeat
of last month's big-space/small-vibe affair.  It's certainly nice to have 
a variety of different flavored parties to choose from.

Elmo's day in Labor was aborted due to the threat of water breaking on us.  
This was especially a bummer since it turned out to be a fine day.  I can't 
help but to be a little worried about our Oct. 3rd event.  I went home where 
I got paged to spend the rest of the day emboiled in a major work crisis. 

By late evening I was psyched up again.  Both Fluid Groove and Deep Star 9
were gonna be 5 minutes from home.   Although FG was by far our 1st choice, 
we were a little concerned that it would be too cold or would get busted.  
I checked it out while Janie napped, getting there as Ethan sweet-talked 
the SFPD into giving us their blessing.  I guess not all cops are pigs. 

The weather was balmy, but not too cold, and with the fire and a friendly
vibe, there was plenty of warmth to keep things cozy.  Before retrieving 
Janie,  I stopped over at DS9.  The place seemed to be jumping at 2:15; 
10$ for Jeno, Garth, Dutch, Carlos on one floor, open tables on another.  
No ins&outs.  The people on line seemed vibeless, but not necessarily 
unfriendly.

We easily decided that Fluid Groove was the place to be, and for the rest 
of the morning it was like being in a dream.  Otherwordly music, 
fog-shrouded GG Bridge, blinking lighthouse, splashing waves, seagulls 
painting trails in the sky, and an overriding feeling of family.  There's a
rather beautiful Amorphous Androgynous song that Pete played around sunrise 
that will now have a special meaning for me.  We played it twice more at 
home while chilling in the afterglow.  

Thanks to Bryce & Ethan not just for making this happen, but also for the
*way* you guys made it happen.  Knowing that there are people like you
around reminds me that being a humanoid is not necessarily a bad 
thing.  Also thanks to our out-of-state visitors for bringing over some 
fresh energy.  There's a lot going on in the SF House scene, and it's often 
hard to predict the quality or flavor of a particular party.  But with a 
little perseverance, everyone can usually find the type of party that stll 
makes raving a special activity here.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

we may never know the real story behind.  Were the first house party/raves
in England direct off shoots or copies of something going on in Chicago or
Detroit, or is that just where the music originated from?  Or was it an
innovation that English kids made using American music?  Was it an example
of parrallel evolution?

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

well i was looking up origins of street names and found two that have
become names of raves...so i thought i would share what i found...

(take from Louis K. Loewenstein, "Street Names of San Francisco")

MISSION ROCK "This street lies on the approach to the Mission Rock ship
terminal, named for the large rock in what was once called Mission Bay. 
(There was also a Mission Creek which fed into the Bay.)  All these places
take their name from the nearby Mission Dolores.

CHARTER OAK "Probably after a street of the same name in Hartford,
Connecticut, famous for the oak tree which once shaded it.  Legend has it
that Captain Joseph Wadsworth hid a Royal Charter in its trunk. This
document gave the residents a claim to a strip of land as wide as the
state itself-fifty miles--and on westward to the Pacific, cutting a stripe
across the continent.  The charter was hidden from Sir Edward Andros, who
attemped to seize it in 1767."

partyon....susie (:

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep  7 23:25:29 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>I also wonder about rave history, Chris.  It may be one of those things that
>we may never know the real story behind.  Were the first house party/raves
>in England direct off shoots or copies of something going on in Chicago or
>Detroit, or is that just where the music originated from?  Or was it an
>innovation that English kids made using American music?  Was it an example
>of parrallel evolution?
>
>-Mark


Make NO mistake Mark, the house scene started in Detroit/Chi-town.  New
York runs a close second (if not first by their estimates).  But it started
HERE in the US first.  What the folks from the UK did was take the shit to
a whole new level.  Introduced some hip electronics, and sound manipulation
etc.  It has ALWAYS had some basis in drugs, whether it be coke, rush,
booze, e, adam, or acid.  Once the English got ahold of it, and as it
spread across Europe it bounced it's ass back over here for a redux.  Now
innovation comes from all corners of the globe.  Detroit/Chicago/New
York/Miami are doing some hip shit technically, and have proven constant
producers of good stuff (not to take anything away from our local
boys/girls and European producers). England/Italy/Belguim are three
countries who have the mental shit.  At this point it is really a matter of
who has the vision, and the will, rather than the location.

In any case....
John

"I will not be pushed, filed, stamped, indexed, briefed, de-briefed
or numbered!..." - No. 6
                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com 
=================================================================

>Make NO mistake Mark, the house scene started in Detroit/Chi-town.  New
>York runs a close second (if not first by their estimates).  But it started
>HERE in the US first.  What the folks from the UK did was take the shit to

Uh, that's an awfully america-centric view of things don't you think?

I assume we're talking about rave history here, and not just house
music history. I'd say there are alot more facets to what we currently
call "rave" than chicago house music. 

If you're going to talk about the scene, you'd better start going back
to reggae soundsystems in Jamaica back in the 60's with producer/DJ's
like Lee "Scratch" Perry taking the reggae music to a whole new level
with DUB. (They don't call him "scratch" for nothing -- he is probably
one of the first people to scratch a turntable and did some amazing
studio magic back when there was very little electronics to do it
with). In the late 60's and 70's, Reggae dancehall and soundsystems of
course spread to the east coast of the US and England as well.
Likewise, people that think that  rapping originated in america
completely forget that its roots originated from reggae DJ "toasting"
as well....

In the UK, the dub stylee was taken to new heights with newfangled
digital studio equipment by the likes of Adrian Sherwood, Gary Clail,
Tack>>Head, Dub Syndicate, African Head Charge, etc. This movement
began in the early 80s and is easily the grandfather of some
"progressive techno/house" that we hear nowadays (The Orb, Future Sound
of London).

At the same time, elements of techno are present in early 80's
disco/electro sound ala "Planet Rock" and even old school
rap/funk/disco from the Sugarhill Gang... And yes, people even danced
all night to that stuff.

Finally, IMHO, mass-ecstacy/acid inspired all-night raving truly came
together in "Balearic Beat" on the Balearic Islands off the coast of
southern spain, a popular vacation spot for british hipsters and
euro-trash of all ilk. This happened concurrently with the rave scene
in England circa '87-'88. I happened to find myself on the Balearic
Island of Ibiza in the summer of '88 and did my first real raving there
while taking a break from a biz-ness trip to the UK. I met some people
there who then pointed me in the rigth direction for raving in London
upon my return. I noticed a definite cross-polination of scenes going 
on between the UK and Ibiza at the time. The Ibizan sound was alot more
electro (e.g. wacky Kraftwerk and Yello remixes) while the UK sound was
more acid (e.g. Baby Ford, and a bunch of other stuff I didn't
recognize).

Though I must say that the rave music being played in SF nowadays is
FAR MORE INTERESTING musically than any of the sounds I heard in London
or Ibiza back in '88. Praise Jah.

Hey, I'd like to stay a while and talk, but my compile on this
piece-of-shit-excuse-for-a-computer-and-operating-system (DEC Ultrix)
finally finished, and hey, maybe it'll do the right thing and work for
a change. (Arrrrgh!).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

On Tue, 7 Sep 1993, Mark Guthrie wrote:

> I also wonder about rave history, Chris.  It may be one of those things that
> we may never know the real story behind.  Were the first house party/raves
> in England direct off shoots or copies of something going on in Chicago or
> Detroit, or is that just where the music originated from?  Or was it an
> innovation that English kids made using American music?  Was it an example
> of parrallel evolution?

How I see it here in the UK, is that Chicago/Detroit house/techno provided
the seed that grew into the Uk rave scene. It evolved/mutated into current
stuff by simple evolutionary process. The harder stuff was more 'dancible' to
and this fuels the desire for harder and harder beats.

A situation has been reached, where the mutant UK music scene is now so
different to the original US style, it is being imported back to the US as
a brand new thing. Which is basically the old house scene +20 BPM, louder
sound rigs, lasers, smoke hype etc.

May be that sounds too cynical :)



From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep  8 09:22:43 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28710; Wed, 8 Sep 93 09:22:43 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA28703; Wed, 8 Sep 93 09:22:40 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA09293; Wed, 8 Sep 93 09:22:45 -0700
Message-Id: <9309081622.AA09293@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 8 Sep 1993 09:22:44 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: back from SF . . . :-)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hi!  I got back to New Jersey last night after two weeks in San Francisco.
California is cool, but a little weird (in a good way).  So here's the
report on the 2nd half of my trip.

Let's see, last time I talked about Your Sister's House, and going to LA.
Did I mention the Full Moon Rave?  Well, I'll start there.

It was big (400 people?).  It was on a beautiful beach.  It was so cold I
couldn't really enjoy it.  Also, I learned something very interesting about
myself.  Basically, I can't dance while experiencing large influxes of 
serotonin in my brain.  All I want to do is snuggle up to people, and if the 
man I love happens to be there I get *completely* distracted from the music.  
So, no more xraving for me (but plenty of vraving :-) ).  So, I'm not sure
if I didn't like the FMR because I was *sooo* cold, because of the music
in general (I'm not really into that slow funky groovy stuff I was hearing
all night, although Markie went into a strecth of white noise/acid house 
that I really enjoyed, and then Jeno at sunrise was happy and fun to dance
to too), or because of being distracted.  I'll have to do the massive FMR
thing again sometime to be sure, this time with *many* more layers of 
clothes, and nothing in my brain other than my usual bottle of home-brew
smart drinks to keep me going.

Onward . . . I spent most of Wednesday and Thursday sleeping off the FMR.
I also managed to make myself rather sick by eating about 1/2 a pound of 
Ghiradelli chocolate for breakfast one day.  Man that stuff is GOOD! The best
American chocolate I have ever tasted . . . and the best hot fudge sauce 
I've ever had, too.  Suprizingly enough, even though I was a complete 
chocolate pig most of the time I was in SF, I actually *lost* weight on this
vacation!  Must be the cool air . . . I probably shivered all the extra
calories off at the FMR and YSH.

Which brings me to the 2nd YSH I went to:  this one was outdoors, and it
was rather chilly but I wore more clothes so it wasn't so bad.  Lili Tran
started the night with very slow hip-hopish music, it was interesting and
sort of reminded me of Larry (Days-X-One) back home.  After her came Tara,
who did a good job technically and had some interesting tracks . . . but
her selection sort of petered out toward the end (I think she was running out
of records).  I went next, and kept things very slow for me (135 bpm) and 
mixed better than at the 1st YSH I did, but still not up to my best.  It was
good to see people dancing, and their energy kept me going . . . when Susan
arrived I was glad to see her because I was tired and cold.  Susan's set
really hit me in a good place.  She played a lot of very acidy tunes, which
were very energetic even though they were slower than what I usually like.  I
realized then that she truly understood the concept of *phatness* in dance
music, and her creative mixing combined with her great track selection turned
what had been a rather sad/frustrated/upset evening for me compeletely around.
She was the first DJ I really connected to out there in SF.  

Friday during the day Mike, Mary, and I played tourist and wandered around
Chinatown.  I had been feeling sort of homesick for New York all day, but when 
I got to the dark, crowded, dirty (by SF standards) streets, I suddenly felt
a lot better.  We also drove around and went up to the Coit Tower.  Friday 
night Brian and I rode the cable cars around.  Doing that was not only fun, but 
it also gave me a good feeling for some of the different areas and 
neighborhoods in SF.  One of the cars we rode was operated by a real kamikaze 
driver . . . he'd wait at the top of a hill for all the traffic to clear, then 
let off the brake and we'd WOOSH down the hill.  San Francisco, the city with 
its own built-in roller coaster.  I loved it!

Saturday afternoon Brian and I drove around Marin, and walked around the
Marin Headlands for a while.  That place is SO incredibly gorgeous, these
HUGE mountains that end right in the Pacific Ocean, amazing views of 
mountains, SF, the Ocean, and the Golden Gate Bridge.  We did a bit of
site-hunting, too!

Saturday evening started with a party at Casa Twitch (nifty studio, guys) but I
wasn't feeling so well so wasn't exactly sociable.  Brian and I left early to
go to Basics, where he was working doing parking.  Basics was held in a
national guard amoury . . . it was funny when they turned on the lights during
set-up because suddenly you could see all the non-blacklight military
banners hanging amongst the blacklight-activated Basics banners.  Basics
was big by East Coast standards . . . about 2000 people.  I was tired so I
took a nap in a way cool chill space that had the most *amazing* trippy
computer graphics projected on some hanging parachutes . . . the graphics
had dance sequences from old Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly movies, plus footage
from some Disney movies like "Alice in Wonderland" all interspersed with 
fractals, trippy blobs, and swirls of color.

I was pretty bored/lost/unhappy until people from the Casa Twitch party
started turning up around 1.00 am.  Some of the music had been pretty good,
but there's nothing I hate more than being left alone at a rave where I know
NO ONE, so it was very hard for me to enjoy myself.  Once Anne, Pete, Jo,
and others got there I relaxed, and soon noticed "Transform" coming out of
the very large speaker set-up.  "Oh my god, German Trance in San Francisco"
I thought, and I parked myself in front of the speakers and danced like mad
for about 45 minutes.  Brian returned from parking at that point, and some
seriously trancy acidy stuff was being played by some DJ who's name started
with a D, and I danced until I thought I was going to drop.  We chilled 
for a while both outdoors (where it was cold and damp) and indoors (where
it was lound and crowded) and I fell asleep in the chill space again, so we
headed out to the car and slept for like an hour and a half.  When I woke up
I was grumpy and very cold, so we collected Seth and went home around 6.15 am.

As far as big parties go, Basics was very well done.  I'm not sure how vibey
it was, because 99% of vibe is in your own head, and my head was *not* in
a very good place that night.  But, nonetheless, I managed to have a good time
so it must have been pretty good overall.

Sunday brought with it the event I'd been waiting all week for, Fluid Grooves.
I've already posted about this to sfraves, so I'll just re-post the review
of that to ne-raves when I get done with this.

So, in conclusion, San Francisco is both very different and very similar to
the East Coast.  It's very pretty, but in a different way from the green
plains and gentle hills I'm used to out here.  The City of SF itself is
MUCH prettier, cleaner, and more residential than NYC, that's for sure.
Berkeley reminds me a lot of most other large-university towns I've been
in, and closely resembles Austin, TX, a town I love dearly.

The rave(house) scene there feels a lot like what we have here, it's just
that there are so many more people involved out in SF.  Also, there are many
many MANY more people aged 22 and over involved in SF than there are back
East.  Because there are so many more people, and so many more older people,
the scene feels stronger and more mature at the base.  However, the good 
parties in SF seem to be just as wonderful as the good parties back home.
Similarly, the not so good ones have similar problems to the not-so-good
ones back here.  There are many many many more parties/clubs/events to choose
from in SF, but then they have the numbers of people involved in the dance
subculture to support it.  I honestly can not and do not claim that one is
better or worse than the other, or that one is FUNDAMENTALLY different from
the other.  Both involve people getting together to dance, have fun, hear
music they love, and be in community with others who love the music and the
dancing, too.  Both scenes can be very vibey, or not, depending on the 
night.  The music is rather different from here to there, but it's effect on
the people who enjoy the music is the same.  The sheer numbers of people 
involved in SF seems to carry the rave(house) culture into everyday life too, 
which is something we don't have out here, but perhaps if the same numbers
of people were involved it would be like that here.  (However, due to the
HIGH incidence of yuppidom and rat-racing out East, I sincerely doubt it
will ever happen simply because the critical mass of of age 22+ ravers out
East will never be achieved, whereas such odd flights of spirituality are more
the norm in San Francisco in general.)

It was great to meet so many sfravers, and to see a totally new part of the
country.  In all it wasn't the most blissfully perfect relaxing vacation
I've ever had, but it was a very REAL experience being out there.  I *will*
be back again, and am in fact planning on coming in mid-October for a long
weekend.  I still owe you sushi, Mike W., which is why I'm coming :-).  I
am very much looking forward to seeing my SF friends again! 

Love and community,

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep  8 09:56:59 1993

Subject: Dance History (was Rave History)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Wed, 8 Sep 93 9:57:15 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

	As is the case with popular music over the past forty years or
more, it tends to move between continents - import/export. Rock & Roll,
Punk, what have you. House music originating in Detroit and Chicago was
directly influenced by European outfits such as Kraftwerk and Depeche Mode.

Also in the early days in Chicago DJ's like Frankie Knuckles would program
drum rhythms and play disco records over the top of his beats in the club
environment.

American House music was being played in the Gay Clubs in England for a good
two years + before any sign of acceptance in the straight scene (circa
1985 - 1987) and even a few chart hits like 'Jack your Body' and 'Love
Can't Turn Around'.

	During the Eighties in London a warehouse party scene developed
that featured soul music ie. Hip-Hop, Disco, Uptempo R&B, Rare Groove,
Jazz Funk etc. This directly gave rise to Pirate Radio, notably Kiss FM -
a weekend station that was listened to by over a million people. There has
always been a strong underground soul scene in England ever since James
Brown & Co . invented the Funk.

Sometime in 1987 a few unconnected groups of people started throwing
all-night House parties. 'Schoom' and 'Phycic T.V '. Schoom was agroup of
South - London soccer 'fans' from the soul-side whereas Phycic T.V came
from the Industrial edge. These small parties grew in size and started to
attract the 'Trendies' (i.e fickle club kids). Inject a new designer drug
(Ecstacy) and stir with a nice helping of media and ....... Acid House.

	Of course this shit started to get played on the radio, with a
whole host of new fly by night pirate stations springing up. Larger and
larger parties. You wanted to go to a party you listened to the radio-
they told you where the map point was. Out-of-Control! So much so that the
British Government paniced. All these people gathering together and no
trouble? They don't like that. Keep everyone divided and oppressed. Also
they weren't getting their cut ($).

	Markie !)



	 --


--

I heard Moby was  on television. He was on  "Wavelength" a youth talk    show
 dealing with everyday life of our generation. They did a  little historical
segment that said house music started  out in Detroit,Chicago and was picked
up from there  to the U.K. scene. They had also taken actual footage from a
few raves to show what the scene was  like. Overall it was educating the
viewers about the Underground scene and how it is not a drug orgy, but more of

a peacefull gaathering where everyone can enjoy themselves and have a great time

Greetings, Ravers!

I want you all to know that I have invested in a 5kW generator.
We powered Ethan's Sound Vision system with it, and there was
juice to spare.  I mention this to you all because I want to
make this available to anyone on the list who wants to throw
a renegade (or even a permitted outdoor event!) and needs
a generator. It is an American made generator, on wheels,
with a continuous output of 5000W, surge load of up to 6250W
(for you techies).  It does run rather loudly (compared to
some that you may have heard), and we're working on that.
The important thing is, there's lots of portable power
that is now in the family. Oh, yes, and we're working on 
getting it set for an *electric* start (push a button to
start--won't that be groovy!), though it does have a pull
cord also.

Please contact either Ethan or I if you want to use the
generator.  Our contact info is:

Ethan:     nrg@netcom.com         415-826-6137
Bryce:     brycer@netcom.com      415-776-7249

Any donations or use fees will be gratefully accepted to offset
the cost of the generator, but are not required to use it. This
is party power for all of us!
-- 
Bryce Ryan -- Specializing in AMBIANCE -- brycer@netcom.com
"The revolution will not be televised, 
 but the proceedings will be available online."  Art McGee

Date: Wed, 08 Sep 93 13:08:10 EDT
Subject:  Massive culture
Status: OR

Notes on Massive Culture:
  
Massive Culture was an admirable event that takes lots of focus, good energy,
money and support; (I have promoted rave events and they are expensive and
take good heart and great organization).

MC had easy parking and access off 580 in Livermore. Two hugh tents, ambient
tent,  outdoor stage, industrial food trucks, lots of merchandize booths,
video game tent, visual walls, laser, VR, orbiter,. etc. Outdoor venue at a
flea market type place, no dust but walking and dancing on asphalt for 8
hours is a chore.

There was a large  friendly crowd (3,000??) -no bullshit we/them sort of
thing- I talked with some hip/hop folks and they really were into the
"Wicked" house tent scene; and they still love their "body-slammin" music. 
Many left the venue when the outdoor band stage closed at 1 am. But the
Wicked tent raved on hard and large.
 
Other notables/compliants:  No alcohol (keeping it safe) !!, great sound
systems, killer DJ's (Carlos woke up the ambient tent for an hour or so with
a killer set), Jermy, EFX, and some "live" house music creators were knocking
it out in a mostly empty tent near the enterance.  

All the action was at the hip/hop stage and the Wicked tent. Lots of cool
bands, high priced food and water (tacky). Great security without oppression
- many-many security folks - but friendly (not like the assholes at the Grove
Kichen last month).

Lots of cool booths with the normal scene merchandise, but some great stuff
from the raggae, American Indian, and craft jewerly creators. Biggest crowd
was at the Legalize Marijuana booth. VR and Brain Dream were cool and
popular.

I had a good time and I'm glad I went to support this crossover music effort.
It was a good vibe - to share the music and broaden the new world culture. It
came off peacefully  and the scene has spread out and touched more people in
a positive way. 

Given the high level of energy and effort this type of event takes, I would
say that it was a success; maybe a smaller mix without all the security and
high production costs will make for a more intimate experience. After the
Full Moon at Bonny Dune last Tuesday its hard to want to be anywhere else.
 

Peace, Love, and Rave

Forrest 

Sub note:

Several messages on the ravenet recently  strike me as elitist, having a "we
vs. them" attitude about the "scene" and people who come new (or experienced)
into rave culture. To those (hopefully only a few elitist ravers) who
continually decry the "loss of the scene" or big events; or put down
newcomers -  "they just didn't dance right or 'look' right", I say get your
head and stuckup rave nose out of the air and open up your mind.

Welcome All into the One World Tribe and spread Respect and Celebration for
each others differences. That's how we spread peace into and disapate all the
maddness of hate and fear -- 

The world of music and dance is the focus of a new community where we have
the opportunity to respect each other in real time, and where we give more
priority to honesty of feelings, and celebrating our  differences in thought,
culture, and goals.
  
   "We are not material beings on a spiritual journey; 
    we are spiritual beings who need an earthly journey 
    to become fully spiritual"  

                                 Blessed Be!

Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1631      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



After a spectacular four day weekend, work schedules and deadlines seem far
too trivial for concern.  So here's an addendum to the list of reviews.

The gem of the weekend (and possibly the whole summer :) was Fluid Groove.
The first sight of the fire worshipers and the energy surrounding all will
stay with me for a long time to come.  It still amazes me how everything 
came together (lack of a bust, balmy weather, good people, incredible
net DJ talent, great planning, the list goes on) to provide a true TAZ in
every sense of the term.  I just want to add my heartfelt thanks to all who
made this event the spiritual re-awakening I have needed for so long.  (And
definitely watch for more of Sound Vision -- pure aural ecstasy.)

A pleasant surprise on Saturday was Basics.  After the bad rap that space 
has received in the past, it was great to discover and experience the high
energy a big party is capable of generating.  True, the vibe at Fluid 
Groove was much purer and closer to my heart, but the energy at Basics was
more than I expected for such a large and diverse group.  And Tony is well
on the way to becoming a 10 on my list of mind-altering DJs.

Jazzid Up at the Oasis also deserves mention.  Although more hip-hop'ish
then jazz, a decent crowd (although maybe due to the long weekend) and a 
nice way to chill a Monday night.

                    Shamanic, artistic, archaic revival.

Chris asks:
> Did anyone catch the Wavelength cable TV show yesterday?

By chance, I caught the tail end of it.  It was a pretty positive
presentation, with Moby and a couple of Detroit promoters spouting 
how anti-drug and wholesome their scene was.  Some guy from the
audience who went to a couple of Chicago raves claimed that he saw lots 
of kids on LSD.  He was told, emphatically, that the scene is different 
in Detroit, where no one does drugs.  Right.

The best part was when the segment ended with the entire studio audience
and hostess dancing/smiling/laughing to "Go".  Good PR I guess, even if 
tailored for mainstream consumption.

> Excuse me if this is a terminally stupid question,but I was
> curious who this person was..Was it Scotto of NASA? (one of my
> customers...)

I couldn't tell you.  The bottles he had on display did not look
like any of yours, though.

- leg of eel

Some forwarded mail that may be of interest. The promotional literature
mentioned called NEXUS 'brominated cathenine'.

>From: Alexander T. Shulgin
>To: malcolm@lingua.cltr.uq.oz.au
>Subject: nexus
>
>[...]
>
>Thanks for the mailing -- yes, I am very much familiar with the
>new drug NEXUS.  I had received a copy of a mailing sent to
>[Person X] who had received a brochure and a
>set of three capsules.  He sent me copies of everything, and I
>agree with you that since cathenine has no meaning, brominated
>cathenine also has no meaning.  Cathenone and cathine are real,
>but cathenine is a non-word. [Also, Cathenone is aka cathinone]
>
>And then I received a promotional mailing out of Los Angeles,
>probably similar to the one you [actually, someone in Florida]
>received, quite slick, and there was a personal letter attached,
>soliciting a promotional comment of some kind.  
>
>I ran the base extract on one of the gelatin capsules, and it
>was 2,5-dimethoxy-4-bromophenethylamine, or 2C-B.  Something of a
>shame, in that if this drive for commercial exploitation is a
>success, it will certainly force the Federal authorities to do
>something, and the something will surely be the scheduling of
>2C-B.  A shame to have that particular compound join the others
>in the illegal bin.

Malcolm

Article 56592 of alt.drugs:
Newsgroups: alt.drugs
Path: agate!howland.reston.ans.net!europa.eng.gtefsd.com!uunet!olivea!apple.com!guest.apple.com!anarch
From: anarch@apple.com (The Anarch)
Subject: Re: Zenith/Nexus
Message-ID: <1993Aug21.203040.20072@apple.com>
Date: Sat, 21 Aug 1993 20:30:40 GMT
References: <1993Aug14.031355.20757@cltr.uq.OZ.AU> <CBtJ4F.G6M@murdoch.acc.Virginia.EDU>
Organization: Secular Humanists from Hell
Lines: 30

In article <CBtJ4F.G6M@murdoch.acc.Virginia.EDU> fhw2n@faraday.clas.Virginia.EDU (BISON) writes:
>ok... i've now seen many references to this stuff claiming that
>is legal and feels like a cross btw acid and extacy.. 

I have no idea what this stuff is, but if it feels like a cross between
acid and ecstasy, then it is probably illegal.  See the Controlled 
Substance Analogue Enforcement Act of 1986:

  "...the term `controlled substance analogue' means a substance...which
   has a stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect on the central
   nervous system that is substantially similar to or greater than the
   stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect...of a controlled
   substance in schedule I or II;...[or] which such person represents
   or intends to have a stimulant, depressant, or hallucinogenic effect..."

and:

  "A controlled substance analogue shall, to the extent intended for human
   consumption, be treated...as a controlled substance in schedule I."

The only exception to these rules that might apply to Zenith or Nexus or
whatever is if there an approved new drug application has been made to the
FDA.  Since no one seems to have any hard chemical/pharmaceutical info on
the stuff, I assume that's not the case.

--
