okay this is going to kinda second mark's remark but not...
niel posted implying distaste with so cal
last week jon drukman said it should be nuked
joachim threw in a smiley face comment about it
hoss sarbaz spoke up in defense of so cal putting in his bit
and then mark said that blanket statements like 
"southern california is better than the bay area" 
should be avoided

well, yes... im not saying its anyway intentional, but i've seen
socal/la bombed more than just the few times im mentioned,
but no one is told not to make blanket statements...
becuase hey.. its LA...

personally i find beauty in compton, more so than in newport beach,
and ive been to a hell of a lot better raves in compton than in
newport beach OR the bay area (none of the ones in compton have been
busted)

now, its not just statements, but its attitude, because, quite frankly,
i dont need no attitude from someone just because they live where they do
really, i dont have that much choice about it, i dont have the money/resources
to get up and move wherever the hell i want to
and if you think that because you do, or because you happen to end up in
a certain area of the world that that makes you a better person
then do me a favor and tell me where that better place is
so i can make sure its not here

i may be a little bitter about this, but this is where i've grown up
where my parents raised me, and i may not like all the things about this town
but im going to be happy with it and proud of it for what it has done
that is postive 
some people may not think that is much and some people may know 
better than others what is wrong or not with whatever area
but im sick of mine being trashed
im sorry, but im really goddammotherfuckingtipspilling sick
of people talking shit about places that they dont live in
rarely visit and rely on hearsay to find out info about
especially when that place happens to be my home
i personally think it would be better not to be cutting any location down
and instead dealign with the problems or the positives of teh area you live in

thank you

 ,
dana

We went to "Burning Man" and saw road warrior/rocky horror picture show
hybrid tribe burn huge man in a harsh desert environment. Rave tent was
there, 2 miles from center of camp. TAZ must have been responsible.

boy from Reno injested a MDA related compound made by his in-frat chemist.
his first psychadelic experience was spent pinned to the desert floor as a
haight ashbury clinic doctor tried to unravel the autistic groove the boy 
found himself in. Took 7 of us to hold him down as his convulsions were beyond
epeleptic. BEWARE new synthetics. Burning Man is a next year must-all 3 days.

four wheeling for the weekend and dropped in to visit some friends who
with the sign crew.  They are from the midwest and were surprised by the

From: hart@ntmtv.com (Chris Hart)

>other pertinent questions:

>1.	when did outdoor events start happeneing?

I don't know- 

>2.	where/when did e&a bcome popular?

If you're inquiring about when/where e&a became popular in the rave/house
scene(s)- I also don't know the answer to this one, but speaking generally:

A: look to the beat poets of the 50's; to my knowledge they were the first
   to include hallucinagens in a "scene." Of course the Mayans and the 
   Native Americans included hallucinagenic experiences in their rituals 
   through various methods-  including bloodletting, mushrooms, peote, etc...

E: I don't know who developed MDMA, but it was initially used by the 
   medical community to help in marriage counseling and to ease acute 
   depression. Pharmaceutical Ecstacy was manufactured in Dallas.
   Soon it made it's way into the clubs, etc... throughout Texas. 
   Bartenders would sell it more or less over the counter statewide. It was
   popular in the late 70's/early 80's. On Sept 1, 1985, MDMA was made illegal 
   (classified as a controlled substance). I remember this date very well,
   becuase the first time I took ecstacy was in June of that summer- the 
   only time I would ever get to take it legally.
   (OK- so I didn't have a perscription (:  I was fourteen- a fact 
   I added for those of you who think <21 can't handle themselves. I
   did it in the most controlled of all environments- at home. And I
   was too much of a Good Kid (tm) to have to worry about my parents'
   suspicions. I took walks- hiking some nearby trails and chilled 
   in the livingroom to some music with one other charged up friend.

   The rest is only a guess:
   I think what happened was that when ecstacy was made illegal in the 
   U.S. (or when the wheels to make it illegal were put in motion)
   many chemists with entrepreneurial aspirations headed for 
   Mexico. There (and also in the US) the drug continued to be 
   manufactured, not only making its way back to the US, but also 
   to the many clubs in the tourist meccas of Mexico- boom- it went
   international!



>3.	where/when did 303's get popular (those "blippy" sounds, right?)

>who knows?  someone must!!! 

I don't, but I'd like to know! 


>any of you wicked types (markie!) know any of this history?

Ditto???

Peace-

Jocelyn

i think e became popular in dallas tx (!!) clubs in mid-80's . some distributor
wanted to sell lots of it but it eventually got the attention of the fda.
as for acid at raves, i think it came from a misunderstanding in uk as to
the meaning of 'acid house.' they thought it meant u take acid and dance
to house music when in reality  'acid' here is chicago slang for sampling
or stealing bits of musick from other people's songs.
hope this helps.
take care/shalom/rave on
ovid

>From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
>>Make NO mistake Mark, the house scene started in Detroit/Chi-town.  New
>>York runs a close second (if not first by their estimates).  But it started
>>HERE in the US first.  What the folks from the UK did was take the shit to
>
>Uh, that's an awfully america-centric view of things don't you think?

Not really, I do think it does address what his question was which is,
where did rave start.  And I do beleive, from all accounts it started here,
in the US.

>
>I assume we're talking about rave history here, and not just house
>music history. I'd say there are alot more facets to what we currently
>call "rave" than chicago house music.

True enough, but the FOUNDATION or PARENT of rave is house....but let's
continue. 
>
>If you're going to talk about the scene, you'd better start going back
>to reggae soundsystems in Jamaica back in the 60's with producer/DJ's
>like Lee "Scratch" Perry taking the reggae music to a whole new level
>with DUB. (They don't call him "scratch" for nothing -- he is probably
>one of the first people to scratch a turntable and did some amazing
>studio magic back when there was very little electronics to do it
>with). In the late 60's and 70's, Reggae dancehall and soundsystems of
>course spread to the east coast of the US and England as well.
>Likewise, people that think that  rapping originated in america
>completely forget that its roots originated from reggae DJ "toasting"
>as well....

That last senetence reeks Neils.  Rapping has many , many different
origins, most of them African in nature.  African-American's have been
rapping waaaay before there were turntables, or electricity.  It goes back
to scat, and even farther as a means of protest and message sending that
was undetectable to the slave masters.  As for "toasting" I would say that
it has more parallels with scat and jazz.  "Toasting" ain't nothing more
than a form of signifying, bka the dozens.  African's have been doing that
since before slavery.

>
>In the UK, the dub stylee [deleted...agreed on all points though, your
>historical perspective is to be admired, although a bit flawed earlier ;)].

>Though I must say that the rave music being played in SF nowadays is
>FAR MORE INTERESTING musically than any of the sounds I heard in London
>or Ibiza back in '88. Praise Jah.
>

What's that?!!!? We agree AGAIN? ;)

>a change. (Arrrrgh!).

>1.     when did outdoor events start happeneing?

My guess is that people liked Woodstock so much that they decided to have more
similar events, though on a smaller scale, where they can smoke pot, take acid,
have fun all night long. Woodstock was probably the biggest psychedelic event 
hence the psychedelic era evolved into disco-funk music from which folks 
"borrowed" (steal maybe) peices and made their own upbeat music.

Then if you put this all together somewhwere along the line the Underground 
Generation started........It maybe not be exactly so but its a guess.

Hoss

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 02:24:32 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04147; Thu, 9 Sep 93 02:24:32 PDT
Received: from dir.bris.ac.uk by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: Miles Pearce <Miles.Pearce@bristol.ac.uk>
Message-Id: <23961.9309091024@irix.bristol.ac.uk>
Subject: Rave History
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 1993 10:24:00 +0000 (GMT)
Cc: miles.pearce@bristol.ac.uk
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1462
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hiya Folks,

May I add what I percieve to be the History Of Raves....

What we loosely term as house music definately had its' origins in
Detroit/Chicago with artists like Mr Fingers. It has roots in the Gay
club scene as a progression of Hi-Energy Disco.

It was subsequently picked up by the Clubs here in the UK and I remember 
local DJs playing Jack and Garage as early as '85. Then in '86 tunes like
Love Can't Turn Around and Jack the Groove made the UK Top 40. Clubs were 
full of the this early stuff.

'87/'88 saw the advent of Acid House as it became known - lots of sqeaks and
and samples.

Meanwhile in the UK in the Summer of '88 the first summer of love occured
mainly around Londons' M25 Orbital Motorway - mostly illegal gatherings
- a large stage, huge PA, Lasers, lights, E not Acid and thousands of people
having the eexperience of a lifetime in Unison. These events had parallels
with the Clubs on Ibiza, where house had also taken a stronghold.

Acid House was a term picked up and used by the sensationalist low market
press and twisted to portray some sort of link with the drug. 'Evil
pusher/innocent teenager syndrome stories. This was a misconception
taken up by punters new to the scene - hence is use now at raves.

Raves are basically large outdoor dance parties that go on all night -
that's what they were called in the UK in '88. 

Inciently the Raves now are nothing like those in those good ol'
summers of love.

Cheers'

Miles

About six months ago I talked with a friend of a friend about raves etc.
She's about 45 and has lived in SF her whole life.  She was telling
me about all-night events in the Haight 20-something years ago.  From
what I remember, the things she described sounded very familiar.
An all-night party, colored lights, music (obviously not techno), lots
of people not in their normal minds.  I wishh that I could remember
more.

I guess my point is that maybe rave-type events are a case of convergent
evolution;  the old example of the Shark's eye and the dolphin's eye.
The history of raving I've heard says it started in England;  from the posts
the last couple of days it looks like the music was transplanted.

Does anyone know more about this?
-matt

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 07:04:38 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05518; Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:04:38 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

	id AA12188; Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:04:50 -0700
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:04:50 -0700
Message-Id: <9309091404.AA12188@netcom.netcom.com>
To: wicked@netcom.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Re: Dance History (was Rave History)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>        As is the case with popular music over the past forty years or
>more, it tends to move between continents - import/export. Rock & Roll,
>Punk, what have you. House music originating in Detroit and Chicago was
>directly influenced by European outfits such as Kraftwerk and Depeche Mode.
>
>Also in the early days in Chicago DJ's like Frankie Knuckles would program
>drum rhythms and play disco records over the top of his beats in the club
>environment.

It is very cool and strange how things leave different continents only to
come back, like a boomerang, in a new form.

In terms of "house", I was under the impression (I know that we are on the
rave tip at this time) that it began right after disco "died".  Things were
driven underground and flourished.  I think I saw it on two documentaries
on dance, one was on this video tape "dance International", the otehr was
on "Rave" (some show on cable), and the other was a PBS special on Dance.

The comment I made about it started here in the US is flawed at best.
Seeing as by the time it was driven undeground it had already had much
infusion by the "techno" of the time (Kraftwerk, et al.), and rap was
beginning to take off as commercially viable.


>
>American House music was being played in the Gay Clubs in England for a good
>two years + before any sign of acceptance in the straight scene (circa
>1985 - 1987) and even a few chart hits like 'Jack your Body' and 'Love
>Can't Turn Around'.

It usually takes a long time before a straight scene acquires something
new.  The funny thing is how the music had changed and then was embraced by
the straight scene.  Most of the vocals, hi-hats, timbales, that
characterized the music at the time had been replaced by harder bass beats,
and signal processing.  It's even funnier that people like vocals, as long
as they are tripped out & processed (unless it's a morning set). As soon as
those divaesque vocals appear you will see damn near every straight guy run
for cover away from the dance floor ;).   


>
>        Of course this shit started to get played on the radio, with a
>whole host of new fly by night pirate stations springing up. Larger and
>larger parties. You wanted to go to a party you listened to the radio-
>they told you where the map point was. Out-of-Control! So much so that the
>British Government paniced. All these people gathering together and no
>trouble? They don't like that. Keep everyone divided and oppressed. Also
>they weren't getting their cut ($).
>
>        Markie !)
>

That is IT isn't it?  The main reason wherehouse parties are shut down is
due to the city not receiving ANY revenue from the venture. The stuff about
safety, although true, is nothing more than a smokescreen for greed. 
Because if the REALLY cared they would be in the middle of converting those
wherehouses to some good use (housing for the homeless is not the city's
idea of good use since it makes them no $$$).

Anyway,
John

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 07:31:48 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05620; Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:31:48 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA05613; Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:31:46 PDT
Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA15040; Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:32:03 -0700
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 93 07:32:03 -0700
Message-Id: <9309091432.AA15040@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: dj in the middle...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I wanted to know, from DJ's and pariters (ravers) alike:

How do you feel about the DJ being in the middle of the dance floor?


The reason I ask is that @ Basics that's what they did.  As far as I am
concerned they were overdue for this for several reasons.  First, for
whatever reason, people form these  "sit-down" encampments, at ALL of his
events.  Right in the middle of the dance floor.  When these people do this
it interrupts the flow of the floor. Secondly, he barely utilizes the space
to it's fullest. Usually the dancefloor has some amorphous boundary and is
never distinct.  4 corner sound?  Hell Martin's parties was where I got the
idea (along with Toon-Town).  Recently he has resorted to that
"wall-of-sound" that I despise so much.  Four corner , when done well,
gives sound a whole new flavor.

I like the fact that putting the DJ in the center, and surrounding it with
sound seemed to cut-down on the sit down posse's.  Also it was a nice
effect looking from above at all the people dancing central to the DJ.  My
only question is how do the DJ's as well as ravers like it?  Should MORE
parties do this?  If you didn't like it, what didn't you like about it? 
I've talked to one person about it and am interested in other's thoughts on
the matter.



Peace out,
John

Beyond the ultraworld of Sean Casey:
> 
> I hear on the east coast they usually have the DJ elevated above the
> crowd. I personally don't think I'd like this because of the
> separateness.

Just my 2 canadian cents:

DJs have to be separated from the rest of the crowd for a lot of reason:

I dont like my vinyls or CD getting stolen. In all small parties (compared to
club work where the DJ is far from the crowd) i have DJed something got "lost".
Once it was another DJ, but most of the time it's the crowd. It is also very
anoying having someone have his flashlight on your records when you are trying
to mix. Also, when you are with the crowd, people tend to touch things they are
not supposed to. And i dont mean just equipment... (but then, this happens
more in clubs). Also, when people are dancing too close they can make the
turntables skip by either pushing a bit on the table or just by jumping around.
Also, i remember once where a DJ booth was about level to ground with an eye
level wall. Some girl put her high heel shoe on the edge (dunno why...) and it
fell down on one turntable (the one playing of course). And i could go on...
Raves seem a little more well behaved than a club crowd, but still several
points still apply. If the DJ is to be in the center of the crowd there has to
be something that prevents people direct access to equipment and to the DJ.
For 100 or 200 people events, a table is usually enough, but for big events
(400+) you HAVE to have some kind of booth.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion
    '  _   _   _

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 10:23:33 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06429; Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:23:33 PDT

	id AA12976; Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:23:35 -0700
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:23:35 -0700
From: Laura La Gassa <laura@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <9309091723.AA12976@soda.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  dj in the middle...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sean reports:

>I hear on the east coast they usually have the DJ elevated above the
>crowd. I personally don't think I'd like this because of the
>separateness. Imagine Carlos having to be separated from the crowd :(.

Ahh the dangers of hearsay.  Let's see, I'm from the East Coast, and
this is what I've seen:

In the CLUBS the DJ is usally elevated/seperated from the crowd.  This
is actually a good idea in that club crowds here are often very different
and not as friendly as rave crowds, ergo the DJ is given a level of
insulation from drunkards, klub kidz doing heroin (it's the latest rage
out here), etc.  Of course, I've only been to 7 East Coast clubs this year,
but all of them (Fright Yard in Allentown, PA, Oz in Philadelphia PA,
1310 Russell St. in Baltimore, MD, The Limelight in NYC, Axis in Boston,
Man Ray in Boston, and Venus in Boston) had the DJ either elevated or
definately otherwise protected from the floor.

The RAVES I've been to are very different.  The VAST majority of the time
the DJ has been set up on a table at one end of the dance area, on the exact 
same level as the dancers.  None of the raves I've been to have had enough 
sound equipment to do like Basics did and have four corners of speaker stacks 
with the DJ in the middle (which is WAY cool in my opinion).

Now, there have been a *few* exceptions to this -- LIFE was held in a 
theatre, as was BOLD 2 (well in a performing arts space) and logistically
it made the most sense to put the DJs on the stage.  SPUTNIK I and II
also utilized stages, but all these were nearly a year ago.

I guess the best you could say about DJ positioning and the East Coast is
that the MEGA raves tend to use stages or at least slightly elevated 
platforms, but the smaller raves (500 and under) and renegades put the DJ on 
the floor.

Laura
(your East Coast connection [tm])

       "dj in the middle..." (Sep  9,  7:32am)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: dj in the middle...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I personally love that arrangement, as long as the sound coming out of the
speaker stacks is strong enough to make it sound like one sound system
rather than 4 different sound systems.  I've seen parties fail because they
placed the speakers too far apart, leaving huge gaps in the sound in the middle,
when instead the middle should be the best place to be.  I liked the fact that
the speakers were elevated at Basics, too.  

The best example in my mind of having a DJ be in the middle of everything was
the setup used at 1015 Folsom for Come/Unity parties - the DJ would be in front
of the stage, and people were allowed to dance on the stage behind him, as well
as everywhere else.  What made it great was not only could people see the DJ's
from different angles, but they could see *each*other* while dancing, something
that I feel is lost in big warehouse parties where everyone is at the same
altitude and I can only see the 5 people surrounding me....

        Brian

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom4.netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


>1.     when did outdoor events start happeneing?

I'm sure they've been going on for a long time. I've heard of outdoors
reggae soundsystem wars being set up in various parks in the UK.

Likewise in NYC, I've heard that soundsystems and DJ's would jam
outdoors in parks, back in the days when Hip-Hop was underground (early
eighties). There's even lyrics to that effect on a great "old school"
jam by D.ST on the "The Bronx is the Home of Hip Hop" cut (Celluloid NY
185):

	Stackin up speakers in the park 
	Settin up the system before it gets dark
	DJs just payin their dues
	Make hip hop fires to spread the news 
	They rock in the park in the sunshine
	Then rock in the dark in the wintertime

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
> >>Make NO mistake Mark, the house scene started in Detroit/Chi-town.  New
> >>York runs a close second (if not first by their estimates).  But it started
> >>HERE in the US first.  What the folks from the UK did was take the shit to
> >
> >Uh, that's an awfully america-centric view of things don't you think?
> 
> Not really, I do think it does address what his question was which is,
> where did rave start.  And I do beleive, from all accounts it started here,
> in the US.

All I'm trying to say is that the origin of anything is everything and it
is short-sighted to start gettin' all biblical and saying FrooFroo begat
Nimrod who begat Bootylicious. That just doesn't happen in sociocultural
events.

Perhaps as an event, "rave" has its closest origins in underground house
events. But they also have alot of similarities to early 70's underground
disco events too (as mentioned in that "Rave" documentary presented a while
back on A&E (TV)). My statements were about the music, the DJing, and the
style. In terms of music, there is a much broader coalescence of
backgrounds.

And, in my opinion, house is not the origin of the music. THings go farther
back than that. Back to old school jams. Back to reggae. Back to DUB. Back
to pre-saturday-night-fever disco. Back to classic early funk. Back to
parliament/funkadelic.

Perhaps in the background of your arguments is the following shameful
legacy of popular music -- the US was never able to take the pure
unadulterated black music forms (Blues, R&B) and make them popular. It
always had to take a transatlantic trip for the stuff to whiten up and
become packaged for commercial consumption in the US. The blues/r&b sources
from which the Beatles and the Stones and the Who derived their inspiration
rarely got rich or became popular. But the covers (often unacknowledged)
done by those groups did become popular in the mainstream....

Likewise, it took the UK to discover american underground funk and give it
the "Rare Groove" appelation. Groups like Massive Attack, The Young
Disciples, or Soul II Soul regularly expose a broad segment of people to
remakes of forgotten rare groove from the past.

In the background of my arguments is the fact that I find very little
"house" enjoyable for listening or dancing. Perhaps I'm one of those
straight white males that you speak of -- I too clear the floor when a
house jam comes on... (but I'm right there in full-enjoyment-mode when Rare
Groove, Classic Funk, Hip-Hop, Reggae or other afro-american-originated
musics come on the system).

> >with). In the late 60's and 70's, Reggae dancehall and soundsystems of
> >course spread to the east coast of the US and England as well.
> >Likewise, people that think that  rapping originated in america
> >completely forget that its roots originated from reggae DJ "toasting"
> >as well....
> 
> That last senetence reeks Neils.  Rapping has many , many different
> origins, most of them African in nature.  African-American's have been
> rapping waaaay before there were turntables, or electricity.  It goes back
> to scat, and even farther as a means of protest and message sending that
> was undetectable to the slave masters.  As for "toasting" I would say that
> than a form of signifying, bka the dozens.  African's have been doing that
> since before slavery.

I'm not trying to put together a PhD thesis on the subject, so please don't
give me shit about it. For one, my statement was an aside -- it would have
taken a few more paragraphs to complete my thoughts there. For example, the
"dissing" and "nasty" style of rap has it's origins in the music heard in
juke joints way way back (like >> 50 years ago).  Like I said above,
when it comes to culture, the origin of anything is everything.

I guess we have a legacy of flaming each other, so I guess you needed
to get in your last dig.

Flames aside, I'd love to hear more on your thoughts about the origins
of rapping. Some ravers may think it's not topical, but I do. 

> As for "toasting" I would say that
> than a form of signifying, bka the dozens.

Could you elaborate on "signifying" and "dozens"?

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 10:34:04 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06580; Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:34:04 PDT
Received: from cardinal.Stanford.EDU by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06573; Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:34:01 PDT
Received: from localhost (she@localhost) by cardinal.Stanford.EDU (8.5/8.5) id KAA12461; Thu, 9 Sep 1993 10:33:58 -0700
From: Jessica Grace Wing <she@leland.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <199309091733.KAA12461@cardinal.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Rave History
To: plunkett@uclink.berkeley.edu (Matthew James Plunkett)
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 93 10:33:58 PDT
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9309090031.AA06018@uclink.berkeley.edu>; from "Matthew James Plunkett" at Sep 8, 93 5:31 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

> 
> About six months ago I talked with a friend of a friend about raves etc.
> She's about 45 and has lived in SF her whole life.  She was telling
> me about all-night events in the Haight 20-something years ago.  From
> what I remember, the things she described sounded very familiar.
> An all-night party, colored lights, music (obviously not techno), lots
> of people not in their normal minds.  I wishh that I could remember
> more.
> 
> -matt
> 

Sounds like she may be talking about the "Acid Tests" put on by Ken
Kesey et al. in San Francisco in the 60's.  From the description of them
in _The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test_ (Tom Wolfe), they sound amazingly
like modern raves--basically they were dance parties where almost
all were tripping, with psychadelic light shows, loud dance music (albeit
by the Dead and Jefferson Airplane), and weird music made by Kesey and crew
from tape loops and micropones.  In addition the dress was similar--Kesey
and crew, at least, were into wearing crazy costumes often inspired by
cartoon characters--Kesey would dress up like Captain Marvel.  And there
is even a reference in the book to girls walking around blowing whistles!

The book is really cool and offers a different view of the "hippy" counter-
culture... Kesey's group of folks were really into technology and multi-
media stuff and not at all your typical "back to nature" regressive
stereotype.  In fact they would paint the trees around Kesey's enclave in
La Honda fluorescent colors... pretty unnatural but pretty ravey!

Jessica Wing

dont try to find the beginning.. it aint gonna happen
at least not with looking deep into roots
cuz face it..
it started when the first person made noise by dropping a rock or something
and then started slapping it to see if she could do it again
and then found a gourd or something...

history is really important and i think it would be good to come
up with a definitive history of raves, but pick a starting point
cuz, yes, rapping comes from african roots, but it comes THROUGH jamaican
toasting... and then theres no mention of ska and i dont see how
you talk about reggae without ska.. etc etc.

house music and raves arent the same thing.. dont blurrr :) things..
keep them succinct... 

i think the best way is to pick a now and work backwords instead of picking
a then and working forwards..

but thats just me

 ,
dana

what's playing, as well as what record store to find it in :) :) :).

If you separate Carlos from the crowd, you might miss out on the most
awesome thing you've ever seen. That hallway scene at Wicked was the
best craziest most positive vibe I've ever experienced. I was smiling
so hard my face hurt :). Carlos really gets into a crazy dancing crowd
right in front of his face, so make that possible.

My recommendation: Get him as close to the crowd as possible. If
leaning is a problem, maybe use a large (and very heavily weighted)
table.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 11:38:17 1993

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Thu, 9 Sep 1993 11:37:27 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: dj in the middle...
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Sean asks if having people too near the DJ is a geographic problem.

Well, not really, except that your average raver in SF is *significantly*
older than your average raver back East, and it is often the case that
increased age brings with it a greater sense of responsibility for ones'
own actions.

Also, at Basics, even though the DJ was in the middle, he was still elevated
on a small platform and protected from people swarming him/bumping him by
the table itself and several stacks of equipment, plus by the mixing 
monitors themselves, so it's not like he was out there in the open with
his crate there for people to look at and his water bottle there to trip
over (both of which happened to me at the first YSH I spun at in San
Francisco).

Besides, no matter how well you hide the DJ, or how well you put them in
the middle of the action, a *LARGE* PART of the DJs connection with the
dancers depends on the DJ himself/herself.  I have been in a situation
twice where I was on a balcony spinning above the floor, yet both times
felt completely connected because I was looking at the crowd a lot, dancing 
with them (in the booth) between mixes, and smiling and laughing and checking on
my friends and stuff.  Similarly, I have been in the situation where I was
pretty much in the open, but was distant and disconnected (mostly due to
nerves I'd say), and would hardly look up or smile and would spend time
between mixes rummaging in my crate.

Laura

Content-Type: text

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



> How do you feel about the DJ being in the middle of the dance floor?

I really liked the way Basics was set up: DJ in the middle and 4 corners 
of sound set away from the walls allowing traffic to flow around, rather
than through, the dance floor.

I never really understood why the DJ was hidden away off in the corner
somewhere.  I personally get a lot of energy from being able to see the DJ
while I'm dancing.  I'm not into the DJ worship thing like a few at Basics
were (the ones glued to the tables with their mounths hanging open :), but 
I do like being able to watch a good DJ in action without having to crowd
around the tables with everyone else.  

It's also cool to have the DJ immersed in the middle of the vibe she/he is
creating.  When positioned in between a couple of main stacks, the DJ seems
more like a controller than a channeller.

Of course, I think this setup only works for larger venues with lots of
room leftover for the dance floor.

Date: 	Thu, 9 Sep 1993 13:22:24 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I'm not so crazy about putting the DJ in the middle (for one thing, it
increases turntable vibration as compared to being slightly behind
the perpendicular axis of the speakers, which is the usual place).
Also, it makes the DJs even more the center of attention (me, I've
been accused of being a 'DJ slut' recently ;-).

But one thing I agree with jsl 100% about is the superiority of the
four-corner sound approach.  I wish this was done more often --
especially at outdoor events where I've never seen it done (though
someone told me it was done that way at a Gathering last summer?).

My all-time favorite sound system hands down bar none was the one at
the old Trocadero circa January 1993, which basically took the four-
corners concept to the max.  The sound in the center was loud, clean
and KICKIN'!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 13:31:02 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>

Subject: Re: dj in the middle...
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <93Sep9.133001pdt.14182-2@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 9 Sep 1993 13:29:59 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Responding to Francois' comments, it's pretty universal in SF to have
the DJs at dance floor level -- in most warehouse and even club situations
that's the only option anyway, except at places like 177 Townsend which
have permanent DJ booths.  I much prefer this to what I've found elsewhere,
for example at the Depot here in Portland, where the DJ is on this huge
elevated platform above the dancefloor (the old disco style).  While
security is a concern, of course, I very rarely see anyone jostle the
DJ's table -- that indicates a level of respect and awareness in the crowd
that's one of the most attractive attributes of this scene.

>four-corner sound approach.  I wish this was done more often --

>someone told me it was done that way at a Gathering last summer?).

yeah, last year's Let Freedom Rave had speakers in a ring.
unfortunately, if you stood anywhere other than right next to a stack,
you got all sorts of horrible delayed echoes from the other stacks.

it was a mess.  i think this is why most 4-corner setups don't work
out.

From: Jeffrey Moore <jmoore@well.sf.ca.us>
To: inhuman@mindvox.phantom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: dj in the middle...
Message-Id: <93Sep9.141858pdt.14183-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 9 Sep 1993 14:18:53 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The only problem with putting the dj in the middle of the dance floor is
that it will fuck up the dj's monitoring.  The PA's are usually big and
loud, and my personal experience is that they are lousy monitor mixes and
can be distracting, not to mention potential ear damage (the dj doesn't have
the ability to leave if his or her ears become really fatigued).  All in
all, the music will most likely suffer if the dj (or any performer for that
matter) isn't comfortable with the monitor mix.

-Jeff

Received: by well.sf.ca.us id <14183-1>; Thu, 9 Sep 1993 14:30:34 -0700
From: Jeffrey Moore <jmoore@well.sf.ca.us>
To: jsl@netcom.com, phred@well.sf.ca.us, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  dj in the middle...
Message-Id: <93Sep9.143034pdt.14183-1@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Thu, 9 Sep 1993 14:30:20 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Four corner sound is fine if you have a quad mix (which isn't very common),
but for stereo sound, you are basically destroying all the hard work that
the audio engineer goes to in building a stereo mix.  I've been an engineer
for a while now and stereo imaging is one of the things you work hardest on.
For my money, I much prefer an A-B speaker setup.  They're easier to work
with and a more faithful representation of the recording.

If you want to add a multichannel placement device to your PA rig, that's
another thing...

-JEff

optimal, but trippy as all hell. This year's July 4th gathering had better
sound.

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by flyers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them end...

If having people next to the DJ causes so many problems, then is it
geographic? In all the events I've been to in the SF bay area, I've
rarely seen problems. Maybe it's a different scene altogether in other
places in the country, I dunno. Maybe I've found my niche :).

------------

I "pester" DJ's, but usually they don't mind.  4 ex., at the last YSH
I heard a record I want to own;  I asked the DJ what it was and she told me
as well as showing me the jacket, etc.  rick preston, on the other hand,
tried to (tried yes, succeeded no) bite my head off for the same thing,
but I couldn't have cared less (PS: Rick, if you're out there, I found the
rekkid in spite of your ass!!).  I'd definitely say that the YSH scene is
a niche I can handle...and the DJ's have been really good every time I've 
gone.

To: glenn.fajardo@aldus.com, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re:  Crystal's Impact on the Community
Cc: nw-raves@wimsey.bc.ca
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



hey,

Having been around during the punk days in SF ('80-present), I've
witnessed several close associates turn into bona-fide reptiles
using that stuff.  I won't say you shouldn't *ever* do it, BUT if
you use it in ANY regular way, it WILL take a heavy toll on both
your body and mind.  Much of the complaining about changes to or
lack of a (friendly) vibe are consistent with its use.  The fatigue
it produces will make it very hard for anyone to be friendly, not
to mention the neurotic characteristics that usually accompany its
use.  I don't want to preach "just say no" BS, but it IS very strong,
very available, and if used w/out caution, VERY DANGEROUS.

nuff said........

*

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

well the basic stuff about people bumping and what not is understandable
it SUCKS to have someone do something stupid like mess around under the
coffin and lift his head up to hit the needle up about 30 secs before
joachim fades out taylors last song... but anyhow..

id say that one thing that was mentioned last year in SD was that
some DJ's would walk up to the turn tables to snag titles so 
they could play them as well.. to the point where people
had friggin note pads... and would jsut copy it all down
(in response people wrote wierd stuff on their white labels
and sometimes covered over the real labels with white labels)

i think its a much better idea to maybe look genereally at the label
and figure out what it sounds like and what the song before/after is
and then talk to the DJ afterwards... im sure she'd appreciate it then
more than if she were in the middle of something...
but thats if you dont know the DJ

if you know the DJ then obviously do whatever you think is okay
i know when its okay to bug the DJs i know (ie talk to) and when i should wait
till they are more settled down and stuff...

 ,
dana

At Basics the DJs were in a DJ booth that was in the middle of the dance floor.
The booth was elevated about three feet above the ground, so the crowd could
easily see the DJ, and the DJ could easily see the crowd, but there was still
a physical separation between them.

Andrew Sherman sez:
> 
> Hi Folks,
> 
> This isn't rave related, but does anyone have any experience of using a
> Sun with a trackball? I have some sort of typing injury and a trackball
> may help. All advice welcome!
> 

The only pointing device I've ever seen connected directly (i.e.
non-X-station) to a Sun is the lame cursed weak optical mouse Sun
ships with SPARCStations.  If you happen to be on an X-Terminal, you
have a number of options, including ditching the thing so you can get
a Mac or NeXT or PC w/Xservers and a Kensington Trackball ( a very
good one, IMHO.)  If you are slaved to the Sun console (God help ya),
you may be screwed (financially or situationally or both) in this
case.  Sun isn't exactly noted for its i/o.

-H-

> From: wicked@netcom.com
> Subject: Dance History (was Rave History)
> Date: Wed, 8 Sep 93 9:57:15 PDT
[...]

> 	During the Eighties in London a warehouse party scene developed
> that featured soul music ie. Hip-Hop, Disco, Uptempo R&B, Rare Groove,
> Jazz Funk etc. This directly gave rise to Pirate Radio, notably Kiss FM -
> a weekend station that was listened to by over a million people. There has
> always been a strong underground soul scene in England ever since James
> Brown & Co . invented the Funk.

I used to go to some of these warehouse parties in London.  They are
still the best parties/clubs that I have ever been to.  The one we used
go to most was called "Battlebridge Road" - it was just in a squatted
warehouse near Kings Cross, down by the gasometers. This was in
1983/84.  It was lit by one light bulb, a UV lamp, in the center of the
room. The toilet (singular) was broken. But what a place. It had non
ego-oriented DJs - Sean Oliver was one I think, Dave Dorrell another?.
And it was gree-e-e-a-t!

The next year was the big year for pirate radio. Solar FM!

-Andrew

Well you could hire a 280 pound experienced raver to dance infrot of
the tables and keep everyone else at bay :)

All kidding asside, I dance pretty wild and have NEVER hit the turntables
or smacked someone by accident.  As you get experience you learn how
to move through a crowd and not do this.

I know some DJs like Garth have thanked me for dancing close by the
tables when they are in a strange venue, they feel safer, and I'm definitely
generating vibe and sending them immediate feedback since they know my
patterns and call easily tell how what they are playing is effecting me.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep  9 20:05:21 1993

Subject: Re: Rave History (was: Rhythm at Townsends)

>> >Uh, that's an awfully america-centric view of things don't you think?
>> 
>> Not really, I do think it does address what his question was which is,
>> where did rave start.  And I do beleive, from all accounts it started here,
>> in the US.
>
>All I'm trying to say is that the origin of anything is everything and it
>is short-sighted to start gettin' all biblical and saying FrooFroo begat
>Nimrod who begat Bootylicious. That just doesn't happen in sociocultural
>events.

Right on, and agreed.  I especially like the Bootylicious, you funkin
funkster you (you got that from ooooold Parliment non?)

>
>Perhaps as an event, "rave" has its closest origins in underground house
>events. But they also have alot of similarities to early 70's underground
>disco events too (as mentioned in that "Rave" documentary presented a while
>back on A&E (TV)). My statements were about the music, the DJing, and the
>style. In terms of music, there is a much broader coalescence of
>backgrounds.

Yeah, I see what you're saying.  It seems as though with "rave" it kind of
happened everywhere, in different forms, at roughyl the same time.  If not
that then there is some serious overlap, which makes the job of saying "who
begat who" even more ludicrous.

>
>And, in my opinion, house is not the origin of the music. THings go farther
>back than that. Back to old school jams. Back to reggae. Back to DUB. Back
>to pre-saturday-night-fever disco. Back to classic early funk. Back to
>parliament/funkadelic.

Keep goin' back bro...I think that Dana's comment about the first idea of a
drum is where this will all lead to...but in any case house is definitely a
conglomeration of musical styles that overlap each other in many ways.  I
have heard plenty of "house/rave" songs take an old Jazz hit from Miles, a
couple from Trane, the Funk of Parliment (btw that WAS Bootylicious ;), and
The GFOS James Brown.  The stuff is a potpourri if nothing else.

>
>Perhaps in the background of your arguments is the following shameful
>legacy of popular music -- the US was never able to take the pure
>unadulterated black music forms (Blues, R&B) and make them popular. It
>always had to take a transatlantic trip for the stuff to whiten up and
>become packaged for commercial consumption in the US. The blues/r&b sources
>from which the Beatles and the Stones and the Who derived their inspiration
>rarely got rich or became popular. But the covers (often unacknowledged)
>done by those groups did become popular in the mainstream....
>
>Likewise, it took the UK to discover american underground funk and give it
>the "Rare Groove" appelation. Groups like Massive Attack, The Young
>Disciples, or Soul II Soul regularly expose a broad segment of people to
>remakes of forgotten rare groove from the past.

Right on!  Preach my man!!! :) :) :)

>
>In the background of my arguments is the fact that I find very little
>"house" enjoyable for listening or dancing. Perhaps I'm one of those
>straight white males that you speak of -- I too clear the floor when a
>house jam comes on... (but I'm right there in full-enjoyment-mode when Rare
>Groove, Classic Funk, Hip-Hop, Reggae or other afro-american-originated
>musics come on the system).

Oh, I didn't say anything about white, just straight, but I do get your
point.  I must say that when I first got into house/rave (see I used it
without ""), I HATED that diva shit.  Now I love it, as long as it has a
strong beat (i.e.boomin bass) and trippy in some way. For instance (please
forgive me, I'm a promoter, not a DJ ;) that "Been along time..." track
(outta Miami me thinks), and others like it are on my boogie list.  I love
stuff like that (btw Markie does that song special justice with 3
turntables ;)!

>> That last senetence reeks Neils.  Rapping has many , many different
>> origins, most of them African in nature.  African-American's have been
>> rapping waaaay before there were turntables, or electricity.  It goes back
>> to scat, and even farther as a means of protest and message sending that
>> was undetectable to the slave masters.  As for "toasting" I would say that
>> than a form of signifying, bka the dozens.  African's have been doing that
>> since before slavery.
>
>I'm not trying to put together a PhD thesis on the subject, so please don't
>give me shit about it. For one, my statement was an aside -- it would have
>taken a few more paragraphs to complete my thoughts there. For example, the
>"dissing" and "nasty" style of rap has it's origins in the music heard in
>juke joints way way back (like >> 50 years ago).  Like I said above,
>when it comes to culture, the origin of anything is everything.
>
>I guess we have a legacy of flaming each other, so I guess you needed
>to get in your last dig.

I wouldn't call it a dig, whatever.  Yeah we have had at it many a time,
but this is FAR from being a flame.   More like opinion sharing.  In any
case I agree with the sentecnce before last "...origin of anything is
everything".  Nice chaos theory my friend.

>
>Flames aside, I'd love to hear more on your thoughts about the origins
>of rapping. Some ravers may think it's not topical, but I do. 
>
>> As for "toasting" I would say that
>> than a form of signifying, bka the dozens.
>
>Could you elaborate on "signifying" and "dozens"?

Signifying/Dozens:

I am sure you've heard African-American folx do the "Yo mama's so...", and
the braggartly "Man, my dick is so...", "I got so much...". Well these are
forms of signifying, or the dozens.  The "yo mama" is a dozen.  The object
is to be quick consise and lethal (not getting too personal of course) with
a comeback, until the other person cannot come back with something as
brutal.  The idea is to get nasty, but not too nasty (for instance you
could talk about your mama's weight, but if she had a heart attack you
would never even approach that subject.  Whoever does that loses, and
usually gets into a fight!).  Personal digs are OK, as long as it is
something that the person can help.  Therfore any disability is considered
poor taste, all else is WIDE OPEN. Signifying is more braggart oriented. 
Usually  there is talk of posessions, physical prowess, sexual
prowess/conquest. 

From the outside it seems BS talkin to talk.  But think of what it
requires.  It requires mastery of the language, quick thinking, and the
ability to twist words around quickly.  Also humor is a big part of it. 
You have to make people laugh!

These oral traditions are still quite alive in Africa, and plenty of
African people's play them with expertise.

The "toaster" is a prime example.  Twisting around words, telling a story,
signifying (bragging), sometimes fast, sometimes slow, sometimes in patua. 
In any case it requires quick thinking.  I was talking to DJ Josh who
recently came back from Jamaica.  He met this dude who had his own "sound
system" (he took a picture, and beleive me it was MASSIVE !).  He would
turn it on and "toast" for hours.  Doing all types of sound manipulation,
while DJ'ing and carrying on.  Bragging about his system, his life, telling
a story.  Just carrying on something that has been going on for many
millenia.

So when I hear "toasting", or "dancehall", or "hardcore" rap, I hear the
same thing, just presented differently.

On another tip (getting farther out there):
Gangsta rap.
Now, I do love gangsta rap, but not just any.  I love Ice-Cube (can't stand
Ice-Tea), and the Ghetto Boys.  Use to love 2-live-Crew (from my Hometown
no less).  The thing that they all have in common is that they are funny as
shit.  When you get past all the "I wanna kill this...", and "Fuck the
police...", and hear how it's presented it makes me laugh.  It is nothing
more than Richard Pryor put to a beat.  Which once again, is nothing more
than signifying/dozens told in a story form.  Many people say that the
stuff is violent.  But the fact is from all the folx I have talked to they
laugh as well, and get many of the jokes.  The ideas they put forth are
just that, but they put it in a, uh "black" way (as in "black comedy"). 
But all the braggadacio, and sexual mishaps, and juvenility is nothing more
than the dozens/signifying...which begat bootyliciuous, which begat yo
mama, which begat....;)

Rap/Dancehall/Toasting are all the same thing. All have oral traditions in
Africa, and all are put to a beat.  The transformation of American rap (esp
Gangsta) is even more interesting.  Now dig this.  Here you have a form of
rap, rather angry (still funny tho') that rails against "the man".  And yet
rap's origins are tied to Kraftwerk, YMO, Yello, etc.  Like you said,
rappers would rap over mixes of Kraftwerk and work out  little digs with JB
slammed in for good measure.  I do wonder, many times, if the hardcore
rappers understand "their" origins.  I mean, I know that they know their
beats come from Kraftwerk and shit, but do they know Kraftwerk are a bunch
of Germans from Dusseldorf?  That YMO are Japanese, that Yello are Belgian?

One other thing.  Rap of late (sans Duice who did the Dazey Duks deal),
epsecially gangsta, have really tried to get away from euro-beats.  They
are relying heavily on their masters (Miles, Trane, Duke E., Cab) for
beats/licks.  More and more rap has been infused with Jazz, and old R&B
standards.  70's soul/funk (Digable Planets/Pharcyde/Ice-Cube/Das Efx) are
all the rage, and rap continues to THRIVE (hell rap is the only music
making money, so much so many record companies prop up their rock artists
with the mega that's made from rap), grow, and transform...which brings me
to another thing....changing (this is my last deal so...).  Have you
noticed how the rap terms and the sayings keep changing, like weekly.  Use
to be "homie" and "yo" now it's something else?  Well this is another
version of trickery.  In the "community" these terms change with such
regularity, that by the time the mass culture has gotten ahold of it, it is
out of date.  Change is necessary for survival....

What are YOUR thoughts on Rap/House/rave (hell I already know about your
ranting ;) evoltuion?  For instance, do you think rap plays a really strong
role in the creation of house/rave, or is the funk that it's based upon the
prime motivator?
If funk is the shit with house/rave, why aren't more people of color "into"
it? Is there "really" funky house or is it just imitation/acquistion? 
Tribal...now to me there really is no such thing, to me all this "tribal"
stuff is "trance" with timbales..your thoughts?

>
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=


There is more, but my Thesis on The Funk is late and the Mothership waits
for nobody!

Peace out,
John

or numbered!..." - No. 6
                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com

yes, it was definitely one of the best wknd in a long while...

Basics was quite wonderful...i was full of apprehension after 
everything id heard about the previous one, but i had a really good time,
especially when towards early morning i went wild dancing to a song that
i love but havent heard since let freedom rave back in early july...

anyway, i won't reiterate how incredible fluid groove was, since everyone 
has already said everything that could be said....except that it was for
me probably the best time ive had since my first fmr, & that the small number 
of people there was a very nice change from having throngs of people crowd
you from all sides while you try to weasel into a clear spot...
that bay view will stick in my mind for a very long time,
especially those grey early morning hrs w/ the perfect music in the background
i agree w/ tamara- definitely one of the best parties ever.

it's memories like the ones of last wknd that make me feel happy and alive
whenever everything else is falling apart & academics have you by the throat...

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 10 00:32:56 1993

	id AA09224; Fri, 10 Sep 93 00:32:51 PDT

	id AA25718; Fri, 10 Sep 93 00:32:49 PDT
Date: Fri, 10 Sep 93 00:32:49 PDT
From: rpcaras@srv.PacBell.COM (Bob Carasik)
Message-Id: <9309100732.AA25718@zeus.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Burning Man Festival, September 3 - 6.

"People are the best part of nature"
		- Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy

"No Spectators" read the 30 - foot banner hanging across the central
part of the campsite.  7 hours out from San Francisco, we ( me & my
wife and our almost-kindergarten daughter ) had reached the site of
the Burning Man festival, out in the featureless middle of the endless
mudflat that is Nevada's Black Rock Desert.  It was late Friday
afternoon.  Scattered loosely around the 100-yard central "square"
were everything from pup tents to RV's to a fancy old bus with a
satellite dish on top.  The only pattern to the situation was provided
by the neat clumps of portapotties a couple hundred yards to the
north, west, and south.  This was a true TAZ, with very little
infrastructure besides the installations, costumes, vehicles,
fireworks, and, of course, *water*, brought by the participants.
The attitude towards nature was less reverential than one might have
felt in a smaller group; not too messy, certainly not much waste going
on, but we were the humans, and we were thre to play with our toys and
each other.  The setting was a tad harsh to lead one to think too much
of harmony with the All.  To be honest, the heat and emptiness created
more of a dialogue or call-and-response with "nature" than a soothing
featureless harmonic hum.

The Black Rock Gazette, the onsite newletter, proclaimed: "There are
no spectators here, only particpants.  No audience, only palyers.
Here on this sere and desolate plain, our community springs form the
desert floor like a strange and beautiful mushroom, a postmodern
Brigadoon in an ancient wasteland.  Its name is whatever you name it.
Its welath is whatever you bring. Next week it will be gone, but next
week might as well be never.  You are here now."  And all 900 of us
lived up to it, mas o menos, and made the festival a place where off-duty
religion and untamed theatre could meet out back for a smoke and maybe a
round or two of Graham Cracker.

We were there to burn the genderless Man, a 40-foot high wood frame
construction festooned with neon tubing and fireworks.  Why?  " If we
didn't destroy him, we wouldn't have to make him again." said Larry
Harvey, alleged instigator of this custom which started on Baker Beach
some years ago and has been a desert festival for 3 or 4 years now.
What followed was a wonderfully wrought combination of chaos,
planning, and spontaneity. The festival included a number of fun
rituals, for example, the Sunday predawn Java Cow Ceremony, where a
cow-thing miraculously yielded coffee: "we'll take it black!",
responded the parishoners.  Saturday night, 24 hours before burning
the man, there was a lesser burning, of a mud-covered spiral sculpture
a short ways away.  I got to be a torch-bearer, swinging fire around,
missing people's heads.  Several ceremonies were held at the Dog Head,
the 20-foot plastic doggy that once adorned the Doggy Diner, including
sets by Mudwimmin and Three-Day Stubble.  Some folks from the
Cacophony Society ( 415-663-0351 ) held a Christmas party, complete
with eggnog and misteltoe, 95 Farenheit, humidity zero.  Some stuff
that had been advertised before the festival never materialized, such
as a Friday night potluck, a baking workshop, and a quilting
something-or-other.  But then, the "cafe", which was nothing more than
a shade tent in the middle of the camp, took on a bit more form on
Saturday, as a esspresso truck form Davis showed up for business, and
another guy set up a taco and beer stand.  I did my volunteer bit by
personing the information table, which meant I tried to start rumors (
"a motorcycle club from Houston is coming up here to practice Sumerian
rituals and eat acid-laced beef" ) and spread any that came my way, as
well as pointing various arriving techies towards the two busses which
seemed to contain audio and visual and pyro equipment of various
sorts.  My table-mate was glad to be in a gathering of folks from both
ends of Cali where we could be free of SF vs LA rivalry.  "It's great
here, people can be so equal" she exulted.  "It doesn't matter what
kind of car you drive".

Of course, being out in the wilds was big fun in itself.  We went to a
hot spring about 8 miles away, navigating there basically by pointing
the car between two mountains and flooring it.  It was a big
plastic-lined trench near a railroad, very warm at one end, too hot at
the other.  We smeared mud on ourselves, swam, and almost convinced
some other mud bathers to "stay away from that part over there, we
stepped on a ribcage."  Afternoons were spent in whatever shade could
be found, drinking water, eating melons, and drinking more water, but
the heat actually wasn't uncomfortable.  Dust was a bit of a problem,
but it didn't cause any distress really, no sore throats or sneezing.
The windstorms on Friday evening and Saturday afternoon were pretty
obnoxious, with tents getting blown over and stuff.  My daughter
didn't like the windstorms at all, but she came up with great ideas
for holding down the tents with various large objects :)

There was a wide range among the participants, both in degree of
involvement and degree of camping experience.  Aside from the freakout
that mmetz reported, and one real sloppy daytime drunk, it seemed like
people helped each other out, traded food, etc, pretty well, and there
was certainly much less random rowdiness and stoopidity than at yer
basic state park.  We hooke up with some friends that we'd cajoled
into coming and saw several more people that we hadn't seen in a
while.  As the weekend went on, the organization of the event became a
bit more apparent. The "Black Rock Rangers" really did kind of roam
the nearby desert and guide lost people home.  And the pyrotechnical
stuff was kind of professional.  The large "events" seemed planned;
but it seemed possible for anyone to pull any kind of stunt they
desired, and to recruit whomever wanted to join.  Such things, of
course, start more easily when there's some pre-existing clumps of
people to snowball around.

For my money, these tongue-in-cheek ritual tacked together from a
rummage sale of old jokes and genuine archetypal stuff like fire,
dancing, bathing, and drumming, made for a lot more spirituality than
any museum-like reconstruction of Native American, Celtic, Sumerian,
or whatever cultural borrowing happens to be chic among alienated
urbanites.  ( Nothing against Native Americans, Celts, or Sumerians,
I'm just not one of 'em ).  Unabashed clowning made for a genuine
carnival, a true holy-day for what the Subgenii called "inherently
bogus religion".  The Burning Man Festival spoke to me as being truly
of my postmodern, eclectic, culture, a veritable Rio Grande of
whatever meaning one's heart desired.  It was serious fun, "serious"
in the sense of demanding some effort and commitment in even getting
there, and better yet in having a shtick; "fun", well, if wearing odd
costumes and dancing and shrieking around a huge bonfire with
firecrackers going off isn't your idea of fun, well, you jes' don' eat
chicken on Sunday.  Religion Lite, perhaps, but I'd call it a true
affirmation of humanity, given the comparative absence of other
species and the age old significance of fire as monkeyfella's first
serious attempt to lift naturebuddy by the scruff of the neck and
shake till there's a snap.

Made me feel real anyway.


The actual burning was everything one might hope for.  First a formal
cocktail party in the central area, with tuxedoes, drag, mud, naked
bodies, and LL Bean all glittering in the blood-red sunset.  Then a
few dozen volunteers raised the man to standing position by hauling on
a rope.  Then the whole festival formed a procession, torches, drums,
and all, out to the man, an eight of a mile away.  Heat lighting
played in the mountains.  The expectant crowd grew ever more expectant
;+).  The lowering sky darkened.  The lightening grew more frequent,
until we were surrounded, at least 300 degrees.  Once night had truly
fallen, the neon was turned on, and the man stood in its glory,
glowing blue against the mountans, now barely visible.  A few minutes
later, and its arms were raised up.  Then the torches were applied,
and the man went up in flames.  The neon failed on one limb, then
another, and fireworks went off throughout the man.  A little while
more and he crashed to the ground.  The crowd moved in a little, as
people formed a dancing circle around the burning wooden carcass.
Young men leaped over some glowing ribs.  "Why they doin' that?" asked
my daughter.  "Because they can", I replied.  Lightning probed the
rising smoke, and the very air started to move.

After fifteen more minutes of hanging around this festive scene, my
daughter had had enough.  It was Time To Go To The Bathroom, on the
other side of the festival.  As we walked, we felt the first drops of
rain.  Then the rain quit and the squalling Baby of All Windstorms
roared into being. Resisting a contrarian urge to pee into it, we
found shelter in the portapotty, and started back to the tent.  The
wind got windier, the dust, dustier.  We had to stop, couldn't see,
and soon enough got back by dead reckoning.  It was pouring rain as we
entered the tent.  But the rain got no rainier, and after an hour or
so it stopped.  Serious rain might have made the mud impassable, but
all that really happened was some tents and other stuff blew away, and
some peopl had to take shelter with strangers or their cars, for a
little while.   I remained in the tent for the night, since I didn't
want to leave while there was any chance of the storm cropping up, and
besides, it would have been hard to top what had happened, anyway.

Nature sure chimed in, as if to say very gently, in response to all
our incohate energy, "mess with me, and I can mess with you too, buddy".

On the way home the next day, we stopped at Pyramid Lake to rinse off
the dust and sulfur in the nice cool agricultural runoff.  Then lunch
at The Nugget casino in Sparks, just for cultural balance.  But as
drove down the Western Slope towards home, we saw a real life piece of
a rainbow floating in the thin overcast clouds.  "God gave Noah the
rainbow sign / No more water, the fire next time".


ObRave:
	There were rave events both Saturday and Sunday nights.  I'm
told that the Sunday night one was a lot of fun ( 75 people, 50
dancing ) but I didn't attend either one, as it turned out.  I had
heard that there was something about sfraves on the bulletin board,
but it had blown away by the time I looked for it.  I saw Liz across
the way, and that was it for familiar sfr faces for me.

- AstroBoy

P. S.  Send me a SASE, I can send xeroxes of some of the materials
that were passed out there.

P. P. S. I have no official connection with the Cacophony Society.
But then again, neither do they!!

On Thu, 9 Sep 1993, Michael Wertheim wrote:

> At Basics the DJs were in a DJ booth that was in the middle of the dance floor.
> The booth was elevated about three feet above the ground, so the crowd could
> easily see the DJ, and the DJ could easily see the crowd, but there was still
> a physical separation between them.

Actually, I noticed several people managing to lean over the table to check
a record or just to stare at the DJ.  At one point, a guy even grabbed a
record from Spun's hand as he was trying to replace it in his crate.  Of
course, he just wanted to check the title, but I'd say that's about as
rude as it gets.  As for the sound setup, it was impressive to look at,
but the extremely high volume and power at four corners in combination
with an extremely reverberatory, high ceilinged space makes for extremely
muddy sound IMHO (Wow, I finally got to use one of those annoying net
abbreviations :).  I would gladly sacrifice two speaker stacks and a
teensy bit of volume for the ability to differentiate more than just
beats and bass from the music.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 10 07:25:29 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17508; Fri, 10 Sep 93 07:25:29 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17501; Fri, 10 Sep 93 07:25:27 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA02021; Fri, 10 Sep 93 07:25:43 -0700
Date: Fri, 10 Sep 93 07:25:43 -0700
Message-Id: <9309101425.AA02021@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: DJ face down in the....
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Hmmm some interesting comments from everyone about placing the DJ in the
middle of the dance floor.  I think it's a great gimmick, and have joked
with many a DJ about putting them in the middle, preferably on some sort of
roataing platform.  You know like a rotisserie for DJ's ;)  All kidding
aside, I like the idea BUT:

- Someone brought up the deal about ear damage, and although I have never
thought of it,  the importance is quite real.  Having a DJ in the middle,
AND having them listen to CRANKED UP monitors is baaaad news.

- Too many cracker-jacks!  I HATE it when people shine flashlights on DJ's
records, or WORSE try to talk to the DJ about what he/she is spinning while
thier doing the do.  I hate it when people STAND (not dancing mind you) in
front of the DJ to attempt to read the label, or try to get the DJ's
attention.

- Stolen property is another thing.  People steal stuff.  When placed in
the middle of the floor it is much harder to control access to the booth.

Although I think it is a great idea (in some instances), I would probably
not do it.  Getting to the booth would be a problem for the DJ.  The DJ
should NOT be the center of attention at a party (this is not a rock show),
and I think it is just difficult to work under such conditions.

In LA, where I first got involved in the house/rave scene, they used to use
this place called the Casa.  They would have the dj wayy up high.  You
wouldn't even know where the DJ was.  You were surrounded by sound, smoke,
great prodution, and a vibe.  And that is what a party is all about IMO.  

The DJ is indespensible in creating that feel, but if they are hampered by
folx bothering them, or can't hear afterwards, or someone steals their
stuff, that vibe will be ruined.

I like the DJ to be off the dancefloor, kind of anonymous, in an area that
has restricted flow.  To me it's better for the DJ, better for me (since I
won't have to hear about cracker-jacks and thieves), and better for the
crowd (more room to dance).

4 Corner sound is a MUST.  I am  not talking about quad, just 4 corner. 
And when I say 4 corner I mean right & left channels are diagonal:

R        L
 



L        R


In this way you maintain the integrity of the stereo signal no matter where
you are.  The other neat effect; when you stand in the middle the sound has
the illusion of rotating (this is especially noticiable with records that
have heavy transforming going on).  When the level are right the BASS has
good penetration, and the highs (when placed above the head) sound great,
without piercing!
The probelm with usign this config in large venues is the delay, but at the
last "get down,ugly,stoopid" the main hall had somehow cut the delay to a
min.  The standing waves were not much of an issue either.  Outdoors I
don't think it works too well. It requires more power, and the sound almost
always sounds washed out.  A wall is best , IMO, for outdoors.

Still, that (4 corner) and a dj in the middle....nice one!

or numbered!..." - No. 6
                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com

member that one showing up on 45 on Dj Dan's Wicked Burning Frenzy.  Anyhow,

canned, part of the song.

anybody else is familiar with it.  I caught Renegade Soundwave, Underground
Resistance, Orb, and Aardvark, but the rest is a mystery to me.  Perpetual
play on my walkman, though.

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: GGPark Update 
Cc: sfraves-planners@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Thanks to cash received this weekend, and a check I just got yesterday,
We've reached the break even point for Connection Earth in GG Park.

Expenses:
300 - park permit
 35 - SFPD sound permit
 35 - U-haul rental for the sound system
  5 - gas for the generator
---
380

Funds received: $385

There will be some other assorted minor expenses to cover limited flyering,
garbage bags, fruit/snacks that won't amount to much.  

Thanks to everyone who supported this effort.  Because of the great response 
and the numbers of people who said that they were gonna give $ but didn't get 
around to it yet, I'll definately plan to do another one.  But I'm not gonna 
accept any more donations until planning for the next one begins.

A couple of other notes: After hearing Ethan's sound system at Fluid Groove,
Brian B.  & I have decided that a 2nd system will not be necessary.  But we 
need volunteers to help load & unload the system.  Anyone who thinks they can 
be available at 11:00am Sunday should let me know.  

Although my permit only allows amplified sound from 1 - 5pm, I'm gonna try 
to start the music earlier, at a lower volume, depending on who's watching.  

We have Marx Meadows all day, so there's nothing preventing people from 
coming earlier to hang out.  Maybe Bob R. will even bring his rave-in-a-box 
for a morning preparty?

Anyway, Oct. 3rd is a long way off so I probably should shut up for a while.
Let's just hope the wearther holds out.  Thanks again to everyone for
all the support and encouragement.  It's become obvious that the SFRaves
community here has become a powerful grassroots movement in the rave
scene.  With our networking, resources and commitment, our contributions
to the SF House Movement, both spiritually and practically, can be a big 
factor of what will keep raving here viable and special.  Remember, there
are no rules, just ideas that we choose to act upon.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

I don't know about it's use with a sun but one of the smartest things I ever
did is let my friends dad, who was advising me on a PC purchase, talk me into
a keyboard with a built in track ball.  This was before I had ever seen a
track ball (except for tempest, the vid game) and before they were as popular
as they are now.  I don't know why they haven't made mice obsolete yet.  Takes
less space, it's easier to move your hands between it and keys, and you don't
have to b
OOps.
you don't have to pick it up and move it to the other side of the mat when
you run out of space.

-Mark

From: Jeffrey Moore <jmoore@well.sf.ca.us>
To: jsl@netcom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  DJ face down in the....
Message-Id: <93Sep10.122941pdt.14172-4@well.sf.ca.us>
Date: 	Fri, 10 Sep 1993 12:29:32 -0700
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

jsl@netcom.com sez:
4 Corner sound is a MUST.  I am  not talking about quad, just 4 corner.
And when I say 4 corner I mean right & left channels are diagonal:
 
R        L
 
 
L        R

This is a big pa no no with a stereo mix.  Your going to severely destroy
the sound (ie hi frequency response will be hurt from the phase problems
that are inherent in this kind of setup).  At the very least have the setup
like:
L    R

L    R

You will reduce the amout of phase problems and the system will be a lot
easier to deal with and produce good sound.

I recommend getting a hold of the Yamaha Sound Reinforcement Handbook.  It
has a lot to say about setting up PAs and producing the best possible sound
from the equipment you have.  It was the main text in most of the
engineering classes I took that dealt with PAs and mic placement.

I also recommend getting a surround sound processor (preferebly Dolby) for
doing this kind of setup.  It'll handle a lot of the phase problems and
allow you to make your setup sound more like a quad (or more) setup.

-Jeff

|Path: dziuxsolim.rutgers.edu!uunet!elroy.jpl.nasa.gov!decwrl!toad.com!gnu
|From: gnu@toad.com (John Gilmore)
|Newsgroups: sci.crypt
|Subject: Crack DES in 3.5 hours for only $1,500,000!
|Message-ID: <38294@toad.com>
|Date: 9 Sep 93 23:16:49 GMT
|Organization: Cygnus Support, Palo Alto
|Lines: 68

Be the first on your block!

Michael Wiener <weiner@bnr.ca> produced a complete design for a DES
key search machine, which he presented in the "rump session" at Crypto '93
last month.  He designed a single custom chip which can do 50 million
test encryptions per second, and the boards and racks and frames into
which it fits.  The full design has about 60,000 copies of the chip,
solves DES in 3.5 hours, and is fully described in the paper.  Here is
an excerpt from his conclusions:	

    It is possible to build a $1 million machine that can attack DES and
    recover a key in an average time of 3.5 hours.  The machine uses a
    known plaintext to exhaustively search through the DES key space and
    could be developed for $500000 in about 10 months.  Because a great
    deal of detail has gone into the design of the key search machine, we
    can have high confidence in the assessment of its cost and speed.
    The key search design presented here is one to two orders of magnitude
    faster than other recently proposed designs.

    Even cryptosystems with 64-bit keys may be vulnerable.  If DES were
    modified to use 64-bit keys, there would be 2**8 times as many keys to
    search through, and a $10 million machine would take an average of 3.7
    days to find a key.

    It is possible to build a key search machine that can support a range
    of modes of DES with little penalty in run-time.  A $1 million machine
    would take 8 hours on average to find a key used in 1-bit CFB mode
    and 4 hours on average for any of ECB, CBC, 64-bit OFB, 64-bit CFB, or
    8-bit CFB mode.

    This work shows that exhaustive DES key search is alarmingly
    economical.  If it ever was true that attacking DES was only within
    the reach of large governments, it is clearly no longer true.  A
    fairly painless way to improve security dramatically is to switch to
    triple-DES.

The paper was written as a warning to DES users (bankers) and their
customers (depositors).  DES is used to protect electronic money
transfers among banks all over the world.  Several billion dollars per
day are moved in this way.  Within a day of finishing the machine, a
criminal could easily pay back the $1.5M in capital.  In the second
day, they'd have the capital required to build a second machine, and
in the third day a positive cash flow would begin.  Banks can do 
nothing to stop this -- if they shut down their comm links, they go
out of business; if they keep moving money over them, intruders suck
money out at will.  I recommend not keeping your money in banks...

Most organizations who would build such a machine (national
governments and other forms of organized crime) have probably already
constructed many similar machines.  This paper will not help them.  It
is intended to help people who thought that DES was secure.

The full paper is available in PostScript via ftp from:

	ftp.eff.org:/pub/crypto/des_key_search.ps
	cpsr.org:/cpsr/crypto/des/des_key_search.ps

cpsr.org also makes it available via their Gopher service.

CPSR.org is on a slow link; use the ftp.eff.org archive if possible.
(The file will appear there shortly; apologies for any delay.)

	John Gilmore
	Electronic Frontier Foundation
-- 
John Gilmore                gnu@toad.com  --  gnu@cygnus.com  --  gnu@eff.org
 "Looks like they took a hand grenade to a decent operating system" --
						      Bob Kresge on Solaris 2
