Subject: Your Sister's House, free party Sunday & legal defense party Sat.
Date: Fri, 10 Sep 93 18:05:00 -0700
From: doom@banneker.Stanford.EDU
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Jill and I went over to Azteca Thursday night, expecting the
traditional pre-Your Sisters House dinner, but it turns out
we were on our own.  (Food was good, though kind of heavy
for a dance warm-up, I thought... and I think I like
Chabella's better.)

We went over to Your Sister's House, and we were somewhat
disappointed...  this was held at Cleo's this time,
essentially a bar in the lower Haight, and the space just
wasn't that good.  I gather they had to be paranoid about
noise, because the sound system was a bit quiet, and all the
windows and doors were kept shut.  Add a bunch of candles,
some incense, cigarettes of various types (notable Rose),
and a bunch of dancers, and you've got a situation to
challenge anyone's breathing ability.  I was having a little
trouble with the anaerobic dancing myself, and there was no
chill space to speak of.  It was kind of cold on the side
walk, and they couldn't have people congregating there for
fear of attracting police attention.  The light show was
really cool, though, and the music was decent (if a bit
old).

There phone message talks about a free party there in the
same space on Sunday, so if you happen to be in the
neighborhood, you might want to stop by to check out the day
time scene (I think it's around 2PM, but call their number
to check)... Maybe they won't have to worry about noise then.

One last thing.  Not really ravey, but some folks here may
be interested in this: a legal defense fund party for some
libertarian types how were hassled by the cops on a
marijuana charge...

A PARTY FOR MARK AND PAMELA PICKENS'S LEGAL DEFENSE

Place: Freedom's Forum Books, 1800 Market Street, SF
Date:  Saturday, September 18		Time: 7:00 p.m.
Donation: $10.00 (All proceeds go to help defray legal expenses.)

On July 28th, the San Francisco Police Department smashed in the front door
of Mark and Pamela Pickens, seized their property and trashed their home.
Mark was charged with possession of marijuana; after a night in jail he
was released on $2000 bail.  He has since spent thousands more in legal
fees.  Mark's lawyer, Alex Reisman, is working hard to ensure the lightest
jail sentence possible.

You may know Mark as a former San Francisco Libertarian Party Chair and
four-time Libertarian Party candidate (SF Supervisor/79; Assembly/80-82;
State Senate/84).  What you may not know is that he personally persuaded
over 1800 voters to register with the Libertarian Party in 1979 as part
of the successful effort to get the California LP permanent ballot status. 
(This was over 5% of our total registrants in the entire state!)

Without his generous financial support in 1991, it is doubtful that
Proposition O (the First Amendment Initiative) would have made it to
the ballot.  Prop O passed by an overwhelming 73%.

Mark and Pamela are also two of the co-founders of Residents Against
Prohibition, a coalition of Libertarians and Liberals dedicated to ending
the drug war.  The RAP brochure was created by Pamela on her computer which
was seized by the SFPD.  Fortunately, thousands had already been
distributed.

Please join us on Saturday, September 18th at Freedom's Forum Books to
support Mark and Pamela and their legal fight.
                                                           George L. O'Brien
                                                   San Francisco LP Chairman

P.S.  For those of you unfamiliar with Police search procedure, Mark and
Pamela will be showing a videotape of their apartment taken immediately
after the raid.  This might be instructive for those who think that the
Police mean well and are simply "doing their job."

--
Anton Sherwood						   DASher@netcom.com
+1 415 267 0685		1800 Market St #207, San Francisco, California 94102
(another Friend of Pickens)

On Mon 6 Sep 93 19:05:01, Laura La Gassa (laura@soda.berkeley.edu) wrote:
> voyage. I'd also like to thank everyone who came, especially Jo who danced
> like a REAL Brooklyn Bass-Bin Worshiping girl during the hardcore parts, her
> enthusiasm helped to make me feel like I was doing right by you all.

<chuckle>

thanx laura...8-) im glad  everyone made you feel at least somewhat 
at home in SF
though dancing that hard in sand resulted in a rather tweaked lower back,
but, hey, it was worth it.

<sigh>

maybe im just a ne-raver at heart...

at any rate, perhaps its most un-SFR-like of me, but i found i *really*
loved the hardcore material that laura played, as well as the hard trance,
some of which i actually recognized at Basics...
maybe it's b/c being a one-time metalhead i feel that occasionally
the harder & faster, the better.

Nevertheless, i still love SF-style of music as well....
tho even with all these new musical interests, i still love lots of other 
kinds of music ranging from classical to latino-brazilian dance 
as well as metal...

over the months since ive gotten into raving, i've noticed a lot of argument
over what style of music (house vs. hardcore vs. ambient or what-have-you) is
better...

i don't see anything wrong with liking any/all kinds of music - whatever 
works for you. 
perhaps too much attention is drawn towards what kinds of music are typically
"east coast" or "west coast" & the idea that if it's not in that particular 
musical vein it's just not worth being given a chance.
Fluid Groove was a great success in that sense b/c SF ravers were able to 
get into more east-coast style of music, & everyone had a great time.

of course, not everyone can or has to like every single kind of music,
(i certainly don't - as with most people, there's a lot of things out there
that are not exactly my cup o' tea) but everyone is entitled to their 
individual tastes, & needn't be put down for it...

one of the things i have gathered from "rave cultcha" is that 
being  open-minded is ideally meant to be one of the main underlying themes 
behind the rave mentality.

what i'm saying in my convoluted way is at least keep an open mind & give new
things a chance...

Hell, if i hadn't, i wouldn't be here now, writing/being involved in the rave
scene. To say that i *hated* techno or anything remotely attached to this
musical genre scarcely a year ago [& thought thrash/death
metal was the be-all and end-all of music] is an understatement...but i gave
it a listen again, & i suppose the rest is rave history....8-)

But as laura was saying, a party with the right vibe/attitude/people will
be a good party no matter what music is being played- 


this is just me 2cents on the topic - but after all, to each his own.

-jo
the lambada-dancing raver/mosher/bellydancer.......*grin*

>L        R
>
>This is a big pa no no with a stereo mix.  Your going to severely destroy
>the sound (ie hi frequency response will be hurt from the phase problems
>that are inherent in this kind of setup).  At the very least have the setup
>like:
>L    R
>
>L    R
>
>You will reduce the amout of phase problems and the system will be a lot
>easier to deal with and produce good sound.

 Sorry but I have to disagree.  WIth a good engineer and good equipment the
phase prblems are ELIMINATED!  I have used this setup at every party I've
thrown, and have had: No phase problems, bno feedback, great sound, great
efx.  Preston still uses this type of configuration at his gigs (if I'm not
mistaken).

>
>I recommend getting a hold of the Yamaha Sound Reinforcement Handbook.  It
>has a lot to say about setting up PAs and producing the best possible sound
>from the equipment you have.  It was the main text in most of the
>engineering classes I took that dealt with PAs and mic placement.
>
>I also recommend getting a surround sound processor (preferebly Dolby) for
>doing this kind of setup.  It'll handle a lot of the phase problems and
>allow you to make your setup sound more like a quad (or more) setup.
>
>-Jeff


I agree on th euse of a surround sound processor, but it CAN be done quite
well without.  The problem is most sound co's dont have one.  And those
that do genrally don't do raves.  I will look at the text you recommended
though.  SOunds quite useful.

or numbered!..." - No. 6
                 from the village of jsl@netcom.com

>From resist Fri Sep 10 23:01:30 1993
Subject: Food Not Bombs arrests continue after one week...
To: 
Date: Fri, 10 Sep 1993 23:01:30 -0700 (PDT)

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Status: OR

FOOD NOT BOMBS ARRESTS CONTINUE AFTER ONE WEEK

As of Friday afternoon (September 10), 41 food servers and witnesses have
been arrested and two vehicles confiscated as part of SF Mayor Frank Jordan's
campaign to eliminate Food Not Bombs/San Francisco (FNB). Jordan initiated
this campaign last Thursday, September 2, when San Francisco Police
arrested twelve members of FNB for serving free food.

Yesterday (9/9/93), six people were arrested at the lunch serving in front
of SF City Hall and a vehicle was confiscated. Three of those arrested
belonged to AYUDA, a Latino homeless organization connected with the
Coalition on Homelessness (the Coalition is not a standard liberal
"homeless industry" group but rather an autonomous group organized by the
homeless and housed together on an equal basis). The vehicle also belonged
to AYUDA. Today, twenty police descended on the lunch serving and arrested
two people. Their attempt to arrest a third person was frustrated when
that person jumped into a nearby fountain. The police, not wanting to get
their nice riot jumpsuits wet, decided against going into the fountain to
arrest him. They waited over an hour for him to come out, coaxing
him with promises of lessened charges, but he told them that he would only
come out if they promised him full amnesty for all those arrested in the
last week. The police tired after an hour and left, leaving him free to
escape. Last Wednesday (9/8/93), FNB held a large demonstration in front
of SF City Hall attended over 250 people. As members of the city's elite,
dressed in tuxedos and ball gowns entered city hall to celebrate the start
of the opera season, FNB served food and marched around the building
despite the presence of many riot police.

Most of those arrested have been charged with violating a court injunction
that prohibits FNB from serving free food to homeless and hungry on the
grounds that FNB refuses to apply for the "proper" permits. FNB has
applied for permits in the past, but under a 1991 Parks and Recreation
Commission regulation (a commission composed of direct mayoral
appointees), NO PERMITS ARE TO BE ISSUED TO ORGANIZATIONS SEEKING TO GIVE
AWAY FREE FOOD IN CITY PARKS OR OTHER PROPERTIES. This regulation was
created specifically to criminalize FNB. The court injunction is ludicrous
considering that no permit even exists to apply for.

Both the court injunction and the Parks and Recreation regulation
are political ploys originated by former Mayor Art Agnos. Agnos used the
injunction and a prior one to arrest over 300 people between 1988 and 1991.
For the past two years, however, the court order stood unused and no one
was arrested for serving free food, despite FNB's twice-daily meals. Of
the hundreds of people who have been arrested since 1988, nobody has been
convicted.

This latest campaign to eliminate FNB comes as part of Mayor Jordan's
Matrix "Quality of Life" Operation. Jordan has assigned special units of the
San Francisco Police to certain areas of the city (the downtown and the
primarily Latino Mission District) whose sole purpose is to criminalize
homelessness through the arrest and harassment of the homeless themselves. 
Hundreds of people have been arrested or cited as part of this program
since it began at the start of August. The campaign to eliminate FNB is
part of the Matrix Operation; as well as attacking the homeless directly,
Jordan has decided to attack any support structures that the homeless may
have.

Jordan has also directed his attacks against other communities.
Specifically, he has joined the anti-immigration bandwagon that has been
building momentum in California (as it has been all across the United
States and other advanced capitalist countries). Jordan led the
(successful) attempt to overturn the city's sanctuary ordinance. This
ordinance prohibited the the City of San Francisco or the San Francisco
Police from cooperating with the Immigration and Naturalization Service of
the federal government (INS). Clamoring that the city's jails were
being overrun by "illegals", Jordan succeded in re-writing the ordinance so
that the police could cooperate with the INS if someone was arrested for a
felony. Of course, the number of felony bookings of Latino surnamed
arrestees has increased by 500% since the ordinance was changed.

To show solidarity with San Francisco FNB, call Mayor Jordan's office at
(415) 554-6141 and tell him what you think of his campaign against the
poor, the hungry, and people of color. Although Jordan isn't the sole
responsible party for the fascist trends in SF, he is the primary
spokesperson and point-man of the fascist element in the city.

For more info, to comment or to support SF FNB contact resist@igc.apc.org
or andyrose@netcom.com. Or call FNB voice mail at (415) 330-5030.

From

                  \o/   resist@uclink.berkeley.edu

From sfraves-owner  Sat Sep 11 17:12:12 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA27356; Sat, 11 Sep 93 17:12:12 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA27349; Sat, 11 Sep 93 17:12:09 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA12356; Sat, 11 Sep 93 17:12:19 -0700
Message-Id: <9309120012.AA12356@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Sat, 11 Sep 1993 17:12:19 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Guide to Outdoor Parties
Cc: socal-raves@ucsd.edu, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

This is version 0.9 of something I've been promising to write for a long
time and finally found it in myself to come up with.  It's basically a
guide to attending renegade parties, the do's, the don'ts, everything.
There are a few, er, choice words for certain things in here but I stand
behind everything I say.  However, I'm sure it could use grammatical and
structural revision and possible additions.  I hereby submit it for your
perusal, and if you have comments let me know.  If you like what you see,
feel free to copy it to other mailing lists or make hardcopies and hand
them out or whatever; when I get comments on it I'll be making a few 
laser-printed nicely-laid-out copies in Word or something to hand out to
the general public.  I welcome any and all comments....

        Brian

p.s. - if you reply, make sure to not reply to every mailing list I'm
sending this to, but just here or the mailing list you're local to....

		     ICONEKT COMMUNIKATION 1

			 GOING OUTDOORS


This summer has seen quite a few outdoor renegade parties.  Everything
from the large full moons every month to the smaller parties such as
Xochipili and Harmony and the Mother Earth Sound System gigs showed
that people in this scene understand and appreciate the incredibly
liberating feel of dancing to house music in the out of doors, where
many people feel it belongs, despite what law enforcement and the
predominant government policies towards "public land" may dictate.

However, many of these parties have been busted, sometimes after a few
hours, sometimes in the morning, sometimes even before the sound got
going.  There were also cases where the people who came to celebrate
the beauties of the earth left a very distinct scar where the dance
floor was.

It doesn't have to be like this.  There is a LOT that you, as an
attendee of renegades, can do to help ensure that the party does go on
without a hitch.  What I am about to present here is a checklist, if
you will, of actions/thoughts/memes you should consider next time you
head out for that outdoor party.  These rules are primarily designed 
for the people attending renegades, though if you're throwing them you
should probably read these too.  

BE COVERT

There's a LOT of strategy involved in deciding on a site for the
party.  I'll save that for a later post; the advice I'll give here
presumes the organizers have done as much as they can to make it as
remote as possible.  But no place is gonna be 100% silent. so...

When driving to the site, do NOT blast techno out of your car windows.
You want to make the people living on the route to the site as
ignorant of your presence as possible; which means make SURE you know
your way there (a Thomas Bros. map is essential), have a full tank of
gas, and bring all the water and food and such you'll need with you.
Don't presume there'll be a 7-11 nearby; the quickest thing to alert
the locals is 40 ravers hanging out at 7-11 at 2am in the morning.
Try not to drive in big caravans, either, coz nothing will turn heads
like 20 cars following nose-to-tail down a deserted road.

Upon arriving at the site, there is a lot you can do to help ensure
that if/when police show up, they have as little to gripe about as
possible.  When you arrive, park as closely together with other cars
as you can, so that as many cars as possible can fit in the (probably
small) parking area.  If there is someone coordinating parking, listen
to what they have to say and don't try to find a closer space.  If
there's no one coordinating parking then use a bit of intelligence in
parking by avoiding obvious places and parking under NO PARKING signs
and such.  Sometimes you can't avoid the NO PARKING signs, so consider
any parking ticket you might get as payment to the local authorities 
to allow the party to go on - they usually won't ticket if they demand 
that you leave, and they'll only tow the people parked in really stupid
places, like where the shoulder of the road is only 2 feet wide or
something.  Besides, a $20 parking ticket gets stretched pretty thinly
between passangers if you carpool, which you should do as much as possible
anyways.

WORK THE VIBE

The best thing you can do now, if the music hasn't started, is leave
your car and go to where the actual site will be - or offer to help
carry equipment.  Basically, do ANYthing except be outside your car -
you wanna stay out of the parking lot.  I have seen more than a few
renegades busted because the music hadn't started yet and everyone
was around their cars, blaring music out of the speakers, drinking 40's,
setting off firecrackers, etc, and the cops could see it was just a bad 
scene - had all these people been down on the beach or on the grass
waiting for the sound system to start, it would have been completely
different.  Head straight for the site.  If there are residences nearby,
be as QUIET as possible when walking.  The last party at Berkeley Marina
was busted because people staying in the nearby hotel heard the people 
slamming their cars doors, not because of the giant sound system on the
other side of the hill.

Now, it's time for the three NO-NO's of outdoor events - the three things
which should not be present in any significant amount.  They are serious
VibeKillers, and even though separately they may be enjoyable they really
have a negative impact almost every time I've seen them at parties.

1) NITROUS.  Nitrous is fun, I've done it.  But Nitrous also brings a
mindset and a culture which makes it very antithetical to the outdoor
experience - when a guy shows up with a tank and starts selling
ballons for people, it does 2 things: it draws people away from the
vibe of the crowd, because when they suck on a balloon it takes them
into a world of their own for a while, lost in their own headspace,
pretty much uncommunicative with anyone else.  It also creates that
"nitrous greed", where you want more and the seller wants to sell you
more and more and more money exchanges hands.  I could care less what
you want to do at your own parties, the constant SHSHSHSHSHSHSH sound
that is heard at many parties these days is like a drill to those of
us who wish it wasn't there.  And you KNOW it's a lot more obvious to
police, and gives them a huge fucking reason to shut us down.

2) ALCOHOL.  This has probably been beat into the ground so it should
be obvious, but evidently not to many people.  Alcohol doesn't help
you dance, it doesn't help you stay up longer, it doesn't give you
energy beyond a short-term buzz, and it never works well in
combination with other psychedelics.  Again, it's not a drug I'm out
to abolish or anything, there are certainly times it's appropriate,
but like nitrous, is can seriously impair most vibes.  It's also the
only reason I've ever seen rudeness or violence break out and outdoor
parties.

3) FIRECRACKERS.  This wasn't a problem until a few months ago, but at 
the August 1st FMR, when someone set off a bottle rocket, I heard one 
ranger say to the other, "that's it, we gotta shut this down".  And I
don't need to remind you all of near-disaster of the hill fire at
Let Freedom Rave last July (we are the luckiest scene on the face of this
earth, I tell you.)  Please, for the sake of the party, don't bring em.

Okay, *phew* sorry about all that vitriol.  Now to more positive things.

RESPECT THE MOTHER

One goal of outdoor parties has always bheen to leave the place "cleaner
than we found it".  However, even if we take out all our trash the mark
we leave is totally obvious.  There are things you can do to minimize your
impact:

Respecting the mother means if it's grassy, take off your shoes.  I do
this all the time, and never catch a cold because the rest of my body
is warm.  If you can't stand the cold, get some thick wool socks; the
goal is to tear up the ground as little as possible.  Even tennis
shoes are better than, say, docs or hiking boots.  I've seen gorgeous
grassy fields turned into mudpits after a single renegade because
people wore boots with think cleats and insisted on doing a shuffle
dance.

Respecting the mother means not tearing down plants and defecating or
urinating in bushes if portapotties are within any sort of walk.
Respecting the mother means looking out for signs which say
"endangered species", and staying away.  Respecting the mother means
not pulling down live trees to add wood to a fire (I've seen all these
happen).

And finally, respecting the mother means not throwing cigarrette butts
on the ground.  Put them in a spare pocket or throw them in a trash can.  
But they are NOT recyclable, contrary to popular belief. 

Why is this important to the non-bust-ness of a party?  If a ranger
comes and sees that people are keeping to themselves and not harming
the land, which is what he's worried about, then he may be persuaded
to simply let us go.  But the other extreme is the Palo Alto Estuary
ranger after the FMR in May, who was so enraged with the treatment the
wetlands got that there is now a cop sitting in the parking lot EVERY
NIGHT.  "Don't ever come back!"  he reportedly said to the last car of
ravers out of there.

DON'T FLINCH

I have been to VERY few parties where the police do not arrive.  And 
actually, to be honest, I feel better if the police arrive, talk to 
people, and leave, than if they never know about it at all.  There is
*nothing* inherently immoral in gathering outdoors to dance to music - 
we may be violating specific laws regarding sound permits and "park
closing hours" (why should public parks have closing hours??), but 
the right to assembly is guaranteed by the constitution.

So, when the police do arrive, the handling of the situation needs to
be very careful.  There are two main scenerios I've seen:

1) The police arrive to see what's going on, they find a group of
happy people dancing.  No local residents have complained, there's no
danger of violence emanating from the group (cops can sense that
"vibe" too), there's no alcohol or other obvious drug use (though
everyone there may be off their gord in one way or another!) and the
site isn't getting trashed.  At this point, they may decide to simply
let the party progress.  What is important here is that you treat the
officers with dignity and respect, and understand that they are only
doing a job thrust upon them by superiors.  For those of you who are
confident and not tripping and understand what their situation is, go
up and say hello, introduce yourself, explain what's going on, etc.
Be gentle, tell them you understand the park is closed, etc.  BE
HONEST.  You don't have to give your name, but if the timing and
attitude is right giving your name and showing ID might build trust
with them.  Tell them the site will be cleaned up in the morning, the
place will be left "cleaner than we found it".  Anyways, eventually
you may be able to build up a level of trust, either personally or
from the group, and the officer may simply say, "okay, I wasn't here.
But if the site is trashed in the morning..."  and at that point
you're clear.  Keep in mind that busting a party is not a small task,
and a couple of cops probably won't want to go through the paperwork
to do it unless they see some reason.  Give them no reason to go
through it, and they may let you go on.

2) The police arrive and are not happy.  Either they have a
pre-existing and media-formed bent against "your evil rave parties",
or something was done to really piss them off.  In such a situation,
there's not much you can do.  The party is over, and it should be
moved to a backup site.  You can try talking them into an hour more or
until sunrise or something, but do not see this as a battleground.
There is a time and place for everything, and a remote field is not
the place for a constitutional showdown.  The cops bark is worse than
its bite - they may threaten to haul everyone's ass to jail and
impound the equipment, but like I noted before it's a lot of work for
them; if everyone just packs up and leaves they're usually happy.
Feel free to catcall and cajole; but remember that usually the order
to disband the party comes from higher-ups than they.  The worst thing
to say: "do you really want a bunch of fucked-up kids on drugs on the
streets?".  Drugs are a real sore point, to say the least, so don't
even think of trying to use that as a bargaining tool!

It is important to remember what you are doing is NOT illegal.  It's
simply unpopular with the powers that be.  You wanna change that?  You
can, by sending letters to your city council, the mayor, to anyone you
feel has a direct influence upon policy.  Or, make an attempt to get
a site legally - it *can* be done, it just takes a bit of legwork and
cash.  Register to vote, register your friends, and make them know that
you wanna be HEARD.  Your rights are only yours if you choose to defend
them.

ENSURE THE FUTURE

If the party was successful, even if only for a few hours, be sure and
help out with donations so that the organizers will know their effort was
appreciated and so they can give some to the DJ's and sound guys and
whatnot.  You don't have to give a lot - $5 is a good figure to go by - 
but even beyond its monetary worth is the message *I believe in you*.  


There is a lot more to say on outdoor parties, but I think this will
be enough for now.  Look for future communikations on other topics....
If you have email you can send me feedback at iconekt@uclink.berkeley.edu.
See you outdoors!

	Brian

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


 Does anybody out there have any sugestions for sound euipment that would
survive the outdoors for 6 to 12 hours at a time? The equipment I was 
particularly interested in was:

1. Preamps , mixers.

2. Compression units , equalizers , and other sound modifiers.

3. Power amps.

 The kind of environments I was thinking of were those of the "typical"
outdoor rave - beaches , dusty lots , foggy/drizzly parks. I'm assuming that 
I could have a covering of some kind to keep the direct moisture and
sunlight off the equipment ( kind a big case and/or a tarp or small tent ).

 If there are magazines that review this kind of stuff , I'd research it
myself , but I don't know what those magazines/trade journals are. Do people
in the business of sound reinforcement go by word-of-mouth , or is there
some other avenues of information?


 As always , I'll be glad to get replies by personal email , and then 
compile the answers and post it to SFRaves. 

					Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From: pendell@netcom.com (Dale Alexander Pendell)
Date: 8 Sep 93 17:59:08 GMT
Newsgroups: alt.drugs
Subject: Calif forfeiture law

California's asset forfeiture law expires this year, unless it is renewed this
week, which, due to an intense police lobby effort, seems likely.  This abusive
law subverts the most fundamental principles of American/English/Anglo-Saxon
justice: that is, your property can be seized on suspicion on the part of the 
police, and you have to prove your innocence to THEM.

Fax your state assemblyman and state senator immediately and urge them not to
renew the forfeiture law.  

Many horror stories of police abuse of this law were documented in the San Jose
Mercury News last week.

  JACOB> i think e became popular in dallas tx (!!) clubs in mid-80's
  JACOB> . some distributor wanted to sell lots of it but it
  JACOB> eventually got the attention of the fda.  as for acid at
  JACOB> raves, i think it came from a misunderstanding in uk as to
  JACOB> the meaning of 'acid house.' they thought it meant u take
  JACOB> acid and dance to house music when in reality 'acid' here is
  JACOB> chicago slang for sampling or stealing bits of musick from
  JACOB> other people's songs.  hope this helps.  take
  JACOB> care/shalom/rave on ovid

Hmmm... the origin of the term "acid house" is often argued about.  I
have read that one of the Detroit clubs where some of the seminal acid
DJ's played had a reputation (almost certainly false...) for lacing
their tap water with LSD, and that the word "acid" could very probably
be a reference to this club (in much the same way that house was a
reference to the Warehouse, Chicago, and garage was a reference to the
Paradise Garage, New York....)

In particular, i have an article by a person who claims to have
invented the explanation that "acid house" is a refenence to sampling
and stealing sounds.  He says that it is completely false, and that he
spread this as deliberate misinformation to try and difuse the bad
media attention that the UK acid house parties were getting, trying to
play down the connection between the parties and drugs....


	Cosmic Roy

Last night there was a real bad television report on women DJ and i'd like to
correct them a bit. So, there is  a list of women DJ floating around and beeing
updated regularly. Anybody has the most recent? In case my message was not
added the last time, here are some club women djs from Montreal:

Martyne Prevost
Bettina Costenzo
X-rated Marie
Lucky Luce
Mescaline

The blurb said: "We have searched hard, and only found 2 women DJs in all of
the province of Quebec". Yeah, right... very hard. These 5 are well known in
the club circuit. Then, you have the ones that spin at micro raves and
underground events. Plus, of course radio DJs. And i think they count as much
because there are a lot of DJs who dont even beat match, and radio DJs have
a larger crowd listening to them too. And there are probably women DJs in other
clubs too which i dont know.

I also find it very strange that neither Martyne or Bettina or InBeat staff
(where the tv crew got some footage along with Campus and Kox) didn't say a
word about the other female DJs in Montreal or the others in the province,
Canada and of course the States (at least 2 of them came to Montreal to spin:
DJ Laura of ne-raves fame of course and another at Metropolis which i dont
remember the name right now. Oh and Bettina was at R.E.C., so she saw you
spin, Laura...).

And well, there are things like YSH in SF, something i'd like to happen here
too, but people dont seem to be ready for that. Not the ravers, the DJs (male
and female). Oh well...

Yousef> i said 3 DJs, because Lucky Luce and Martyne Prevost dont spin techno
at all.

Subject: Re: Rave History (was: Rhythm at Townsends)

>Hmmm... the origin of the term "acid house" is often argued about. 

Yawn.  Historical data can be fun if you're playing a game of Trivial
Pursuit, but I often wonder why people spend so much energy attempting
to recreate some vision of the past in their minds.  Unless the information 
has relevance to our understanding of Now and the Future, I say let's
move on.  One thing I love about house music is that it treats all available
information as equal.  Stuff from every musical genre can be sampled and
reused because it is relevant to what the music is trying to put across
*today*, not for some nostalgic trip for people who are trying to relive 
feelings from their past.  History makes for fun reading, and I have always 
been fascinated by archeology, paleantology, etc., but please, can't we at
least wait for the Rave Era to near completion before writing it's
obituary? 

Sorry for the negativity, I guess I'm still recovering from all the disco 
that was played at Boogie Buffet where I was kicking myself for not going 
to Vision the night before. 

- leg of eel

Subject: Acid House
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Mon, 13 Sep 1993 12:13:29 -0400 (EDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1229      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The term acid, in reference to acid house, does not come from the drug. Of
course acid was popular at acid house gatherings (acid parties as they were
refered to here).  But the reason, at least back in 87 when i first got into
that scene, the term was used was because the sound was really transformed
and usually were in reference to strange echoey voices, brakes and backspins
and not in reference to the TB-303 which is now refered to as the acid machine
(since about 90 i think) after it had been used in a lot of acid house, so
people said, oh yeah the acid bass sound... Brakes can be heard for example on
KLF WTIL (SSL). Oh, and i also forgot, the acid hit. Kinda like an orchestral
hit, but weird sounding.

The reference to stealing bits has nothing to do with acid. Dont know how this
got started. However, in acid jazz, this definition would make sense.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 13 09:42:12 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA07681; Mon, 13 Sep 93 09:42:12 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA07671; Mon, 13 Sep 93 09:41:39 PDT
Received: from sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA06795; Mon, 13 Sep 93 09:41:52 -0700
Received: by sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu (5.57/Ultrix2.4-C)
	id AA07000; Mon, 13 Sep 93 09:40:46 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 Sep 1993 09:40:21 -0700 (PDT)
From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Reply-To: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Rave History Not Trivial Pursuit
To: Lee Fogel <lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com>
Cc: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
In-Reply-To: <9309131605.AA14478@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9309130917.A4001-b100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


   I agree that *history* can degenerate into trivial-pursuit type
details, and I agree that the continual announcement of the "death of
raving" can be annoying to those who still find it very much alive. But
I've got to stand up for the pursuit of historical understanding. Unless
you're a prophet, the future is beyond our grasp. The present is a moving,
razorthin edge. Everything we know is in the past, and our understanding
has to be based on how we put together the pieces of the past into a
coherent picture of how the world coheres.
  If all you want to do is dance, that's cool. Putting yourself in synch
with the rhythms and the other dancers is most of what raving is about.
But the next day, when you're sitting in a cafe or just walking through
Golden Gate Park, you might want to think about where things you care
about came from, and how you fit into that evolutionary picture. Like it
or not, we're all part of a bigger picture in time and space. The Beats,
the Hippies of the Haight; UK crop circle raves, Detroit house, Kraftwerk
-- these aren't just tidbits for QuizShow 2000: they're part of our heritage
as SF Ravers. To learn about that heritage isn't just "nice to know": it's
a form of respect we pay to the people who came before us: they had their
ideas, danced their dances, made their music, and passed it on to us. Now
its our turn. 
  And what will we give to those coming along next?





From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 13 10:28:23 1993

	id AA08018; Mon, 13 Sep 93 10:28:23 PDT

	id AA08010; Mon, 13 Sep 93 10:28:17 PDT
Received: from piaget.harlequin.co.uk (piaget.cam.harlequin.co.uk) by holly.cam.harlequin.co.uk; Mon, 13 Sep 1993 18:29:38 +0100
Received: from wundt.harlequin.co.uk by piaget.harlequin.co.uk; Mon, 13 Sep 93 18:29:02 BST
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Mon, 13 Sep 93 18:29:01 BST
Message-Id: <8703.9309131729@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: dionf@ere.umontreal.ca, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Francois Dion's message of Mon, 13 Sep 1993 12:13:29 -0400 (EDT) <9309131613.AA21306@brise.ERE.UMontreal.CA>
Subject: Re: Acid House
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


The reference to acid house meaning stealing things is a deliberate
piece of misinformation that was spread by a member of the YOung
Conervatives as part of a campaign called Freedom to Party.  The media
had latched on to the idea that people took acid at acid house
parties, and he needed to publicize an explanation to support his
(false) claim that the party scene had nothing to do with drugs.  So
he just made an explanation up, and it has become quite well known
now, and repeated in print many times....

The article appears in an appendix to Saunders' book, E for Ecstasy....

XDZebra Review #36

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
Email angst@psych.colorado.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to techno.stanford.edu.
They're in the pub/raves/music/reviews directory.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #36 Contents:
DWFS: Hemispheres
Compilation 3
Digital Odyssey - A Cybersonic Adventure
Harthouse America - A Taste of Hard Trance
Pod Communication Presents: Atom Heart
Moby: Move EP
Amorphous Androgynous EP
Futurhythms [Promo]


DWFS: Hemispheres
Adrenalin/Micmac: ADR 9205
1  146	05:04 Drome in Effect
2  145	07:15 Snowbound
3  139	03:46 Sphynx
4  152	03:42 Quake
5  	00:15 Chant

Comments: DWFS produces hardcore that lies somewhere between Brooklyn and
Aphex.  There seems to be a single underlying theme to this EP, probably due
to the use of the 808 kickdrum on every track.  However, tracks like "Sphynx"
and especially "Quake" turn in an extremely noisy excursion over the analog
dial, tart and sour.  "Snowbound" is an attempt at hard trance, but it is so
cliched with the use of chorals it really is a sagging point on the disc.

Summary: 6/10.  A good use of analogs, but the rhythms in the background tend
to bore.


Compilation 3
FAX: PK 08/05
CD 1:
1  148	05:39 Deltraxx: Arcangel (Red Stripe Mix)
2  144	07:12 Limelight: rerum natura (pluris costare Mix)
3  144	06:59 Hearts of Space: All About Sensuality
4  136	09:27 Sequential: A Trip to Paradise
5  134	07:44 Olympic: Marathon - London
6  152	05:27 Crypt Corp.: It's All Around Us
7  160	05:17 Sythadelic: I'm A Secretary
8  157	06:07 Minimalistic Source: Minimalistic Overboost
9  126	06:25 Harmonize: Mediterranean Moods
CD 2:
1  145	06:28 Eternal Spirit (Northern Mix)
2  144	04:50 Oversize Pussy: Orange
3  160	06:05 Subsequence: Walking in my Dreams
4  140	06:19 Stanley Conaway: Pepperbee
5  128	11:32 Sequential: Saturn Cruises
6  140	08:50 Sextant: Global System
7  155	06:12 Escape: Escape to Neptune
8  144	08:02 Syn: If Only You Could See...
9  145	05:52 4Voice: Move

Comments: Yet another severely cool compilation from FAX records.  Not content
to produce just excellent hard trance anymore, this compilation branches into
experimental with "Saturn Cruises", acid jazz with "Mediterranean Moods",
progressive house with "Pepperbee" and head bleeding hardcore with "Move".
"Move", however, is on the Hoover vacuum side, 4Voice has definitely produced
better stuff in the past.  As for the the staple hard trance and trance, it is
completely up to par.  "Escape to Neptune", "rerum natura", and the Sequential
tracks are among my favorites.  Olympic's "Marathon - London" is an
interesting bow to a certain Kraftwerk piece, except this time its on foot.  I
like Olympic's vision better.

Summary: 9/10.  Another wonderful comp from FAX.  This time on two discs.
Pricey, but more music for the money.


Digital Odyssey - A Cybersonic Adventure
Moonshine Music: M 50087-2
1  123	06:42 Masters at Work Feat. India: I Can't Get No Sleep
2  125	05:06 Desire: Try the Love in Me
3  130	06:03 Crunch: Devo
4  128	08:19 Whoosh: Sometimes
5  132	05:26 Transform: Transformation
6  138	04:58 Aphrodite: Break of Day
7  130	05:25 E.K.O.: De La Casa
8  133	05:51 Decadance: Jump to It
9  140	05:16 Cold Automatic Eyes: Nasty Groove
10 137	05:54 Dektition: Love Rush
11 129	07:44 Free Love Foundation: Take My Love

Comments: A domestic collection of newish house grooves.  Most of the tracks
on here fall distinctly under garage house, and unfortunately, that is the
wrong end of the spectrum for me.  I do enjoy Transform's "Transformation" and
high breakability of Aphrodite's "Break of Day" but that is about it for this
compilation.  Dektition does merit some mention, but only for the fact that
they sound just like Altern8.

Summary: 4/10.  Yet another comp for house lovers.  Be wary if you're not
ready for divas and disposable music.


Harthouse America - A Taste of Hard Trance
Moonshine Music: M 50085-2
1  138  05:29 Arpeggiators: The Spirit Makes You Move
2  140  04:59 Hardfloor: Acperience III
3  150  07:19 Futurhythm: Red Heat
4  136  06:07 Barbarella: Barbarella I
5  153  05:08 Arpeggiators: Trancemission
6  143  06:27 Spicelab: Wierdo

Comments: Instead of simply domesticating the excellent Harthouse comp, "The
Point of No Return Chapter 1", Moonshine elected to give a fresher perspective
on what Harthouse is up to.  Arpeggiators kicks things off with their standard
fare of hardtrance and breathy female vocals, then another visit to the
"Acperience" progression is due with #3.  "Red Heat" is a disappointing entry
by "Futurythm".  It just seems to be another 303 wank, it certainly doesn't
compare to "Butoh".  "Barbarella I" is a bit harder than expected from
Barbarella, but no surprise to owners of the album.  Then Arpeggiators returns
with a noisy crusher in "Trancemission" which is definitely the highlight of
this collection.  Finally, Spicelab does an uncharacteristic soft trance
track.  They definitely do acid much better.

Summary: 6/10.  Good stuff from Harthouse via Moonshine, but not enough.  Most
tracks seem to be just the latest instead of the greatest.


Pod Communication Presents: Atom Heart
Pod/Sonic/Instinct: SNC-2026-2
1  138  05:29 M/S/O: Move Right Now
2  160  06:01 Urban Primitivism: 684
3  127  05:47 Datacide: Ritual of Transparency
4  137  05:18 Bi-Face: Mouthpad
5  132  06:27 Ongaku: Mihon No3
6  111  08:26 Lisa Carbon and Friends: Swing Me Machine
7  154  05:44 Atomu Shinzu: Red
8  132  06:35 M/S/O: Shiny Flowers
9  136  05:22 D'ammond: I Want You
10 127  06:34 i: 23'rd Autumn
11 134  04:59 Millenium: Vektor
12      07:25 Atom Heart: One Atomsecond

Comments:  Well on its way to becoming the noisiest, most acidic label in
techno, Atom Heart's Pod Communication becomes domestic to the states via
Sonic/Instinct.  This collection is a top notch example of Heart's work and
collaborations.  Every track has his stamp on it, save Pete Namlook's guest
appearance with Millenium.  Atom Heart is definitely the Richard James of
Germany and although he is only starting to come close in quantity, he is
starting to topple James with variety.  "Red" by Atomu Shinzu has to be heard
to be believed, techno by forced machine labor.

Summary: 8/10.  Noisecore to the fullest with the right amount of funky
variety, "Atom Heart" is a piece of distinguished work.


Moby: Move EP
Elektra: 61569-1 & ED 5663
Side A:
1  132	Move (You Make Me Feel So Good)
2  141	Morning Dove
Side B:
1  138	All That I Need Is To Be Loved
2  165	Unloved Symphony
Promo A:
1  132	Move (You Make Me Feel So Good)
2  140	Move (Sub Version)
3  132	Move (Radio Edit)
Promo B:
1  123	Move (M.K. Blades Mix)
2  151	Move (Disco Threat)
3  131	Move (Xtra Mix)

Comments: Moby's first release on Elektra is very much in his trademarked
style.  A nice variety of mixes is included on the extra promo vinyl, with the
energetic "Disco Threat" mix, and the ultrasmooth "Xtra Mix".  The main
problem with "Move" is the fact that it does bear a strong resemblance to his
past hits.  There isn't any real progression here.  Wailing divas and smashing
piano riffs, but no innovation.  The "Love" side of the EP is positive proof
that hanging around Liam Howlett for too long can be detrimental.  It is
Moby's first shot at fast breakbeat, and with the overhanging symphonic
strains, it sounds too much like Prodigy's "Weather Experience".  One track
though, stands far apart from the rest, the incredible tribal-middle-Eastern
whatmayyoucallit "Morning Dove".

Summary: 5/10.  A bit of a disappointment as far as new material for Moby.
Some killer remixing as usual, with one fantastic track in particular.


Amorphous Androgynous EP    [45]
Astralwerks: CAROL 6102
Side 1:
1  129	Liquid Insects
Side 2:
1  115	Mountain Goat
2  136	Skyscraper

Comments:  With just one bonus track on this EP that is not present on
the album, and no remixes, this release makes you wonder just why
they did it.  "Skyscraper" is a spacey, rubber-sounding mover, but
is definitely bottom material for Cobain and Dougans.  The other two
tracks are identical to the album.

Summary: 6/10.  Not bad, just pointless.  It would have been better
as a 33 with a few remixes tossed in.


Futurhythms
Warner Bros/Giant/Medicine: PRO-A 6474
Side A:
1  125  05:22 Leftfield: Song of Life (Club Mix)
2  125  04:18 Leftfield: Song of Life (Radio Edit)
Side B:
1  130  05:29 Q.B.N.Z.: A Great New Adventure
2  126  06:22 Young American Primitive: Young American Primitive

Comments: This is a short promo preview of a compilation being released soon.
The reason for release is to mainly get "Song of Life" on the floors before
releasing "Futurhythms".  Frankly, the press release excites me more than this
12".  Artists like Jungle High, Moby, The Tripp, and Sven Vath will all be
included.  As for "Song of Life" itself, this is the first time I've heard it
and it is probably the best thing I've heard out of Leftfield.  All four
tracks on here make good use of female vocal samples, but YAP stomps all over
the other two groups in structure and progression.  "A Great New Adventure" is
weak and lacks any real intelligence.

Summary: 7/10.  The compilation looks exciting, although most of the tracks
have been available on import for a while.  I think they could have picked a
better frontrunner than "Song of Life".

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 13 12:47:24 1993

[Sorry for the wide distribution, but...]

> >> Compilation 3 FAX:PK 08/05
> 
> Should it not be Compilation 4.....?

Nope.

> Compilation 3 was an ambient collection last time I saw it, and it's been around for
> quite a long time.... And track listing is pretty different....

Nope again.  There are two series of compilations from Fax, the
regular ones and the ambient ones.  And they are not numbered
sequentially, they are numbered after the series of releases from
which their selections are taken.  There have been Compilations 1, 2
and 3, and Ambient Compilations 2 and 3.  There was no Ambient
Compilation 1.  Compilation 4 and Ambient compilation 4 are scheduled
for release during weeks 38 and 35 of 1993, respectively.

-Ed     SLiP
        "into something more comfortable"

        ne-raves Fax junkie

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 13 13:51:40 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09161; Mon, 13 Sep 93 13:51:40 PDT
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09154; Mon, 13 Sep 93 13:51:38 PDT
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA19974; Mon, 13 Sep 93 13:51:58 -0700
Date: Mon, 13 Sep 93 13:51:58 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9309132051.AA19974@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: VISION report
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Vision report
=============

  Sorry for being late,  but I attended VISION,  and it was truly amazing.
VERY BIG venue,  lots of room,  dance floor crowded,  but still lots of room
to move around.   Very low cigerett smoke level (Although smoking was banned,
nobody payed attention to no-smoking rule).   Chill out benefit factor about
a 6 on the 1 to 10 scale (Due to large space).   There was free water and
even ice.   The DJ's were totally awsome,  with good mix of techno, funk,  and
jazz.   Apparently the same security company as one of the previous raves,
as some of them recognized me and said "I saw you at the last event".  I think
it was Funkey Techno tribe at the Galleria.

  The Santa Rosa police appeared to be rather mellow,  and in a cheery mood.
At least the ones I encountered by the front door as I was chilling out.

  The location was convenient for me because I live in Marin and it took only
40 minutes to get to Santa Rosa.   I missed the Synergy video stuff,  as they
weren't present,  but the projector system was rather spacey.

  All in all,  I had a wonderful time,  and the smile factor was really up
there (About an 8 on the 1 to 10 scale).

  After that,  I went to Deep Forest at Big Heart city,  but missed Carlos's
set because I got ride with someone else,  and got home late.    But after that
I boogied over to Boogie Buffet,  which was REALLY GREAT.   It was very crowded,
more "housey" music than normal on the bright area,  as this was special party
for 2 DJ's and it went on till about 4 pm.   Saw a lot of the same people that
were at VISION.    Had LOTs of energy left (As I normally do),   and was dancing
for 2 hours straight non-stop.   Not even to chill out,  because I found a place
on dance floor where the air conditioner was blowing and was able to keep very
cool during the dancing.   For those that missed it,  I'm sorry that you could'nt
make it....

  Oh!  BTW,  I picked up Basics T-shirt...  It'e really awsome...

Cheers
CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 13 14:38:56 1993

	id AA18098; Mon, 13 Sep 93 14:38:45 PDT
Date: Mon, 13 Sep 93 14:38:45 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9309132138.AA18098@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu
Subject: Re: Rave History Not Trivial Pursuit
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Arthur says:
>  the future is beyond our grasp.

Except that it is something that we have some control over.  The ability
to influence the future puts it into our grasp to some extent.

> The present is a moving,
> razorthin edge. Everything we know is in the past, and our understanding
> has to be based on how we put together the pieces of the past into a
> coherent picture of how the world coheres.

This is true.  But because there is so much past (10 - 20 billion years
of it) we end up filtering most of it out in our attempts to understand
it.  The end result is usually a gross biased distortion of what really
happened.  There is very little hard data with supporting physical evidence 
when it comes to the explanations of the evolution of cultural trends.  
Even the memories of someone-who-was-there require lot's of corraboration.  
There's been a recent uproar in the the Psychology community as it is now 
being discovered in many cases, childhood memories of trauma and abuse that 
shrinks yank out from the subconscious of their patients are often memories 
of childhood *fantasies* with little basis in reality.  Just like people
who discover under hypnotism that they were once abducted by UFOs.  Human
experience is stored in RAM, not ROM.

Realizing that we can't even trust our own minds, "Reality" becomes a
pretty tenuous thing.  Linear thought (cause->effect->cause->effect)
itself is an oversimplified straightjacket of modern consciousness.  
What I'm trying to say here is that understanding what's *really* going on 
in the near-present/Now is a daunting enough task.   Knowing the true 
origin of "acid house" will not change our world view or inspire us
to act any differently.  All knowledge is valuable, but there is so
much to know and the bandwidth of our sensory input devices, (and the power
of our CPUs) is quite limited.  Choices have to be made as to what we're
going to focus our mental energy on, and we're all free to make any choices
we like.  Sometimes I just wonder why people make the choices they do.

> To learn about that heritage isn't just "nice to know": it's
> a form of respect we pay to the people who came before us: they had their
> ideas, danced their dances, made their music, and passed it on to us. Now
> its our turn. 
>   And what will we give to those coming along next?

In my naieve idealistic view of things, I don't see what we're doing in
life as a baton that get's handed over to the next runner in the race.
Raving, as an ageless openended evolutionary activity, is more than a 
cultural trend upon the ruins of which the next trend will spring forth.   
If three-year-old raver Andrew Miller is any example, the "next" generation 
will be raving alongside us long before we are ready to "pass it on" and
give them their "turn".  Our rituals will continuously evolve and we all 
will continue to *live* history together rather than ponder it from afar. 
Let's put an end to the idea of people waiting in line to be "next".  

Trivial details aside, dancing and trancing out to rhythm and sound has 
putting humans in touch with each other, themselves, and the Universe for
thousands of years.   If we're not careful, a historical perspective 
can narrow our view rather than broaden it.  If you want people to really
understand raving, do you lecture them on its musical origins?  No, you 
take them to a fucking rave!  If it'll make them feel better, I suppose
there's no big harm in feeding them questionable historic data to satisfy 
their idle curiosities later.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com
____________________________________________________________________________

On Sep 13,  1:51pm, Crunch proclaimed:
}   Sorry for being late,  but I attended VISION,  and it was truly amazing.
} VERY BIG venue,  lots of room,  dance floor crowded,  but still lots of room
} to move around.   

I thought all things considered it was pretty good too - a real 
professional production, with care put in at every level.  However,
it lacked a certain.... one-ness.  Everyone was happy, sure, the
sound system was great and the majority of people were in fact dancing,
but the place was so big and so dark it felt like a big convention,
rather than a *party*.  Everyone was at the same level, except for two
or three small platforms set up near the DJ; thus, it was hard to look
around and get a sense of scope, a feeling of being in touch with people
around you.  This might sound trite, but what would have really helped
would have been a single big laser from behind the DJ booth.  It would
have brightened the place up, which it desparately needed (indeed, the
most perceptible "vibe" I felt was when they turned the lights on after
Josh's last song, and everyone was screaming for encores) and would 
have given people something to focus on, much like it did at last year's
Vision.  They had all the usual Basics/Gathering art posters up, but no
blacklights around them, for some odd reason.

} Very low cigerett smoke level (Although smoking was banned,
} nobody payed attention to no-smoking rule).   Chill out benefit factor about
} a 6 on the 1 to 10 scale (Due to large space).   There was free water and
} even ice.  The DJ's were totally awsome,  with good mix of techno, funk,  
} and jazz.  Apparently the same security company as one of the previous raves,
} as some of them recognized me and said "I saw you at the last event".  I 
} think it was Funkey Techno tribe at the Galleria.

All of the Basics/Gatherings etc.  use Lyon security.  Seriously, we as 
ravers couldn't ask for a better security force, except for none at all.
They are very cool people, they have been doing [parties for a long time,
and they for the most part know that they have no reason to bully down
on people like they might have to at concerts.  They are fully licensed
and have good working relationships with police, so their presence allows
Martin to use sites that otherwise might not not be available.

}   The Santa Rosa police appeared to be rather mellow,  and in a cheery mood.
} At least the ones I encountered by the front door as I was chilling out.

Yeah.  And I saw a couple older-generation folks walking around the place,
dressed in slacks and sweaters, and the vast majority looked like they were
having a good time (some even stayed till the very end, with perma-smiles on
their faces).  

}   The location was convenient for me because I live in Marin and it took only
} 40 minutes to get to Santa Rosa.   I missed the Synergy video stuff,  as they
} weren't present,  but the projector system was rather spacey.

The location was a good place for a large party, in a half-cylinder which
absorbed sound VERY nicely.  But it really did cry out for a laser, or
more visuals.

}   All in all,  I had a wonderful time,  and the smile factor was really up
} there (About an 8 on the 1 to 10 scale).

Agreed. :)

}   Oh!  BTW,  I picked up Basics T-shirt...  It'e really awsome...

Yeah, I got a "Communion" shirt.  Great logo - "Know your limits.  Cross
them."

	Brian

Yeah, I had a good experience and a bad one with this security.
The bad experience leeds me to believe that the guy hassleing me was a 
PIG in sheeps (Lyons) clothing since most of Lyons security know me by sight
(if not by name) and know that I am on their side.

When I got there some of the security, recognized me right away and said
Hi, I haven't seen you in a long while! Where Ya been!
I told them I had other things to do in my life than just rave :)
I was with two younger friends one of which was only 17 and only
had a school ID (which didn't have her age on it) but they let her
pass based on the fact that I said I was old enough to be her father and
I would look out for her.  After going through the first bunch, it was time
for a search, I usually get the once over but since these guys (and Gals)
know me, they usually don't bother me.  This guy goes through ALL my shit!
He looks through my backpack makes me empty every pocket in my fanny pack,
open vitamin bottles,  I was pissed but knew I was COMPLETELY clean
so I didn't have anything to worry about, I tell him he's wasting
his time because I don't do drugs (at least not tonight :), finnally he 
see my swiss army knife say something like whoa what have we here, he calls overhis superior (who knows me) and a couple of other guys (who also know me)
one of the guards says I know this guy he's OK but this fool was stuck on 
"the rules", I couldn't put it in my car cuz the folks I came with had already
gone inside. Finally one of the security people offerted to hold it for me
till the end, I recognized him from numerous parties before so i said OK.
(Later this person gave me back my penknife inside and apologized for his
collegue.  So as always folks, it the personal relationships that count
the most in this world.  I still think that Lyons are the best security
I've seen and would use them for any large party that I would have,
If I could afford them.

	Hi all,
Its been a while...

	This is paraphrased from Saturday the 11th's San Jose Mercury News:

Friday night the California Legislature killed the state's
asset-forfeiture law.  Basically this is how it will work form now on:

			Current Law		New Law

Criminal Conviction	No			Yes, except in cases involving
Required First					seizures of > $25000 in
						cash or if owner flees

Real Estate 		Can be taken w/o a	Owner must be convicted of  
			conviction		using the prop. to sell drugs

Prop. owned by 		Can be taken  if owner 	Can be taken only if
innocent third parties	knew or should have     actual knowledge of
			known of illegal use	illegal use is proved
						beyond a reasonable doubt
			
Standard of proof for	More likely than not	Beyond a reasonable doubt	
state to win a
forfeiture case

Where the money goes	90 % to law enforcement	   75% to law enforcement
			10 % to the state Office   20% to state general fund
			of Criminal Justice Planning   5% to anti-narcotics
							fund

Police use of seized	Police can keep and use  Police can keep and use 
property		anything		 anything but automobiles



That about sums it up...

Hope to see ya soon!


Gioni Pasquinelli					
pasque@hamlet.ucdavis.edu      What doesn't kill you makes you stronger

Lee says:
There's been a recent uproar in the the Psychology community as it is now
being discovered in many cases, childhood memories of trauma and abuse that
shrinks yank out from the subconscious of their patients are often memories
of childhood *fantasies* with little basis in reality.  Just like people
who discover under hypnotism that they were once abducted by UFOs.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
They just coincidentaly all describe the same aliens without having ever seen
them in media before.  I'll grant that many abduction experiences are fantasies
but I'm not so  sure aobut *all* of them.

-Mark

From: brians@unislc.slc.unisys.com (Brian Sassone)
Message-Id: <9309141544.AA16380@unislc.slc.unisys.com>
Subject: WARNING: More Historical "Facts"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (Bay Area Ravers)
Date: Tue, 14 Sep 1993 09:44:10 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1967      
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



For those of you who have an insatiable desire to trace our roots *and* those
of you who think history is simply a twisted figment of our own creative 
imaginations.  :)

	Acid house came about in 1988 as a result of Throbbing Gristle
	member Genesis P-Orridge's felicitious misunderstanding of the house
	term, "acid", as in Phuture's 1987 single "Acid Tracks", on
	Chicago-based Trax label.  In Chicago, "acid" 12-inches were
	bare-bones rythym tracks draped by static harmonies, mesmerizing in
	the same way the buzzing of a fluorescent light is mesmerizing.
	They were designed to provide a foundation for virtuosic quotes from
	other records, in real time, by dub deejays; "acid burn" was Chicago
	slang for ripping off someone else's sounds.

	To P-Orridge, a techno-pagan whose private pantheon is peopled with
	dandies and debauchees from Alister Crowley to Brian Jones, "acid"
	conjured visions of paradise regained with the aid of confetti-sized
	squares of blotter paper.  In 1988, P-Orridge released _Jack_the_Tab:
	Acid_Tablets_Volume_One/Original_U.K._Acid_Dance_Freakbeats_
	(Castalia Recordings) and _Tekno_Acid_Beat:_Pure_Acid_ (TOPY).
	These compilations ushered in the British acid sound, a swampy,
	woozy, reconciliation of Electric Ladyland with "Autobahn" and dub
	raggae, enlivened by backwards drum fills, wolf howls, a looped
	phrase sung by Hindu singer Najma, and snatches of '50s juvenile
	delinquent movies.  _Tekno_Acid_Beats_ ends with Margaret Thatcher
	making like a Merry Prankster as she pronounces a schoolroom science
	experiment successful: "Now, that's what I call the real acid test!"

	Mark Dery
	From an article on Techno
	Keyboard, April 1993



-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-
              Activate the rythym that has always been within.
                    Shamanic, artistic, archaic revival.
-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-\-/-

	for 
Received: from quickmail.apple.com by jumbo.apple.com with SMTP (5.64/22-Jun-1993-eef)
	id AA04434; Tue, 14 Sep 93 17:27:11 PDT
	for sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <9309150027.AA04434@jumbo.apple.com>
Date: 14 Sep 1993 17:13:46 -0800
From: "Jens Alfke" <jens_alfke@quickmail.apple.com>
Subject: Re: WARNING- More Historica
To: brians@unislc.slc.unisys.com, "Chris Hart" <hart@ntmtv.com>,
        roy@harlequin.co.uk
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

 RE>>WARNING: More Historical

Chris Hart writes:
>>    "acid burn" was Chicago slang for ripping off someone else's sounds.
>I'd be interested to know if anyone has any more direct evidence for
>this oft-sited explanation.... as i said before, there's someone in
>the UK, who claims to have invented this explanation as deliberate
>misinformation ....

There's an interview with Genesis P-Orridge (of Psychic TV) in Option magazine,
circa '88, where he describes the origin of the acid-house scene in England. He
says PTV was touring the US, got into the house music, bought various
acid-house records and brought them back to England. They misunderstood the
meaning of "acid" (Gen mentions the definition quoted above), assumed it meant
LSD, and things went on from there...

This seems like a pretty unimpeachable source. PTV were (as I understand it) in
the forefront of the English acid-house scene, and Option is a reputable
magazine that printed Gen's quotes more or less word-for-word.

--Jens Alfke

So, I went up to see the San Francisco supervisiors in
action... didn't see any other sfravers around, but then 
there's a bunch of newer folks I haven't met yet. 

Supervisor Hallinan (who is proposing an ammendment
eliminate the obscure, archaic curfew prohibiting people
under 21 from being in a "cabaret" after 2:30 AM) wasn't
there.  He had some flimsy excuse about having a baby that
day (or maybe it was his wife or something...), so nothing
was settled on this issue.  There's going to be another
hearing in a two weeks, so y'all still have a shot at making
your presence felt.

They went through with the hearing anyway.  The forces in
favor of keeping the restriction in place were (a) the cops,
and (b) some store owners near clubs (notably The Emporium).
The good guys, on the other hand, were (a) the owner of the
Palladium (b) rave promoter heavy weights from "Choice" and
"Organic Productions" (which I gather is The Gathering
posse), (c) lots of random ravers and clubbers and (d) one
or two "keep the kids off the streets" type organizations.

I'd like to summarize the bad guys arguments, but I doubt I
can do them justice since very little of it made sense to
me.  It seems that there is some problem with vandalism in
areas where there are clubs, which the store owners are
convinced would disappear if those pesky 18-21 types weren't
attracted to the area.  There was also some histrionics
about jammed parking, and how terrible it was seeing ravers
on the streets while you're going to work.  

The cops had some weird "statistics" about something like a
total of five violent incidents outside of 18+ places, over
a period of several years.  They made dire predictions of
San Francisco becoming a magnet to gang kids through out the
bay area, claiming that no one else let's 18+ folk dance
after 2 AM.  After Martin spoke, the Captain there made some
nasty remarks about raves being the work of British
expatriates who were chased out of their own country.  He
also talked about how if you let 18 years old in, then the
16 year olds can try and sneak in.  And lots of people
talked about drugs at raves, rarely with much of a clue
(e.g. they kept talking about crack, or the threat of crack,
which always brought giggles from the audience).  The cop
captain claimed that a typical club doesn't pay enough in
taxes to cover a cops salary for a month (implying that they
make something like 45K, which never occured to me before),
and complained that they only have about 4-5 guys to cover
all of SoMa on a given night (this is news to me, since it
seems like they're all over the damn place).

The arguments the Good Guys made are probably obvious to all
of you, except perhaps the point that state law (since 1972)
has already mandated that people over 18 are not minors, and
this particular (ancient) law declares that they are.  The
Palladium owner was particularly impressive, citing his long
and peaceful period of operation, and listing in detail all
the taxes the city picks up off of his establishment
(including, for example, income taxes on the jobs he
provides).  The Gathering posse emphasized that they do
everything legally and above board, and hire lots of private
security, and work very closely with the police in other
counties (e.g. Richmond), and in general talked about peace
and love and good vibes for all.

It would be nice to believe that the Good Guys have got this
one sewn up, but you never know about these things.  The
strength of your arguments isn't always as important as your
political weight, and the supes may decide that it ain't
worth pissing off their cops and the economic might of The
Emporium, et al, just to placate a couple of club owner
types...  especially considering that 18 year olds are such
tremendous wimps about getting involved with politics
anyway.

We'll see in a few weeks... but remember, Doom says: don't
relax on this one yet.

An interesting afternoon, overall.  A little more
engaging than the typical Palo Alto City Council, anyway.
And it wasn't a bad crowd: if I'd felt like socializing, I
could've made a bunch of friends among the ravers &
clubbers, not to mention promoters & club owners...

(Oh, and incidentally it was suggested by several people
that shopping at the Emporium is now definitely out.)

    Nice to hear from you, the answer is Yep! 'fraid so. It was only a matter
    of time. After a really successful '92 and 1st half of '93, finances got tough
    enough to take the mothership beyond the point of no return, a position
    which rendered her unrecoverable.

    was ow'd, an' the coffers were bare, me hearties. The last shindig was a final
    attempt to reach the breakeven waters of safe harbour. She never made it. 
    Sadly the ship was requisition'd by a fearsome gang of pirates known as
    the Receivers.
    
    Wild rumour has it that there be a trove filled with gold, buried unknown to
    but to he, the crafty Treasurer.

First a note about securtiy, especially Lyons.  I don't know WHY Martin
keeps hiring those fucks without telling them whats what first.  They, at
times, literally search people (more than patting down - this is ILLEGAL). 
They are also quite rude, and ruin the "vibe" for many going to their first
party.  They are a bit better when they know you OR they know you're wayyy
older than 21.  Other than that they are assholes.  They tried to search my
partner in crime (he's a very tall 6' 5"), he looked at them and said "Look
man, you can pat me down, but I am NOT opening my pockets for inspection!".
 They looked at him, and let him in, no problem.  We promptly found Martin
and told him about the incident.  Martin acted as though it was no big
deal.  Well it was to us.  I will never hire those people to do security
unless they quit acting like "super cops" (methinks they watch too much Cop
TV Drama). ;)

As for the CAB laws-  HUH!?!?!  I don't know why the word was not spread
about this one!  It wouyld have been good to have a show of force (along
with a nice long petition signed by VOTING 18+'s).  I hope that in two
weeks we can get a bit more organized for the next round.  Let's get some
petitions signed, some voters registered, and show City Hall that they have
more than the cops to worry about...how about their jobs as Supes?!?  Also
SOMEONE (I have already started) should write letters to the Emporium
telling them to lay off or face the wrath of a full-blown boycott by 18+'s
(who is one of their major demographics).

When will the next one be (hearing: the date please)?  Will there be a
general meeting before hand to get together some type of strategy?  Has a
stronger economic element been addded to the argument? Etc. etc...?

One importnat thing to note in our favor that came out of this meeting is
that state law defines a minor as under 18 while in SF the cabaret law
defines a minor as between 18 and 21; these being clearly in conflict
lawyers present at yesterday's meeting feel very postitive about the
possibility of overturning this ridiculous (sp?) law.

see ya later

On Sep 15,  8:20am, you proclaimed:
} First a note about securtiy, especially Lyons.  I don't know WHY Martin
} keeps hiring those fucks without telling them whats what first.  They, at
} times, literally search people (more than patting down - this is ILLEGAL). 
} They are also quite rude, and ruin the "vibe" for many going to their first
} party.  They are a bit better when they know you OR they know you're wayyy
} older than 21.  Other than that they are assholes.  They tried to search my
} partner in crime (he's a very tall 6' 5"), he looked at them and said "Look
} man, you can pat me down, but I am NOT opening my pockets for inspection!".
}  They looked at him, and let him in, no problem.  We promptly found Martin
} and told him about the incident.  Martin acted as though it was no big
} deal.  Well it was to us.  I will never hire those people to do security
} unless they quit acting like "super cops" (methinks they watch too much Cop
} TV Drama). ;)

I knew I'd get in trouble for my comments :)  I based my claim that they were
the best security that parties that large could hope for on watching how they
respond in specific cases... that for the most part, if your friend forgot
their ID and everyone else in the group is 18+, they'll let him/her go in...
that they let you bring water and lots of other stuff in... and even though
they wanted to search your friend, when he said no way they didn't put up a
fight.  I also based the claim on having talked to a number of them, 
including the sargaent, at length, and knowing that they are pretty clued
in into what goes on at raves.  Sure, there are going to be individual cases
to complain about, but I dunno if you can completely avoid those.  Given 
that you *have* to have security at a large party (sad, but a fact of life)
putting up with light pat-downs and occasional miscommunications is fine with
me.  If you don't want to be patted down go to Disneyland :)  (or small 
parties of course).


	Brian

just a random bit of info down from socal that may or may not be pertinnent

this actually has to do with a 18- club...
cuz a couple months ago a club down here that was all ages
was shut down by the police over some really stupid charges
(ie serving alcohol to minors when they dont serve alcohol at all)
but anyhow..

because they hire a LOT of security and have it covering outside the door
as well as inside the club, the police were saying that
the crime rate in that area had dropped incredibly
also it dropped because kids were inside the club instead of on the streets
when they got shut down a lot of parents complained to them
saying that their kids had no place to go anymore and 
woudl be just wandering the streets

i dont know if you could actually find out crime rate statistics
for areas around these clubs but it might be an interesting idea

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: cabaret law fight in Chron
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Wed, 15 Sep 93 10:14:10 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


The cabaret law hearing got a mention on the front page of the "Bay Area"
section of the Chronicle - there's a picture of a few ravers holding up
signs saying "We Can Vote/Why Can't We Dance" and "Dancing is Safe Sex".

The copy reads, "SF Dance Club Curfew Protested - An obscure SF police
ordinance that prohibits people under 21 years old from being in dance
clubs and cabarets after 2am came under attack last night at a committee
meeting of the SF Board of Supervisors.  Rochelle Brown, Michael McCormick,
Ken Boddy, and Leslie Homan listened to the cons of allowing 18- to 21-
year-olds into after-hours dance clubs.  No action was taken, although
an amendment is being proposed that would lower the age to 18."

Would have been nice if they had reported the arguments for and against
to make people aware of the general lameness of the law.

If anyone gets information about the time of the next hearing, I'll help
distribute flyers (and also add it to the calendar).
