>On Sep 15,  8:20am, you proclaimed:

I am ALWAYS proclaiming something!  I have an application with City Hall in
as the "Town Crier" ;)

>I knew I'd get in trouble for my comments :)  I based my claim that they were
>the best security that parties that large could hope for on watching how they
>respond in specific cases... that for the most part, if your friend forgot
>their ID and everyone else in the group is 18+, they'll let him/her go in...
>that they let you bring water and lots of other stuff in... and even though
>they wanted to search your friend, when he said no way they didn't put up a
>fight.  I also based the claim on having talked to a number of them, 
>including the sargaent, at length, and knowing that they are pretty clued
>in into what goes on at raves.  Sure, there are going to be individual cases
>to complain about, but I dunno if you can completely avoid those.  Given 
>that you *have* to have security at a large party (sad, but a fact of life)
>putting up with light pat-downs and occasional miscommunications is fine with
>me.  If you don't want to be patted down go to Disneyland :)  (or small 
>parties of course).
>
>
>        Brian

You and I are in agreement here Brian.  My post was not against security,
but Lyon's way of handling it.  Yeah, they let many people slide since they
have been clued in.  But at times, and they have been numerous, they take
it upon themselves to be REAL irritants.  You and I have worked with these
people, so it is unlikely that either of us would incur their wrath.  The
point is MANY people have no other choice but to deal with them, when they
are at their worst.  At one of the Basics parties (at the Armory) there was
this security guard lady gurading the back door aftyer 7:30 a.m.  I was
looking for my ride and they were looking for me, inside.  I asked her to
let me back in so that I can get my ride and leave.  Like a robot she said
"No ins, no outs!".  I looked at her and said (hoping to score on the
African-American tip ;) "Sistah, look, my ride is inside.   I want to leave
now.  They are looking for me and I don't want to wait.  So why not let me
inside, get them, and allow me to leave.  They are 20 feet away and I don't
want to scream to get their attention.  So how 'bout it?".  She stared at
me with those thick-ass glasses, looked me up AND down, and said "Ok, but
you BETTER, find them, and you'd BETTER leave!"  I walked in.  I found my
friends and began to look for the last person in our party.  She walks in
to get ME (leaving her guarded post, mind you).  She started to grab my
arm, I jerked away and told here "Look, I am waiting for the last person. 
I am right here near the entrance!  You know I am not going anywhere, and
I'm not wandering around. So please be patient, we'll all be out in a sec!"
 She moved her chair from the door to where I was, staring and watching us.
 Our person came, and we left.  Of course, being pissed, I said to her as I
left "Have a very nice day, and thank you for being a complete jerk!".  I'm
glad I "flipped" that night or I wouldn't have been so cordial ;).  Lyon's
are jerks.  They really do need lessons in how to "do your job, and act
human too".

Another quickie,  I understand the need for security at large events, but
how much is too much.  I know that there have been jerks at the parties of
late.  But you don't need 6-9 guards for raves, generally. 3-4 in strategic
locations is good enough, IMO.  Since Lyon's are such bullies, I would
suggest that 6-9 is overkill.  You only need 1 or 2 of Lyon's "Super Cops",
to man a 10,000 person rave.  They have enough meaness for everyone! ;)

Peace out,
John

        nm-list@reef.cis.ufl.edu
Subject: Multimedia music mailing lists?
Date: Wed, 15 Sep 93 10:48:41 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


I'm soon going to be getting the equipment and network bandwidth for
doing multimedia mail more easily... and i've been thinking... 
Wouldn't it be really cool to send around short samples of audio to
illustrate your messages, your music reviews, or your replies to
sample-ology queries?

Seems like the simplest solution would be a reflector list (e.g. given
list-name@foo.com you'd also have list-name-mm@xxx.com) which would
provide audio annotations for the associated message. The separate
lists would be maintained so as to not drop megabytes of unexpected
samples into the maildrops of people equipped to handle ASCII only
text.

Oh, yeah, and I guess we'd have to agree on audio format, or
standardize on whatever MIME defines.

==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==

>   what's the context surrounding that?  Who is it, etc?


	I know this to be completely untrue because I made up this
	explanation at a press conference held to launch the Freedom to
	Party Campaign at the Conservative Party conference in October 1989.
	I was attempting to desperately play down the drug aspect in a
	forlorn attempt to discourage anti-party legislation ..

	Nicholas Saunders
	from "E for Ecstasy"

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: security loves you
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU





>I don't know what the answer is to security at large parties, but I do know
>that when I'm hanging out with me friends in the "save haven" of a rave (and
>I mean that in more ways than one) and I see some large person in a very
>police looking uniform with a nightstick and a very large phallic looking
>flashlight, it totally sours my mood.
>                                                Pete


Cops always make me nervous, on the road or wherever.  I doubt I am the only
person who reacts this way.  It isn't like I freak - but I do become very aware
of their presence and I focus on my own behavior.  This isn't what I want if
I am trying for a more transcendental experience.

A security guard who looks like a cop is just as bad.  

My suggestion is that security be forced to wear an alternative
uniform.  Of course they should be easy to recognize, but who wants
pseudo-military scary people marching around?  Security should contribute
to the experience.

All they need are some kind of cheap, silly, interesting, fantastic, amazing,
beautiful, supercalifragilistic uniforms to take the goddamn edge out of there
very necessary presence.

Dave

    out of a club at 2 AM (especially if those kids know that the

    a bunch of tired kids who are leaving the party after having danced all
    night and now it's morning and the early commuters are all about.
    
    The justification for their position does not hold water.  There
    must be another reason for it.  Are they run by fundies or something?

Received: from epikt.agc.com by curly.agames.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA03996; Wed, 15 Sep 93 16:10:26 PDT
Date: Wed, 15 Sep 93 16:10:26 PDT
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Message-Id: <9309152310.AA03996@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: a small post-burning note
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Anyone at Burning Man who left the scene as the storm was starting missed
a nearly transcendental experience.  The phrase "drumming up a storm"
was taken literally.  I had set up next to someone who had two floor toms
(I had one) and was banging out rock-solid tribal rhythms.  I jumped in,
and began to experience one of the longest stretches of uninterrupted
pure rhythm I've ever helped to create.  It was intense.  People were
jumping and twirling as if possessed (no doubt some were) and we only
stopped once to rush in close as the Man fell in a triumphant pile of
whirling sparks.  We drummed, and tranced, and drummed, and danced, and
the desert revealed its power to us as the skies opened, lightning cracked
and roared, and the wind nearly blew us out of the state.

I will always remember that timeless moment: shouts of joy and terror,
wild, half-clothed shapes leaping and cavorting by the red-gold glow of
the Man's ashes, the wind so strong I felt I could give up and let it
blow me away, the feel of enless alkali dust and clean rain on my skin
as my drum and I pounded out the only time that mattered, accepting the
incalculable force of the universe yet still shouting against the Infinite,
knowing that the Infinite would never notice and the value of our defiance
was that we did it anyway.

To some people, this vision would have been of Hell, and I one of a host
of demons leading the masses into wickedness and sin.  Call it what
you want.  I'm there.

(Btw: I was the drummer with one floor tom, no shirt, many earrings,
and black sweats with skeletal dragons on them.  I met a lot of folks
but don't know if any were sfravers.  Big thanks to Kim (?) from YSH for
sharing the most beautiful sunrise I can remember, the Planet 6 people
for Techno In The Face Of Adversity, all the other drummers, Richard for
the ride, and everyone else who did stuff that helped make it happen.
No thanks to the TV crews for trying to turn it into a freakshow.  I was
drumming alone during the day by our tent and got more people videotaping
me than people coming by with drums to jam.)  

Sometimes it takes a Gut Blowout to make me remember what's important.
Simple animal pleasures of warmth, food, fire, the touch of others --
how did everything get so complicated, where you can buy everything 
except what you really want?

// g

good two years ago!

andy

Subject: Re: Cabaret Law hearing at SF City Hall
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


  >>  how terrible it was seeing ravers
  >> on the streets while you're going to work.

I've come to the conclusion that this is one of the most pressing
problems facing most western societies: fear of subcultures or
societies which are different.  People are scared of other people who
live their lives differently, and they seem to believe that society
has the right, even the duty, to hide from them those things that they
are scared of, that they don't understand.  Even to the extent of
destroying other people's culture or locking them up....

Mainstream western culture is a dominator culture....  it feels the
need to westernize and "civilize" all that it touches.  It can't
except that there might be another way.  As long as the very idea of
peaceful coexistence and mutual respect for different cultures is
anathema to the dominant society, we're lost....

Just my 2p worth....

	Cosmic

Just a quick reminder to let everyone know about
today's SFR South Bay Lunch ...

When: Thursday, Sept 16th  
Time: 12.00 noon
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
   ( Southbound : Drive past University Ave. )
   ( Northbound : Drive past San Antonio Road ) 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Park in the first
  carpark to your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Subject: SF City Hall & the homeless
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>  Howard> Pity that they don't consider it terrible to see homeless people
>  Howard> on the streets as they drive to work, though.  
>
>They probably do.  That is, they consider it terrible to have to *see*
>the homeless.  Couldn't the government move them on to some slum where
>they won't be seen by the middel classes....? 
>
>Maybe I'm being unduly cynical......

The fact is this city is quite generous to homeless folx.  Moreso than
other places, which is why we have a disproportionate amount of them here
in the city.  The problem is the limited resources the city has to deal
with the problems.  Handing out free food IMO only makes things worse. 
When they stopped food-not-bombs dude from handing out freebies, many of
the recipients started flocking to Berkeley.  Now Berkeley is complaining
about them coming from SF to the East Bay.  They cannot support them
either.  I don't think there are any quick answers for this problem, except
a better economy, more compassion, and a true effor to help anyone who is
needy.  We still have many vestiges of greed in our society.

Until that time...not in my back yard.

Late,
John

Agreed!  I think the other thing is this societies non-acceptance of the
13th Generation.  Who for the most part have said "Fuck 9-5 since I will
not have the standard of living my parents had.  Why work for someone who
will not be as committed to you as an employer." etc. etc.  I saw some
BULLSHIT TV show yesterday (I was home sick BTW) that said essentially ,
and I paraphrase, "People must lower their expectations of this society
(USA), and face the fact that the boom of the 50's that allowed great
prosperity may not happen again for some time."  So in other words, forget
about owning a home,forget about retirement (since those 40 somethings+ 
will drain SSecurity by the time WE are all recipients), and accept the
fact that you may have to take a low paying job, DESPITE your education.

Well, that is exactly why there are soooo many underground opprtunities
available, esp here in SF (you all know what I mean).  They told us to stay
in school, go to college, and prosperity will be ours. Another myth to keep
the masses distracted from the reality of an economic disaster.  Keep 'em
in school so they won't notice.  I dunno, just a thought!

It saddens me to talk to someone who has gone thru Cal with great grades,
and a degree, and see this talented individual have a very difficult time
finding work.  Instead he/she must take a low-ball, low-paying job that
they are overqualified for, with little chance of moving up.  I have, and
will not have this problem, since I have many years of experience in my
field (even without the degree, I am more valuable since I have more
experience than someone straight outta college).  But they don't even want
to give college grads a chance, and THIS sucks!

Just rambling,
John

I disagree Roy.  The laws here are quite explicit about search and seizure.
 First they asked Geoff to open up his stuff (illegal!  Only the cops can
do this and they must have reasonable cause.  Security cannot, they do not
have the color of authority! Sorry.).  Secondly they confiscated a
pocket-knife.  That's seizure.  Illegal since the search was illegal,
illegal since they did not have probable cause.  That is why REPUTABLE
security, does pat-downs for weapons, and usually dis-allows back-packs,
since they cannot legally search backpacks.

  I have a feeling,that whether NAFTA passes or not,we are heading into a
society where machines using artificial intelligence,technologies like
expert systems,voice recognition,robotics and easy telecommuting are going
to free a lot of people from the necessity of doing work.(If anyone
disagrees with me,I'd like to see their arguments.. this is a very
interesting subject for me.) This can be looked at as a good thing.Why try
to compete with the low wage countries,when technology can do many things
much more efficiently? Ultimately this will be dealt with by our social
system,the alternative is total chaos,class warfare along the lines of
what we've been seeing happening in Los Angeles,Florida,Detroit,here,etc.
but I dont think we can expect that until large sections of the middle
class (as opposed to the underclass) begin to lose their jobs.This time
now represents a transition period.Ultimately I think the government will
adopt the only sane policy.Encourage people to drop out of society if they
want to,to go to school,do art,live in the woods and smoke pot..whatever.. 
With 5% of the worlds population here in the United States using 40% of
the worlds resources reducing consumption is the only way to go. Otherwise
the world is heading towards a living hell, and no amount of walls or guns
will protect the idle rich from it's repercussions.We can do it. America
is the most productive economy in the world. A good first step would be to
legislate a 30 hour work week. Some may think I'm crazy,but sooner or
later people will come around.Better to have 300 million people riding
bikes than to have 50 million driving tanks and the other 250 million
people -make that 9.95 billion (by the year 2000 -7 years away) throwing
bombs and Molotov coctails at them. Its our choice for the future.. We
have to stop defining people by their jobs.In a future where few people
have to work.. with the present paradigm..this will mean that most people
will be considered worthless?  Another thought..  In San Francisco,does
the curfew law mean that if you are under 21 and homeless (hence "out all
night" ) does this mean you are technically breaking the law? Do people
think this will survive a court challenge? 
I have a feeling that in the future,many more people will be in this position.
Look at the recent surveys on literacy. Does anyone think these people are
going to be working in 5 or 10 years?
   There are only so many Mac Donalds 's
(which are already being computerized) and ditches to dig.
-Chris

I'm sure Mark Heley would love to be thought of as the founder of

degenerated from a club with a vision into overly-commercial buffoonery..)

ToonTown was held in the basement of Big Heart City. (while Mark was still
in England,I think.) He was however,to be credited with some good

In-Reply-To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
       "SF City Hall & the homeless" (Sep 16,  8:33am)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Subject: Re: SF City Hall & the homeless
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

warning - non-rave-related, but in as much as rave culture talks about
compassion and healing, this may be of interest.

On Sep 16,  8:33am, J.S.Lee proclaimed:
} The fact is this city is quite generous to homeless folx.  Moreso than
} other places, which is why we have a disproportionate amount of them here
} in the city.  The problem is the limited resources the city has to deal
} with the problems.  Handing out free food IMO only makes things worse. 
} When they stopped food-not-bombs dude from handing out freebies, many of
} the recipients started flocking to Berkeley.  Now Berkeley is complaining
} about them coming from SF to the East Bay.  They cannot support them
} either.  I don't think there are any quick answers for this problem, except
} a better economy, more compassion, and a true effor to help anyone who is
} needy.  We still have many vestiges of greed in our society.

Two separate issues here: Operation Matrix, Jordan's "answer" to the homeless
problem, is nothing more elaborate than telling homeless people "you can't be
here, so leave".  The police are on record as not being happy with this 
operation, and a few have threatened to quit if it continues, all citing its
inherent sillyness.  Meanwhile, back in front of the Civic Center, an
operation called Food Not Bombs have been giving out free food to the homeless,
and getting arrested for "not having a permit", when in fact they have tried to
get a permit and none in fact exist!  The situation has gotten more heady every
day, with currently about 40 people arrested.  

These two policies are indicative of an "out of sight, out of mind" approach
to solving the homeless problem, which is clearly not the answer.  Arguing that
providing care to the homeless only encourages more people to become homeless
is like saying that building more jails encourages more people to become 
criminals.

For more info about the goings on of FNB, read ba.general, ucb.general, or
oddly enough, alt.wired.  There might be an alt.org.fnb.... also, you can
send mail to andyrose@netcom.com, he's the FNB spokesman on the net.

	Brian

	id AA01720; Thu, 16 Sep 93 12:22:49 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA01713; Thu, 16 Sep 93 12:22:45 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA26987; Thu, 16 Sep 93 12:22:34 -0700
Message-Id: <9309161922.AA26987@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 1993 12:22:29 -0700
In-Reply-To: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
       "Re: Cabaret Law hearing at SF City Hall" (Sep 16,  1:12pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Cabaret Law hearing at SF City Hall
Cc: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

On Sep 16,  1:12pm, you proclaimed:
} I've come to the conclusion that this is one of the most pressing
} problems facing most western societies: fear of subcultures or
} societies which are different.  People are scared of other people who
} live their lives differently, and they seem to believe that society
} has the right, even the duty, to hide from them those things that they
} are scared of, that they don't understand.  Even to the extent of
} destroying other people's culture or locking them up....

I think "fear of the unknown" is a trait that has been with us for a long
time, is not just a Western concept, and is something that's very much a 
part of human nature, so fighting it isn't ever a good solution.  

As this applies to the rave scene - I think we should make ourselves less of
an unknown entity to the "outside".  Not saying we have to bend over backwards
to accept outsiders into our fold, but we shouldn't fool ourselves into 
thinking that everything will be fine if we just keep to ourselves.  If the
scene here involved, say, less than 1000 people total and a few parties a 
month rather than a few parties a day, then it could be argued that we're small
enough not to matter.  But we're too far along now to isolate ourselves, 
imho.  I know I'm going to sound like a heretic on this, but what might help
is if someone on the inside were to produce a really good, really factual,
really REAL documentary of who we are, what we're about, how it all boils down
to music.... and get it shown on PBS or distributed to theatres or otherwise
let people KNOW that we're not the boogeyman.  Other forms of communication 
can work too - we just have to communicate the essence of our existance.  The
gay community has been able to within one generation almost completely reverse
the "outside" world's image of them.  Our challenge isn't going to be anywhere
near as hard... but it'll still take the active commitment of people to stand
up when we get pushed down by the outside.

} 	Cosmic

	Brian

p.s. - so when are you coming out to visit, Roy?

>Subject: Homelessness,cabaret laws and curfew
>
>  I have a feeling,that whether NAFTA passes or not,we are heading into a
>society where machines using artificial intelligence,technologies like
>expert systems,voice recognition,robotics and easy telecommuting are going
>to free a lot of people from the necessity of doing work.(If anyone
>disagrees with me,I'd like to see their arguments.. this is a very
>interesting subject for me.) This can be looked at as a good thing.Why try
>to compete with the low wage countries,when technology can do many things
>much more efficiently? Ultimately this will be dealt with by our social
>system,the alternative is total chaos,class warfare along the lines of
>what we've been seeing happening in Los Angeles,Florida,Detroit,here,etc.
>but I dont think we can expect that until large sections of the middle
>class (as opposed to the underclass) begin to lose their jobs.This time
>now represents a transition period.Ultimately I think the government will
>adopt the only sane policy.Encourage people to drop out of society if they
>want to,to go to school,do art,live in the woods and smoke pot..whatever.. 
>With 5% of the worlds population here in the United States using 40% of
>the worlds resources reducing consumption is the only way to go. Otherwise
>the world is heading towards a living hell, and no amount of walls or guns
>will protect the idle rich from it's repercussions.We can do it. America
>is the most productive economy in the world. A good first step would be to
>legislate a 30 hour work week. Some may think I'm crazy,but sooner or
>later people will come around.Better to have 300 million people riding
>bikes than to have 50 million driving tanks and the other 250 million
>people -make that 9.95 billion (by the year 2000 -7 years away) throwing
>bombs and Molotov coctails at them. Its our choice for the future.. We
>have to stop defining people by their jobs.In a future where few people
>have to work.. with the present paradigm..this will mean that most people
>will be considered worthless?  Another thought..  In San Francisco,does
>the curfew law mean that if you are under 21 and homeless (hence "out all
>night" ) does this mean you are technically breaking the law? Do people
>think this will survive a court challenge? 
>I have a feeling that in the future,many more people will be in this position.
>Look at the recent surveys on literacy. Does anyone think these people are
>going to be working in 5 or 10 years?
>   There are only so many Mac Donalds 's
>(which are already being computerized) and ditches to dig.
>-Chris
>

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep 16 13:19:27 1993

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 1993 13:19:21 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: SF Sherriff comes out for Legalization, and 2 1200's for $600.
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Two posts in one:

First, while perusing the Classified Flea Market, I found a pair of 
Technics SL1200's for $600.... call 510-687-5038 if you're interested.

Second, here's the text to the article in this week's SF Weekly:

[SFWeekly: September 15th, 1993]

HENNESSEY BRAVELY URGES REPEAL OF TOUGH DRUG LAWS

by Vince Bielski

In the dusty American tradition of literary lawmen, San Francisco's
own Michael Hennessey has penned a cover story for "American Jails"
that will rattle more than a few sheriffs' cages.  "I'm also on the
cover in the nude with a bulldog on my butt and a black panther on my
shoulder," joked the proud sheriff.

But Hennessey's gun-slinging artcile in the July/August issue, titled
"Our National Jail Scandal," is no laughing matter.  The story puts
him on record as one of the first active law enforcement honchos to
declare the war on drugs a sham and to call for the decriminalization
of drug use laws. "This was an unwinnable war from day one, a war that
has resulted in billions of wasted tax dollars, and a war that is,
ultimately, almost solely waged against minority Americans," he said.

The mag's managing editor, Ken Kerle, expects Hennessey's piece will
stir up trouble among readers of the country's preeminent publication
on jail matters.  In his editorial, he praised Hennessey "for his
candor and courage tin putting his views into print."

Is the sheriff worried? "I haven't gotten any heat yet, it just came
out.  But I will take heat.  The editor said he can't wait for the
letters to the editor."

No doubt.  Says the badge-wielding scribe of his fellow sherifs:
"Like crackheads and heroin users who infest the inner city, we are
hopelessly addicted to ever-increasing incarceration."

The United States has the "dubious distinction" of having a higher
ratio of its population behind bars than any other country in the
world, including tumultuous South Africa, the article says.  These
locked-up Americans are "overwhelmingly minority, predominantly young,
and invariably involved with drugs.  African American and Hispanic men
under the age of thirty who use drug sales as a means of economic
sustenance and advancement."

Not only has the "industry of massive domestic incarceration" failed
miserably to curb crime, the sheriff asserts, it creates career
criminals.  "Time in jail only further alienates inmates from
society's mainstream, separating them from the basic societal
structures that truly keep people from becoming career criminals:
family, jobs, positive reinforcing peer groups."

The roots of thie "national tragedy" are political.  Cowardly
politicians pander to a frightened public by passing tougher crime
bills to help get themselves elected. (Hennessey, who has been elected
sheriff four times, shows there are other paths to power.)  Like
Prohibition in the 1920's, which nurtured organuzed crime,
prostitution, gambling, and political corruption, the tought drug laws
of today have created "a society strangled by the illegal drug
industry" in which "thousands of lives are lost in murderous turf wars
and entire inner-city communities are held hostage by escalating drug
violence."

Hennessey dismisses the argument that decriminalization will lead to
increased drug use.  "History has shown that prohibition actually
draws people to experiment with drugs, offers them an opportunity to
defy authority, and brings economic opportunity in the creation of a
black market."

Instead of resorting to punishment, the sheriff urges more funding for
drug treatment programs, which would lead to a 25 percent reduction in
population of San Francisco's overcrowded jails, he says.

In addition to being a published writer, the sheriff fancies himself a
Sex Pistols aficionado.  During a photo shoot, he pulled from his desk
drawer a picture of himself dressed as a punk rocker, wearing an
earring, orange spiked hair and a snarl on his face.  (The politician
in him has vowed never to allow the picture to be published.)

While Hennessey's office is filled with the mystery novels, law
enforcement tomes and books on rock and roll, he insistshe doesn't
plan on becoming a journalist.  "It doesn't pay enough," he said.

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep 16 13:34:34 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02292; Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:34:34 PDT
Received: from bronze.lcs.mit.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02285; Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:34:19 PDT
Received: by bronze.lcs.mit.edu 
	id AA01839; Thu, 16 Sep 93 16:32:55 EDT
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 93 16:32:55 EDT
From: abbe@bronze.lcs.mit.edu (John C. Abbe aka Rademir)
Message-Id: <9309162032.AA01839@bronze.lcs.mit.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Homeless, Energy, Building
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Okay. It's long. But I *do* get back to raves. Really. Trust me.
 
`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,`,
 
jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee) wrote:
>>  Howard> Pity that they don't consider it terrible to see homeless people
>>  Howard> on the streets as they drive to work, though.
>>
>>They probably do.  That is, they consider it terrible to have to *see*
>>the homeless.  Couldn't the government move them on to some slum where
>>they won't be seen by the middel classes....?
>>
>>Maybe I'm being unduly cynical......
>
>The fact is this city is quite generous to homeless folx.  Moreso than
>other places, which is why we have a disproportionate amount of them here
>in the city.  The problem is the limited resources the city has to deal
>with the problems.  Handing out free food IMO only makes things worse.
>When they stopped food-not-bombs dude from handing out freebies, many of
>the recipients started flocking to Berkeley.  Now Berkeley is complaining
>about them coming from SF to the East Bay.  They cannot support them
>either.  I don't think there are any quick answers for this problem, except
>a better economy, more compassion, and a true effor to help anyone who is
>needy.  We still have many vestiges of greed in our society.
>
>Until that time...not in my back yard.
>
>Late,
>John
 
What a great turn of phrase! We could make it into an acronym! NIMBY!
 
Seriously, not just a flame. It is *exactly* this attitude that keeps a whole 
lot of people from addressing the problem. And, you're right, a lot of people 
jump on the handing out food/philanthropy/charity bandwagon as another way of 
avoiding the real issues (oh, those poor homeless!).
 
People deserve more respect and need to regain the ability to handle more 
responsibility than a handout often gives. On the other hand, you've gotta 
eat to stay alive, and most people who are homeless need some really basic 
needs met, from food and mental/physical health care to clean clothes and an 
address before they can even think of making it on their own. And to some 
extent this may all little more than a rearguard action as we try to mature 
as a species and a society to the point where we stop doing this to our 
selves. I mean, it doesn't make sense to wait until someone is homeless 
before you think about helping them. And that's why Food Not Bombs is 
important, 'cause they try to point that out to people. The fact is, people 
are getting bumped down the socio-economic ladder every day. Chris talked 
about people being freed from the 'necessity' of doing work in the near 
future. It's already been that way for a long time. How many people in this 
society work on life's basics? Very few. The rest is luxury time, if you look 
at it as a society, which we have 'chosen' (pretty unconsciously) to split up 
so that some (mostly the unemployed) have lots of luxury time, but then we 
also have chosen as a society not to support them. Many others (the 
majority), we support minimally-to-quite-well to provide services for each 
other and the select few who do pretty much as they like and still get 
supported (the rich/powerful-enough-to-not-have-to-work). Looking at it from 
this societal perspective, it's pretty screwy. And the answer is not to have 
the rich occasionally hand some stuff down from on high, through taxes or 
donation or whatever (and feeling generous about it!).
 
The whole system's gotta go.
 
And it's going. We can feel it. But rather than putting energy into helping 
tear it down, I see a need to build a new system. *Before* the old one's 
gone. One that has a conscious societal perspective, allowing us to choose to 
support everyone, and to stop exploiting each other (and our future, 
environment/resources-wise), and to still create more than enough for 
everyone to lead very fulfilled lives. And dammit, I *still* haven't been to 
a rave, but I can feel that energy here!
 
This is *complex* stuff. There's a lot for us to learn, and we're trying to 
do it while the old system is just starting into it's death throes, so we're 
having to do a lot of working around it (events get busted, people charge 
lotsa $$ for some events, certain chemical preferences are illegal, these are 
all visible effects of this dynamic). What we're trying to do is hard, hard, 
hard. Expect it to be challenging. There is and will be falling out within 
the community, and among the many communities that have this energy. There 
will of course be many conflicts with the old system. It's a self-preserving 
system, how else would it have been at all stable? It's always tumultuous to 
be *growing up*, which is what we are doing, as a society, hopefully as a 
species. We're going through one of those difficult ages (terrible twos, 
adolescence...), it's a time to learn, learn, learn. And to try to sit back 
once in a while when we can and reflect on it all a little, hold it in a big 
enough perspective so that we don't get down on individual people too hard 
(like, I started this post mad at John. Sorry, d00d :-). Slack. Perspective. 
Conscious (and keep it fun!).
 
--Johnnie steps off the soapbox and plunges to the ground, barely keeping on 
his feet. Hmm...hadn't realized it had grown that high. <sheepish grin>
Just my, uh, 2 dollars?

homelessness is important because several ravers that I know have wound up
homeless.  It's important to talk about the Constitution because last time
I checked we had the freedom of peaceable assembly and could not be
subject to unnecessary search and seizure, all very important if you
are going out raving. Perhaps you were mistaken and thought raves were just

Busy weekend, especially for some SFR DJs, check out Tamara at YSH
tonight and again (along with several other SFR DJs) at Liquid Air (a
Fluid Groove Production) on Saturday.

Also there's a Wicked this weekend (the first stand-alone Wicked in a
while), and a few smaller events which look interesting.

About two weeks from now there will be another hearing about the
law in SF which prevents 18-20 year-olds from going to after-hours
clubs.  Hopefully I'll have more details by next week, but in the
meantime, you can contact Supervisor Terence Hallinan's office
at 415.554.5184 and voice your opinion.  (Hallinan favors repealing
the law)

good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness

If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly hope
to get all the info every week. 

Brian Behlendorf, bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu, 510-649-0351 and
Derek Chung, dhchung@us.oracle.com, 415-506-6195


To subscribe/unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
majordomo@sfraves.stanford.edu with either the line

subscribe sfraves-calendar   or
unsubscribe sfraves-calendar   

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep 16 13:41:13 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02394; Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:41:13 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02387; Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:41:11 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA13958; Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:41:21 -0700
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 93 13:41:21 -0700
Message-Id: <9309162041.AA13958@netcom.netcom.com>
To: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: the homeless & healing
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>warning - non-rave-related, but in as much as rave culture talks about
>compassion and healing, this may be of interest.
>
>These two policies are indicative of an "out of sight, out of mind" approach
>to solving the homeless problem, which is clearly not the answer.  Arguing that
>providing care to the homeless only encourages more people to become homeless
>is like saying that building more jails encourages more people to become 
>criminals.


This is not what I said.  It does not encourage people to become homeless,
but it does encourage people to come here for such free services.  There is
only so much a city should/could provide for it's citizens (taxpayers &
non).  When they come here (I hate the term "they" for the Homeless, but it
is less to type) they put a strain on the already overburdened services we
provide.  Many missions are full, the local programs are overburdened and
undersupported.  And the general climate of SF, esp of late, does say "Hey,
not in my back yard!".  I know I don't want anyone homeless on MY doorstep.
 The FACT that the Berkeley city council complained about people coming
from SF to Berkeley to get some of their goodies, indicates that there is
SOME migration that occurs.  Primarily to places that have services.  That
is all I was saying.

As for the Food-Not-Bombs, I don't necessarily agree with what he is doing
(esp considering his history).  But but I think he should be allowed to do
it.  The permit thing is a complete farce.  Just more of the same for SF. 
But it is suprising that of all places the city council of Berkley would
complain about having to take on more than they can chew, when SF has been
doing that for some time.  I guess when it's time for the left to do it's
share, all it can do is complain.  Let's see how Berkely effectively deals
with this crisis.  I predict, like other citites, they will do the same
thing SF has been accused of.  They will make "laws" in such a way as to
discourage the homless from being there. And when that fails, they will
have their own "Matrix" to deal with.  News at 11!

>
>For more info about the goings on of FNB, read ba.general, ucb.general, or
>oddly enough, alt.wired.  There might be an alt.org.fnb.... also, you can
>send mail to andyrose@netcom.com, he's the FNB spokesman on the net.
>
>        Brian
>
>

When o when will these "POP" organizations stop the BS.  For instance, why
not "Jobs Not Bombs".  How about "Defense Conversion Not Bombs" or even
"Re-open safe, clean, mental facilities not bombs".  These are the REAL
issues here.  And until they are adressed we will always have this
sickening homeless situation.  Typical of Western thought, attack the
symptom, but leave the problem alone.  Food is all fine and well, but when
you don't adress health, education, and welfare, all the food in the world
solves no problem at all.

Just a thought.  A more holistic approach would be the best!
John

>                      Subject:                              Time:  11:52 AM
>  OFFICE MEMO         Fresh Friday                          Date:  9/16/93
>Hey everyone...
>
>Rumor has it...all right, Scotty told me that this Friday is the last Fresh
>Fridays at FX and he is gonna spin and so will Rick Preston (who got SLIGHTED
>at that vision...it's too bad---when are people gonna take the risk and break
>up the Jeno/Garth/Josh conglomerate?  Great DJs, but there is a lot of great
>talent out there, and Rick is a pretty incredible dj--check him out at
>Grooooove Kitchen)....
>it should be a good time...also check out FreeLife (if it going on) at FX on
>Monday...Deep Space is tonight..
>
>wow, I am just your South Bay info line today...
>
>be happy, be happy, be happy.
>
>m i k e

One other note before I commnet about JenoGarthJosh:  The Zanzibar is
closing down.  It will be open this friday, and I think a couple more after
that before it closes.  Josh will be ripping it up until then.  Come out,
say hi, have a drink, socialize (for the longest time they didn't check
ID's on Fri/Sun)!  This place was at one time the Mecca for the After-Hours
of the scene here in SF.

Onto the drug: 
The JenoGarthJosh isx Martin's thang.  Just like YSH has it's crew of
people who always spins, just like Wicked has it's posse, and just like
Deep Space has it's own, Martin has his thang.  Every club/party/rave has
an indentity.  It's all in how the promoter wants to present that identity,
is what counts.  For instance, Groove Kitchen is this weekend (I'll be
there in full form!).  Preston has made it a point to let ANYONE spin who
can do the do.  And he has always given breaks to new talent, as well as
give props to the people who've been in the mix for a while.  So he has
John Howard (great guy, good dj!), Ernie Munson (nned anyone say more), and
Spun (Who?  Only kidding, another great one!), and Rick Preston (good dj,
great guy, great dj, good guy). John's the newest of the bunch! Then
there's Wicked, you know that lineup (Jeno, Garth, Markie, Thomas)!  Each
have their own identity.  Wicked has it's crew that hardly ever changes
(unless one of them is out of town).  Both are great parties.  One has a
"formula" (i.e. same DJ lineup), one has a different "formula" (vet DJs
with relative newcomers thrown in for spice).

The problem I see, is that people have become quite used to the formula of
JenoGarth.  And there is this mythos that not booking them will kill your
party.  The promoters who think that, as well as the people who will only
go out when these two are in concert, are part of the problem.  The Bay
Area has, by far, some of the greatest talent to choose from.  There is no
reason why you could not book lesser known DJ's and do quite well. The BEST
mix though is some seasoned vets along with some new meat, like Preston
does.  I personally like all vets, since I hate to play with the vibe.  

My dream lineup would be:
Markie, Ernie, Josh, James, Tony. The first party to do that combo will be
one killa party (each DJ for 2.5 or 2 hours!). I can feel it now!

John

Subject: Technology
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

 I have a feeling,that whether NAFTA passes or not,we are heading into a
society where machines using artificial intelligence,technologies like
expert systems,voice recognition,robotics and easy telecommuting are going
to free a lot of people from the necessity of doing work.(If anyone
disagrees with me,I'd like to see their arguments.. this is a very
interesting subject for me.)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
I don't know how I feel about this Chris, but I have seen some convincing 
arguments that say that technology just re-arranges the work force.  Takes
out workers here in this field, creates work in another.  This is supported
(or seems to be) by the fact that in most households with two adults, they
both work.  30, 40 years ago this was not true.  Even though the unemployment
rate is higher, there are more human bodies working.  Combined with the 
economy, we have more workers getting less out of the money they work for.

-Mark

Hey All-

Wendy (my roommate) told me that the San Jose Police sent a flyer
out to the hospital where she works stating that the newest thing in
gang initation is to drive around at night without their car lights
on and wait for the first random driver to flash their lights at them.
Well, this may not see like such a big deal...but the kicker is that 
once a car flashes their lights they follow the car and then shoot the 
driver.

I just thought I'd spread the word so my favorite people don't start
flashing their lights.


Drive safely!

|have the color of authority! Sorry.).  Secondly they confiscated a
|pocket-knife.  That's seizure.  Illegal since the search was illegal,
|illegal since they did not have probable cause.  That is why REPUTABLE
|security, does pat-downs for weapons, and usually dis-allows back-packs,
|since they cannot legally search backpacks.

John, I think you're a bit confused about "rights" like those against
search and seizure.  The Constitution specifically says what the
FEDERAL government may and may not do, that's pretty much all.  Some of
the more recent amendments cover state governments, and through them
(esp. the 14th [?] Amendment, which says "no state may deny anyone
his life, liberty, or property without due process of law") the
Supreme Court has extended most of our "fundamental rights" to apply
to state governments.  The reason these apply to city police as well
is presumably that city governments do not have separate legal powers
from state governments (unlike state vs. federal government) but are
strictly subservient to them.

However, NONE of this applies to private citizens such as Lyon security
guards.  There are entirely separate laws for this (e.g. those that
prevent theft).  THERE IS NO LAW that says it's illegal for a private
citizen to search your possessions.  What the law does say is that
this can't be done without your consent (this would be trespassing,
I think); however, Lyon is breaking no laws by asking you if they
can search your bag, and is breaking no laws by requiring you to
leave if you refuse to submit to the search.  Now if they only did
this to black people, or women, or whatever, this would be different
because there are anti-discrimination laws that forbid this sort of
behavior.  But there are simply no laws that prevent discrimination on
the basis of refusing to submit to a search.

ben

	id AA05711; Thu, 16 Sep 93 15:40:59 PDT
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 93 15:40:58 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9309162240.AA05711@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, abbe@bronze.lcs.mit.edu
Subject: Re: Homeless, Energy, Building
Cc: jlf3@attmail.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Rademir declares: 
> The whole system's gotta go.
>  
> And it's going. We can feel it. But rather than putting energy into helping 
> tear it down, I see a need to build a new system. *Before* the old one's 
> gone. One that has a conscious societal perspective, allowing us to choose to 
> support everyone, and to stop exploiting each other (and our future, 
> environment/resources-wise), and to still create more than enough for 
> everyone to lead very fulfilled lives. And dammit, I *still* haven't been to 
> a rave, but I can feel that energy here!

IMO, The problems of our society do not reside within the structure of our
political/economic systems, but rather with the fundamentals of human
nature.  There will be no significant change without some kind of
spiritual reawakening.  When people start becoming aware of the powers
within them, and how they are interconnected with the forces around them,
then they might start acting for the common and individual good.  Instead,
we tend to live in fear of each other and of a world where idealism is 
fantasized or scoffed at while each of us fights for a piece of a 
shrinking pie.

I find Raving to be one of the few modern rituals that promotes an 
idealistic (and doctrineless), yet experiential, awareness of the harmony 
that exists within us, with each other, and with the Universe in general.  
There are many things we can do in many areas of our lives to try make 
things "better".  But most of these things are just addressing the 
symptoms of the frightened and confused nature of the human psyche.  If
society is going to evolve, than individuals must too.  I'm not saying that 
we should deny our current biologically evolved nature, just that we have 
to start realizing that being human is just a part of something much bigger.

In a sense, I think we have outgrown our own usefulness as humans.  We are
on the threshold of being able to genetically and physically reengineer 
our bodies and our brains.  But do we even know what we are aiming for? 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

>John, I think you're a bit confused about "rights" like those against
>search and seizure.  The Constitution specifically says what the
>FEDERAL government may and may not do, that's pretty much all.  Some of
>the more recent amendments cover state governments, and through them
>(esp. the 14th [?] Amendment, which says "no state may deny anyone
>his life, liberty, or property without due process of law") the

>strictly subservient to them.
>

>guards.  There are entirely separate laws for this (e.g. those that

>ben

Hmmm...your premise is that there can be FEDERAL laws do not apply to
private citizens, and I beleive this is not true.  FEDERAL laws supercede
all laws.  No state can make laws more restrcitive than those of the fed,
but they can make laws giving GREATER freedoms. So in the case of Lyons,
who has no authority, legal or otherwise, they cannot confiscate anything,
legally.  Only entities that are given powers by the State or those given
powers by the Government have such recourse.  And you as a citizen cannot,
just by giving them permission, chuck your rights out of the window.  The
Bill of Rights applies to ALL people, and to all people given color of
authority. So Lyon's, IMO, is clearly in breach of this.  As for
searches..I still think that they are in the wrong.  They cannot search
ANYTHING without prior consent, reasonable suspicion, and without the
pwoers of the state (none of which they have, expcept for those people
willing to put up with such BS).  In other words if the state cannot
search, and the fed cannot search, then private citizenry, certainly cannot
search.  I take the evidence of most places dis-allowing backpacks, because
they KNOW that the LAW says they cannot search them.  Esp here in
California that has very explicit, and very powerful privacy laws.

The idea that FEDREAL laws do not apply has already been rebutted.  This is
why individual citizens, who deprive others of their rights, can be tried
for "due process". "violation of civil rights", etc.  IMO, Lyon's is
guilty, and they know it.  That's why when it comes to it, if you back your
shit up, they will back down.  Or just don't submit to their searches,
cause a stink in the line, until these super-cops back the hell off!  They
will, beleive me, they will.


Interesting thoughts you presented...maybe we oughta cite some cases?
John

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep 16 21:46:10 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06035; Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:46:10 PDT
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com (uucp4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06028; Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:46:06 PDT
Received: from dms.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA28552; Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:02:10 PDT
Received: from curly.agames.com by agames.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA00498; Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:00:29 PDT
Received: from epikt.agc.com by curly.agames.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA00221; Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:00:33 PDT
Date: Thu, 16 Sep 93 21:00:33 PDT
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Message-Id: <9309170400.AA00221@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Why we never end up working less
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Since less meaningful work is required due to automation, many people no
longer have their original jobs.  Since they don't want to accept a lower
position in the capitalist economy (or no position at all >^) they know
they must get another job to support themselves within the system.  Supply
goes way up while demand decreases: therefore market price drops sharply.
Businesses know this, and realize that it is in their short-term interest
NOT to let people work less hours because they will then require less people
and can take advantage of the surplus of workers.

To break this system we must either place artificial controls on it (I think
a 20 hour work week is plenty: aobut 5 hours/person is sufficient for
subsistence food and shelter given current technology) or remove ourselves
from it by joining the underground economy or dropping out altogether, or
as much as is possible within the USA.  Small and mostly self-sufficient
communities exist all over, and you don't have to work that hard to sustain
once you have set up if you have planned intelligently.  Trouble is that
we are trained to be good consumpto-units, not self-sufficient individuals.

I would personally enjoy starting on this path via putting together
a musically oriented housing co-op in San Jose: for instance, a small apartment
building with communal studio, lounge, and possibly even kitchen space.
It would reduce much of the wasteful duplication of household appliances
and musical instruments, enabling all of us to do more than we could if we
bought it all ourselves, and be a fun place to hang out.  I would imagine a
mix of long-term residents, who would co-operatively own, and renters, who
would be shorter-term, would work well, since not everyone can commit to 
even short years of mortgage payments.  With this approach we are not making
money for a landlord, and mortgage interest is tax-deductible if we did it
right, so it would be cheaper than traditional housing of comparable
luxury.  Santa Clara Cohousing is a good source of information if some people
want to start something like this.

The best way to bring about change is to change.  Anyone interested?

// g

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Homelessness & USA 2001
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

C. Beaumont declares:

>  I have a feeling,that whether NAFTA passes or not,we are heading into a
>society where machines using artificial intelligence,technologies like
>expert systems,voice recognition,robotics and easy telecommuting are going
>to free a lot of people from the necessity of doing work.(If anyone
>disagrees with me,I'd like to see their arguments.. this is a very
>interesting subject for me.) 

The only question I want to ask is WHO will have these "wonderful" (my
phrasing), technologies.  Right now we have a very large underclass, that
has never touched a computer.  What you speak of will drive them further
into the abyss.  Until technology is in everyones hands, and until everyone
has the opprtunity to use it, then we continue the cycle of have/have-nots.
 And technology, for all it's benefits, makes that situation even more
cruel than it is now.

> Ultimately I think the government will adopt the only sane policy.

Govt. is concerned with ONE thing only.  More Govt.  The policies they
adopt are to perpetuate themselves.  Depending upon this single party
system we have here in the US to solve ANY problems, is like pissing in the
wind; No matter which direction you turn, it'll always end up in your face.

>With 5% of the worlds population here in the United States using 40% of
>the worlds resources reducing consumption is the only way to go. Otherwise
>the world is heading towards a living hell, and no amount of walls or guns
>will protect the idle rich from it's repercussions.

True on the first statement, but when you look at the complete brainwashing
this country has done on it's citizens, Icannot see things turning around
drastically anytime soon.  People love the USA's Bread & Circuses (A TV in
every home and American Gladiators on each channel, and food for all), and
are unwilling at this stage to give them up.  Until we form more clannish
communities based upon respect & trust, the opportunities to change this
corrupt system is nil.  And until such opportunities for change present
themselves, there are plenty of guns, and plenty of money to keep the
natives in line.

>America is the most productive economy in the world.

Yes indeed. Also one of the most exploitative. Also one of the worlds MOST
unbalanced.  1% of the people who runthe show here control 80% of the
wealth.  All on the backs of workers, who have seen more mergers, buyouts,
and conglomerations form at the cost of their once "prodcutive" jobs.  All
to keep this economy going.  Sickness, my man, sickness.

>In a future where few people
>have to work.. with the present paradigm..this will mean that most people
>will be considered worthless?

The future is NOW.  People are considered worthless in this society.  We
throw away human beings here like we flush the toilet.  We talk a good game
about change, but when it really comes down to it, all most care about is
themselves. The fact that there are still soo many incumbents in office is
proof positive.  The fact that there are soo many illetrates is another
proof.  Homelessness seals my case. The fact that things can be changed
now, by people getting involved and participating to change this system
(via the vote), and by only a 30% turnout just shows me we have a long way
to go.  Hell, if people won't do it when it's easy, what makes you think
that when things require some real effort that they won't revert to the
easiest route;Mob Rule! (BTW I don't want any of these lazy folx making any
decisions when the time comes!). Bladerunner, here we come.

All I can say is that your vision of the future is bright, yet my forecast
sees cloudiness with perpetual rain for some time to come.  Until then,
I'll do what I can to change NOW, but prepare for LATER.  That is the only
logical recourse, IMO.

Peace,
John

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 17 08:43:16 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09123; Fri, 17 Sep 93 08:43:16 PDT
Received: from cdp.igc.org by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09116; Fri, 17 Sep 93 08:43:12 PDT
Received: by igc.apc.org (4.1/Revision: 1.106 )
	id AA12974; Fri, 17 Sep 93 08:41:29 PDT
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA06035; Fri, 17 Sep 93 08:20:31 PDT
Date: Fri, 17 Sep 93 08:20:31 PDT
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <9309171520.AA06035@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: WARNING:Non-rave, Party's getting rough! 
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Folks if you want PGP better get it while you can!
Looks like it is about to go the way of the AK-47!

The important thing here is that ViaCrypt is producing a legal
fully licensed PGP.  The feds don't want you to have this program
(or any other strong crypto for that matter) find out why...





--------------------------------------------------------------

On Tuesday, 14 September 93, Leonard Mikus, president of ViaCrypt,
also known as LEMCOM Systems, in Phoenix, Arizona, was served a
Subpoena to Testify Before Grand Jury, to produce documents.  The
subpoena was issued by the US District Court of Northern California,
by Assistant US Attorney William P. Keane in San Jose, as part of an
investigation from the San Jose office of US Customs, conducted by
Special Agent Robin Sterzer.  The US Attorney above Keane is Michael
J. Yamaguchi.

ViaCrypt is the company that will be selling a fully licensed
commercial version of PGP, starting in November.  ViaCrypt has a
license from PKP to sell products that embody the patents held by
PKP.  That includes PGP, using the RSA algorithm.

The subpoena, dated 9 September, orders the production of "Any and
all correspondence, contracts, payments, and records, including those
stored as computer data, involving international distribution related
to ViaCrypt, PGP, Philip Zimmermann, and anyone or any entity acting
on behalf of Philip Zimmermann for the time period June 1, 1991 to
the present."  The date specified for the production of documents is
22 September 93.

The written agreement between ViaCrypt and myself explicitly states
that US State Department cryptographic export controls will be
adhered to.

The implications of this turn of events are that this US Customs
investigation has escalated to the level of a Federal Grand Jury and
a US Attorney.  US Customs says that this change was precipitated by
a ruling recently handed down from the State Department that PGP is
not exportable.  Other subpoenas and/or search warrants are expected.

I am the principal target of the investigation.  I have advised EFF,
CPSR, and my other attorneys of the situation.  A legal defense fund
will be set up by my lead attorney (Phil Dubois, 303 444-3885) here
in Boulder. 

This case raises some serious public policy questions regarding First
Amendment rights to publish, rights to privacy as affected by
widespread availability of cryptographic technology, the equivalance
of electronic publication with paper publication, the availablity of
lawful domestic cryptographic technology in the face of export
controls, and certain other Constitutional rights.  This may turn into
the test case for these issues.


-Philip Zimmermann
 prz@acm.org
 303 541-0140
 



-- 


----- End Included Message -----

>How, and why is it that a great section of the civilian population=
 in the US
>is armed?
>
>Miles
Probably here it's because people are scared.Theres a growing gap=
 between rich and poor..a very quickly growing one.. Rich people=
 arm themselves because,ostentiably they want to protect themselves,but=
 also because they
feel,quite tangibly,the growing hatred of the have-nots.Poor people=
 arm themselves for protection,primarily because urban America is=
 becoming a very dangerous place indeed.In my neighborhood,for=
 example..there have been four street killings (by "in my neighborhood",I=
 really mean _on my block,_ Miles.)
One person was killed on July 31 literally eight feet from my front=
 door.
His crime,trying to sell crack on the wrong corner,probably.This=
 certainly
is effecting me...I'm an early riser, and I was just in the coffeeshop=
 downstairs drinking my morning cup..The waitress was playing an=
 old record..
"Harvest" by Neil Young..and a song came on that I havn't heard in=
 years..
"Are You Ready for the Country"..The chorus goes.."Are you ready=
 for the country,because its time to go..." I burst into tears..
With the recent thread in the newsmedia about studies indicating=
 that a huge number of Americans are functionally illiterate,you=
 really wonder how much hope
there is to turn this violent trend around in the future..As John=
 Lee stated,
a lot of people talk a big talk but really couldnt give a flying=
 fuck about anyone other than themselves,if helping other people=
 means they might have to
pay an extra 2 or 3 percent in taxes.In LA something like 30 _public_
communities have applied to wall themselves in,like feudal cities.They=
 think that they can wall it out..but no wall is high enough to keep=
 out the reality of a nation disintegrating from within.Sorry that=
 this thread isn't rave related..but isnt the whole original concept=
 of the rave thing trying to build extended global community.It makes=
 no sense to dance when there is really nothing to dance about.Maybye=
 another part of the rave thing lies in encouraging CONTENT.I move
to change the charter of this group to rave-with an emphasis on encouraging=
 enlightening quantum leaps in social change.We have the tools,if=
 anyone does,but we have to work like wild speed demons.. The social=
 fabric is unraveling right before our very eyes.

national gaurd won't be able to touch your house. Real practical. In the
mean time, shoot at strange looking people that pop up on your doorstep in
the middle of the afternoon. Hell you don't know them, and if they are
foreign, they're probably trying to break in anyway. And don't listen to
those bleeding heart types about gun control. Be Bad Guys will have them,
even if they are illegal.

outdated and stupid as the rest of the shit that was in it and updated? It
isnn't carved in stone. Look at countries like Germany, where it is next to
impossible to get a gun. Surprise! not much violence using guns. Funny how
that works.

--> When will people realize that even if it is in the constitution,
--> it is as outdated and stupid as the rest of the shit that was in
--> it and updated? It isnn't carved in stone. Look at
Reading stuff like this really scares me.  The constitution is what
this country was founded on, and if one of the Bill of Rights
ammendments is deemed "outdated and stupid" what's to stop the
government from deeming all of the outdated and stupid?  You can
already see how your right to protect you from illegal search and
seizure has pretty much gone away.  What about freedom of speech,
freedom of religion?  It sure would be convenient for the government
to get rid of those too, wouldn't it.  And it might even make the
country a safer place to live if we never heard any opposing views or
just threw suspected persons in jail without due process.  But is a
violation of our liberties!  Open your eyes!  Our government was
founded with the purpose to protect the liberties of the people!
That's why you're supposed to be innocent until proved guilty in the
US. We have to try to make today's government follow those principles,
and when we encourage them to take any of our freedoms away we are
going down the wrong path.

I don't want to turn this into a flame war, but I assume that you agree
that changes to the constitution over time makes sense- you know, things
like oh, say, women's right to vote. How about that bit about people with
non-white skin being equal citizens? Things like that. The perspective from
which the constitution, that of propertied white men, is not representative
of the United States (representative of who has the power, granted, but...
that's my point). Until enough people realizze thier highschool history
books are crocks, and that people that would tofay be branded as mindless
assholes and racists wrote the 'supreme law of the land' for us, things
will continue to be Just Plain Lousy. You wan treferences to a well written
constitution? Look at Germany's. (I keep goin gback to there as an example
because it is the only place that I 1) am familiar enough with to feel
qualified to comment, and 2) think has a better way of handling things.)

 To bring this back to where it started, I am sorry- the right to posess a
gun is one right I am more than happy to see go out the window- conflicts a
little too much _every day_ with that other right- that to live.

From acohn@synopsys.com Fri Sep 17 09:08:51 1993
From: Ari Cohn <acohn@synopsys.com>
To: mtview@synopsys.com
Subject: BOGUS SJPD Gang Crime Alert

I have just spoken with a representative from the San Jose Police
Dept. Gang Crimes Unit.  They are saying that the e-mail message
forwarded to us yesterday about a lethal gang initiation rite--killing
motorists who flash their headlights at them--is a complete lie.

The SJPD's guess is that some bored or malicious e-mail network
correspondent started the message spontaneously.

Please do not forward the original message about a SJPD Gang Crime
Alert to anyone else.  If you already have, please forward this
message as well.

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com

I perused the postings and checked on a faq of uncertain vintage
and didn't notice this one.  I am a little concerned that I didn't
see it in the postings since it has been around in Chicago for about
a week.  Oh well.

By the way, I will violate all standards of net courtesy and NOT
indicate the following quotes by putting them beside  greater than
signs.  I'm not sure how this program works with posting but I 
think it hates quotes.

Suffice it to say, nothing after my name is mine.  The postings can be
found on chi.general if you want to contact the posters.  The Chicago
Police non emergency number is 312-744-4000 (you'll get forwarded).
By the way, I called to make sure they would confirm this and they
did.  The fellow I spoke with said he had heard of it, that it was
"a farce" and he first heard the story over the weekend.


Richard

beckwith@ils.nwu.edu

Subject: flashing headlights / "Lights out" initiation?



This was forwarded to me by a friend who works for the First National
Bank of Chicago, who says the originators of the message seemed serious.

This story sounds a bit like an urban legend -- but as someone who
regularly flashes my headlights to let other drivers know theirs are
off, I'm a bit jumpy.  Can anyone comment?


-----begin forwarded message-----

  Subject: Warning From FNBC Security Division

  Here's an electronic copy of a memo from the FNBC Security Division:

  Beware of "Lights-Out" Gang Initiation!!

  There is a new gang initiation in the Chicagoland area known as
  "lights out."  The crime is initiated by gang members driving around
  with their car lights off.

  When motorists flash their car lights to advise another car that
  their lights are out, gang members take the signal literally as
  "lights out", after which they follow you to your destination and
  kill you!

  To date, two families have already fallen victim to this senseless
  crime.  Therefore, please be aware and inform your friends and family
  not to flash their car lights at anyone!

-----end forwarded message-----



***************************************************


I came across a nearly identical warning today, circulating at UIC Hospital
in the form of a many-times-photocopied flier.  My wife saw a copy of a
similar warning that was faxed to various people at the U of C.
I do not recall any references to 'FNBC Security,' on the flier, however.

I am inclined to believe that this is merely a prank, but I wouldn't go
around flashing my lights at people anyway...
I certainly haven't heard any 'official' comments from CPD or anyone else
on this subject, so, it's probably best just to ignore cars that don't have
their lights on at night.  There are enough wackos in this city anyway.


***************************************************


My wife says that the same sort of fax memo was posted at her Chicago
Public Schools office.  Sounds like an urban myth.  Anyone interested in
goin' out on a midnight drive to check it out?


***************************************************

The Chicago police have said that there were no such incidents.

***************************************************


Yes, the man who started this whole thing now steps forward...

THe co-worker who sent the warning to me said it was a serious memo
(although I didn't ask where/how she got it).  My hypothesis is that
someone in bank security heard the story, and wrote a memo without
checking the facts.

BTW, "FNBC" stands for First National Bank of Chicago.



Article: 85171 of alt.folklore.urban
Newsgroups: alt.folklore.urban

Beckwith  <beckwith@aristotle.ils.nwu.edu> wrote:
>-----begin forwarded message-----
>
>  There is a new gang initiation in the Chicagoland area known as
>  "lights out."  The crime is initiated by gang members driving around
>  with their car lights off.
>
>  When motorists flash their car lights to advise another car that
>  their lights are out, gang members take the signal literally as
>  "lights out", after which they follow you to your destination and
>  kill you!
>
>  To date, two families have already fallen victim to this senseless
>  crime.  Therefore, please be aware and inform your friends and family
>  not to flash their car lights at anyone!
>
>-----end forwarded message-----

Well, this was reported on Channel 5 (NBC) in Chicago tonight.  
I was initially worried becasue of some semi-lurid previews
in the lead-up to the segment, e.g. "Are gangs engagingly in
a deadly game of tag?" or some such.

Pleasantly surprised was I, however, to see them denounce it
as "URBAN MYTH" (their caps) near the beginning of the story,
followed by denails of its existence from the CPD, as well
as a brief summary of the urban legend concept illustrated
with a picture of _The Choking Doberman_ and mention of
Jan Harold Brunvand.


I don't know what other stations reported, of course; Ch.2 is the
worst offender in the tab tv department these days, thought
Fox 32 is running a close second (they stole 2's producer).

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9309171906.AA22614@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Your Sister's House, Yum!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


OOOOOoooo aaaah I'm in heaven :)

Last night's YSH was one of the best ever:

   Small but *very happy very dancing* crowd.

   Beautiful beautiful color slides projected - some of the best I've
   ever seen at a rave. Made for a gorgeous effect projected across
   the crowd.

   The wonderful wonderful TAZ space.

   Liz n Laura n all the sisters.

   and... Tamara!

Darcy is one of my favorite DJs in the word. She'll be spinning, and
look up at you with this impish smile that means "Oh, I'm not nearly
done with you yet :)." And she can throw the funnest acid trance
groove and plug into the back of my head and make me dance until
things start to break.

So I try and make a point of it to catch her sets. And coming off the
exhilarating end of one of her sets when Tamara started, I really
didn't know what to expect.

Ha ha ha! Little did I know!

Tamara just about killed me. I swear I danced my ass off for her
entire set nonstop. Two hours. My body thought I was going to die. My
brain was in pure heaven. She played "The Naked and the Dead"!! I
can't believe she played that song. I have been wanting to hear it at
a rave for so long... Oh my. Oh my. Very well done. Few DJs have ever
managed to keep me cranked for so long without a break. I love it :).
Can I marry your record collection?

After Tamara, Rebecca played her usually bizzare (at least to me) set,
but by then I was too thrashed. Chill out time, and enjoy the company
and watch the Rebecca show :) (and a show it is).

--BUT WAIT

Stay tuned for next week...

Susan's really excited about her set, which is going to consist of a
lot of new trance and tribal stuff out just this week. Deep tribal
drums. [Picture Susan scrunching up her face and saying with great
emphasis] "Primal, _PRIMAL_ drums."

Oooo la la. I am salivating already...

Sean

"FRIDAY NIGHT????!?!? Capn!!! It'll take at least a full night's sleep!"
"We haven't got a full night's sleep. I need those Phasors tonight."
(sighs) "Aye, capn, I kin jury-rig it..."
"...but you don't know how long she'll hold. I know. Thanks, Scotty."

Subject: not going to WOMAD Sunday?  Why not check out South Bay?
Date: Fri, 17 Sep 93 12:39:19 -0700
From: vivianm@src.dec.com
X-Mts: smtp
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The 2nd Annual SOFA Street Fair is going on in downtown San Jose 
on Sunday for those of you who don't already know. It starts at 12 
noon and goes till 9pm.  I didn't go last year but have seen the lineup this year and it looks really good.  
Here is the low down:
The Dance Stage
**          **

Catastrophic Funk
The Deborah Magee Dancers
Clams Cabaret (a mock casino)
Jozelle Cox
Hot Mixers including: Jazzy Jim, Rex Santa Elena, BB Hayes, and Chris 
Campos
Various DJ's including: Richard G., King Raffi, Jesse, Fred, Brian 
Raffi, Billy Berserk, Frankie, Rick Preston, Harry Who, And Julius"Vitamin 
J" Papp
**          **

On the Rock Stage
**          **

Inka Inka
Phoenix
Riverthings
Touch
Fungo Mungo
Jim Brusseau 
Groove Shop
Shovelhead

On the Arts Stage
**          **

Capoeira San Jose
The Ajax Poets
Farouche and the Desert Delights
The F/X Players (performing a bit from "Hair")
Los Lupenos de San Jose'
Made Sukerti Berg
ComedySportz
Dancers of the Crecent Moon
The Flamenco Society
Velvet Darkness

The clubs in the area of First St. will be open all day serving alcohol. 
I believe for this event is is legal to drink in the street outside the 
clubs. There is even a free screening of the movie "King of the Hill" at 
Camera One. After it is all over, there is an after party at FX that night.  
It should be really fun and it's free.  


Check it out, what have you got to lose..  :-)




vivianm

  was looking for M2000.  Store attendant said they're no longer carrying
  it, due to 'obscene' material in one of the issues.  When prompted for
  details, said attendant mentioned something about "naked people doing
  things you don't want to see"..

MEANWHILE, "Mortal Kombat" was running on the Sega boxes right behind the
  attendant, and characters on the screen were ripping each other's heads
  off and whipping the victim's extracted spinal cord around like taffy.
  The screen was awash in blood. 

What a peculiar sense of 'obscenity' the Dalton Book chain has! Tell me,
  sfravers, which sorts of people would YOU rather have over for dinner,
  the knife-weilding chiropractors from HELL out of Mortal Kombat, or the
  Mondo2000 buff photo-crue???

Uh, John, maybe you don't hang in Berkeley much or know much about it but
Berkeley could be considered a homeless capitol or a homeless mecca.  I don't
know this as fact but I bet we have more homeless per capita than SF or maybe
any city.  But, our overburdened system will be more so if your mayor keeps
rudely forcing more homeless in our direction.  Anyway, the tone of your 
mail seems to indicate "now it's berkeley's turn, let's see what they do"
and I just wanted you to know we've been on the ride at least as long as SF,
if not longer.  No hard feelings or anything, I just wanted it to be known
if it wasn't already.

-Mark
