Sean Casey sez:
> 
> Jamie 'Bobo' Lawrence writes:
>  > When will people realize that even if it is in the constitution, it is as
>  > outdated and stupid as the rest of the shit that was in it and updated? It
>  > isnn't carved in stone. Look at countries like Germany, where it is next to
>  > impossible to get a gun. Surprise! not much violence using guns. Funny how
>  > that works.
> 
> While you're looking at Germany, look in your history books about
> oppressive governments.
> 

Germany has some very interesting solutions to some problems.  I guess
you could say they handle things in a typically german manner.  When I
was there, I commented to a native about the lack of homeless people.
(This was in Bad Kreutznach, a town to the west of Frankfurt and just
south of Bingen).  He seemed to not understand what I said (not
unusual, my German is pretty poor :-) but what he didn't understand
was how we had a homeless problem overall.  Apparently, in BK its
illegal to be homeless (something like vagrancy here) and the police
will pick up people and give them jobs picking up litter and such
until they can afford to move on.  (This isn't as bad as it sounds,
spending nights outside there esp. in winter would definantly prove
lethal pretty quickly).  I didn't find out where the people live, but
it was apparent that no one stayed in such a program long.

In any case, there were no homeless, and the city was very clean, (except
for the American army base I was at, pretty damn disgraceful if you
ask me).  

I have no idea if large German cities handle things this way, and I
neither approve nor disapprove of this policy, but it lends some
insight into the different roles that americans and europeans feel
their government should play.

-H-

sfraves is not a gun control mailing list.

I know a lot of people who rave and shoot/own guns.
I know a lot of people who rave and don't.
We're not psychopathic killers, we don't go around
playing vigilante or anything stupid like that.
Guns used in crime and guns owned by normal people
are two totally seperate issues, which have very
little to do with each other.  And no involvement
in raves whatsoever, presuming everyone's being 
cool at the Raves 8-)

my first ever visit to YSH was last night.  scary neighborhood, but
fortunately parking close to the spot was a cinch.  i think $5 is
kinda steep to hang out in someone's loft, but that's why oracle pays
me the big bucks.  anyway, the scene was very cool, and made me wish i
could get out more on weeknights.  since i only got 4 hrs of sleep and
am not too terribly tired right now maybe i'll try it more often...

anyway, i heard a little of darcy's set which was interesting but not
really my cup of tea.  then, tamara's debut was great.  give her a big
hand people - when i only had her level of experience, i was horrible.

Jon Drukman                                         jdrukman%dlsun87@oracle.com

From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: gang violence
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



gwh@lurnix.com wrote:

>sfraves is not a gun control mailing list.

No, it isn't, but safety issues with respect to raves have often 
been discussed here. Lest we forget, Gabe was killed at a rave 
in Santa Cruz by random gun fire.

>I know a lot of people who rave and shoot/own guns.
>I know a lot of people who rave and don't.
>We're not psychopathic killers, we don't go around
>playing vigilante or anything stupid like that.

I also know many people who have guns, and most of these people are 
very responsible gun-owners. However, given the large and ever-increasing
amount of violent crime where guns and gunfire are involved, I am
committed to finding some middle-ground on the right to bear arms.

As an aside- most killers aren't psychopaths. In this day and
age I might be hard pressed to even consider them as sociopaths;
killing is becoming at the least tolerable if not acceptable
in our society. Perhaps it's always been this way though.

Here are some proposals:

1.For those who enjoy the firing range:

You can buy a gun at the firing range, where you can also store it
in your own rack. The price of storage would be included in the price 
of the gun. To use it you would "check it out" by signing for it,
listing time of use, etc... and then check it back into storage when
you're finished.

The firing range places would have to acquire a special permit 
to allow them to sell and hold guns. No guns could be carried 
onto the property and no guns could leave the property (except 
those acquired by the range to sell, of course).

2. For those who enjoy hunting:

I grew up in Texas, where hunting is both glorified and ritualized.
I understand that to some banning hunting would be comparable to 
outlawing football (oh no!). That said:

The arrangement would be similar to the firing range, except at 
a hunting lodge. Again you would have to store the weapon at the
lodge. You would sign it out for X number of hours or days, indicating
your destination ,etc.... If you were late in returning 
the gun, you would have to pay a whopping fine
(despite the flat tire you got on the way home :) both to the lodge
and to the govt. Only appropriate hunting guns would be allowed.

3. For those who insist on having guns at home:

You must acquire the same permit as those that the hunting lodges and 
firing ranges have to be able to have guns on your property.
If you don't own your own property, you must first get the landlord's
permission and signature to apply for the permit.
Like the firing range, the firearm cannot leave your house, nor 
can weapons other than the one you own be stored on your property,
or brought onto your property.

4. Transporting guns:

If you move and you want to bring your gun with you:

from the firing range or lodge- apply to a new facility in your new
vicinage. Have the lodge/range ship the gun to the new lodge/range.

Transporting guns would also require an expensive permit.

from your home- apply for a permit to personally transport your gun-
giving day(s), time(s), where you're coming from and moving to.

4. Make carrying a gun (also known as packin') without proper permits
   a felony.

That way people can have guns, they just can't have them in public-
sort of like alcohol regulations, but a little bit stricter.

I know there are many holes in my ideas- feel free to point them out!

Sorry if I wasted bandwidth-

Jocelyn

"Then she melted down all the weapons and made friendship rings
for the world to wear." - narrator in Hurray for Betty Boop!

I (susan raisty) said this about the US constitution:
--> >founded with the purpose to protect the liberties of the people!
--> >That's why you're supposed to be innocent until proved guilty in
--> the >US. We have to try to make today's government follow those
--> principles, >and when we encourage them to take any of our
--> freedoms away we are >going down the wrong path.


Then (Jamie 'Bobo' Lawrence) jamiel said this:
--> I don't want to turn this into a flame war, but I assume that you
--> agree that changes to the constitution over time makes sense- you
--> know, things like oh, say, women's right to vote. How about that
--> bit about people with non-white skin being equal citizens? Things
--> like that. 

--> jamiel@sybase.com "Static- It's all just static"- Bryna Bank


There is a fundamental difference between ammending the constitution
to allow women and minorities vote and removing an ammendment from the
bill of rights - the right to bear arms in this case.  One grants MORE
liberties to the citizens and the other TAKES them away.

Jocelyn:
>No, it isn't, but safety issues with respect to raves have often 
>been discussed here. Lest we forget, Gabe was killed at a rave 
>in Santa Cruz by random gun fire.

No, Gabe was killed at a rave in an intentional shooting due to
gang-related violence (they didn't like the party).  They'd started
several fights earlier, if I remember correctly, were ejected after
trying to knife a security guard (but not arrested) and came back 
and shot someone.  IMHO this was a security failure, as these people
should have been arrested and the police should have been asked to
post a guard nearby if they couldn't be arrested.  There was an
obvious threat which was unfortunately not dealt with and Gabe
died.

>I also know many people who have guns, and most of these people are 
>very responsible gun-owners. However, given the large and ever-increasing
>amount of violent crime where guns and gunfire are involved, I am
>committed to finding some middle-ground on the right to bear arms.

>As an aside- most killers aren't psychopaths. In this day and
>age I might be hard pressed to even consider them as sociopaths;
>killing is becoming at the least tolerable if not acceptable
>in our society. Perhaps it's always been this way though.

Killing is in no way acceptable in this society.  The society of
carreer criminals and gang members does not hold the same views
as my society does, though, and they're going around killing.

Don't blame me for them.  I am not them.  You can't take away their
guns, they already get them on the black market.  You can only
convince them to live in peace, deter young people from that
society, and if all else fails put them in jail.

-george

Received: by NeXT.Mailer (1.87.1)
Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Our Community
Cc: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, mw-raves@engin.umich.edu
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



Where are our intentions going?  what are we evolving into and why; and who as 

members of these list asserting ourselves as.  


What happens to families as time moves on and as the framilarity of each other
and the common ground between the becomes defunct?  How is it that they stay
togther and not disentigrate with the passage of time.

The topic of rave, techno, house, etc....are inherantly limited - 

and by limiting ourselves to these topics we are limiting the true potenitonal
of our community.

We are a community - by joining these lists your are a part of what goes on 

between us - we all have our peeves and hangups - likes and dislikes of the
members of the lists but we have joined in a common ground.

As a community we have the ability to learn, experince, and devlop ourselves as
human beings.  As a community we should not limit ourselves to discussions of
one topic - when their is literally a whole world of information and stuff
out there that thouches each and every one of our lives - and the needs to
be disscussed, explored, expanded upon, learn.

Rave is not only the party. For those of you who belive that rave is only for
8 hours a week on saturday night, you are missing the most beautiful point 

of rave.  Rave is a philosophy, it takes the feeling of unity we experince
in a vibe filled room - and shows us what the world could become - it 

becomes a part of our daily lives and (at least for me) has changed EVERY
aspect of how I live, act, and treat others.

It is nessecary to examine the everyday world within the context of the 

philosophy that we are forming - without that - rave dies - it is no longer
something special - it is something to do, much like doing laundry.

We here are the cutting edge - we have the potentioal to develop a new style
of living - a new relationship with the world that can, and if done
will utlimatley lead to the changing of social structure within the world.

To achive these ends we mustn't limit ourselves - we mustn't stifle
the potentoal we have - but rather examine and devlop
our methods of thinking to better them, and better the world.  Examine,
and then act - working towards a vibe filled world cannot hurt - even if
this community only touches one living soul into betterment then we have 

achived.


this is us, this is now - here is the world - see it change - devlop + 

envelop it into you belive is correct.

--Kurt

P.S. Did you ever think you would see Rabin and Arrifat shake hands?  I wept
when I saw that - a beautiful moment - we have the ability to make more of
these moments happen; we just have to try and move slowly - developing our
philosophy and allowing it to touch those who surround us.

at midnight, until we're done.  Audio is by our very own Sound Vision, 
and some of your favorite net.djs will be mixing up the tunes.

Tamara, hot off an awesome SF debut at YSH

freshest talent in the Bay Area! Experience sound surrounding you

Hi,

	Yesterday night, just before going to YSH, I was reading a computer
	magazine and I found this article presenting another fractal program.

	I started reading and this is what I found:

		BACK TO THE FUTURE

		It is a little known fact that "techno" is actually
		"disco" converted to hexadecimal and spelled backwards.
		Think about it. It makes sense when one realizes that
		the ravers of today's MTV culture are yesterday's
		LSD-mutated babies. Platform shoes, bell-bottoms, and the 
		center part: our twentysomethings are wreaking a revenge
		that could only be conceived in the 70's.

		FracTunes, "The 21st century Light Organ", is the software
		embodiment of the current cultural drift back to the
		spangled decade. But with a 90's twist: in the 70's neither
		personal computers nor fractal geometry yet mattered.
		Leave it to rEvolutionary Software to make up for history's
		minor deprivations by creating "a light organ for the
		twentyfirst century".

						-- Anonymous --


	So, anybody want to write the algorithm to convert
	"disco" to "techno" and "LSD" to "MTV" ?


	Anyway, does any of you know anything more about this program ?
	It seems pretty cool. The article says that it use sound files
	(or MIDI files) as a base to "animate" a fractal or other 
	images. I will try to get more info about it and I'll let you know.



	YSH: what else I can say... I keep going and I keep enjoing it.
	I really liked the final part of DRC and the full set of Tamara.
	I couldn't rest for more than a few minutes. Yesterday Rebecca was
	to housy for me ( "techno" can be the transformation of "disco" but
	I still DON'T like "disco" :-)


So, hoping to see you around this weekend...

Ciao,
	Raffaele

Anyone who wants to explore these issue in a group may e interested in
a 'class' that a friend of mine is offering:

-=> Creating A Life That Makes More Sense <=-

five Mondays 7pm-9:15pm, October 4 - November 1
It will meet in a home just east of Ashby BART

Some stuff paraphrased from the flyer:
*Not* about any particular political or spiritual ideology.
Participants will be using a variety of learning techniques
(talking circles, journal-writing, brief lectures, exercises,
and, of course, your own life :-)

In the class everyone will work on:
* Developing an outer life rich with intimacy, good people, community and
  commitment--that balances with an deep inner life of connection to self,
  nature, and spirit.
* Creating an alive, satisfying and non-overwhelming
  information/media environment
* Creating paid work and paying the bills (including having bills you
  want to pay :-)
* Changing the world.

The teacher is Karen Mercer. She's worked on personal and social change
for 25 years, here and around the world. She also has a masters in
Social Work, has written published articles, and has been involved
in a variety of therapeutic models. She has lived communally most of her
life and been involved in other community-building efforts. Nature is
a major source of personal energy and clarity in her life.
[She's also a really neat, *very* open person --John's addition]

--------============>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>><<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<============--------

The flyer also has unfortunately-irreproducible word balloon edited
imags of Calvin Hobbes and Winnie the Pooh. Anyway, the number to call
if intersted is 510-658-1307. I know that she's hoping to finish admitting
people Real Soon Now so i would call this wekend if you're interested.

I just typed this in a hurry, so all transcription errors are my fault,
mea culpa, mea culpa.

Peace, love, etc.,
-Johnnie

well....i did some researchin' yesterday at city hall with the help of
halinans office...(and did some reading of the police code)

first of all i belive the first action to take would be to call the other
two memebers of the committee (Health Public Safety & Environment) and
ttell (or fax them) that ... 

"I support Terence Hallinan's amendment to allow 18 year olds to dance
after 2 a.m..


Supervisor Susan Leal 415 554 6644
Supervisor Kevin Shelley 415 544 4005

this is IMPORTANT!  we must be able to moblilize lots o people

it must first be passed through this committee...sooo that means we
need people to show up at the committee meeting...i will post about
this....(we also need people to bring posters) the tentative date for
this is sept 28 at 10 am either in chambers or room 228.

i was wondering if we could bring the sfr banner???? brian???

also if you do go to the meeting it is important to sign in...also i
believe that people (ie citizens) can speak but i dont' know how this
works...but i will find out...maybe even some 18-21 articulate person
could speak on behalf of there peers????

now...here is the the text that is trying to be amended...

Amending artical 15.2 of the San Francisco police code by amending
section 1070.16 thereof to permit persons over 18 to enter, be, or
remain in premises that are operated as cabarets.

     Be it ordained by the People of the City and County of San Francisco:

     Section 1.  Artical 15.2 of the San Francisco Police Code is hereby
amended by amending Section 1070.16 thereof to read as follows:

     Sec. 1070.16  MINORS.  Exept as provided in this section no persons
under 21 years of age shall enter, be, or remain in or on any premises
operated as a cabaret.  A licensee shall notlpermit such a person to enter,
be, or remain in or on any such premises except on Friday and Saturday
nights there shall be a one-half hour grace period, until 2:30 a.m., for
the departure from cabarets of persons 18 to 21 years of age.

now this is the amendment that is being tagged on to the end of this...

Notwithstanding the other provisions of this Section, persons between the
ages of 18 and 21 may enter, be, or remain in or on premises operated as a
cabaret. 

____________________________________________________________________________

does anyone want to write any of the newspapers, help circulate petitions,
or etc....(basically i am asking for help)

I just finished editing an episode for "Cyberia."  I'm still
putting together the staff, so there won't be the usual hostess
and virtual worlds.   It's a clip show featuring the best
animations that appeared in the 90-91 season.  Here's the lineup
for the September U Network feed.  


C O M P U T E R   A N I M A T I O N S


"Dirty Power" from Robert Lurye at Ohio State
    
     One of the most sensual computer animation ever done.

"More Bells and Whistles" from Wayne Lytle at Cornell

     MIDI-driven computer graphic objects perform in a rock band. 
     Lytle created some very inventive software for this  one.

"Venus and Milo" from Donna Cox at University of Illinois

     A janitor get careless in an art gallery

"Broken Heart" from Joan Staveley at Ohio State

     Award winning piece.  One of the best fine arts computer    
     animation.

"The frog who wanted to be as big as a cow" by Isabelle Bourdin
at Sheridan College

     Amphibian imagination.

"Columbus on the Edge" at William Patterson College

	Student group work tells the real Christopher Columbus     
     story.

"Fuzzy Lust" by Barbara McAleese at Rutgers - Camden

     Sometimes watching TV can be exciting

"Bad Chair" by Ted MacLeod at Sheridan College

     Living room furniture terrorism.

"Camera Work" at William Patterson College

     Student group work about darkroom dreams.

"Cuisine Art" by Leo O'Young at Sheridan College

     The squash family spend a day at the art museum.


T E C H N O   M U S I C   V I D E O


"House of God" by DHS;  Directed by Ben Stokes

     Computer animation video from this "classic" techno song.  I
     am excited about the House of God.

"Holofonic Remix" by DHS; Directed by Ben Stokes

      Disaster film samples over a techno track.

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9309190327.AA00327@pilot.njin.net>
To: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: gang violence
In-Reply-To: <9309180047.AA15337@dre.hal.com>
References: <9309180047.AA15337@dre.hal.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The reason gun rights were written in the constitution were not for
the firing range or hunting. This is a misconception a lot of people
seem to have, and the justification a lot of them seem to have for
wanting to limit the ownership of so-called "assault" weapons.

The reason it is in the constitution is to provide a check on the
government's power. To acknowledge that the citizens may have to
revolt if the government were at some future time to get wildly out of
control.

Although we've been pretty lucky in that aspect, other countries have
not. I don't think it's a given in this day and age by any means.

As I told someone else on here, I am all for disarming the
populace--all of them--if one also disarms the government. Until then,
I believe there has got to be a balance, and that's why the right was
put on paper.

Sean

scene, but there are quite a few (including myself) people who resent
any kind of government attempt to restrict what a person may do by

sentencing for drug convictions is another manifestation of the same
problem.

because if I ever would want a gun (which I can't picture...at this
point) I would just obtain one illegally, if some silly law stood in
my way.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 20 10:05:45 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00696; Mon, 20 Sep 93 10:05:45 PDT
Received: from netcom2.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00689; Mon, 20 Sep 93 10:05:43 PDT
Received: by netcom2.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA25974; Mon, 20 Sep 93 10:06:09 -0700
Date: Mon, 20 Sep 93 10:06:09 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9309201706.AA25974@netcom2.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Universe party .... a private one I attended
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings...   I have some enlightening info from those producers of
the Universe Rave that was supposed to happen this last weekend.   I attended
a private party with those folks and I think I know ONE reason why they
backed out,  based on a conversation I had with Rob,  one of the main
producers.    One main reason is of course the financial problems,  but
more than that is the acceptance of the Calif scene to the much faster
"hard core" and "Acid trance" sets put on by the Brits..   

At the party,  I got a chance to dance to the extremly fast "Hard core"
sets typical of Universe type raves,  and WOW!!   It was totally energizing,
but in all reality,  I don't (Nor do the Universe folks) think that Calif
ravers are ready for this.   I find it hard to go back to the 120 BPM
Techno,  but now I have adopted new dance styles to acommodate both.

The Hard core sets are lot shorter than the sets layed down by our local
DJ's,  and are broken up by rapping over the music.   Then the pace changes
to a lower pace,  and gradually moves upwards again to a totally energetic
climax.   A TOTALLY DIFFERENT scene.

I met some othe ravers who managed to get into the party comment that it
was too fast for them,   and when the real fast stuff came on,  nobody
from that group was dancing.   But another reason was that the previous 
night a more public party was held at the same spot put on by the Universe
people (More public),  and people were burned out because of that party.

I'm sorry I missed Fluid Groove,  I sorta wanted to go to that (Or Wicked
or GK),   but at $20 a pop,  one can only afford to go to just ONE of
those parties.   Sorry for not attending...

One other thing,  at that party,  a few bozo's tried to break into the
party (which was private)  and really made an ass of themselves.   Don't
know if they were ravers or local Santa Cruz folks trying to crash it.
They broke Everett's (the owner of the place) windows,  but the SC police was
called and they agreed to drive by a few times.   After that,  things went smoothly
and the music was provided by good quality recordings of the UK event that
took place early in the summer.

It is the Universe folks plan to gradually break the Calif rave scene into 
the faster stuff on a more gradual basis by holding future parties gradually 
increasing the tempo to the usual 190 BPM "Hard core" tempo.  US DJ's take
note...   Try to be more diverse,   up the tempo ocassionally,  and vary the
music,  as I think this will soon be the future trend.

By the way WOMAD was great!!  Don't have time now to do a report,  I'm sure
others may make one,   Saw a FEW raver friends there,  but couldn't find the
people I wanted to find (Obviously because there were 100,000 people there).

I left after the 2nd encore by Gabrial,  had NO problems with traffic because
I parked in advantagious location (NORTH of the park and close to the
101 GG Bridge access).

Cheers
CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 20 11:00:43 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA01075; Mon, 20 Sep 93 11:00:43 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA09319; Mon, 20 Sep 93 11:00:34 -0700
Message-Id: <9309201800.AA09319@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Mon, 20 Sep 1993 11:00:33 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: fast music and free parties
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Crunch says (about Universe):

>but more than that is the acceptance of the Calif scene to the much faster
>"hard core" and "Acid trance" sets put on by the Brits..   

This is kinda funny when you think that Jeno, Markie, Garth, and Martin
(among others) are all British too, and seem to form a backbone (with
Wicked and Basics/Gathering) in the SF scene.

But anyway, it looks like the East Coast scene is much closer to the 
European scene in terms of acceptance of high bpm music.  However, when
I was out in SF August/September, I was playing music from 130 to 160, and
people were dancing.  Like the Universe crowd, I was pretty worried no one
would like it, but once I got started enough people enjoyed it that it
didn't seem to be a problem.  Now of course, I wasn't investing hundreds
of thousands of dollars into throwing a huge party . . . but the point is that
contrary to my previous beliefs and apprehensions, there IS an audience for
hardcore/hardtrance/acidtrance in San Francisco.

But hey, if Universe wants to pull out then that's their call -- that
leaves *me* to take care of you all . .  you are MINE, all MINE (insert
maniacal laughter and about 100 smileys here).

I heard DRC was putting down some pretty blistering stuff at the last YSH,
and that it was successful.  Maybe the higher-bpm "market" is emerging and 
Universe needs to look around a bit to make sure they aren't throwing the baby 
out with the bathwater.  But then again, when throwing a party as big and
expensive as Universe/UK was, financial considerations become HIGHLY
important, so it gets harder to blaze new ground for fear of loosing money.
Let's hear it for smaller FREE parties where we can do what we want, when
we want, without fear of ending up in Bankruptcy Court. :-)

>but in all reality,  I don't (Nor do the Universe folks) think that Calif
>ravers are ready for this.   

After my experiences in August, I don't believe this is the case.  No,
the majority of the scene might not go for it, but it seems NO ONE is
providing the alternative for the definite number of people who tried it
and liked it either on journeys East or when I was out there.

>I'm sorry I missed Fluid Groove,  I sorta wanted to go to that (Or Wicked
>or GK),   but at $20 a pop,  one can only afford to go to just ONE of
>those parties.   Sorry for not attending...

Lack of money is a bad excuse for missing Fluid Grooves:  it was free (Bryce 
asked for donations to cover his and Ethan's costs, but no one was being 
turned away for financial considerations.)

>It is the Universe folks plan to gradually break the Calif rave scene into 
>the faster stuff on a more gradual basis by holding future parties gradually 
>increasing the tempo to the usual 190 BPM "Hard core" tempo.  

190 bpm?  Oh gack, I forgot that in the UK they call "hardcore" what we 
call "breakbeat."  Right now the big thing there is what they call "darkness"
which is hyper-fast breakbeat with lots eerie samples and minor keys and 
the like.  Some of it clocks in at 210 bpm.  In the US we use the term
"hardcore" to refer to the 150-170 4/4 Dutch/German/Belgian/Brooklyn-style 
hardcore.  This hardcore is slowing down (most records around 160 rather
than 180 like last summer) and getting trancier (not as much dissonance,
screaming, and distortion as last summer).

>US DJ's take
>note...   Try to be more diverse,   up the tempo ocassionally,  and vary the
>music,  as I think this will soon be the future trend.

Acutally, the future trend depends on where you are.  In SF the music might
get harder . . . out East it's getting housier and slower . . . in Toronto
the "darkness breakbeat" is getting hugely popular.  I think the only thing
you can really ask for is for DJs to buy what they like, what really turns
them on, and for dancers and small party organizers to give DJs they've never 
heard of a chance.

For all those craving a bit of very odd acidtrance, mixed up with some 
hardtrance and hardcore come to then NEXT Fluid Grooves/Liquid Air party, 
to be held October 15th.  I just got my plane tickets today, so I will be 
there with a pile of new records, many of which blur the lines between 
house/tribal/trance/acid/hardcore/ambient.  As always, it will be a FREE 
event, but the organizers ask for donations because, after all, lollipops, 
speakers, U-Haul trucks, and gasoline don't grow on trees.

See you then!

Laura

From: sap@lucid.com (Synthia Petroka)
Message-Id: <9309201851.AA00987@laura-palmer.lucid.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject:  False alarm about headlights and gangs
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Per Mercury News, 9/18/93:


COPS TRY TO ARREST RUMOR OF GANG RITE 

CHILLING REPORT OF INITIATION CALLED `FOLKLORE BY FAX' 

By KIM BOATMAN 
Mercury News Staff Writer

A particularly chilling rumor with all the earmarks of an urban 
legend is racing through Silicon Valley, testimony to both the 
speed of electronic communication and our increasing fear of 
violence.

Despite reassurances from San Jose police that the rumor is baseless, 
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
the tales about a new type of crime used to initiate San Jose gang 
members have been fueled to a full-fledged wildfire in the past two 
weeks.

The warning has spread, via electronic mail, faxes and word of mouth, 
to companies such as Sun Microsystems and Amdahl Corp. to 
Independence High School, to Alexian Brothers Hospital, to 
concerned citizen Joe Najar's cousin's friend's cousin.

Police have been deluged with phone calls. However, the rumor seemed 
to recede a bit Friday with a new batch of electronic mail messages 
saying the warning isn't legitimate. And it turns out the rumor 
isn't even original.

``It's very hot in Chicago right now,'' said folklorist Jan Harold 
Brunvand, a University of Utah professor who has written five books 
about urban legends. ``It actually popped up in Memphis first.

``Somebody's just trying to cause a panic. This (gang-related rumors) 
might be replacing the satanic panic.''

The Mercury News is not revealing specifics because of law 
enforcement concerns about copycats. But the rumor involves a 
lethal gang initiation that targets motorists.

The rumor took the same form in Memphis, Tenn., last month and in 
Chicago earlier this month, with a warning supposedly coming from 
local police departments. A Memphis police spokesman said Friday 
the unfounded rumor has spread to two other Tennessee cities, 
Knoxville and Chattanooga.

The crime depicted in the phony report hasn't occurred in San Jose, 
said police Lt. Daniel Ortega of the department's gang unit. His 
office alone has fielded more than 50 calls in the past few days 
>from companies and private citizens, taking time that might be 
devoted to ``pro-active'' work.

The police have sent letters to many businesses asking that they post 
the department's response.

``This is something we have to respond to,'' Ortega said. ``We're 
trying to put out a fire the best way we can without adding to it.''

As these tales usually do, the rumor took on new dimensions as it 
spread. One electronic mail message Thursday attributed the warning 
to an Independence High history teacher and said a niece's 
boyfriend's mother who works at Alexian Brothers Hospital knew of 
four victims who had been treated in the hospital's emergency room. 
But there have been no victims reported.

Copies of the ``warning,'' containing misspelled words and typed on 
blank paper with no official letterhead, had been posted in some 
wards. Najar, the concerned citizen, said he has been told by 
Alexian employees that police posted the warnings. And he remains 
unconvinced about the urban legend nature of the rumor.

But Supervisor of Nurses Marsha Haney said Friday no one at Alexian 
Brothers knows how the report came into the hospital.

Independence High Principal John Sellarole, who heard about the ties 
to his school when his wife brought home an electronic mail memo, 
also is working to dispel the rumor after finding no evidence of 
its veracity. Sellarole went so far as to ask one company to 
distribute his name and phone number over an electronic bulletin 
board.

When officials talk about an information superhighway, they probably 
don't think of traffic in terms of Waco, Texas, jokes and urban 
legends. But the gang initiation rumor proliferated on Internet, a 
global computer network, among others.

``One guy got it here and immediately posted it. A minute after he 
got it, the other 18 of us got it,'' said Richard Hansen, president 
of Silicon Engineering Inc. in Scotts Valley. ``If that happens in 
a place like Sun or Silicon Graphics, a thousand people could be 
notified in the space of a couple of minutes.''

Hansen said hoaxes are rare on Internet. But high-tech communications 
networks are the frequent vehicle for what passes for folk culture 
these days.

``The folklore that is being created has an almost instant 
transition,'' said Alan Dundes, a University of California, 
Berkeley professor of anthropology and folklore. ``I call it 
folklore by fax.''

And the most current urban legends reflect the troubles that plague 
our society. One, too graphic for public consumption, plays on 
fears about AIDS, foreign travel and foreigners.

Some new legends are just plain strange, such as the traveling 
businessman who meets a woman and later wakes up in a hotel room to 
find himself on bloodied sheets and with a kidney missing, the 
victim of a ring of organ thieves.

The gang initiation rumor might have its origins in the violence 
against tourists in Florida or in the growing concern about gang 
activities, Dundes said.

``It is reflective of a fear of teen-agers or young toughs,'' he 
said. `` . . . There is certainly a perception that teen-agers are 
dangerous.''


Mercury News Staff Writer Bill Romano contributed to this report.

MERCURY CENTER ID: me25641r


Transmitted:  93-09-18 05:55:55 EDT

I  don't mean to single you out John, but this is just a good example.  It's
annoying to me when people (especialy East coasters) think that just because
we (cali people) don't generaly play fast hardcore at our raves that were
ignorant to it,  not ready for it, have never experienced it, don't like it,
etc.  I happen to love it but I can't influence the taste of all our local
popular djs.  I think a lot of people out here are the same, too.  I just
think this is a strong mis-conception that even some of us have about ourselves,i.e., comments similar to:  I can't wait to go to the east coast or for this
east coast dj to come out here and show us some "real east coast techno", as ifit all hails from out there or something and you can't get it at record stores
around here.  We don't go around saying:  Ya, we'll send John D. out there to
show them what "real SF tibal/trance" is all about, because we know better.
We don't make the shit here exclusivley, it's just that our local DJs and
dancers tend to favour it but we know it gets heard and played and made
elsewhere.  Anyway, don't mean to rant but this bugs me and I've seen some of
us perpetuate the misconception with certain posts.

-Mark

Subject: Re: gang violence

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@squick.eit.COM>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


> And I honestly didn't think there would be people in favor of letting
> the government take away our liberties in the raver community.

People seem to have this attitude that "government is bad" and "liberties
are good". That is silly, there are plenty of governments that are good,
and plenty of systems that work better and more equitably than the american
system (e.g. the netherlands, denmark, sweden, etc). Just because the US
government is fucked doesn't mean that you should be going all libertarian
on us.

Laws (esp. gun control) are needed because people are too stupid and
selfish to view any of their actions from the distance of "the big
picture".

Take a look at the amount of damage that gets done once the government
listens to all the braindamaged liberterians with their "laws are stupid"
or "laws are bad for business" credo. Take for example deregulating
business practices, as Bush did with S&L's under the Reagan presidency. Can
you say Michael Milken, Charles Keating, Junk Bonds, S&L fiasco? I knew you
could!

As far as I'm concerned, the more I see, the more I feel that libetarianism
is "evil" and the associated dogma of extreme privatization is folly.
Libertarianism isn't actively "evil", just evil in a selfish small-minded
sort of way.  IMHO, Libertarianism is the politics of people that have
given up on improving the human condition.

PS: Of course, the US govt. is busy regulating all the things it shouln't
and deregulating all the things it should. SHOULDN'T REGULATE: anything you
do in the privacy of your own home, without causing bad effects on others,
e.g.  some drugs, consensual sex, sexual preference. SHOULD REGULATE:
anything which causes harm to others, e.g. gun possesion, vehicle usage,
the right to profit from others misfortunes (aka capitalism).

PPS: WE NEED MORE GOVERNMENT, NOT LESS! The US governemnt is underinvolved
in a number of crucial issues where they should be playing a very active
role (health care, science/technology/manufacturing development, social
services, education, infrastructure).  But we need better government, not
the innefectual career bureaucrats and pencil pushers that have coagulated
the vitality of America. People that actually give a fuck. ANd we need to
get rid of our so-called-democracy (really a money-ocracy) and install a
non-hierarchical representation system in which all people are treated as
truly equal with their vote. No more senators and congressmen that can be
bought with money, bribes, and favors to their constituents. No more bought
media-access to brainwash people into voting for some self-serving career
politican.

PPPS: pretty good end-of-first-day-of-work-after-7-months-retirement-rant, eh?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=		       Niels Mayer -- mayer@eit.com                         =
=	     Multimedia Engineering Collaboration Environments              =
= Enterprise Integration Technologies, 459 Hamilton Ave, Palo Alto CA 94301 =

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 20 23:13:37 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04652; Mon, 20 Sep 93 23:13:37 PDT
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com (uucp4.netcom.com) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA04645; Mon, 20 Sep 93 23:13:33 PDT
Received: from dms.UUCP by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA23038; Mon, 20 Sep 93 22:58:23 PDT
Received: from curly.agames.com by agames.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04132; Mon, 20 Sep 93 22:55:48 PDT
Received: from epikt.agc.com by curly.agames.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA01053; Mon, 20 Sep 93 22:55:52 PDT
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Message-Id: <9309210555.AA01053@curly.agames.com>
Subject: Re: Mo' Government
To: squick.eit.com!mayer@netcom.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 20 Sep 93 22:55:31 PDT
In-Reply-To: <9309210224.AA06439@eit.COM>; from "Niels P. Mayer" at Sep 20, 93 7:23 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Neils: you mean well, but you've made a bad assumption or two.

> People seem to have this attitude that "government is bad" and "liberties
> are good". That is silly, there are plenty of governments that are good,
> and plenty of systems that work better and more equitably than the american
> system (e.g. the netherlands, denmark, sweden, etc). Just because the US
> government is fucked doesn't mean that you should be going all libertarian
> on us.

Sounds like you have a warped view of libertarians (see below).  I'm not
one, but read on.

> Laws (esp. gun control) are needed because people are too stupid and
> selfish to view any of their actions from the distance of "the big
> picture".

Laws will always turn on you eventually.  They are not a long-term solution.
I explain below.

> Take a look at the amount of damage that gets done once the government
> listens to all the braindamaged liberterians with their "laws are stupid"
> or "laws are bad for business" credo. Take for example deregulating
> business practices, as Bush did with S&L's under the Reagan presidency. Can
> you say Michael Milken, Charles Keating, Junk Bonds, S&L fiasco? I knew you
> could!

These were libertarian actions on the surface, but were really designed and
written as money grabs for people who helped Reagan get into power, with
the "deregulation" issue being a smokescreen for the real aims.  The
focus of true libertarians is to maximize the liberties of ALL PEOPLE,
not just your rich friends.  You have let others define your terms for you.

For example, a true libertarian would require the strictest possible
environmental safeguards, because poisoning the earth, water, or air
hurts many more people than the money helps one fat board of directors.
In this worldview, your rights stop where mine start, and I don't think
you'll find many people willing to argue that non-poisonous air, water,
and land are not rights.

> As far as I'm concerned, the more I see, the more I feel that libetarianism
> is "evil" and the associated dogma of extreme privatization is folly.
> Libertarianism isn't actively "evil", just evil in a selfish small-minded
> sort of way.  IMHO, Libertarianism is the politics of people that have
> given up on improving the human condition.

No, libertarianism (or anarchism) is the politics of people who believe that
we are all mature enough to be responsible for our own actions, and that 
having our rights and responsibilities returned to us will result in a better
life than before.  This requires a supreme faith in the human condition,
that eventually, given the chance we do not now have, we will get it right.

> PS: Of course, the US govt. is busy regulating all the things it shouln't
> and deregulating all the things it should. SHOULDN'T REGULATE: anything you
> do in the privacy of your own home, without causing bad effects on others,
> e.g.  some drugs, consensual sex, sexual preference. SHOULD REGULATE:
> anything which causes harm to others, e.g. gun possesion, vehicle usage,
> the right to profit from others misfortunes (aka capitalism).

Any time you give other people power to enforce "SHOULDS:" you are left 
with the near-certainty that the shoulds will change for the worse but the
power will remain.  All most "Libertarians" ask for is a return to the
principles of our constitution which have never been repealed but often
get ignored.  I ask for more, but the demonstration holds.

> PPS: WE NEED MORE GOVERNMENT, NOT LESS! The US governemnt is underinvolved
> in a number of crucial issues where they should be playing a very active
> role (health care, science/technology/manufacturing development, social
> services, education, infrastructure).  But we need better government, not
> the innefectual career bureaucrats and pencil pushers that have coagulated
> the vitality of America. People that actually give a fuck.

Here is where your core assumption is revealed.  You think that if we just
had the "right people" in power that everything would get better.  
Unfortunately, there are only two reasons to want power.  1) You want to
order others around.  2) You want to take the power so the type 1s don't
get it.  1) will always win eventually over 2) because the rewards are 
greater.  A society where this will not eventually happen requires the
(possibly gradual) removal of all positions of power and a concurrent 
transfer of responsibility onto all individuals within that society.

> ANd we need to
> get rid of our so-called-democracy (really a money-ocracy) and install a
> non-hierarchical representation system in which all people are treated as
> truly equal with their vote. No more senators and congressmen that can be
> bought with money, bribes, and favors to their constituents. No more bought
> media-access to brainwash people into voting for some self-serving career
> politican.

Look at public opinion polls.  Do you want to be ruled by the whims of the
majority directly?  We are truly equal with our vote, and it doesn't matter.
The myth that our government is unrepresentative is spread by insecure
people who can't accept that they're in the minority.

+++

I don't care who you grant the power or authority to, whether it be a king,
shaman, minister, president, or 280 million random Americans most of whom
believe that ritual genital mutilation of male children is a good idea,
it's still going to go sour on you, because power corrupts, and absolute
power corrupts absolutely.  Even Marx envisioned the state as a temporary
stage on the way to non-governed autonomous collectives, but history tells
us that it always sticks on the "temporary dictatorship of the proletariat"
part.  Human nature.

The only long-term solution is to educate ourselves and act according to our
own desires, and take full responsibility for the consequences.  Any other 
system is open to exploitation and eventual fascism.  You can't change
other people: you can only change yourself.

"So you'd better start living the life that you're talking about" -Fugazi

// g

Thanks much to Bryce for putting together the second Fluid Groove production!!  Liquid Air's housey sets definitely contrasted with the first Fluid Groove's faster, faster, faster (northeastern influenced) sounds.  And though I generally prefer the latter (is this sacrilege for a SF raver?), I really got into Tamara's, Jon's, Timothy's, and Ethan's stuff.

Tam spun a more laid back set than what she played at last Thursday's YSH.   "Laid back" is relative, since  I think Tamara was *jammin'* during her short, hour-long performance.  And it was only her second "professional" gig!  Wow! (Oh, and the highly self-critical DJ did make a couple mistakes, but they were hardly noticeable. :) )

Jon was excellent, of course.  Timothy's debut spinning was well done in spite of a few troublesome mixes (the crowd was really great in supporting him through these).   And Ethan, you are the House Meister!  Good job!

Thanks also to Ethan/Sound Vision for the super sound system. It cranks!

I wonder...since Laura is playing with Tam and Jon at the next Fluid Groove, does that mean that Laura will influence them to speed it up a bit? :)  No matter what, I will look forward to dancing my butt off at that event!!

Rob
(throb@netcom.com)

 > Having been brought up in a non-gun owning society, I don't see being
 > denied the liberty to own a killing machine as being very different

  Sean> One has the right to kill people in certain situations.

And that's a right that I sincerely hope I never have to exercise.

Maybe all countries should maintain nuclear capability, so that they
can teach another country a lesson, in case the need should arise.

I'm sorry, I don't buy the hypothetical argument of what *might*
happen as a justification to own a killing machine.

I should re-emphasize thatmy views are undoubtedly quite strongly
influenced by the fact that I've grown up in a non gun-owning culture.
But I don't see any reason to change that.  I don't hear any calls to
arm to population of the UK with handguns for self-defence....

From: Roy Badami <roy>
Date: Mon, 20 Sep 93 13:15:13 BST
To: gwh@lurnix.lurnix.com
Cc: roy%harlequin.co.uk%uunet@uunet.uu.net, Miles.Pearce@bristol.ac.uk,
        gwh@uunet.uu.net
In-Reply-To: gwh@lurnix.lurnix.com's message of Fri, 17 Sep 93 14:03:47 -0700 <9309172104.AA29499@krupke.lurnix.com>
Subject: Re: gang violence 


  gwh> sfraves is not a gun control mailing list.

Point taken.  I've taken the thread off the list....

  gwh> I know a lot of people who rave and shoot/own guns.
  gwh> I know a lot of people who rave and don't.
  gwh> We're not psychopathic killers, we don't go around
  gwh> playing vigilante or anything stupid like that.


I'm not sure what you're trying to say.  I've shot a revolver at a
target.  So what?

My point is that it's *much* easier to get a gun in the US than in the
UK, and as a result there are far more guns in circulation.  This
probably has something to do with the relatively high incidence of
shootings.

That said, despite our gun control policy, the number of illegal
firearms circulating in the criminal fraternity has been steadily
increasing over the past few years.  

I don't know what the answer is.  But I happen to prefer our policy.
Guns for target shooting is one thing... but as soon as you buy a gun
for the purpose of killing people, should it be necessary in self
defence, I think that's the start of a slippery slope.  Too much scope
for mistakes and errors of judgement....

And anyway.... if someone breaks into your house (in the US), the main
reason you're gonna feel you need a gun to defend yourself is because
you're worried that he might be armed himself.  In the UK that's just
not the case.  I mean, he might have a knife, but it's still pretty
unusual for housebreakers to carry firearms....  See the point I'm
makeing....?  The only reason you *need* a gun to defend yourself is
because everyone else has one.  Kind of like nuclear weapons, and
Mutually Assured Destruction.

As an example of how low the incidence of gun use is here, let me
point out that it is still the case that our police are not routinely
armed with anything more than a baton.  They carry guns only if
they're dealing with an incident where they expect guns may be
used....


	Cosmic Roy

On Mon, 20 Sep 1993, Laura La Gassa wrote:

> Dave Mch Mahon says:
> 
> 
> In England lately, according to GeoffE, the kids listening to jungle/darkness
> breakbeat aren't a bunch of light-headed lollypop suckers, but rather are
> dancing maniacs much like the usual hardcore bass-bin worshippers we ahve
> out East.  What I'm getting at is that the environment that the English 
> breakbeat scene takes place in is vastly different from, say, the Boston
> Club Scene.  So hating breakbeat because of northeastern club kids makes
> about as much sense as hating classical because the musicians who made it 
> are mostly all dead.
> 
I think you can group clubbers/ravers in the UK into 5 groups.

i) 	The housey house house clubber. Will listen to the same thud tish thud
tish all night. Is more bothered about how s/he looks than the music
(which all sounds the same anyway). Never bought a record.

ii) The vicks up yer nose, bobble hatted, white gloved, 6 E raver. Only
goes to events with 2000 or more clones, never been to a club, doesn't
want to. Listens exclusively to ridiculously fast breakbeats as expounded
by Progidy, SL2 etc. Actually does put hands in air when told to by MC. 

iii)	The garagey I'm so funky type. Like i) only substitute boring
female vocals over house track (maybe slow it down a bit).

iv)	Techno-heads (include me in this category). Think May, James,
Hawtin, Robbers, Atkins etc all descended from heaven (carrying obligatory
303/909's). Stands in front of speaker stack (often with head in bass bin)
admiring 'the texture, the sheer richness of the....'. Refuses to dance to
anything other than 'pure' techno.

v)	Acid/Trancers. Similar to iv) only more likely to dance. Often
seen repeating the same dance move, over and over again, to an alarming
degree whilst drooling. (include me here too).

Spot any friends there?

Actually, it splits into 3 (but I had fun doing the above).  

a) House/garage
b) Breakbeat/Hardcore (in London sense)
c) Techno/Acid/Trance/Hardcore (in Belgian sense)

Ambient isn't really dance music, so I haven't included it here.

greggy303

In-Reply-To: Greg Eden's message of Tue, 21 Sep 1993 14:28:55 +0100 (BST) <Pine.3.07:930517.9309211458.C21311-c100000@aidan>
Subject: Re: Musical opinions

  Greg> Actually, it splits into 3 (but I had fun doing the above).  

  Greg> a) House/garage
  Greg> b) Breakbeat/Hardcore (in London sense)
  Greg> c) Techno/Acid/Trance/Hardcore (in Belgian sense)

Actually, i'd tend to say (a) and (c) are quite close, with (b) being
another world.  

I'd say the really big split in the uk dance music scene is hardcore
(ie jungalism, darkness, lots of breakbeats) and house/techno (ie
everything else).

There are a lot of people who will *only* listen to hardcore, or
*only* listen to house/techno.  

Within the house/techno scene, people are far more open to other
things....  lot's of people get into house through trance, or vice
versa.  But that's probably because garage/house/porgressive/
trance/techno/gabba is more of a continuum...


	roy

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 21 08:24:08 1993

To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: 190 Huh?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

J.S. Lee advises:

>I tell you what...unless you're a Goa Gill fan, better leave those fast ass
>records home!  It's the easiest way to kill any vibe on a dancefloor here
>in SF.  Put that shit up to 140-190 and watch what happens to the
>dancefloor....can you say bowling lane?

John, I know you weren't at YSH the two nights I spun there or at the first
Fluid Grooves party . . . so how can you say what will or won't work for
sure in *all* cases?

I was playing stuff from 130 to 160 and people were dancing their butts
off.  I got all kinds of comments about how much they've been missing
faster harder beats, and lots of thanks for coming and giving it a whirl.
Sure, a number of people were standing around going "what IS this shit?"
but whenever I looked up the floor was hopping.  People should be given
the choice, the alternative to hear the freshest most inventive dance 
music of ALL genres, you know?  Diversity!

Maybe in the "big party" sense it won't work, since many of the big parties
have financial considerations they have to worry about, but there IS an 
undeniable audience in SF for other than funky 120 bpm house and tribal.

>(I hate that aggro speedo 140+ rubbish, and will do my best to stay away
>from clubs that play that speed (as in meth) oriented music!)

If you think it's all aggro and crystal-meth related, then you haven't
been listening to what has been coming out in the past 6 months.  Some
very lovely records, some happy, some tweaky, and even some dark, all
around 140-150.  The days of the dark 180 bpm dutch-guy-screaming hardcore
are over, this is true, but faster music does live on and is picking
up influences from other generes and is getting more creative and more
interesting than ever before.

So many people who claim they hate the harder stuff are basing their
opinions on the music that was coming out a year to 18 months ago.  The
20 records I've bought :-).

See you all in 23 days (I'll be bringing those 20 records, and more besides),

Laura

<mayer@squick.eit.COM>

--> Laws (esp. gun control) are needed because people are too stupid
--> and selfish to view any of their actions from the distance of "the
--> big picture".
.....
--> PS: Of course, the US govt. is busy regulating all the things it
--> shouln't and deregulating all the things it should. SHOULDN'T
--> REGULATE: anything you do in the privacy of your own home, without
--> causing bad effects on others, e.g.  some drugs, consensual sex,
--> sexual preference. SHOULD REGULATE: anything which causes harm to
--> others, e.g. gun possesion, vehicle usage, the right to profit
--> from others misfortunes (aka capitalism).

OK, you just said that people are too dumb to take care of themselves,
so the US government should act as our collective parents since it can
see "the big picture".  First, is the government really a capable
parent?  Second, what about innocent until proven guilty? With your
gun restrictions you are assuming that everyone is a criminal.  

Lastly, lets assume your point of view: people are two dumb to do the
right thing so the government has to enforce laws to make them.  And
you also claim that the government should not regulate some drug use.
Wait a minute here, you just said that people are too stupid to use
drugs (or alcohol) responsibly, so OF COURSE the government should
regulate them! And when people do use drugs irresponsibly the
government (aka tax-payer money) pays their treatment, at least in the
socialized medical system that you support.  And their families
suffer, etc...  So why should drugs be exempt from government control
but not guns? 

Similarly, should the government legislate safe sex?  People are too
dumb and selfish to use condoms after all.  And unprotected sex can
kill...  Maybe we should make it a law that you have to wear a jacket
in the winter, or that you have to get 8 hours of sleep a night.

Personally, I would rather my government assume that I am an
intelligent person capable of taking care of myself.

The only kind of music that sucks is music elitism
The worst kind of vibe possible is vibe elitism
and i should throw in a mention of drug elitism just for the hell of it

i would rather see 1000 messages a day about gun control
than 1 message a day with someone masturbating their ego

i Think thAt a large KillEr of any SOrt of good eMotional fEelinG is dO
tO the Distinct culturEs that we try to create for ourselves
and then try to make that distinct culture better than any other

Diversity.. strange word.. 

di-ver-si-ty \de-'ver-set-e^-, d[0xF5]^--\ n,  pl -ties
(14c)
1: the condition of being different: VARIETY
2: an instance or a point of difference 

wow.. Variety.. now that would be kinda strange..

you know in LA for the past year we've been talking about how it would be 
really cool to have a club with one room of pounding hardcore/trance
and another of housey vibe...
why is that such a bad idea?

in denmark a friend of mine went to a club where the first room was ambient
the next was housey trance then to house then to harder trance
then to more breakbeat then to HARDCORE ala belgium style
then to moby 1000 bpm being played constantly...

each room had a different sound.. and the deeper in you got the harder it got
is this bad? isnt it better to have everyone in one place and give them
all the variety that they want and people can be happy wherever in that one
place than to have peopel scattered everywhere possibly happy
but secluded definately?

dunno...
just some random thoughts

 ,
dana

--> from others misfortunes (aka capitalism).

  Sue> OK, you just said that people are too dumb to take care of themselves,
  Sue> so the US government should act as our collective parents since it can
  Sue> see "the big picture".  First, is the government really a capable
  Sue> parent?  Second, what about innocent until proven guilty? With your
  Sue> gun restrictions you are assuming that everyone is a criminal.  

Human society, collectively, is dumb, or it wouldn't put so much
effort into designing and perfecting killing machines.  Whether it is
the fault of the government, society, or the individual, I don't know.
Probably all three.


  Sue> So why should drugs be exempt from government control but not
  Sue> guns?

The difference is that the purpose of a gun is to be an efficient
killing machine.  That's what it was desinged to do.  Granted, you can
shoot them at targets, but guns are designed to kill living
creatures....  And to be perfectly honest, the primary purpose of a
gun, the reason it was designed, has always been to kill *people*.

I see a big different between using drugs in a responsible manner, and
killing people in a responsible manner.  Like the latter seems to be
largely a contradiction in terms...  I don't think you're making a
fair comparison...

	roy

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 21 10:37:20 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08361; Tue, 21 Sep 93 10:37:20 PDT
Received: from holly.cam.harlequin.co.uk by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08354; Tue, 21 Sep 93 10:37:16 PDT
Received: from piaget.harlequin.co.uk (piaget.cam.harlequin.co.uk) by holly.cam.harlequin.co.uk; Tue, 21 Sep 1993 18:38:16 +0100
Received: from wundt.harlequin.co.uk by piaget.harlequin.co.uk; Tue, 21 Sep 93 18:37:51 BST
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 21 Sep 93 18:37:48 BST
Message-Id: <14874.9309211737@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: raisty@berlioz.nsc.com
Cc: mayer@squick.eit.com, sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, dionf@ere.umontreal.ca,
        winston@lurnix.com
In-Reply-To: Sue Raisty's message of Tue, 21 Sep 93 10:19:41 PDT <9309211719.AA29159@berlioz.nsc.com>
Subject: Re: gang violence
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

  Sue> Uh, pardon me.  I said using drugs responsibly and using guns
  Sue> responsibly.  Don't twist my words, please.  This is not just a
  Sue> semantic difference and you know it.

Sorry, I'm not trying to twist your words, I'm just trying to explain
the situation as I see it.

Granted, you *can* use guns for target practice, but my point is that
the *purpose* of a firearm is to *kill*.  It is intrinsic to the
nature of a firearm.  It is not just a tool, that can be used for good
or evil.  It is a complex mechanism, which didn't happen by accident.
It was designed.  And the designers had a purpose for their machine.
It was to make it an efficient killing machine.

Granted, *despite* the fact that guns are desgined to kill, it is
possible to pervert that purpose, and use them in a variety of other
ways.  But none of these uses are so fundamental that they actually
require a killing machine to carry them out.

Can you say that *any* of the above applies to drugs....?

Actually, if you had argued the point, which I deliberately put very
bluntly, to make it unpalatable, that it is *not* a complete
contradiction to talk about killing people repsonsibly, then I'd have
a harder time arguing with you.  You could argue that it *is* a
responsible act to kill in self defence.

Face it, most guns are bought for the purpose of killing people, or at
least for the deterent value of the threat of killing people.  Either
bought by criminals, or bought by innocent people to use in self
defence.  So when we're talking about the right to own a gun, we're
*not* talking about the right to engage in target practice (we have
that right here, too.)  We're talking about the right to use that gun
to kill people....  

It's a difficult question, and i'm not saying that, particulalry in a
violent and heavily armed society like the USA, people shouldn't be
prepared to kill in self defence.  But you can't evade the issue --
this is about killing people, and nothing else.

	roy

>--> sexual preference. SHOULD REGULATE: anything which causes harm to
>--> others, e.g. gun possesion, vehicle usage, the right to profit
>--> from others misfortunes (aka capitalism).
>
>OK, you just said that people are too dumb to take care of themselves,
>so the US government should act as our collective parents since it can
>see "the big picture".  First, is the government really a capable
>parent?  Second, what about innocent until proven guilty? With your
>gun restrictions you are assuming that everyone is a criminal.  

Government, in an actual democracy, would be capable parent - it would
be the result of rational debate among the populace or representatives
of the populace, and if there is no absolute standard for right and
wrong, we have to go with the consensus opinion.  Of course, today
in the U.S., there are many problems with government and democracy,
but for the single issue of gun control, we don't have to go into 
all that to discuss the issue.

What I haven't heard gun-control opponents address is how much
easier guns make it to kill people.  As a recent armed-robbery victim,
I can tell you that a gun makes you almost helpless and the gun-holder
has your life in his hands.  If the attacker has a knife or is just
using his physical strength, you could be killed, but you also
may have the chance to run, and probably have a much greater chance of
survival.  

Now I'm not convinced gun control (waiting period, ban on assault
weapons, ban on all weapons) will work, and I'm certain it won't
cut violence to the levels of other countries in the short term,
but the statistics on violence and homicides in Europe and Japan
sound awfully good.  The sheer number of guns that already exist
in the US would make those goals hard to reach, but if it gun control
saves 10 lives, or 100 lives, or 1000 lives, is it worth it?

I suppose the controversy hinges on whether people believe that
the level of potential harm that guns present crosses a threshold
that makes them worthy of regulation.  I would assume that just
about everyone would agree that we should prohibit people from 
owning a nuclear weapon, but we can't prohibit people from owning
knives.  Where do guns fall?

>
>Lastly, lets assume your point of view: people are two dumb to do the
>right thing so the government has to enforce laws to make them.  And
>you also claim that the government should not regulate some drug use.
>Wait a minute here, you just said that people are too stupid to use
>drugs (or alcohol) responsibly, so OF COURSE the government should
>regulate them! And when people do use drugs irresponsibly the
>government (aka tax-payer money) pays their treatment, at least in the
>socialized medical system that you support.  And their families
>suffer, etc...  So why should drugs be exempt from government control
>but not guns? 

Again, the potential social harm in drugs is much less - it's some
number of dollars, relatively small in terms of the whole health-care
system.  Gun-related violence, on the other hand, takes LIVES and adds
fear to everyday life (in addition to its medical costs), so I think
it is certainly higher on the scale of damage to society.  Is it above
the level at which it becomes important for the government to
regulate?  That's what the democratic process could decide.

>
>Similarly, should the government legislate safe sex?  People are too
>dumb and selfish to use condoms after all.  And unprotected sex can
>kill...  Maybe we should make it a law that you have to wear a jacket
>in the winter, or that you have to get 8 hours of sleep a night.
>
>Personally, I would rather my government assume that I am an
>intelligent person capable of taking care of myself. 
>

Safe sex and not wearing a jacket pretty much fall under the 
"anything you do in the privacy of your own home and don't do any
bad effects on others" (assuming the decision to practice unsafe
sex is consensual), except for the potential medical costs, which 
again are probably less a burden on society than violence.

I would love it if all people were intelligent enough to take 
care of themselves and were able to recognize the effects of their
actions on society.  But obviously, there are going to be disagreements
on this, and the best solution we have now is democracy.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

My mailer says that John S. Lee said:
> 
> I tell you what...unless you're a Goa Gill fan, better leave those fast ass
> records home!  It's the easiest way to kill any vibe on a dancefloor here
> in SF.  Put that shit up to 140-190 and watch what happens to the
> dancefloor....can you say bowling lane?
> 
Maybe in the clubs, but there's more raves than clubs. I've personally
never even seen true, well mixed acid ever done at a club or mega-rave,
anyway, so I have no basis for comparison.  And frankly, Goa has *no*
skill at mixing, so no wonder the dance floor clears.  He does have a
good following, though, so he must be doing *something* right. Also, I
have noticed the sound of 303's at a lot more commercial events in the
past month that in the entire previous year. Do I sense a trend?

> Nothing against that hardcore stuff, methinks though that SF has already
> gone through that monotony and decided that enuf was more than enuf (thus
> the very few DJ's who play it).  SF has it's own style, and I LOVE it! 
>
SF does *not* have it's own style.  DJs have their own style. As for that
"house stuff", methinks that we've had enough of it :). Just kidding.
Seriously, though, there is more than enough room in SF for many kinds of
music.  There are *weekly* events devoted to house, hip-hop, acid jazz,
deep house, soul, rock, classical, folk, world beat, and more. One genre,
or even a whole bunch of genres, added to the overall SF music scene can
only add to the richness we already have. As for the number of DJs who play
acid, I went to a smallish event last weekend where I counted no less than
five kick-ass acid DJs. The DJs are out there, they just know that none of
the current big party throwers can afford to let them spin a set.

> (I hate that aggro speedo 140+ rubbish, and will do my best to stay away
> from clubs that play that speed (as in meth) oriented music!)
>
Saying that "fast" music is meth music 
is like saying that ambient music is quaalude music. Puh-leez! Music is
music, and has no inherent association with any drug. I can dance to 140bpm
at 70 (or even 35) bpm, and then you'd think i was on Prozac. There's also
ambient music that is seriously twitchy.  It is sufficient to know that
you don't prefer certain music.

And everyone will do very well to be in places that they are comfortable with.
I wouldn't go to an acid jazz event if i didn't feel like listening to
acid jazz that night.  To do so is a disservice to everyone, coz i'll be
there off in a corner, all frowny faced and shut in, which detracts from
everyone else's fun. Ditto for whatever style of music i'm up for at any
particular moment of time.  It works best when everyone is enjoying 
themselves and wants to be there.
--

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 21 11:06:21 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08594; Tue, 21 Sep 93 11:06:21 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA08587; Tue, 21 Sep 93 11:06:14 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA01605; Tue, 21 Sep 93 14:06:09 EDT
Date: Tue, 21 Sep 93 14:06:09 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9309211806.AA01605@pilot.njin.net>
To: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Gun control
In-Reply-To: <8222.9309211151@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
References: <8222.9309211151@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Roy Badami writes:
 > And anyway.... if someone breaks into your house (in the US), the main
 > reason you're gonna feel you need a gun to defend yourself is because
 > you're worried that he might be armed himself.  In the UK that's just
 > not the case.  I mean, he might have a knife, but it's still pretty
 > unusual for housebreakers to carry firearms....  See the point I'm
 > makeing....?  The only reason you *need* a gun to defend yourself is
 > because everyone else has one.  Kind of like nuclear weapons, and
 > Mutually Assured Destruction.

I think you're assuming that a gun is only warranted if an intruder
has one. Most state laws are worded something like this: "Lethal force
is warranted if one is in imminent danger of death or great bodily
harm." It doesn't matter whether they're armed or not.

I believe that the mindset is not "everyone has guns, we need one". I
believe the mindset of buying a gun for home defense is to have as
much advantage as possible in a defensive situation, no matter how an
intruder may be armed.

The sound of a shotgun action being worked, or the sight of a laser
aimed at one's chest has been known to scare intruders off without any
other action being taken.

Personally, I don't think restricting guns is going to reduce violent
crime any more than throwing people in jail will make drugs less
available. I've heard a lot of Brits point to their society and say
"Look, it works here." I think they have the cause and effect
backwards. Theirs is a much older, far different society where
something like that can work. Our problem is a deep societal problem
and the easy availability of weapons is because of that problem, not
the other way around. The only effective way to cut down on weapons is
not to take them away, but to effect real change so that people no
longer want them. Banning any sort of thing has never been effective
in our society. It usually results in a black market, turning
consumers into criminals, more violent crime, and a worse situation
than one had in the beginning.

The only real way to fix America is to stop just treating the symptoms
and start solving the underlying problems. Want to remedy violent
crime? The answer isn't to try and confiscate guns or put everyone in
jail; the answer is to eliminate the need for violent crime. That's a
very tough agenda, yes, but the only long term solution.

Sean

be in imminent danger of death...

  Sean> I believe that the mindset is not "everyone has guns, we need
  Sean> one". I believe the mindset of buying a gun for home defense
  Sean> is to have as much advantage as possible in a defensive
  Sean> situation, no matter how an intruder may be armed.

because it makes you feel safer...?

A gun is an *offensive* weapon.  Surely the only reason you'd even
consider using a gun in *defence* is because of the high probability
that the intrudor is lethally armed...

  Sean> The sound of a shotgun action being worked, or the sight of a
  Sean> laser aimed at one's chest has been known to scare intruders
  Sean> off without any other action being taken.

going to try and pick out potential burglars from the other end of the
street, and take them out before they get anywhere near your house...?
Just what kind of weapons *are* freely available in the US...?

  Sean> Personally, I don't think restricting guns is going to reduce violent
  Sean> crime any more than throwing people in jail will make drugs less
  Sean> available. I've heard a lot of Brits point to their society and say
  Sean> "Look, it works here." I think they have the cause and effect
  Sean> backwards.

I guess the question, then, is what is the fundamental difference.
Why is is that gun control works here, and we don't get civil rights
groups up in arms about it....?  Why is it that most people here don't
want to own guns....?  When there's news of a violent attack, you
don't get people campaigning for the right to go out and buy a gun to
protect themselves.  We just don't seem to think like that...?  

But as long as you continue to regard gun ownership as normal, you
*will* continue to think like that....

From: megatest!kermit!preiter@uu2.psi.com (Pete Reiter)
Message-Id: <9309211822.AA04007@kermit.megaeng>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: fast vs. slow
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 871
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

On the subject of fast vs. slow beats. One thing to consider is that different
speeds of music engender vastly different dancing styles. Ever notice how
elaborate hip-hop dancing can be? Watch In Living Color some time. Lots of
jumps spins and various acrobatics. That's only possible because the beats
are so slow.

Speed the music up a bit to 120 bpm. You can still jump around a bit, but the
acrobatics are now impossible. Once you get up to 140-160-180 bpm you're 
reduced to standing in one place and twitching. Full body movements are
very difficult unless you're totally hopped up on some powerful stimulants.

I for one like jumping around, that's why I like 120-130 bpm music.

But my main point is that if you're going to expose people to a vastly different
speed of music, they have to change their dancing styles, so there may be some
resistance.

						Pete

Laura La Gassa writes:
 > I was playing stuff from 130 to 160 and people were dancing their butts
 > off.  I got all kinds of comments about how much they've been missing
 > faster harder beats, and lots of thanks for coming and giving it a whirl.
 > Sure, a number of people were standing around going "what IS this shit?"

I agree 100%. Diversity is one of the things that makes the scene so
special. Diversity in people, diversity in the music. If you don't
like what the DJ is spinning, you can chill out for an hour or two,
and hear someone different. It's great! And Fluid Grooves definitely
passed the litmus test. People were dancing their butts off and having
a great time. It got the best reviews I've ever heard of a rave.

There's plenty of interest in SF for some of the faster beats. I don't
know how many people I've heard tell me they'd like to hear some more
of the faster stuff. I know that the _next_ Fluid Grooves is going to
be packed, largely for that reason. (Get em, Laura)

SF is in no danger of being swamped with hardcore. I for one hope we
get more of it because there's a lot of people it will make very
happy.

Sean
