Derek:
>What I haven't heard gun-control opponents address is how much
>easier guns make it to kill people.  As a recent armed-robbery victim,
>I can tell you that a gun makes you almost helpless and the gun-holder
>has your life in his hands.  If the attacker has a knife or is just
>using his physical strength, you could be killed, but you also
>may have the chance to run, and probably have a much greater chance of
>survival.  

Have you ever tried running away from someone with a knife?
I've SEEN someone killed that way.  By the time it's a threat,
the guy is probably four feet away... you can't run when they're
that close.  It just doesn't work.

Btw, last time someone took a shot at me I was able to run and
wasn't hit.

>Now I'm not convinced gun control (waiting period, ban on assault
>weapons, ban on all weapons) will work, and I'm certain it won't
>cut violence to the levels of other countries in the short term,
>but the statistics on violence and homicides in Europe and Japan
>sound awfully good.  The sheer number of guns that already exist
>in the US would make those goals hard to reach, but if it gun control
>saves 10 lives, or 100 lives, or 1000 lives, is it worth it?

How many people will die because they couldn't defend themselves?
Several million people in the US have defended themselves with
guns, and 99% of them didn't have to shoot to do so.  How many
of them would be dead instead of alive today?

>Again, the potential social harm in drugs is much less - it's some
>number of dollars, relatively small in terms of the whole health-care
>system.  Gun-related violence, on the other hand, takes LIVES and adds
>fear to everyday life (in addition to its medical costs), so I think
>it is certainly higher on the scale of damage to society.  Is it above
>the level at which it becomes important for the government to
>regulate?  That's what the democratic process could decide.

Ahh, do you mean drug-related violence?  80% of shootings are
related to the lower-class areas drug dealing where things are
really unsafe.  Do you really think you can disarm these people
who are already importing highly illegal drugs from outside
the US?  They'll just start adding pistols to the loads of
cocaine...

It's not such a pretty friendly world out there.  That's sad,
but that's reality 8-(.

-george

>So you want to be in a position to kill unarmed intruders, just
>because it makes you feel safer...?

Not speaking for Sean, but I'm not worried about unarmed intruders.
They'll probably leave.  I'm worried about the armed ones.

  Sean> The sound of a shotgun action being worked, or the sight of a
  Sean> laser aimed at one's chest has been known to scare intruders
  Sean> off without any other action being taken.

>Laser sighted rifles for home defence....?  You jest, surely?  You're
>going to try and pick out potential burglars from the other end of the
>street, and take them out before they get anywhere near your house...?
>Just what kind of weapons *are* freely available in the US...?

Stop believing movies...

Laser sights are found mostly on shotguns and pistols these days.
It makes it easier to aim at night (and during the day)...
the primary use is at close range.  Thinking that Sean was
discussing offing people a block away is ignorance of 
firearms.

  Sean> Personally, I don't think restricting guns is going to reduce violent
  Sean> crime any more than throwing people in jail will make drugs less
  Sean> available. I've heard a lot of Brits point to their society and say
  Sean> "Look, it works here." I think they have the cause and effect
  Sean> backwards.

>I guess the question, then, is what is the fundamental difference.
>Why is is that gun control works here, and we don't get civil rights
>groups up in arms about it....?  Why is it that most people here don't
>want to own guns....?  When there's news of a violent attack, you
>don't get people campaigning for the right to go out and buy a gun to
>protect themselves.  We just don't seem to think like that...?  

>But as long as you continue to regard gun ownership as normal, you
>*will* continue to think like that....

I suggest you talk to some people who've been shot or stabbed
or even just mugged and ask them about what they think about
self defense.  As a victim of some of the above, I know that
nobody's around to help you, including police; that there are
people out there willing to hurt and kill you for really
trivial reasons; that I do not like the possibility of it
happening again (at this point, I'm pushing my luck on
having survived everything that's happened to me).

It is a horrible thing that it sometimes comes to this, but
if it _does_ come down to someone else trying to kill me
(again), I have a wife and a life ahead of me that are both
much more important to me than the person who's trying
to kill me, and I want to be able to have some control
over my survival.  If the bad guy doesn't go home ever,
that's something I'll regret for the rest of my life,
but I'll be alive.  And nobody has the right to try
and take that choice away from me.

-george

Roy Badami writes:
 > But if the intruder isn't armed, then it's far less likely that you'll
 > be in imminent danger of death...

Death or great bodily harm, to you or anyone else you're around.
People don't fool around with intruders here. Call it American
attitude or whatever you want, but we consider our homes inviolate.
Most people here would feel perfectly justified killing someone about
to kill or greatly injure them or someone they loved. Perhaps what
we're seeing is a difference in societal attitudes about one's space
and one's body.

 > So you want to be in a position to kill unarmed intruders, just
 > because it makes you feel safer...?

Unarmed intruders threatening my life. I'd never shoot anyone I
thought was harmless. I'd never point a gun at anyone unless my very
next action was to kill them.

 > A gun is an *offensive* weapon.  Surely the only reason you'd even
 > consider using a gun in *defence* is because of the high probability
 > that the intrudor is lethally armed...

Technically speaking, in most states, a deadly weapon is anything you
use against someone with intent to kill. A man in KY was convicted of
assault with a deadly weapon when he bashed his wife in the head with
it.

I don't *care* if an intruder is lethally armed or not. All that
matters is that a reasonable person thinks they're in imminent danger
of great bodily harm. Once again, perhaps we just have different
societal attitudes.

Now personally, I'd like to carry Grizzly Bear Strength pepper spray.
It doesn't maim or kill, and it's very effective. Hurts a lot more
too, which might function as some operant conditioning.

 > Laser sighted rifles for home defence....?  You jest, surely?  You're
 > going to try and pick out potential burglars from the other end of the
 > street, and take them out before they get anywhere near your house...?
 > Just what kind of weapons *are* freely available in the US...?

Laser sighted pistols. Laser sights are inexpensive nowdays, greatly
reduce the chance of missing (and hitting innocents), and have a
psychological factor.

 > I guess the question, then, is what is the fundamental difference.
 > Why is is that gun control works here, and we don't get civil rights
 > groups up in arms about it....?  Why is it that most people here don't
 > want to own guns....?  When there's news of a violent attack, you
 > don't get people campaigning for the right to go out and buy a gun to
 > protect themselves.  We just don't seem to think like that...?  
 > 
 > But as long as you continue to regard gun ownership as normal, you
 > *will* continue to think like that....

Beacase here isn't there. Our society, though we speak the same
language, is not your society. And you've still got it backwards.
Taking away guns from honest civilians (not possible in these times)
will not stop criminals, will not change things. It has to be done the
other way around. Stop thinking of us in terms of your society. The
solution here has to come from the root up.

Sean

Pete says:

>But my main point is that if you're going to expose people to a vastly different
>speed of music, they have to change their dancing styles, so there may be some
>resistance.

I agree,  and my style changes appropriatly... And I try very hard to vary my
dance style and stay within the safe physical limitations of low impact on my
back,  arching and bending my back instead of some of the stiff "fucking" motions
I see people do.   The faster the music,  the less time I spend in the air or
off the ground.  I try and do what is good for my body and always staying within
my specific limitation.   Which is obviously different than someone elses limitations.

Which is why I like the rave dancing scene,   where everyone does his or her own thing.

CC

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: 190 Huh again
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Nope, this is not a flame...but after reading the replies to my original
190  Huh? posts....well...naw, it ain't a flame.

The 140+ BPM has, IMO, run it's course here.  The people who have attended
these events have been mostly amped up on speed...I've seen 'em.  There is
little you can do with your body at those speeds otehr than the arrythmic
"pogo" dance.  And speed is great for that type of twitchyness.

(I HATE speed.  It is a stupid drug that I deplore.  I don't like to be
around those that are on it, don't like to see people dance whilst on it,
and I hate to see those buggers come back to earth a complete mess.  If I
had my way the shit would disappear from the planet, but everyone has their
drug of choice.  I do wish people would lay off the stuff.  I saw one
well-known person who is in the clothing biz here in the city do a, uh,
"bump" @ GK.  I was pissed!  Not so much at the person doing it, but
looking at what they had become - a tweeker.  Quite sad actually....oh, how
the mighty have fallen.)

I am not a music elitist, but I DO HATE that style of music(190+).  ACID is
different and for the most part, quite danceable ( until you get up to
about 140+, then you have no choice but to pogo!).

(this whole elitist schtick is waaaay old gents/ladies.  Look, if someone
doesn't like something, and has a preference for something else, and is
strong in that opinion, that is not elitism.  It is called "having a
preference".  And every human being is entitled to such without some sorry
label being attached to his/her persona!  - Thanks)

Hell if you like it, great, blow a gasket, have fun!  I cannot have fun,
could not have fun, nor would want to have fun at such speeds...unless of
course I am in a Ferrari Testosterona on 280 South/Northbound going around
190+mph.

Hardcore, I can leave home without it....ANYTIME!!!

as usual,
John

P.S.  I do really love trippy acid sets, trippy ambient sets, trippy
anything sets, trance, tribal, house, garage, hip-house, anything, even
super-divaesque of late, but never 190+.

I'm in agreement with the diversity-is-great crowd.  But I do think there
  is a legit beef with 140+.  Namely, dancing to that kind of pace is
  --tiring-- (unless, as jsl@netcom.com suggests), you're on speed or some
  equivalent, or just jingling...

IMHO, it's great to show diversity, so it's fine to throw in a set (a
  half-set?) of FBPM at a time, but six hours of it solid leaves bodies all
  over the place.  If nothing else, if you're going to do that, at least
  have the vibe-awareness to setup a second 'floor with slower paced
  stuff...

note: slower pace != chill area...

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 21 20:35:07 1993

From: brycer@netcom.com (Bryce Ryan)
Message-Id: <9309220335.AA11578@netcom3.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: perhaps a less religious viewpoint on high BPM...
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 21 Sep 93 20:35:29 PDT
In-Reply-To: <9309220300.AA01650@ginsberg.CS.Berkeley.EDU>; from "asah@ginsberg.cs.berkeley.edu" at Sep 21, 93 8:00 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I have no religious viewpoint regarding "fast" music (and I use quotes
consciously and to make a point).  I completely understand how someone
moving their limbs at 190bpm can tire out quickly if they're not 
aerobically trained.  It does require a different style of dancing
if one is not so fit.  It does *not* require amphetamines or their
analogs. Dancing at half, third or even quarter speed is perfectly
OK.  And, I'd like to point out that I've seen quite a few people
turn pale during an evening of 120bpm sets put in by Garth, Jeno,
and Tony, so it seems more a matter of fitness and style than bpms.
I've also seen people drop like flies during a set that Taylor (LA)
threw down at LA ToGather--the man *does not* let up on the energy
level of his sets; and he has a huge following.

I stand by my earlier comments. 

And to anyone who has complained about an evening full of high bpm
sets, I'd also like to point out that an
evening full of progressive house, with 4 DJs playing at the same
bpm for 6 hours, gets old extremely fast. Especially when you've 
heard the same sets for six months. (If I hear "Raise your hands"
*one* more time from that same DJ, I'm gonna scream!)  These people
have access to the best music from all over the world; I regard it
as their responsibility to the scene to show the 'masses' what music
is out there.  If I can find "Plastic Dreams" in January in NY, they
sure can. It took the majors four months to break that song. Imagine
the fun we'd all have if the major events broke more new songs and
genres!

So, I ask all who have spoken or thought in terms of diversity of 
music to:

1) support events with diverse styles
2) support DJs who spin diverse styles during their sets
3) rag on the organizers for more diversity
4) encourage your friends to expand their horizons
-- 
Bryce Ryan ------------ AMBIANCE ----------- brycer@netcom.com
Sound surrounds you like Liquid Air ------- Every Month ------
415-487-8497 -- Audio by Sound Vision -- Flyer by Dave Scruton

From sfraves-owner  Tue Sep 21 20:47:34 1993

Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA13924; Tue, 21 Sep 93 20:47:27 -0700
Message-Id: <9309220347.AA13924@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Tue, 21 Sep 1993 20:47:24 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: fast music != speed (out East anyway)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I totally respect people's opinions on the high bpm issue (after all,
what I really want is to be able to give people a choice, but not
to convince them make the choice a certain way), but I want to say 
something:

I don't know about the West Coast, but out East a LARGE number of us 
dance quite well to fast music WITHOUT taking speed or other "speedy" 
drugs.  Yes, the dance is rather twitchy -- but some people (myself
included) have been seen to be moving dipping spinning at quite high
speeds when wrapped up in the music and propelled by the bass bin.

I don't personally know anyone out East who does speed while raving.  
As a purveyor and consumer of fast music, I am upset by insinuations 
that fast music == speed freaks.  

I certainly have never taken speed in my entire life.

And yes, it is rather hard to dance to really fast music for more than 
two or three hours at a time . . . our raves usually build up to 
hardtrance/hardcore for a set or three (and a set is one hour back East), 
and then glide down through slower trance, acid, house, and tribal.  So 
please don't assume all we have is high-speed music all night either, 
because 100% hardcore (german or english style) nights are the exception 
rather than the norm.

My friend Heather was at Universe/UK and she told me there were *7* tents
of music going simultaneously -- an ambient tent, a hardcore (german)
tent, a jungle tent, a breakbeat tent, house, tribal, etc.  People had a
huge choice of what they could hear at any one time.  And some people did
park themselves in one tent, but many others roamed them all, giving many
things a try, sort of like a buffet dinner or something.  Perhaps a 
Universe/SF set up in such a way would work, too, giving people a chance to
try different things without being locked into a choice they decide they
*don't* like.

Laura

Yikes, logging in remote to kill the 200 messages. Please dont send me weird
email because i suggested gun control...

I just said that we had gun control here (you can still buy a gun after you
get the proper permit and pass a course on safety and firearms). So you still
have a choice. but people too lazy to get the proper permits cant go and buy
a firearm anywhere. I also dont think our cultures are that much different, so
if we project the deaths by bullet in Canada to the US, with the same legisla-
tion it should go down from 35000 to 3500 death by bullet, without removing
any rights. Of course, with so many guns in circulation, it would take a lot
of years to actually drop. Anyway... argumentation is not very usefull on this
subject. Actions have to be taken (not sending me hate mail. flames are ok, but
calling me faschist will not resolve anything).

Some song actually feel fast but are slow and vice versa (he, while i am
remotely logged, i said why not say a word on that issue too! :P ). For ex:
i'm currently listening to disintegration (live) by The Cure. What's your bpm
guess on this? 90, 100? Nope, it's 142! Love missile by PWEI? 202!
Boing by Fox present? 151! (it does feel much faster). I know acid at 125 and
i know house at 145. I even have hard trance at 180. Oh, at let's see. You know
N-Joi malfunction? well you can spin and jump and twirl and whatever, and it's
not 120 bpm like it feels, it's 139. In any case, i cant really imagine someone
doing a whole set of 190 bpm songs (there are not that much!).

As for drugs, well most people i know dont take drugs and can easily dance
(not just pogo) at 140 bpm. And myself? well except for aspirins or a beer
once in a while i do not take drugs and can dance on anything i play. If i
cant dance it i will not play it. Be it from ambient to hardcore. (I'm usually
in the 126-160 bpm bracket with once in a while extremes).

Ciao,

> I'm in agreement with the diversity-is-great crowd.  But I do think there
>   is a legit beef with 140+.  Namely, dancing to that kind of pace is
>   --tiring-- (unless, as jsl@netcom.com suggests), you're on speed or some
>   equivalent, or just jingling...


...or just in good shape.  I don't do speed or ephedrine or even caffeine
when I'm out raving.  Eating well, catching a nap before going out, and 
leading a stress free life, all allow me to keep up with faster bpms.

Taking care of yourself also has the added advantages of helping avoid
sickness and allowing faster recovery times after a hard night or weekend of
dancing and sleep deprivation.

As far as what type of music is better -- listen to what makes you happy.  I
like different flavors of music for different moods.  Be open minded,
experiment and go with the flow.  Happiness starts inside and spreads
outwards -- music flows from within.

On Sep 21,  7:40pm, you proclaimed:
} The 140+ BPM has, IMO, run it's course here.  

Huh?  It's barely started!  Short attention span I guess :)

} The people who have attended
} these events have been mostly amped up on speed...I've seen 'em.  

You should be a cop, you seem to be really good at telling what people
are on by looks :)  I really have to disagree with you here; and this
isn't a matter of opinion, or if it were I wouldn't be replying, I'd
be thinking "he has his opinion and I have mine".  This is to contradict
what you say, because in *my* experience, the harder parties recently
(YSH's, which I've never seen you at), various renegades, and even the
most recent Basics (which had stretches of nice hard stuff around 2am,
before Spun dug into his bassy/electro set), HAVEN'T had any sizeable
number of speed tweakers.  And at all of these parties, the hard fast
parts were pretty much limited to one set or so.

} There is
} little you can do with your body at those speeds otehr than the arrythmic
} "pogo" dance.  And speed is great for that type of twitchyness.

This comment has a small amount of truth, but that's only because you and
most others in SF don't know how to dance at those speeds.  Don't try
to do the full body motions and arm swings that you can at 120 or 130;
many people only move on every other beat, in effect dancing similar to
how they would at 80bpm.  There's a lot of creativity in it.  Besides,
who cares how you dance at a rave?  One thing most people like about raves
is that no one CARES how you dnce, and most people don't try to show off,
they just try to channel the music through them, and are usually lost in
their own world when dancing.

} (I HATE speed.  It is a stupid drug that I deplore.  I don't like to be
} around those that are on it, don't like to see people dance whilst on it,
} and I hate to see those buggers come back to earth a complete mess.  If I
} had my way the shit would disappear from the planet, but everyone has their
} drug of choice.  I do wish people would lay off the stuff.

I couldn't agree more.  It's not really good as a *dance party* drug, the
same way nitrous isn't.  Or crack or cocaine or heroin, or ketamine.  But
to be honest if someone looks like they're gonna have trouble making that
1 1/2 hour drive home in the morning, I'd MUCH rather they have something to
keep them awake for the drive than risk crashing the car.  And as I can
relate from experience, there is not a small market in amphetamines for
college students, particularly in med school.  

} I am not a music elitist, but I DO HATE that style of music(190+).  ACID is
} different and for the most part, quite danceable ( until you get up to
} about 140+, then you have no choice but to pogo!).

no, YOU have no choice but to pogo, coz you don't seem to even consider the
possibility that there might be other ways to enjoy the music than in the
context of 120-140 bpm house.  I must admit I probably would find it very
hard to do anything but nod my head at 190+, but if I halve it I get 95, a
nice uppity reggae or electro speed.  There's also a LOT of range between
140 and 190 BPM, something you seem to ignore.

} (this whole elitist schtick is waaaay old gents/ladies.  Look, if someone
} doesn't like something, and has a preference for something else, and is
} strong in that opinion, that is not elitism.  It is called "having a
} preference".  And every human being is entitled to such without some sorry
} label being attached to his/her persona!  - Thanks)

You're mostly right, it is old... so quit thinking that anyone dancing
to anything above 140 is by association a speed freak.  Preferences are
fine, but if I feel they are based on silly criteria I can say so.  
Proscribing your tastes around pure BPM's is like saying you don't like
books shorter than 120 pages or longer than 160 :)

} Hell if you like it, great, blow a gasket, have fun!  I cannot have fun,
} could not have fun, nor would want to have fun at such speeds...unless of
} course I am in a Ferrari Testosterona on 280 South/Northbound going around
} 190+mph.
} 
} Hardcore, I can leave home without it....ANYTIME!!!

That's kinda funny, because I remember the only Vortex I went to at
174 King around the beginning of the year, and leaving at one point
because the music had taken a very hardcore, and very boring, turn for
about an hour from 4 to 5, after my energy hAd run its course and I
was way too spent for it.

} P.S.  I do really love trippy acid sets, trippy ambient sets, trippy
} anything sets, trance, tribal, house, garage, hip-house, anything, even
} super-divaesque of late, but never 190+.  

I like all that too!  But I think SF has been missing a crucial
element in its rush and desire to be "different" from the rest of the
world.  Thinking now upon it, I think my anathema to hardcore had been
based upon always associating the pounding 909 kick and dissonant
chords and all the other stereotypical elements of hardcore circa 1992
with insophistication and a dark step away from the happy vibe I felt
at most SF sets (song with names like "Mother Fucker Man", etc) .  But
it took some exposure to music, despite my initial feelings against
it, to realize the bad attitude had been just about completely dropped
while still maintaining a very nice sinister side, the kind of sinister
that makes you smile.... anyways, I now fully enjoy it as a part of a
night's set, and even have been hearing elements of it in recent Jeno
and other sets. 

John should NOT be flamed for not liking the usual constituents of
hardcore music, just as you shouldn't flame me for professing to not
be crazy about Country music, for example.  But just as I really liked
the Cowboy Junkie's first album, which was VERY country-influence, I
hope John "keeps the door open" so to speak.  But then again, what do
I care. :)

	Brian

  gwh> Stop believing movies...

  gwh> Laser sights are found mostly on shotguns and pistols these days.
  gwh> It makes it easier to aim at night (and during the day)...
  gwh> the primary use is at close range.  Thinking that Sean was
  gwh> discussing offing people a block away is ignorance of 
  gwh> firearms.

I wasn't seriously suggesting that Sean was proposing taking out
people a few blocks away.  But, certainly, I am ignorant of firearms.
That's because I don't live in a gun culture.

  gwh> I suggest you talk to some people who've been shot or stabbed
  gwh> or even just mugged and ask them about what they think about
  gwh> self defense.  As a victim of some of the above, I know that
  gwh> nobody's around to help you, including police; that there are
  gwh> people out there willing to hurt and kill you for really
  gwh> trivial reasons; that I do not like the possibility of it
  gwh> happening again (at this point, I'm pushing my luck on
  gwh> having survived everything that's happened to me).

I still don't get it.  How many people have to die unnecessarily
before the US realises that guns are a bad thing?  Most people don't
think rationally in a crisis situation.  Even if they've been
specially trained, they're likely to overreact.  If you've got a gun
on you, and you know how to use it, you're likely to kill someone out
of fear, rather than out of genuine necessity.  I don't trust myself
to make the decission as to when to shoot someone.  And I don't trust
most people out there, either.  Maybe I'm walking down a dark street,
and I bump into someone.  He panics, and shoots me....

The other problem is that (in the UK) the majority of murders are not
premeditated.  People get angry, and do stupid things in the heat of
the moment.  If they have a gun, they're more likely to do something
stupid, that they'll regret later.  In a non gun-owning society,
they'll probably just end up beating someone up....  How many
shootings result from, say, a man finding his wife with another man?
How many similar incidents are there in the UK?  I don't have the
statistics, but I'd be surprised if they don't surport my point.

It's not that our society is fundamentally less violent than yours.
It's just that gun ownership escalates violent disputes to a higher
level....

	Cosmic

  Sean> Death or great bodily harm, to you or anyone else you're
  Sean> around.  People don't fool around with intruders here. Call it
  Sean> American attitude or whatever you want, but we consider our
  Sean> homes inviolate.  Most people here would feel perfectly
  Sean> justified killing someone about to kill or greatly injure them
  Sean> or someone they loved. Perhaps what we're seeing is a
  Sean> difference in societal attitudes about one's space and one's
  Sean> body.

Actually, I don't think so.  English law has the notion of using
"reasonable force" to defend yourself.  That can include killing
someone.

  Sean> I don't *care* if an intruder is lethally armed or not. All that
  Sean> matters is that a reasonable person thinks they're in imminent danger
  Sean> of great bodily harm. Once again, perhaps we just have different
  Sean> societal attitudes.

What worries me is how often people are going to get scared, and
overreact.  Is it commonplace for unarmed criminals to get shot
because their victims get scared that they *might* be armed...?

  Sean> Now personally, I'd like to carry Grizzly Bear Strength pepper
  Sean> spray.  It doesn't maim or kill, and it's very effective.
  Sean> Hurts a lot more too, which might function as some operant
  Sean> conditioning.

Now that i can relate to.  It's making me sick the number of times
people use the euphamism "defence" when talking about an offensive
weapon.

  Sean> Laser sighted pistols. Laser sights are inexpensive nowdays,
  Sean> greatly reduce the chance of missing (and hitting innocents),
  Sean> and have a psychological factor.

Yep, i guess (as someone else pointed out) I'm just ignorant aobut
firearms.


  Sean> And you've still got it backwards.  Taking away guns from
  Sean> honest civilians (not possible in these times) will not stop
  Sean> criminals, will not change things. It has to be done the other
  Sean> way around.

I think you're putting words into my mouth here.  I'm not necessarily
saying gun contorl will work.  All I'm trying to argue is that the
*problem* is gun ownership.  I don't know how to solve that problem.

Put it another way.  If you introduced gun control, and then magically
confiscated all the guns in circulation, do you think that would
work...?  Yep, people would still be able to get hold of guns smuggled
into the country on the black market, but the numbers would be
small....

Now in reality, achieving low gun ownership is hard, because of the
number of guns in circulation.  I accept that in a society where all
the criminals have guns, gun control laws may actually make things
worse.  But do you at least accept that gun ownership is a *problem*,
and that the *goal* should be to work towards a society where guns are
unusual, both amongst honest citizens, and amongst criminals.

Or is the idea of a non-gun-owning society just not the american way...

	Cosmic

From: Oozing Sincerity...  22-Sep-1993 1344 <gary@ayrmis.enet.dec.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU

Subject: Assorted ramblings from Scotland

	Ok, doubt I've ever contributed to this list before... (Well
	actually I did, couple of days ago, but some mail monster
	got its grubby little hands on it before it made the list)

	So I'm Gary, from Ayr, Scotland.

	Hello...

	I don't live in a 'gun culture', never fired, owned or had 
	any sort of need for a gun. I don't agree that guns should
	be banned in America. Guess I'd better support that view.

	But first, cross culture comparisons are often not completely
	valid. Personally I find adultry and theft to be activites
	best discouraged, but I'm not for the public flogging of
	straying partners and the removal of extremites from the
	convicted thief. Good deterents I'm sure, but too my 
	mind, a bit extreme. 
	
	To my mind punishing innocent people because of the activites
	of others is a bit extreme as well. Thats what your doing
	when you take away other peoples property, or rights.

	See thats what a gun is, property, an object. And I beleive
	the constitution of America allows the individual to own
	such property. People who want to ban guns want to take 
	away that right.

	You see people in America have always owned guns, unlike 
	us natives of the united kingdom, the clamour to ban them
	is a fairly recent thing, the escalating violence is a 
	recent thing. Doesn't this point to something other then
	guns as the source of the problem ?

	Guns deter crime. I beleive that in Florida, not too long
	ago, gun laws were relaxed to deter the rising violent 
	crime. It worked, the incidence of violent crime, rape 
	and assault, mugging and murder, went down.

	To combat the same problem many States placed more 
	restrictions on gun ownership, made it harder to get a
	gun. This didn't work, the crime rate continued to 
	escelate.

	This, as far as I know, if fact. Not speculation like 'In
	the UK...' and assuming that similar action will have
	the same aeffect in the US.

	Look at the figures for firearm realted deaths in the 
	United States, at first they'll seem alarmingly high. Of
	course they are. But look beyond that, look at the amount
	of crime commited by people using legally bought and
	owned guns, the very same guns that some people are intent
	on banning, I think you'll find your left with a very
	small number.

	Whatever, I'll get off my soapbox, If people are getting
	tired of this thread maybe it should be taken to mail.
	I'll be more than happy to debate with anyone who doesn't
	share my views...

	ObRaves - Ack, can't say I'm fond of the Faster-Faster
	More-More high BPM stuff, though to each his own and all
	that.

	More later,
	Gary

Well I don't take speed, haven't taken E or A in a couple of months
and don't even use caffine.  Myy energy source come from getting
plenty of exercise, meditation and doing yoga but that's another story.
(Actually for all you crunchies out there, my kundalini is active which
is why I can dance all night without drugs)

The bottom line for me is whether the music sends me into Trance state.
It takes a subtle combination of factors but basically I have to be able
to set up a "standing wave pattern" with the music, my brain/mind and with
my body.  I can't seem to do this if the BPMs are to fast, (I do believe
that you can most likely get there through "pogoing"  though) and for me if I'm
not tranced, I'm not having a good time :)

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep 22 08:25:40 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15258; Wed, 22 Sep 93 08:25:40 PDT
Received: from kestrel.kestrel.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA15251; Wed, 22 Sep 93 08:25:37 PDT
Received: from zeta-soft.com (gyro.slip.netcom.com) by kestrel.kestrel.edu (4.1/SMI-DDN)
	id AA17801; Wed, 22 Sep 93 08:25:32 PDT
Received: by zeta-soft.com (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA20505; Wed, 22 Sep 93 02:14:58 PDT
Date: Wed, 22 Sep 93 02:14:58 PDT
From: "Scott L. Burson" <gyro@zeta-soft.com>
Message-Id: <9309220914.AA20505@zeta-soft.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Sue Raisty's message of Fri, 17 Sep 93 17:58:49 PDT <9309180058.AA02153@berlioz.nsc.com>
Subject: Freedom
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


   Date: Fri, 17 Sep 93 17:58:49 PDT
   From: Sue Raisty  <raisty@berlioz.nsc.com>

   I (susan raisty) said this about the US constitution:
   --> >founded with the purpose to protect the liberties of the people!
   --> >That's why you're supposed to be innocent until proved guilty in
   --> the >US. We have to try to make today's government follow those
   --> principles, >and when we encourage them to take any of our
   --> freedoms away we are >going down the wrong path.


   Then (Jamie 'Bobo' Lawrence) jamiel said this:
   --> I don't want to turn this into a flame war, but I assume that you
   --> agree that changes to the constitution over time makes sense- you
   --> know, things like oh, say, women's right to vote. How about that
   --> bit about people with non-white skin being equal citizens? Things
   --> like that. 

   --> jamiel@sybase.com "Static- It's all just static"- Bryna Bank

   There is a fundamental difference between ammending the constitution
   to allow women and minorities vote and removing an ammendment from the
   bill of rights - the right to bear arms in this case.  One grants MORE
   liberties to the citizens and the other TAKES them away.  

There is a sentence in the Constitution that says, in effect, that the fact
that certain rights are specifically listed does not mean that these are all
the rights we have.  It was clearly the intention of the Founders that future
generations be able to add new rights as necessary.  Somebody here has already
spoken of the right to safety and I agree: I think there is a fundamental
right to be reasonably safe, not only from the government, but from one's
fellow citizens.

Where rights conflict they must be weighed against each other.  I wouldn't
want to suggest that this is an easy or simple process.  Consider for instance
the right to due process of law.  We hold this right very dear -- at least, I
hope we do -- but we say that it is alright for a police officer to shoot
someone in self-defense or defense of others, because if someone is in the
midst of the act of trying to kill people, we consider that the lives of their
potential victims outweigh their right to due process.  I think this is as it
should be.

However, where the right to keep and bear arms conflicts with the right to
reasonable safety, I think things are grossly out of whack.  I think we
greatly overvalue the right to bear arms, which happens to be enumerated in
the Constitution, and devalue the right to safety, which although it is not
mentioned specifically there is arguably still a right.  (Well, some would
argue that there isn't actually any conflict -- "guns don't kill people,
people kill people" -- but I think that is ridiculous, just like the tobacco
industry forever trying to argue that smoking has no negative health
consequences.)

Anyway, the point of all this is that there can be justification for
curtailing one right if it collides with another.

The other funny thing about the Second Amendment, of course, is the
justification within its wording.  [Roughly] "A well-prepared militia being
essential to the security of a free people, the right to keep and bear arms
shall not be infringed."  It is a little hard to argue (though some, of
course, do) that that justification did not become obsolete at least 50 years
ago.  The Founders did not conceive of tanks, fighter planes, helicopter
gunships, or nuclear weapons.  Or teenage gang violence, or carjackings.

I'm not calling for that amendment to be deleted entirely, but I do urge and
hope that it will be interpreted in a different light.

-- Scott

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep 22 08:42:38 1993

trouble.  The fact that I have been to enough parties to tell WHAT type of
party I am attending does not make me a cop.  If you like to be completely

Thanks for your input, Gary.

I only want to say three more things about all this.  They're just data
points, I don't want to give any opinion on gun guntrol.

1.  By far the most people killed by handguns in america are killed by
    their own or an associate's handgun.  The FBI published statistics
    on this. 

2.  In your own home you are at a tremendous advantage against an
    intruder.  They have (likely) never been there before.
    Additionally, other weapons can be as or more effective in these
    circumstances.  And after all, do you really want to go around
    shooting guns in your own house?  You may hit your family.

3.  I live in a neighborhood where it's not uncommon to hear gunfire a
    a couple nights a week.  I'm still certain that the danger to me
    would be greater if I was armed with a gun, and I've been trained
    to use them.   If two or three guys jump you and you have a gun,
    likely you might get one of them before the others take your gun
    and shoot you.  That's something most people don't consider when
    getting a gun;  Once you have one, it becomes your responsibility 
    to defend not only yourself but also the weapon.  And to do that
    someone is going to get hurt.


Just some thoughts,

-H-

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep 22 09:53:52 1993

	id AA21289; Wed, 22 Sep 93 09:53:41 -0700
Message-Id: <9309221653.AA21289@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Wed, 22 Sep 1993 09:53:40 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: hardcore defined (an attempt)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

John S. Lee gives us a definition of hardcore:
>When I say hardcore
>I mean 140+ BPM (150 is more like it).

This is a good starting definition.  Speed is only one component of the 
definition of hardcore, and just because something is 150+ it doesn't 
automatically make it hardcore.

Hardcore is characterized by a distorted and reverberating 909 kick drum
running at 140 BPM or faster in 4/4 time.  A sort of scrapey hi-hat rides 
on top of the kick line.  Since just about every track copies this, this 
formulation is the basis for the hardcore sound (and the resulting 
observations that all hardcore sounds the same -- if it didnt' sound like
this then it wouldn't be called hardcore :-) ).  Other elements of the 
hardcore sound include use of minor keys, reverberation, and sudden short 
breaks where a vocal sample is dropped in.  This produces an over all "dark" 
effect, much like one finds in "industrial-dance" music, like Front 242.  

Not much of this music is being made these days, by the way.  And it seems
that the people who are making it (Lenny Dee in New York, the PCD collective
in Germany) are getting SO hard with the tracks that you can't really even
call it music anymore (not that it isn't fun to dance to occaisonally, 
though, but I do prefer some music mixed in with my music, so I pass on these).

Many other tracks come out regularly that run faster than 150 bpm but would
never be considered hardcore.  For anyone who heard me in SF, I played a
track a few times that had a sort of muted drum line and was punctuated by
the loon sample from 808 State's "Pacific" and a voice going "increase the
voltage."  This track is 158 bpm, and is a good example of what I mean
by fast stuff that isn't hardcore.  We don't really know *what* to call it,
as labels are having less and less meanings these days as the music drifts
from the definitions that gelled in the summer of 1992.  Similarly, while I 
was in Los Angeles I bought two EPs, one very trancy and one rather acidy,
and the bpms on these ranged from 160 to 171.  Neither of them are 
recognizable as hardcore, though.

Laura

Roy:
>  gwh> It's not such a pretty friendly world out there.  That's sad,
>  gwh> but that's reality 8-(.
>
>But that's a cop out answer.  DO you want to change things?

No, it's not a cop-out.  It's reality.

Of course I want it to change for the better.  In order: I think
that the war on drugs, which is making drug-dealing profitable
enough to kill over, should be stopped immediately (and the
stuff should be legalized, probably); I think that the kids
growing up in Oakland, in New York, in Detroit, the ones who
see no future except being murdered in street violence, have
to be saved and given something good to live for.

I honestly think that "gun control" in any form will be unable
to reduce the level of violence in America any significant
amount.  I also very deeply feel that the two above changes,
about evenly, will cut out nearly all of what's driving american
violence.  Guns aren't it.  The kids who grow up and end up
believing that killing is natural are the problem.  We've lost
more than a generation to that attitude... and they're going
to haunt us for the next 50 years, whether we reform now or not.

-george william herbert

Sean spouts: 
> You know, I thought I had gotten away from that "I'm better than you I
> know it all I'm cool I dance better than you I'm in I've seen it all
> You're all wrong I'm right why don't you worship me while you're at it"
> attitude when I graduated from high school. I _really_ thought I had
> escaped it when I found the SF house movement, with its profound
> acceptance and positive outlook.

It's a matter of degree Sean.  We can't spend every moment of our lives
at YSH.  And the things we feel at those special House Scene moments
don't always gel with the rest of our day-to-day experiences.  For example,
This latest post of yours doesn't show much profound acceptance and
positive outlook toward the way John S. Lee expresses himself.
 
> Okay, John, you're the coolest person in SF. You dance better than
> Brian or anyone else on sfraves. You know more about music than anyone
> else here, even the ones with 2000 CDs and even the DJs. You know
> who's cool and who's not, and you're able to walk into a place and
> immediately sort them out. [rest of tirade deleted]

I think we have to cut each other a bit more slack when interpreting
attitudes from Internet postings.  Sure, John may come across a bit caustic
at times, just like many of *my* postings are exercises in pretentiousness.
All that really matters is that some useful information gets shared that
is somewhat pertinant to the general focus of this mailing list.  I'll be
the first to admit that according to most of society's criteria, most
ravers, myself included, are pretty lame dancers.  It doesn't really
matter, but there's nothing wrong with making such an observation, even
if it's only an opinion.  All I ask from John is that he not point at me 
and laugh out loud when he sees me dancing.  In fact, my guess is that 
when the music's pumpin', the energy's flowin', and John and I are dancing 
next to each other, the last thing on his mind is my style of dance.  
Unless I bump into him, of course :-)

> Are you from New York? Or perhaps LA?

I'm from New York.  What does *that* have to do with anything - YOU STUPID
FUCKING ASSHOLE!!  :-)  :-)  :-)    

- leg of eel

Subject: Re: 190 Huh again
Reply-To: rslau@usc.edu
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

   Date: Tue, 21 Sep 93 19:40:46 -0700
   From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)

   The 140+ BPM has, IMO, run it's course here.  The people who have attended
   these events have been mostly amped up on speed...I've seen 'em.  There is
   little you can do with your body at those speeds otehr than the arrythmic
   "pogo" dance.  And speed is great for that type of twitchyness.

I don't think anybody can claim that an entire city no longer likes a
certain style of music, or anything thing else for that matter.  All you
can legitimately say is that the crowd *you* associate with no longer likes
hardcore.  Living isn't about blindly following trends.  If you like a
particular style of music, does the fact that nobody does make it any less
appealing to you?  It shouldn't.

I happen to love 180+ bpm, and I can do more than 'pogo'.  I've never
dropped, done lines, popped, shot up, etc but I can still feel the raw
energy in hardcore.  But, I also happen to like trance, country, house,
wailing divas, metal and practically every other form of music under the
sun.  You can't condemn or in any way slander a DJ for not playing only
what *you* as an individual want to hear.  DJ's want to make you happy but
there are hundreds of other people in the room who are not clones of you.
Even your closest friends have slightly different musical tastes than you.

Diversity not conformity.
All i can say is, open your ears and your mind and enjoy...

-robert

This week's SF Bay Guardian has a story on the cabaret law fight on
page 12 ('Footloose' law gets workout from S.F.Cops).  I'm not
going to type it in, but it contains some information which has not
been seen in previous postings, so it's worth picking up (read the
story on the Raker Act and public power in SF while you're at it :) ).

Supervisor Hallinan's quote: "People 18 to 21 can be on the
streets legally after 2 a.m.  Why shouldn't they be able to stay
inside licensed cabarets without alcohol?"

Quote by Bill Moratta of Neighbors United: "The Board of Supervisors
should not be encouraging 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds to hang out in
discos.  It is not OK to hang out all night."

******************************************************************************
The next hearing on the issue is at the Public Safety Committee's
September 28th meeting at 10 a.m. in City Hall.
******************************************************************************

If you can't make it, call the other supervisors on the committee
(Susan Leal and Kevin Shelley, I believe) to register your opinion.
Susie has their phone numbers, I think - can you post them again,
Susie?

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

To: csc@pilot.njin.net, uunet!harlequin.co.uk!roy@uunet.UU.NET
Subject: Re: Gun control
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


 All I'm trying to argue is that the
*problem* is gun ownership.  I don't know how to solve that problem.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
No roy!  Criminals are the problem and the ones that use guns to commit 
crime should be put away for ever!  If you magicly eliminated criminals
there would be no crime but there would still be use for guns, i.e., 
hunting, target shooting, and historic memorabilia.  Criminals are THE
problem.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Put it another way.  If you introduced gun control, and then magically
confiscated all the guns in circulation, do you think that would
work...?  Yep, people would still be able to get hold of guns smuggled
into the country on the black market, but the numbers would be
small....
----------------------------------------------------------------------
No again.  The nubers would not be small.  It was just announced that
despite all efforts, there is as much or more cocaine comming into our
country as ever before.  Why would illegal guns be different?
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Now in reality, achieving low gun ownership is hard, because of the
number of guns in circulation.  I accept that in a society where all
the criminals have guns, gun control laws may actually make things
worse.  But do you at least accept that gun ownership is a *problem*,
and that the *goal* should be to work towards a society where guns are
unusual, both amongst honest citizens, and amongst criminals.

Or is the idea of a non-gun-owning society just not the american way...
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Yes and No.  In ideal society there would be no existence of guns but 
by the selfish nature of criminals they will use what is available to
them to further their plans.  Since guns can be imported and made,
there is no chance of a gunless society.  Unfortuneatly, as long as
there are criminals there will be guns.  As someone else pointed out,
it's time to go deeper and try to eliminate the need for people to 
commit crime.  That means closing the gap between haves and havenots,
and the haves will never go for it.

-Mark

Howard says:
> By far the most people killed by handguns in america are killed by
    their own or an associate's handgun.  The FBI published statistics
    on this.

I would be willing to bet that this is an ACCIDENTAL gun death statistic.
Sit for a minute and think about how often you hear about this kind of
unfortunate incicent and then compare it to how often you see/hear/read
about people being robbed and shot by strangers with a strange gun.  It
just doesn't add up.

> In your own home you are at a tremendous advantage against an
    intruder.  They have (likely) never been there before.
    Additionally, other weapons can be as or more effective in these
    circumstances.  And after all, do you really want to go around
    shooting guns in your own house?  You may hit your family.

That advantage would be instently equalized if they had a gun and you
didn't.  I have a family and am about to purchase a firearm for home
protection upon my gun-hating girlfriends request.  The news finaly
got to her.  Of course we will both take a gun-safety course and would
obviosly not shoot at an intruder while they were in the vicinity of
the kids.  The point is with a gun WE would be in control or at least
not as out of control as if the intruder had a gun and we didn't.  That
person is more likely to shoot us or the kids than we would be.

>I live in a neighborhood where it's not uncommon to hear gunfire a
    a couple nights a week.  I'm still certain that the danger to me
    would be greater if I was armed with a gun, and I've been trained
    to use them.   If two or three guys jump you and you have a gun,
    likely you might get one of them before the others take your gun
    and shoot you.  That's something most people don't consider when
    getting a gun;  Once you have one, it becomes your responsibility
    to defend not only yourself but also the weapon.  And to do that
    someone is going to get hurt.

You'd have to be STUPID to attack someone with a gun, especialy if they
just shot your accomplice and most criminals aren't stupid.  Anywone
reading this will verify, when someone has a gun pointed at you, you
do just about anything they say (exception:  You are a woman and someone
is trying to kidnap you from a public place.  If you run you might get
away or you might get shot (unlikely, according to statistics).  If you
cooperate you will probably be shot anyway after many horrible things
are done to you or you won't be shot after many horrible things are done
to you.)

Have a nice day.

-Mark

Mark Guthrie sez:
> 
> Howard says:
> > By far the most people killed by handguns in america are killed by
>     their own or an associate's handgun.  The FBI published statistics
>     on this.
> 
> I would be willing to bet that this is an ACCIDENTAL gun death statistic.

No, I believe it's total gun related deaths.  Domestic violence is a major
contributor, and that's not accidental.  

> 
> You'd have to be STUPID to attack someone with a gun, especialy if they
> just shot your accomplice and most criminals aren't stupid.  Anywone

So you plan on walking around with a gun in your hand?  Otherwise, how will
anyone know you have one until you try to use it?

Say 4 guys decide they'd like your wallet.  The smartest thing to do
would be to give it to them, and maybe take a couple punches.
Unfortunately, if a gun comes out (either you pull it out or you drop
it whilst being punched) the whole situation changes.  If you're
lucky, they'll simply steal your gun.  If not, someone's going to get
hurt pretty bad.

It's easier than you think to disarm someone.  Especially if you
outnumber them.  That's what I meant by 'you might get one of them
before they take your gun and shoot you'.  The point is, the gun is
only going to come into play AFTER you are attacked and people are
close enough to touch (i.e. disarm) you.  Unless, of course, you plan
to go on the offensive :-)

None of that, of course, applies to home defense.  


-H-

>No, I believe it's total gun related deaths.  Domestic violence is a major

No, gun homicides by strangers are about eight times as prevalent as
all domestic homicides.

>The point is, the gun is
>only going to come into play AFTER you are attacked and people are
>close enough to touch (i.e. disarm) you.  Unless, of course, you plan
>to go on the offensive :-)

If you're sufficiently situationally aware, you can tell something
is going to go down before anyone's that close, and this is more
important than being armed.  Once you know something is starting to
happen, or may start to happen, you have an edge... few attackers
want to go after an alerted victim.  Let them know you know what's
going on, establish eye contact, they usually decide to drop the
issue.

-george

good look around, and try to get a feel for the place that I'm at, but for
the most part I am there to enjoy myslef, and dance along with everyone
else.  I don't point fingies at people and say, "look at that guy".  I'm
usually soooo baked I could care less.  But you gotta admit, there are some
winners!  (Like waaay back there was some guy who use to walk around with
this HUGE stick, and would dance with it.  Pretty cool, but when you see it
in the morning, and that damn stick is still bobbing up and down ON THE
BEAT, and the dude is still going off like it's  2:00 a.m. all you can say
is WINNER).  Hell, there are a lot of funny people at parties, the funniest
ones of late are the ones who take their shit sooooo seriously.  GK had a
few of 'em. 

So I was upstairs, and I saw these two really nice looking girls and this,
uh, "gigger".  You've all HAD to have seen him once or twice.  He usually
has a buddy, and they dress alike (Black/White short sleeve shirt, nice cut
baggie pants, really clean looking, and there to put on the show!).  So
they were all on the beanbags doing dance stretching excercises.  Once they
were all stretched out they got up, started hoofing, and proceeded down the
stairs for the main event.  Now that was funny, and to me, they can dance! 
A bit too serious for my tastes, but then again, aren't we all at times.

boggling!  He's a really nice guy, and can fuck it up 2 boot.

when he hit the decks.  He spun some shit that put my ass into Monday of
next week.  Played some really depp, acidic groviness that was quite
coherent.  A full set with full tunes.  Rick's the man!

remained silent).  He is not one of my favorite DJ's, but HE SURE IS NOW!

really comes out with the trnsacidwarpdrivefuckyourbrain set.  Ernie is
dangerous, when he and Markie team up, it is, in a word LETHAL!


Boogie:  I was so out of it, I stayed for 1.5 hours, got to hear my man
Harry Who do the do (he is the morning man 4 me), and went home.

	id AA02224; Wed, 22 Sep 93 18:27:49 -0700
Date: Wed, 22 Sep 93 18:27:49 -0700
Message-Id: <9309230127.AA02224@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Contest, sorry butts stay home!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

I am sick and tired of ALL of you SFRavers talking about BPM's and DANCING.
 Look, for once and for all, back your shit up!

I propose a FINAL word on this by hosting an official SFR Dance Contest Called:
"The Hoofs on The Other Foot" or "Trip Your Feet to Thee Beet".
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

                                PRESENTING
                                 The 1993
                               Hoofer's Ball
                        "Trip Your Feet to Thee Beet"

             brought to you by Dead Horse Productions & Palmolive


The contest rules are as follows:

1.  You must be able to move your feet in rapid succession, to a beat of no
less than 124BPM, no more than 145BPM, on time and TO THE BEAT!

Anyone caught missing a beat will be carried off the dancefloor. Shoes will
be confiscated so that they may go to the winner!

2. You must be able to do various forms of "catching air".  Points will be
given for the "Box-Air-Step", "Super-Betty Strut", and "Acid-Salsa" moves. 
Anything extra wins a bonus.  When performing these steps you MUST get at
leat 2-3 inces of air between your feet and the dancefloor (that means BOTH
feet and the dancefloor).

 Pogoing means INSTANT disqualification.  Feet never leaving the ground,
Instant disqualification.  Shoes will be confiscated so that they may go to
the winner!

3.  Arms must be in "harmony" with the music and the feet.  None of this
rock-and-roll-beat-the-drums-jerky-arms-bullshit.  The body must be in
complete concert, so keep the herky-jerky @ home!  Arms outstretched for
"Acid-Salsa", and arms in walking fashion ala "Super-Betty Strut" are ok. 
Bonus points for more fluid motion. Vogueing is OK, as long as you rep. a
house, and catch air during at least 1 pose.

 Anyone violating this will be disqualified. Shoes will be confiscated so
that they may go to the winner!

4.Stretching must be done, BEFORE you get on the dancefloor.  Any YOGA
moves means instant disqualification, unless you have cuaght air in the
process of making such moves!

5.  Dance teams are allowed, but if done you MUST match in dress, completely.

6.  Hands to the side (like doin the German Lederhosen deal), are OK.  As
long as your feet are moving to the music.

No cardboard will be provided for this event, so bring your own.

Smoking, drug-taking, speed, hallucinogens, are encouraged since this
contest will last for approx 10 hours.  Water provided by Evian.

The winner will be judged by a well known House personality, to be named at
a later date  (hell, at least I know 'em).

The Grand Pize:  Bragging Rights (they don't give no trophies for dancing @
raves), and all of the Losers sweaty shoes!

Runner-Ups:  There are no runner up's at raves.  Go home!
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Entry fee is $20.  Door charge is $10.  Trophy fee is $35.  Evian water (by
the bottle) is $6.  Backpack OK as long as you have no water in them.

Let me know if you are interested, since applications are already being
accepted.

I for one have already sent in my $71!  So if you're man or woman enough to
challenge me...forget the threats, I'll see you on the dancefloor!


Only the headstrong,
John S. Lee  

- Cool guy, Dance King, Mr. House Manners '93, and the Untimate Insider.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Sep 22 18:45:33 1993

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Gang viol., gun cont., etc.etc.... 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 22 Sep 93 12:31:10 PDT."
             <9309221931.AA25467@koko.csustan.edu> 
Date: Wed, 22 Sep 93 18:45:56 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

From: hsarbaz@koko.csustan.edu (Hoss Sarbaz):
> If kids picck uup violence in early age what keeps us from teaching them that 
> violence is bad at   the same time rather than wait till they are  older and more
> violent. 
> ...
> So lets start  to program children as soon as they are able to learn and lets 
> break the fucked up standards we grew up during our school years.

A while back, John S Lee posted something about gangsta rap music, and I
believe he concluded that violent lyrics should not be censored. I wanted
to respond then, but I got too busy. Now I'll respond to both Hoss and
John...

I think violence in the media should be disallowed and censored, much in
the way that sexuality currently is. And I also agree with the current
movement in the US government to censor violence on TV and in the movies
and in music too.

At least in old school rap you'd just get people talking about their dick
size, their cars, how many women they've slept with, and their status.
Nothing really out of the ordinary -- people have been doing that for some
time, and i have nothing against it (in fact, i prefer a lot of old school
rap to the new stuff).

Now people rap about killing anybody who gets in their way, anybody that
disses them. Anybody that even disagrees w/ them. All in the name of being
"hard" "tough" and "gangsta". I've heard all the arguments pro/con, and I
don't think that's the way kids should be socialized. (the usual response
is "we're not violent/racist/sexist, we're just reflecting the reality that
is around us"...  WRONGO...  you're gloryfying it & gloryfying the
lifestyle thereby creating more violence -- a vicious cycle. 

The problem is the media. People no longer socialize people, the media does
it for us. It is the great brainwasher/parent/teacher/babysitter, but it is
teaching us lies & bullshit. Parents today for the most part are too busy
just trying to keep up with the joneses (or at least paying the bills) to
have any time to spend with their kids. So kids are educated and socialized
by TV and movies. No more sitting around with the family by candlelight and
telling stories to each other, no more imagination.

That, and stupid violent video games. Little kids (esp. boys) have always
been into mock-warriorhood. But they did it with mock war equipment.
Nowadays, kids know how to "kill" (at least virtually) before they know how
to ride a bike. ANd in graphic detail too. Nothing left to the imagination.

SO if you really want to change the world, start by promoting media that
doesn't show that easy solutions arise from acts of violence. Make 
violence unfashionable and uncool.

If people are upset by an erosion of rights caused by my proposed
censorship, then perhaps we should replace all TV violence with nudity and
sexuality on TV.  (Tit for tat, literally... :-). Go to south-or-central
america, or even many european coountries, and the UK, and you'll see full
frontal nudity all over the media (and on many beaches). It hasn't exactly
caused an erosion of moral values, but at the same time you don't get
people gunning down kids in schoolyards either.

This being a protestant country, we can't show natural (or "unnatural",
whatever that is) acts of sexuality, nor the beauty of the human body
without clothes. But we can show the insides of a body being ripped out,
bullets shredding flesh and death and mayhem. What's wrong with this
picture? Is this the way that good protestants act out their sexual
repression?

Given kids exposure to such artificial media socialization and the violent
dominator-society values promoted by those media... well, it's no wonder
we're seeing the kind of bullshit we're seeing.

PS-to-appease-ye-libertarians: I don't like the idea of censorship at all,
because of the fascist possibilities it entails. However, given that
violence is so fashionable, something needs to be done.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (JUMP IN THE FIRE)
Message-Id: <9309230528.AA03025@curly.agames.com>
Subject: Violence, rights, responsibility
To: netcom!mayer@netcom.com (Niels P. Mayer)
Date: Wed, 22 Sep 93 22:28:00 PDT
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: <9309230145.AA16018@netcom6.netcom.com>; from "Niels P. Mayer" at Sep 22, 93 6:45 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


This is my last word on these subjects.  Read it carefully.  I have no
more to say.  I'm out of words.  Stick a fork in me, baby, I'm done.

Neils: I still believe you have the wrong solution to the right problem.

> I think violence in the media should be disallowed and censored, much in
> the way that sexuality currently is. And I also agree with the current
> movement in the US government to censor violence on TV and in the movies
> and in music too.

So what makes you any different or better than Tipper Gore and the PMRC?
The fact that you might actually listen to records before censoring their
content?  Censorship = censorship = censorship, no matter which way you
slice it, and you'll find a lot more people wanting to censor the things
you value than the things you abjure.  Best to step out of that
shouting match altogether and work on a real solution.

> At least in old school rap you'd just get people talking about their dick
> size, their cars, how many women they've slept with, and their status.
> Nothing really out of the ordinary -- people have been doing that for some
> time, and i have nothing against it (in fact, i prefer a lot of old school
> rap to the new stuff).
> 
> Now people rap about killing anybody who gets in their way, anybody that
> disses them. Anybody that even disagrees w/ them. All in the name of being
> "hard" "tough" and "gangsta". I've heard all the arguments pro/con, and I
> don't think that's the way kids should be socialized. (the usual response
> is "we're not violent/racist/sexist, we're just reflecting the reality that
> is around us"...  WRONGO...  you're gloryfying it & gloryfying the
> lifestyle thereby creating more violence -- a vicious cycle. 

You're sounding like your parents.  "Elvis' upper body was OK, but his
*pelvis* -- that's going way too far."

For anything you ever say, you can find _someone_ in the US who will
swear to their death that it should be censored.  Once you step on
that slippery slope of legislating moral judgements, you're riding it
to the bottom, where lies eventual fascism and/or violent revolution.

> The problem is the media. People no longer socialize people, the media does
> it for us. It is the great brainwasher/parent/teacher/babysitter, but it is
> teaching us lies & bullshit. Parents today for the most part are too busy
> just trying to keep up with the joneses (or at least paying the bills) to
> have any time to spend with their kids. So kids are educated and socialized
> by TV and movies. No more sitting around with the family by candlelight and
> telling stories to each other, no more imagination.

So don't let them be socialized by the media!  Repeat after me: "I will
not demand that others fix my problems."

> That, and stupid violent video games. Little kids (esp. boys) have always
> been into mock-warriorhood. But they did it with mock war equipment.
> Nowadays, kids know how to "kill" (at least virtually) before they know how
> to ride a bike. ANd in graphic detail too. Nothing left to the imagination.

And a Nintendo is more real than a toy gun?  Kids are inexperienced, but
they're not stupid.  Give them some credit.

> SO if you really want to change the world, start by promoting media that
> doesn't show that easy solutions arise from acts of violence. Make 
> violence unfashionable and uncool.

May the Prince of Lies, Indulgence, and Rash Actions forever protect
me from people who want to change the world to their own liking.  If
the path you have taken looks right to me, I may follow you.  If you
come at me with a leash, I'll bite your hand off.

> Go to south-or-central
> america, or even many european coountries, and the UK, and you'll see full
> frontal nudity all over the media (and on many beaches). It hasn't exactly
> caused an erosion of moral values, but at the same time you don't get
> people gunning down kids in schoolyards either.

Sure you do.  Usually government death squads, though, and with much more
regularity than the occasional deranged killers we get here.

We, as a society, fear unpredictability more than violence.  If a government
goes around killing people, that's OK, because that's what a government
does, and we understand.  But when some random person decides to freak out,
so do we, because it doesn't fit into our conditioning that everything 
should be predictable even at the price of our liberty.

> This being a protestant country, we can't show natural (or "unnatural",
> whatever that is) acts of sexuality, nor the beauty of the human body
> without clothes. But we can show the insides of a body being ripped out,
> bullets shredding flesh and death and mayhem. What's wrong with this
> picture? Is this the way that good protestants act out their sexual
> repression?

Yes.  The solution is to legalize both.  I'd rather watch sex than violence
any day, and so do most people, but if all you can get is violence, then
you take it.  Of course, I'd rather have sex than watch it, but my point
stands.

> PS-to-appease-ye-libertarians: I don't like the idea of censorship at all,
> because of the fascist possibilities it entails. However, given that
> violence is so fashionable, something needs to be done.

Like become fascist?  Oops.  "We will stop at nothing to achieve our
goal of moderation!"

Your feelings of guilt do not excuse your actions in any way.  I am
not appeased.  (I'm not a libertarian, either: I'm an anarchist.)

Why does everybody think that the solution to problems always lies with
everybody else?  Change yourself first!  Otherwise all your strong talk
is worth nothing.

Everyone is always telling me how I ought to be protected from this, and
ought to not hear about that, and ought to do this, and blah, blah, blah.
I will indulge myself with a little hostility towards these people:

MAY YOU BE CURSED WITH BOSSES THAT TREAT YOU THE WAY YOU WOULD OTHERS.

Hmm.  That's already happened.  (As the house nation's brushes with 
the law suggest.)

FUCK OFF!  (Maybe you could use a good fuck.  I know I could.)

GET THEE BEHIND ME, BONEHEAD!  Ia Ia!  Cthulhu fhtagn!  Io Pan Io Pan Pan!
Shemhamforash!  Booga-booga-booga!

Sheesh.  I'm going to go ride my bike at 500 miles an hour until I can't
move my legs.  Then I'm going to crank Ministry at 120 dB until I go deaf
or the police come.  Be thankful I don't just kill you all.  Send me $20
now to avoid your grisly fate.  Just put a 29c stamp on the bill and
address it to "God".  Drop it in the nearest mailbox.  It'll get there.

"Better that all mankind should perish than one free man should refrain
 from any action that occurs to him"	-Freddie Nietszche

// g

(OK, it's a paraphrase.  Don't sue me, find the original.  The point stands.)

Dear friends,

I wanted to take this opportunity to personally invite all of you to Home,
this Saturday, the 25th of September. It's the first big party I've done,
and me and my partner Mark Norby (of Tilt-a-Whirl) have really strived to
integrate all of the concerns that we as sfr have raised and discussed over
our time together into a really great party.

  the party will be 18+
  there will not be too much smoke
  there will be free water
  the party will be reasonably priced
  etc.

Also,it's very important to Mark and I that house music, raves etc. be more
that just a great party. Towards this end, 15% of any profit from this Home
and any future Homes will go to Bay Area homeless children in the name of
the Bay Area House Movement. A full financial disclosure will follow the
party...

Too, in many ways this is an sfr production: I'm promoting, Markie is
spinning, and Tony and Synergy will be providing visuals...

Because we feel this way, we would like to offer all sfravers and their SOs
a $3 discount at the door, bringing the total cost down to $12, a great value
I assure you. Just give us the address of sfraves
(sfraves@techno.stanford.edu) at the door to receive your discount. And
*Please* use this only for yourself and one SO  :)

As a reminder, the lineup is as follows:

Markie
Jon Williams
Simon (UK)
DRC (of YSH fame)
Galen 
Jordan (fresno)

Visuals by
Synergy
Liquid Sircus Delights

Audio by
Sound Vision

The party will be in San Francisco!  :)
Call 415.647.4788 for more info.

I really look forward to seing you all there!
love ya
ethan

PS: if anyone is interested in doing an sfr info table or a vrave terminal,
plz contact me ASAP...

Neils says: I don't like the idea of censorship at all,
because of the fascist possibilities it entails. However, given that
violence is so fashionable, something needs to be done.

I agree. I beleive censorship is not democratic, but I also think censorship is
necessary in certain issues such as showing violence to children, censoring 
preaching prejudice and violence on rap or what have you, etc. This type of 
censorship is acceptable for the good of mankind (who knows mabe your own when
walking from your car to the rave party in "bad terf"). The censorship I am 
talkng about (and probably Neils) is the kind that only restricts children from
buying certain stuff, and not every single individual regardless of age.

Once a child is taught right from wrong and has his moral, social, and humane
values imprinted in his or her brain than there would be no threat of brainwashing
 them or detering them from what they beleive what is wrong and right regardless 
of what violence they are exposed to through the media and/or audio.

I mean we were all taught not to kill or be violent and we are all exposed to 
violence, but because we have our values imprinted in our heads we are not 
subject to carry out those acts regardless of how much we are exposed to it.
Most of the time we do not even bother exposing ourselves to violence that is 
exceedingly bloody.

If you ask me, movie producers would make more money if they concentrated more
on disney movies or the such than if they did in violent movies. Look at all the
movies that came out and make big bucks, many of them has violence but there 
were a few that didn't or at least had acceptable violence. Now if the actors
were not the hippocrits that they are they would have refused to do violent films
and turn the movie industry market around by making movies acceptalbe by all 
audiences, and make more money to make them fat and hearty for the big meal.


Hoss

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 23 Sep 1993 11:51:52 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: What SFRaves Means To Me
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>From one Brian to another, I hear ya man.

Usually when I post to SFRaves, I post as me, bbehlen, one of 277 list members.
Now, though, I want to speak as the SFRaves sysadmin, the guy who started the
list, the guy who runs it, and the one ultimately responsible for the traffic
it generates.

1) The gun control thread has simply gone on too long.  This is a very
emotional issue, and certainly an important issue these days, but
SFRaves is NOT an appropriate forum for discussion.  The thread should
have been taken to email or to a more appropriate mailing list or
newsgroup LONG AGO.  Usually I'm fairly leniant about off-topic posts
every once in awhile, but even I stopped reading this thread about 3
days ago.  This is not a suggestion, this is a REQUEST.

2) It takes all kinds of people to make the world go round.  And there
are going to be some people who have strong opinions and are always
willing to defend them.  Ask me about nitrous, or ask me about a
select number of other things, and I'll argue till I'm blue in the
face about them.  What I'm asking all you you to realize (as most of you
pretty much have) is that there are some people whose style of writing
makes those opinions sound like facts; so when you see posts from them,
giving them the benefit of the doubt and injecting "In My Humble Opinion"
clauses and "I believe" clauses here and there will do a world of good.
Learn to see through their words and try and see if you can decode what
they're really trying to get at.  

Okay, that's all for now.  Music, maestro, hit it!

	Brian
