From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Repost of SFR Guidelines
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 23 Sep 93 13:26:18 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


Here's the posting guidelines that Brian sent out several months
ago.  It's worth re-reading as a refresher every once in a while
(even if you think you already know what it says).


Message-Id: <9305042003.AA14014@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 4 May 1993 13:03:28 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: GUIDELINES FOR POSTING TO SFRAVES
Status: RO

Some guidelines for posting to SFRaves.   Print this out and tape it to
your computer for handy reference.  This list will be given to all new
members from now on.

1)  First realize that

	a) SFRaves is a large mailing list.

	b) The volume is already quite high.

	c) For every editorial or opinion there are hundreds of
	   possible replies.

	d) Topics of world import such as feminism and race relations
	   will *always* be with us, at least for the current generation,
	   and while discussion about them is important the issues *won't*
	   be resolved by just talking about them here on the list.  They
	   are appropriate here as long as they aren't more appropriate
	   in soc.feminism, etc.

	e) Ego has NO PLACE on the mailing list.

	f) Even with a high signal-to-noise ratio, a high volume means more
	   people skim articles than actually read them.  This is a bad thing.

2)  Now for the general rules:

	a) NO PERSONAL ATTACKS - even if someone is being a complete
	   jerk and everyone agrees, please refrain from flaming him/her
	   in public.  Send him/her all the private email you want.  If
	   they flame you first, be the wise one and take the argument
	   off the list.  If he/she is truely being a jerk everyone knows
	   it anyways.  The difference between a well-reasoned argument
	   and a personal flame should be quite clear.

	b) Try and set an upper limit to your number of posts to 2 a day.
	   Making more is fine, but as you're typing your third make *sure*
	   it's something that's worth the time of the 250 people you are
	   sending it to.

	c) BREVITY IS THE SOUL OF WIT.  Paragraphs prove you have a point.

	d) Ranting is the opposite of raving (thanks to rth@netcom.com for
	   reminding us)

	e) Don't reply to a post until you have read your entire mail
	   queue and made sure no one else has replied exactly what you
	   would say.

	f) Refrain from making "me too" posts, where you simply add "I agree"
	   to the bottom of a quoted message.

	g) If you reply to a post someone makes, READ EVERY WORD THEY SAY
	   CAREFULLY, and in the absence of facial and hand gestures interpret
	   their comments in the best possible light.  It's very hard for the
	   "TV" generation (which we are whther you own a TV or not) to know
	   how to communicate without visual cues.  Make sure you understand
	   what the other person is saying.  

	h) If a conversation turns into a particulary heated argument, wait
	   at least an hour before making your reply, to allow you to see 
	   what they are saying in the absence of a testosterone rush.

	i) Be SURE of what you are saying when you say it.  Proofread your
	   comments several times.  Make sure your use of certain words is
	   the generally accepted use by the community at large, not what
	   *you* think that usage should implicate.


We are at the brink of something BIG here, and SFRaves can be a part of
it.  But only if we keep ourselves as high quality as we've been in the
past, and these guidelines are a part of it.  Anyone who's spent a good
deal of time on the net knows these as part of an unwritten policy, but
they bear repeated for those who are new.  

The Conciousness Revolution has begun.

	Brian


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
Subject: This Week's SF Rave Guide!
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFRaves)
Date: Thu, 23 Sep 93 13:58:38 PDT
Cc: sfraves-calendar@techno.Stanford.EDU (SFR Calendar)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL0]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



The important news this week is the upcoming hearing on the proposed
amendment to allow 18-20-year-olds into dance clubs in SF after 2am.
So if you are under 21, or if you have friends that are under 21, or
as long as you believe that it should be OK for 21-- people to dance
after 2am, it's IMPORTANT that you make your voice heard.  In city
politics it's much easier to have a big impact.

So go to the hearing at the Public Safety Committee meeting on Tuesday
morning at City Hall (details in the listings), or call the
supervisors on the committee (Supervisor Susan Leal 415.554.6644,
Supervisor Kevin Shelley 415.544.4005, Supervisor Hallinan
415.554.5184) to voice your opinion.  Believe it or not, there are
powerful opponents on this issue, so your input is crucial!  See the
article in the Bay Guardian for more details on the issue itself.

Now for the fun stuff.  HOME sounds like the big winner this weekend,
it's got SFR's fingerprints all over it. :)  But that's not all!
Tonight there's Your Sisters' House again and a new party, Delusions of
Grandeur; Corduroy City and Mission Rock on Friday, MESS also on 
Saturday.  All this, not for $99.95, not for $49.95, but only $34.95!
But wait!  On Sunday, we throw in the XLSF party for free!  Don't
hesitate, call those info numbers now!  Yes now!

debatable, but they were advertised by flyers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their appropriateness 
in being on the list, let me know.  Also let me know when any of them stop...

Hey,

I sent the following letter to the pres and vice-pres, outlining my disfavor
with the Clipper Chip/Skipjack "encryption with a trap door" proposed
policy.  I find that it compromises the privacy of law-abiding people and
that a trustworthy "escrow agency" is realistically impossible to find
and maintain in this age of Watergate, Iran-Contra-Gate, the S&L Scam,
and most importantly, the Inslaw Software Affair, which involved the 
use or mis-use of just such a trap door by none other than the Justice
Dept. itself!!  You are free to copy my letter, and/or change it to
suit your own position on this, but I  urge that you make your opinion
heard while there is still time and before policy becomes set in stone.

YOU MAY NOW RETURN TO YOUR REGULARLY SCHEDULED PROGRAM...


*


----- Begin Included Message -----

From hart@ntmtv Thu Sep 23 13:26:27 1993
Return-Path: <hart@ntmtv>
Received: from ntmtv.bnr.ca by nmtvs313.mtvyp (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04980; Thu, 23 Sep 93 13:26:25 PDT
Received: from nmtvs313.mtvyp by ntmtv.bnr.ca (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA12970; Thu, 23 Sep 93 14:08:24 PDT
Received: by nmtvs313.mtvyp (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04973; Thu, 23 Sep 93 13:26:22 PDT
Date: Thu, 23 Sep 93 13:26:22 PDT
From: hart@ntmtv (Chris Hart)
Message-Id: <9309232026.AA04973@nmtvs313.mtvyp>
To: PRESIDENT@WHITEHOUSE.GOV, VICE-PRESIDENT@WHITEHOUSE.GOV
Subject: Clipper/Skipjack Is Not Acceptable
Cc: hart@ntmtv
Status: R


Dear Sirs,

I strongly agree with the statements made below with respect to the issue
 of cryptography and the use of a trap door accessible to any government
 agency.  I don't believe there is ANY legitimate reason to compromise
 the privacy of any persons in this country.  Please abandon the attempt
 to institute any encryption policy involving any escrow system or trap door
 of any kind.  Please the the statements below; I agree with them strongly and
 urge you to adopt policies that conform to them.  Thank you very much for
 your time and consideration.

Chris Hart
1827 Haight St. #8
S.F. CA 94117
(415) 771-7017
hart@ntmtv.com

(This message was composed by voice)

A Policy on Cryptography

1.      There should no law restricting any use of cryptography by private
citizens.

2.      There should be no restriction on the export of cryptographic
algorithms or any other instruments of cryptography.

3.      Secret agencies should not be allowed to drive public policies.

4.      The taxpayer's investment in encryption technology and related
mathematical research should be made available for public and scientific
use.            
5.      The government should encourage the deployment of wide-spread
encryption.

6.      While key escrow systems may have purposes, none should be
implemented that places the keys in the hands of government. 
 
7.      Any encryption standard to be implemented by the government should
developed in an open and public fashion and should not employ a secret
algorithm. 

And last, or perhaps, first...

8.      There should be no broadening of governmental access to private
communications and records unless there is a public consensus that the
risks to safety outweigh the risks to liberty and will be effectively
addressed by these means.    

If you support these principles, or even if you don't, I hope you will
participate in making this a public process.


----- End Included Message -----

Sorry to be negative, but this is sort of a last request of a dying
sfraver.  Please, please, fucking well please, be more courteous
in posting to this list.  Some of us in the Stone Age still read
at 2400 baud.  I have enjoyed reading and posting to this list
articles relevant to raving AND relevant to most other list members
since it started, but I'm at the end of my thread (pun) with sifting
through megabyte after megabyte of people's personal
attacks and personal pet threads which belong elsewhere.

Comments like

"use procmail or other mail
distribution agent to filter your mail...Don't worry be happy"

in response to suggestions for appropriate discussion venues is
akin to people who let their dogs shit anywhere they want, and
tell you to "watch where you step".  Yeah, whatever.

When you notice yourself typing phrases like

"This is really ridculous and childish"

you're probably right.  Other catch phrases which tell you
it's time to go to private e-mail are things like:

"petty name calling" and "How did I call someone a name?"


I'm almost outta here.

Someone brought to my attention a mistake in our party directions, so here's
the corrected version:

From SF & East Bay...
Take 101 South to Candlestick Park exit
RIGHT at the stopsign
Enter the park and look for cars along the right-hand side of the road
Park and walk EAST towards the water (the entrance to the path you should
	follow is near the bathrooms)
Follow the paved path until it forks, then take the LEFT-hand dirt path
Perk up them ears!

The most current location info will be on Whit's answering machine:
	(510) 549-6253
Check this number the night of the party, and if the party gets moved.

Remember to prepare for chilly weather, as this spot is by the water and
	may be windy (also shades for the sunrise over the Oakland Hills :)

Subject: Re:  What SFRaves means to me
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

brians@unislc.slc.unisys.com (Brian Sassone) wrote:
>What SFRaves means to me...
> 
>Recently:
> 
>        - Off topic threads
>        - Opinionated thoughtless responses
>        - Personal attacks
>        - Flames
>        - Point, counter point
>        - Rant, rant, rant
>        - Me, me, me
>        - Lack of caring
>        - Lack of restraint
>        - Lack of tolerance (I guess I'm guilty now, too)
>        - Lack of human compassion
>        - Lack of community
>        - Lack of vibe

Heyo heyo,
I know that Brian has since ~apologized for being in a bad mood when he
wrote this, and I'm sure he didn't mean to hurt anyone's feelings, as I
do not. But what he's talking about is kind of going on. And I wonder
why? Is it as simple as sometimes individual people get carried away and
things get a little (or a lot, depending on your perspective) flame-y?
[having now set up the straw man, I will proceed to knock it down :]

Brian also asked:
>Is there some bad shit going around, wrong phase of the moon, a karmic
>catastrophe?  What?

I don't think that any of us think that the flamage is what SFRaves is *all*
about, but yeah, it is in there somewhere, and it's been out and about
some lately. Maybe Brian is speaking for the group in some sense, and
there is some stuff going on that underlies the recent flaminess. In fact
to me it seems normal that a still relatively young community like this
is going to have lots of issues about what what makes someone part of
the scene. Is it politics? Your BPM preferences? Whether you live in/near
the physical origin of the scene? I see this as one (1) possible reading
of the subtext that may exist beneath what's been going on.

At last week's YSH, I was at the discussion, and my topic, "Being aware
of the group-as-a-whole" was selected. This is the kind of thing I meant
by that, if it helps any :)

Most of you are hopefully sweating and smiling, on your way out of YSH
right now. Sorry I missed it, maybe next week...

Peace,
--John

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 24 07:40:08 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29685; Fri, 24 Sep 93 07:40:08 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA29678; Fri, 24 Sep 93 07:40:05 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA06508; Fri, 24 Sep 93 07:40:03 -0700
Message-Id: <9309241440.AA06508@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)
Date: Fri, 24 Sep 1993 07:40:02 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  What SFRaves means to me
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The "what SFR means" thing is starting to disturb me.

When Brian S. first posted his list
>        - Off topic threads
>        - Opinionated thoughtless responses
>        - Personal attacks
>        - Flames
>        - Point, counter point
>        - Rant, rant, rant
>        - Me, me, me
>        - Lack of caring
>        - Lack of restraint
>        - Lack of tolerance (I guess I'm guilty now, too)
>        - Lack of human compassion
>        - Lack of community
>        - Lack of vibe

I started to wonder if maybe me talking about music was somehow considered 
off-topic by the community.  As far as I can tell from the above list and 
from reading sfraves since June, the only "safe" topics of discussion are 
what parties you are going to, what ones you have just been to, how spiritual 
things are, and PC things like feeding the homeless and registering to vote.

Then I saw John Abbe's post, and really started to wonder:
>Your BPM preferences? Whether you live in/near
>the physical origin of the scene? 

Since I was a heavy contributor to the BPM thing *and* I don't CURRENTLY 
live near San Francisco I feel REALLY singled out by this.

So, my question is:  should I just refrain from posting unless it's to praise 
a recent SF party?  

I really feel like I'm somehow being censored here for (1) daring to attempt 
to discuss music in depth and (2) living 2500 miles away yet daring to post 
to the list.

Laura

>I started to wonder if maybe me talking about music was somehow considered 
>off-topic by the community.  As far as I can tell from the above list and 
>from reading sfraves since June, the only "safe" topics of discussion are 
>what parties you are going to, what ones you have just been to, how spiritual 
>things are, and PC things like feeding the homeless and registering to vote.

At one time I thought that there was no such thing as "safe" topics.  But
after some thought,I think you're onto something.

>
>Then I saw John Abbe's post, and really started to wonder:
>>Your BPM preferences? Whether you live in/near
>>the physical origin of the scene? 
>
>Since I was a heavy contributor to the BPM thing *and* I don't CURRENTLY 
>live near San Francisco I feel REALLY singled out by this.
>
>So, my question is:  should I just refrain from posting unless it's to praise 
>a recent SF party?

Hell No Laura!  You should posts whatever you like.  Hell, if there is time
to talk about the homeless, then there is time to talk about BPM's, songs,
parties (good/bad), prefernces, things related to the scene, as well as
thing not related to the scene.  There is plenty of cross pollination to
keep things interesting.  I think that the recent flurry of whatever was
caused by some hitting, for lack of a better word, a panic button.  There
are some issues on the list that NOBODY can discuss without a flurry of
insults being traded back and forth.

Me thinks that most of them are directed at me, but then again, I do have a
larger than life ego ;).  Most have cited by "style" as being a major
problem.  Well, we all have to get over some things at some times, eh?

I would not worry about it.

>to discuss music in depth and (2) living 2500 miles away yet daring to post 
>to the list.

>Laura

  Thought some of you/us might find this post interesting. I thought about
replying to him to tell him about V-raves here, but I haven't been there

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 24 Sep 1993 06:30:46 PDT
From: pmoore@PEG.APC.ORG
To: Multiple recipients of list FUTUREC <FUTUREC@UAFSYSB.UARK.EDU>
Subject: A message from "Mitch"

Hello world. Some of you will know me from the Aleph mailing list.

I am physically at the offices of Pegasus Networking in Brisbane, Queensland,
Australia. A few blocks away at this moment Brisbane's first InterRAVE is
happening; it is in fact a rainforest benefit, all proceeds from the event
will go to support the Rainforest Action Network which, according to my
conversations with the organizers, will go to held develop more sustainable
and locally appropriate methods of economic interdependence, or some
such thing.. I am not an expert on what their methods are, but I have an idea
of their AIMS, which is to take us in their own way one step closer to a
truly better world.

The reason that this message is going out:

An InterRAVE, as I understand it, consists of a number of raves located in
different timezones around the world, all tuning into and out of the IRC
channel #interrave. (Parenthetically, I would like to urge that someone
forwar a copy of this message to emr@mullian.ee.mu.oz.au at Melbourne
University, since she wrote a rather well-known thesis on the topic of
IRC as social medim and I want her onboard some time in the next ten hous
if possible, to see whatever it is that ends up happening.)

The point is this: I have spent the last two years of my life networking, both
in cyberspace and out of it. Tonight, right at this moment, I feel the
potential to bring more of those different networks and the individuals on
them into contact with each other than ever before. It's hard to be more
specific about what it is that I'm trying to do at this stage because I
don't even know if I'm going to be able to get back onto the IRC channel
this evening. But at the very least, something is going to happen with
global ramifications, simply because people across the world in different
timezones will be plugged in during the event.

But to be more specific: I see the potential to greatly extend the power of
us each as individuals to actually affect the course of events here, not
just geopolitically or culturally but in a very literal sense, at the
level of planetary evolution. The conjunction of influences present
encompasses a great range of human cultures, as well as an awareness of
economic, environmental, and technological influences.

I am blathering on like this because I am trying to do whatever is
necessary to convince as many people as possible who will read these
words in time to make the effort to CONNECT TO THE CHANNEL.

Please forward this message on. I will see you if and when I can,

"Mitch"

John C. Abbe aka Rademir writes:
 > Brian also asked:
 > >Is there some bad shit going around, wrong phase of the moon, a karmic
 > >catastrophe?  What?
 > 
 > I don't think that any of us think that the flamage is what SFRaves is *all*
 > about, but yeah, it is in there somewhere, and it's been out and about
 > some lately. Maybe Brian is speaking for the group in some sense, and
 > there is some stuff going on that underlies the recent flaminess.

Well there's a lot of Ego going on lately. A lot of postings with the
general tone of "You have no clue," and a lot of personal attacks,
mostly by John Lee.

Now I don't think we have to be all flowery and overflowing with the
cream of human goodness all the time--we're only human--, but it is
possible to discuss things in a non-belligerent manner, and with a
little care for other person's feelings.  We have a small, very
intimate community. Ripping someone to pieces Usenet style because one
disagrees with them is very much out of place here.

I took some pretty harsh criticism for my flame of John. It came from
some people I love and whose opinions I consider important. I guess
I'd seen John jump down someone I cared about's throat too many times.
Normally, when I'm very upset and want to post something, I'll write
it and file it. A few hours later, I'll decide if I really want to
post it. Most of the time I throw it away. This time I didn't.  So I
apologise for the bad vibes and for those who were offended.

I really don't know what to do. I could permanently filter out John's
mail with about 20 seconds of work. But I feel he _does_ have
important and useful contributions to make, that I might gain from
them. At the same time, his presentation pisses me off. Tons of
attitude, passing judgement, personal attacks on peaceful people when
he disagrees with them.  Very inappropriate for this particular
community. Poison is the word that comes to mind.

Guess I need to think about it a while. I am really bummed out.

Sean


1. Who is your audience?
2. How do you want them to respond?
3. Is your presentation likely to cause them to respond in the way
   that you want? Why or why not?
4. How would you respond if someone made the same presentation to you?
5. What do you respond to?

Thanks to the folks who answered my questions about outdoor sound 
equipment. Here's a summary of the information sent to me:


Sources of information: 

MIX magazine - Saw it at Tower Books , but didn't get it , as it seemed 
   to be aimed at the studio environment and high-end/high $$$ professional 
   market.

Mobile Beat magazine - Self-described as "The Magazine for Professional 
   DJs & Mobile Entertainers" , it seems to be much more geared to what I 
   was looking for than MIX magazine. It's a bi-monthly , published by LA 
   Communications , Inc. in East Rochester , NY. It's full of news , 
   reviews , and hints for people trying to make a living as a mobile DJ . 
   Lots of ads for cases and racks , truntables , mixing boards , samplers 
   , and other audio and lighting gear.

( For your info , the Tower Books store I'm refering to is in the South 
Bay , next to Tower Records at the border of Mountain View/Los 
Altos/Palo Alto )

Newsgroup rec.audio.pro - I took a peek at this newsgroup , and I have 
   the same initial objection to it as I did to MIX magazine - too 
   indoor/studio orientated for my purposes. Still ,it looks like an 
   informative newsgroup , and I may post some questions there eventually.


Recommended equipment/hints :

 I didn't get much in the way of direct endorsements of specific models 
or brands . Here's what I got:

connectors: XLR or Neutrik brand. Also , connector covers to keep out 
    sand & dirt .

cases: Anvil EIA "flight rack" w/ removeable front & back covers , 
    wheels or casters.

tarps: To protect electronics and speakers .

amps: Carver , for good watts/lb. density - 250W/250W in an 8 lb. amp , 
    for example.




                     Thanks again!
                     Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - People have only posted about Technics turnables , when they ever
     mention turntables in a post. Why Technics turntables , vs other
     brands ( Gemini or Denon ) ?

While this isn't directly SFR related, I do believe it's list related 
considering recent threads.

Today's (9/24/93) LA Times has an article on some of the social facets of 
email.  Research has indicated that when using e-mail, as opposed to voice or 
more "personal" forms of communication, peope tend to be much more blunt and 
don't temper what they say.  One researcher noted that anything ambiguous will 
usually be taken in the worst light.

Perhaps something to consider before hitting that "R" reflexively.

-joe-

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 24 14:26:08 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02081; Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:26:08 PDT
Received: from ucdavis.ucdavis.edu by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02074; Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:26:05 PDT
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by ucdavis.ucdavis.edu (4.1/UCD2.05)
	id AA18245; Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:13:21 PDT
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA28547; Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:14:54 PDT
Date: Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:14:54 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)
Message-Id: <9309242114.AA28547@bethe.ucdavis.edu>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: blunt is good
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



>Today's (9/24/93) LA Times has an article on some of the social facets of 
>email.  Research has indicated that when using e-mail, as opposed to voice or 
>more "personal" forms of communication, peope tend to be much more blunt and 
>don't temper what they say.  One researcher noted that anything ambiguous will 
>usually be taken in the worst light.
>  -joe-
 
This is why email lists are interesting.  It is like writing letters but much 
faster - and thus sometimes, less well thought out.  You'll read the 
ocassionally post that is practically an essay and then read a knee-jerk
response.  

It is the anonymity of the medium that makes flaming easier.  
All the rigid formalism that letter writing used to entail
had its origin (I think) in preventing what we call flames.
It is a skill that has been lost over the last 50 years or so. 

Smileys and other net acronyms are shortcuts for personal expression.  
They convey what you could (should?) be able to get across in a really well 
written / well thought out post.  Stuff like humor, sarcasm, and humility.

I think,

Blunt is good.  It saves time.  It is efficient.
Smileys are fine.  They help people get it. They are not "required".
Brevity is *wonderful* (another sign of good writing), but not at the expense 
of accuracy.  Email need not be spoon fed.  
Don't assume a post will be "over there heads" cuz if it is people will
ask (hint hint personal email) or skip it and to do so contributes to the 
mediocrity of a discussion.

Reader beware.
Dave

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 24 17:17:32 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA02952; Fri, 24 Sep 93 17:17:32 PDT
Received: from netcom6.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

	id AA19744; Fri, 24 Sep 93 17:17:56 -0700

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>,
        john@makesys.com (John Turman)
Subject: Turntable Terror (was Re: Outdoor Sound - Thanks! )
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:15:34 PDT."
             <9309242115.AA17256@makesys. com> 
Date: Fri, 24 Sep 93 17:17:54 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

From john@makesys.com (John Turman):
> May I add? What about Micro-Seiki, or Thorens, or Bang&Olufsen, or Linn,
> or how about Carver? There are a number of excellent turntables still in
> existence that are far superior in their specs, and durability to Technics.
> 
> Why such prejudice towards such an inferior product?

Well, I'd venture that most radio shack products sound just as good as
Bang&Olufsen, but they're not as pretty and don't have the required yuppie
cachet. People that buy B&O usually know nothing about sound -- they're
buying a pretty "appliance" rather than a system scientifically designed to
reproduce music accurately. IMHO, their stuff really isn't that good,
sounds mediocre, but costs as much as decent low-end audiophile equipment
that sounds tons better. (and i'm sick of slick euro-design -- gimme
something truly ugly, like a mackintosh! (not the computer))...

And i'm sure backspinning isn't pretty with B&O's linear tracking tonarm.

As far as the other "high-end" turntables you mentioned, the problem is
that they're designed for low-tracking weight stylii (e.g.  0.75-1.25 g)
and are build in a very delicate fashion. DJ and radio equipment is built
for abuse, and designed so that the needle will grind through the 6 inches
of slimy bongwater that have besludged one's records, and built so that
they spin up to speed in less than one rotation; it's not uncommon to see
DJ/broadcast stylii spec'd for tracking at 3.5 grams, and DJ's that are
planning on doing tricks sometimes crank it up to 5 grams so that the
needle stays in the groove no matter what. I'd venture to guess that, a
micro-seiki/linn/thorens only go up to 2 grams max, and the needle would be
popping all over the place in most club situations. THey'd also go out of
alignment after a few gigs, and would not be suitable for DJing cuz they
don't quite have the range of speed control needed for DJing.

(I have an old high-end "Dual" direct drive turntable myself, and i'm sure
it really sucks for DJing, but is good for playing back records accuratly.)

IMHO, techno is an amazingly lo-fi medium, and often sounds better on
medium and lo-fi equipment. On my "pseudo-audiophile" stereo system, I
don't often get the "crunchy" sound that you get when playing techno
through a more traditional home or club stereo system (maybe if I didn't
have a MOSFET power amp, it might sound a little crunchier). On the other
hand, my stereo makes saxophones/horns sound really sweet, while most
"consumer" or club systems make them sound like shit.... Similarly, techno
is the only music that sounds really good on my admittedly pathetic car
stereo, whereas jazz or classical indian music sound like shit and lose
much of their tranparency and clarity.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From: laura@soda.berkeley.edu (Laura La Gassa)

John Turman wonders about something Larry and Mark said:

>> Larry asks:
>> >PS - People have only posted about Technics turnables , when they ever
>>      mention turntables in a post. Why Technics turntables , vs other
>>      brands ( Gemini or Denon ) ?
>> 
>> Because there are no others.  Pretend those other brands don't exist.  This
>> is the only example of a product that I can think of that isn't rivaled.
>> So far nothing comes close - yet.
>> 
>> -Mark
>> 
>
>May I add? What about Micro-Seiki, or Thorens, or Bang&Olufsen, or Linn,
>or how about Carver? There are a number of excellent turntables still in
>existence that are far superior in their specs, and durability to Technics.

Why such prejudice towards such an inferior product?

Well, the Technics in question are the Technics 1200 series of heavy-duty
direct-drive turntables.  These are turntables you can drop off a truck and
still use to DJ with.  No, they won't give you the sound quality of a
Bang&Olufsen table, but do you really want your B&O table sitting outside
on a beach with someone like Garth wanking the hell out of it?

I think the Technics are so popular because you can get them for a really
good price, and because for the money they do exactly what a 
house/techno/hip-hop DJ wants:  they play the records, stop on a dime, hold
pitch well, and don't freak when imbued with a bit of rain, fog juice, or
mud -- and if the cops end up with them at the end of the night you're only
out $350 a pop (on the grey market).

Laura

From sfraves-owner  Fri Sep 24 19:53:29 1993

From: throb@netcom.com (Robert Oliver)
Message-Id: <9309250253.AA23675@netcom4.netcom.com>
Subject: RE: blunt is good
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 24 Sep 93 19:53:53 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

>Today's (9/24/93) LA Times has an article on some of the social facets of
>email....
>  -joe-

Similar to pondering *how* to communicate in SFRaves,  I found it interesting to reflect on *why* we communicate on e-mail.  A previous (9/12/93) Los Angeles Times Magazine's topic was: "The Faceof Cyber Chaos, Five Writers on the Complex Seductions of Computer Culture."

One article (by Margo Kaufman) includes the following:

"As Dr. Joyce Brothers, the psychologist, who recently went on a cyber-business trip, told me, 'In small towns there used to be a general store and you'd sit around the potbelly stove and swap tales and gossip and deal with life.  Later, the stove became the drugstore.  Now it's the computer network.'"

...."the lost art of conversation is thriving on-line."

This last line sounds like a great quote for a signature.  Hmmm...

As the 'zine's title implies, the articles deal most with "cyberlove" and such.   For those of you that connect to the Net from work, Kaufman's article brought up an interesting point about wasted time:

"'When you talk about the decline in American productivity, one factor is that people get lost in cyberspace,' said Stuart Brotman, a communications consultant based in Lexington, Mass.  'It's pretty common in large companies.  People feel that it's their job to initiate and receive electronic messages,but as soon as they do that, they take time away from other things.'  He understands the appeal though. 'It lets you escaped your job without leaving your desk.'"

IMHO, Mr. Brotman's blanket statement about e-mail is like saying "people who work in cubicles take time away from work to talk over the wall and to whomever walks in."  His point at least provoked me into thinking about a continuum between "time saved" and "timed wasted" whenever we use e-mail for communication. We can easily produce examples of clear time savers and obvious time wasters, but there's some "grey" in there too.

Stop pondering!  You're wasting time!!  :)


Rob

throb@netcom.com
--

Subject: Gang Violence at MESS
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Sun, 26 Sep 93 6:50:32 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Some very bad violence occurred at Candlestick Park this
morning.  A local gang broke up the party, and some major
physical fighting broke out.  Some ravers tried to mediate,
things, others got beaten up while many cowered in fear
amongst rocks and trees.  Guns were present, but as far as
I know, no shots were fired.  There were many injuries with
at least 6 people requiring medical attention; cops,
firetrucks and paramedics came to the scene.

We hope everyone's OK, and if anyone else has more information
on this please let us all know.  Our hearts are with you; we
know that the MESS people are amongst the most peaceful and
caring people in our community.  We can only hope that the world
will become a better place than it is, and perhaps through our 
steadfast belief in this hope, we will help make it happen.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Lee Fogel/\/\/\/\/\eVerything/\Is/\possiBlE/\/\/\/\/\lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com

NETRESULTS, the team of people working on implementation and follow-up

government) initiative are using the net to gather examples of
regulations which should be targeted for change or elimination.

it to the NETRESULTS team.  The more details you have the better -
especially if you can give an example of how the regulation stands in
the way of a government which "works better and costs less."

THE SKY HIGH CLUB may be just what is needed after a long weekend of
bad directions,cops with no sympathy for raving, gangs, speed, dank
basement level parties.....

The Sir Francis Drake hotel has started to allow Mike Manahan and
friends to throw a Sunday night party in the fat-assed lounge
on the 21st floor, in the "starlight room". A view for sipping 
spirulina/lecithin laced bloody marys and reflecting on the weekends
events, as Richard Sun said "high above the Psychic plane".

10-2:00 Sunday night.

for a couple months. I think he would appreciate seeing the SFraves friends
more than anything, he has always had the highest regard for your efforts.

IT costs $5 Mike Manahan is a ripping progressive dj who is leaving
to start a scene in Guam. He plays progressive house/spiritual techno
which is almost my ideal (Hard trance With a Gay Vibe).

This from clarinews:

   San Francisco police report that about 10 people crashed an outdoor rave
party at a park near Candlestick early this morning and started beating up
the people attending the gathering.
   Officer Bob Hartmann said the suspects that crashed the party shortly
after 3 a.m. first danced with the crowd, but then started striking people
and taking wallets and other personal posessions.
   Police recovered the stolen goods and arrested two men and one juvenile
boy.
   A San Francisco General Hospital nursing supervisor said four victims of
the fight are at the hospital and in good condition.  She said three will
be treated and released and one of them may be admitted.
   
   NOTE TO EDITORS: The exact location of the fight is uncertain beyond the 
fact that it was at a park near Candlestick.  A San Francisco police 
officer at operations said it was at California Point State Park; a 
paramedics dispatcher at C-med said the call was at Giants Drive adjacent 
to Gilman Park; a fire dispatcher said it was at Gates A and B of 
Candlestick.

Dear sf-ravers,

A friend of mine is going to San Francisco next month (17-24.10) and he
asked me to bug you for information on raves, clubs & shops. I've been
raving about your scene (without having seen it myself) to him so many
times that I would really like to see his trip succeed. Therefor I would
appreciate personal comments & recommendations on clubs, raves etc. as
that is the kind of information that counts. I know from personal experience
that going to a record shops and skimming through the pile of flyers isn't
very helpful in determining what's good and what's a rip off (it's the 
cultural gap you see :) I might also add that Antti (the friend in question)
is no newbie to the scene and being somewhat disillusioned with the Finnish
scene he'd probably appreciate anything truly creative or out of ordinary
(be that a live performance or a 12" of the year). On a last note, if anyone
wants to volunteer to show him around (yes, he speaks english, but lacks
Internet access) that would be - in immortal words of Soundgarden -
UltraMegaOk :)

Your help is welcome,
Samu Mielonen

PS I'm quite the information I'm looking for floats around here daily, so
you might just as well reply personally to avoid wasting the wavelength.

the same

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 01:42:21 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16334; Mon, 27 Sep 93 01:42:21 PDT
Received: from net.bio.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA16327; Mon, 27 Sep 93 01:42:07 PDT
Received: by net.bio.net (5.65/IG-2.0) 
	id AA02653; Mon, 27 Sep 93 01:41:51 -0700
Date: Mon, 27 Sep 93 01:41:51 -0700
From: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
Message-Id: <9309270841.AA02653@net.bio.net>
To: geoffw@nexsys.net
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: Gang Violence at MESS
Newsgroups: 
In-Reply-To: <9309270345.AA01213@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Organization: Straight On Till Morning
Cc: 
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

In article <9309270345.AA01213@nexsys.nexsys.net> you write:
|
|Anybody got any more info on this?
|(Was anybody actually there?
|Please let me know.
|

I was there ...  the info given so far is basically right.  I got
there about 2am, and the shit started happening about a half-hour
later.  It was really too bad; there was a great vibe at the party,
cool acidy music, not very cold at all.  Maybe about 50-60 people
there.

It seems that there were about 10 gang-type people who were hanging
out and drinking somewhere nearby when the MESS people set up the
party.  (It was, I think, in the same place that the FMR a few months
ago got moved to, after the Water Temple was busted.  It was at the end
of a little spit of land that stuck out in the water, somewhere where
you get a good view of Hunters' Point across Candlestick Cove.)  The
MESS organizers told the guys that they were putting on a free house
party, come join if you want, dance, etc.  At some point, I think about
when I got there, they came, and at first were cool ...  but there were
maybe 2 or 3 in the group, real young ones who had something to prove
...  they thought they were being dissed by some people there, or
something ...  it was pretty random, and didn't seem like anybody
really did much to provoke them.  I didn't really catch what happened
until it erupted into a fight, maybe 4 or 5 guys attacking someone
named Ivan, a friend of the MESS people ...  they were also shouting
things like "someone wanna call me a nigger ...?  huh?"  Meanwhile some
older guys in the same group of 10 were trying to calm things down; one
guy, in particular, kept saying, "Man, we don't wanna fight, let's just
dance and enjoy it.  Come on, knock it off ..." etc.  It would calm
down and then erupt again (I guess the young ones were even getting
pissed off at their older friends for restraining them); at first there
was just that fight off to the side, and it wasn't really all that
noticeable, but soon it moved to the center and they had to shut off
the music.  They then tried to start again, but it was clear it wasn't
going anywhere.  They stopped the music and started to shut down, and
the gang types filed off, along with some ravers, including some who
said they'd call the police.  The gang types hung around for awhile and
(it seemed) thrashed a few others; the remaining organizers and ravers
(most of us still were there) were worried about leaving for fear of
getting attacked, esp. with the equipment that had to be carried out;
we were at the end of a spit of land so there weren't too many ways
out.  Some people wanted to leave on their own, but others said that
really wouldn't be a good idea; better to stay all together.  After a
half hour or so the police came by and the paramedics and such, and the
gang types took off.  There were some "scouts" being sent out by the
organizers, who would report on what was happening; from the rave site
you couldn't see much at all except out into the Bay.  (There was this
constant rumbling in the distance, which occasionally grew louder and
softer.  It was pretty eerie and a bit apocalyptic, almost; although it
got put into perspective when I figured out that the rumbling was
coming from planes taking off and landing at the SF airport.  When the
police came to where we were, they naturally hassled us about the party
and told us to leave, which we had every intent of doing anyway.  They
said no one was there so we all filed out, equipment in hand, and found
all sorts of police cars, ambulances, and fire trucks parked near out
cars.  I only saw one of the injured people, this girl who had wandered
off and run into the gang types on their way out; she had blood all
down one side of her face and looked like some image out of a horror
film, but she seemed more shaken up than stirred ...  er, seriously
injured I mean.  (Ivan, on the other hand, apparently got seriously
mauled and was lying by the side of the road for awhile till the
paramedics came to help him.) Some of us hung around, and after awhile,
the cops of course started hassling us ...  ("What are you doing
here????"  "We're waiting for a friend ...  he went back to the site to
look for his backpack."  "Well, everyone leave except one person to
wait for him.")

MESS moved back to Chateau, the co-op at Berkeley where they hail from,
and Susie and I took off for Home ...  a little bit of a strange vibe
there, having to do mostly with the space (Cesar's Latin Palace, at
Mission and Army).  Normally it's (or I should say, it seemed to be ...
I've never been there before now) this kinda cheesy 70's disco place,
and there were lots of people coming there for this and finding this
rave music and getting confused and kinda just hanging there not really
knowing what to think -- it felt to me like there was this culture
clash there that was weirding things out.  But it was nice to see
some familiar faces there.

ben

Subject: Crash Worship et al.

Not directly rave related, but Crash Worship is going to be playing
this Friday night Oct 1st at the Haze Theater in SF.  (2730 16th St.)
Show starts at 9 but there are lots of opening bands so CW probably
won't come on till midnight or later.

If you haven't seen Crash Worship, well ...  they put on an amazing
spectacle, what can I say.  Heavy pounding incessant tribal drumming,
some guy screaming in the background, complete darkness except one
bright fluorescent flashing light, fog, people moshing all around you,
naked painted dancers with huge animal masks, torches, wineskins ...
Definitely not a "clean" experience :-) ...  I guess that sounds
scarier than it is; it's really a fun experience and you can always
move away from the action if it gets too intense.

ben

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 05:39:19 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17511; Mon, 27 Sep 93 05:39:19 PDT
Received: from holly.cam.harlequin.co.uk by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA17502; Mon, 27 Sep 93 05:39:03 PDT
Received: from piaget.harlequin.co.uk (piaget.cam.harlequin.co.uk) by holly.cam.harlequin.co.uk; Mon, 27 Sep 1993 13:39:59 +0100
Received: from gamgee.harlequin.co.uk by piaget.harlequin.co.uk; Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:39:50 BST
From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:39:44 BST
Message-Id: <1733.9309271239@gamgee.harlequin.co.uk>
To: john@makesys.com
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: John Turman's message of Fri, 24 Sep 93 14:15:34 PDT <9309242115.AA17256@makesys. com>
Subject: Re: Outdoor Sound - Thanks!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


   May I add? What about Micro-Seiki, or Thorens, or Bang&Olufsen, or Linn,
   or how about Carver? There are a number of excellent turntables still in
   existence that are far superior in their specs, and durability to Technics.

   Why such prejudice towards such an inferior product?

In pure hi-fi terms, there's no doubt that a Linn LP12 would beat a
Technics SL1200 hands down.  But sound quality isn't the only issue
here.  I'm not familliar with micro-seiki or carver, but the other
turntables you mention would be completely unsuitable for for DJ use.
You're not just playing records... you're mixing them...

So, for a start, you need high torque, so you can stop the record
without slowing down the platter (you have a slipmat between the
record and the platter which is designed to allow you do do this.)

This pretty much rules out belt drive decks, so anything in the
Linn/Thorens school of design will be useless.

You need a good +/-8% pitch control.... that rules out many hi-fi
decks.

A suspended sub-chassis design probably wouldn't be suitable....
be too easy to jog the armboard...

What else...?  Let me see... a strobe might be nice, though not
essential.  That's out of fashion in minimalist hi-fi designs.  How
about a cueing light.... DJ's often have to work in the dark.... i've
yet to see a hifi design that has one....  Oh, most of the desks you
mention will probably never have been tried in some of the harsh
environments that Technics get used....  being knocked and jogged and
bumped around, both in transport, and in use....

There must be a dozen other little points that i've missed.... 

The decks you mention were designed to sound good, with no
compromises.  1200's are designed to sound good, but to do a lot more
besides....


	roy

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 05:41:08 1993

I should add that there are a lot of other DJ decks out there.  Almost
all of them are low cost Technics imitations, and they are without
exception inferior products.  

People use Technics because it's the best....  No serious DJ would
even consider using anthing else...

	roy

Weekend rave report
===================

  I am VERY VERY sorry to hear about what happened at MESS at Candlestick
park.    Radion,  my friend wanted me to take him there,   but I went to
HOME instead,  which I really think was totally awsome.    And best of all
they had fans at the dance floor,  dispite the no ins and outs,  probably
imposed by the owners,   it was really smoke free,  as long as smokers 
didn't stand behind the fans.    The music was out of this world and
I was in such a wonderful trancey mode that I turned into a dance machine
and couldn't keep off the dance floor.

  Unfortunately,  they had to clear everyone out by 6 am,  but I was able
to find all my freinds and we chilled out till Boogie Buffet opened up the
sunlight area.    At the same time,  the Folsom Stree fair was going on
down the street,  and after they set up the sound system,  some DJ's from
England did the most awsome hard-core sets I have ever heard using a
sampler synth in clown suits.   WOW!!   What a wonderful dance experience
it was.   Naturally,  I was one of the only dudes out there dancing to
the fast 160 PBM stuff.  

  Towards the end,  they smashed up the Techniques 1200 turntables on
the stage as an act,  then threw out copies of their albums to the crowd.

  Anyway,  hats off to Ethan for putting on a most sucessful rave,   it
was a very good venue dispite the early shut-down,  the scene was totally
wonderful and pleasant.   I can only hope that Ethan can pull off yet another
one soon.   

  I also met a dude at Boogie in the morning that said that Awaken wasn't
really that good,  and they had to turn down the sound several times,  as
it was held in an armory (Don't recall the city,  but it was in Central
valley).   

Cheers
CC

Wow. Ethan really kicked ass on that one. Home is (thus far) the most
produced event I've gone to, and it just blew my mind away.

The graphics were great, very beautiful and entrancing stuff. The sound
system was fantastic, and very loud. The location was cool once you got
inside, but the security people weren't very nice, and the outside was
actually hostile towards some friends and I.

DRC and Markie played the weirdest acid trance stuff I've ever heard, stuff
I really got into. I dunno who else was up in what order, but all of them
were just amazing.

I heard that Ethan lost money on Home because not enough people showed up.
Too bad. I pity everyone who stayed home or went somewhere else.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 10:55:34 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19241; Mon, 27 Sep 93 10:55:34 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19234; Mon, 27 Sep 93 10:55:31 PDT
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA11854; Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:55:29 EDT
Date: Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:55:29 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9309271755.AA11854@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Home!
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

What a party! HOME went really well, and I had a blast.  We took a
couple of first-timers there, and they had a *great* time.  They'd
never been exposed to the scene or the music before, and they loved
it. Danced their butts off :). Have to go to the butt shop and get new
ones :).

The Bad - The only bad thing I can say about Home is that the security
presence was excessive. They were circulating among the people,
constantly checking the bathrooms, etc., obviously looking for drugs.
No doubt this is Caesar's policy and not the promoters. I guess
there's no point in telling him, but the good officers are just
wasting their energy and his money.

With that out of the way...

DJs - It was good acid trance most of the night.  I got there in the
middle of Darcy's set. She wasn't mixing as well as usual, but it was
still a great Darcy vibe. Then Jon Williams came on. I've never heard
him spin before. Holy shit! Sorry guys, I've got a new favorite DJ now
:). He makes it look soooo easy, too. I got to hear a lot of new
stuff.  Simon was next, with Markie finishing up with a really (as
Fred put it) "mental" trance set. It was a good night to just dance
dance dance. I did my share of speaker worshiping and had a great time
:).

Visuals - *Really* groovy visuals. Some of the best I've ever seen.
There were two screens with color-cycled acidwarp/movies/fractal
images. A huge crowd level screen with slides and bubbly stuff, and
another huge spinning projection at crowd level. I love these sort of
visuals; very colorful and trippy, and close to the crowd. A laser
would have been good too.

Sound - Perfect. Whoever set up the sound should give lessons. A 4
corners system with just the right amount of loud. The bass was really
punchy and the highs came through loud and clear without being
distorted or excessive. A perfect balance. The stereo imaging was
great, and the room was full of good sweet spots where stereo sound
just surrounded you..  Listening to this system is not unlike
listening to my MDR-V6 headphones cranked way up with a bass bin
nearby to punch me good. Total tranceout city. The songs never sounded
better.

The Vibe - I thought it was great. Most of the people were dancing and
having a great time. It had a little bit of a weird edge to it
sometimes because some people were just hanging around like they'd
never seen a rave before.  My idea is, when I see some people sitting
around like they don't know what to do, I just flow with it and get
out there and have fun. Lead by example. Spread your good vibe around
:).  A lot of regulars were there, whom I really enjoyed being with.

Misc Stuff - Free water. Free fruit. No confiscations. A good welcome
at the door (not just for me, I hung around a bit and everyone was
getting a good treatment). Coat check $1. Lots of good chill space.
Good ventilation. Fans.

Ethan, you are a walking talking good vibe. Congradulations (to you
and the Tilt-a-Whirl guy whose name I can never remember) on a great
party :).

Sean

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 12:07:13 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19664; Mon, 27 Sep 93 12:07:13 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA19657; Mon, 27 Sep 93 12:07:11 PDT
Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA23078; Mon, 27 Sep 93 12:07:40 -0700
From: nrg@netcom.com (Ethan I. Miller)
Message-Id: <9309271907.AA23078@netcom3.netcom.com>
Subject: Home Review
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 27 Sep 93 12:07:39 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

Greetings friends...

First off, my very deepest respect, sympathy and wishes for healing to MESS
and all involved in Saturday nights unfortunate Candlestick attack.
Security is really a bitch, more on this follows....

Many, many thanks to everyone that came out for Home; it was IMHO a
resounding success. I had a wonderful time and think everyone else did too.
We ended up with just under 500 paid, and, as usual, more guests than
anticipated or desired; all in all my partner Mark and I lost $809 each... 
18+ spaces that will go all night in SF are damn expensive  :(

But it was never about money anyway, so on to the important stuff...

Positives:
Vibe: Really great energy all night; dancing people with big smiles, lots
of hugs, nothing beats dancing with friends and family. My wife actually
had a great time at this party; very unusual event. Maybe she'll get out more
often now :)

Music: Killer music all night long! Jordan was excellent and is a really
nice guy to boot; lots of heart. he does fairly large parties in fresno;
I'm gonna try and make his next one. Galen was great as well; definitely
some up and coming talent well represented here. DRC was fantastic; harder
than your usual sf rave goer is used to lots of trance and an occasional
piece of techno thrown in as well, very funky an danceable; I can't tell
you how many people asked me who she was. Jon Williams was incredible: high
energy progressive house with lots of uplifting vocal and keboard riffs;
really got the floor moving; people jumping up and down, yelling screaming
etc. really a hoot. Simon treated us to a feast form his all new double
crate of records. By his own admission he's tired of disco, funk, etc. and
is moving in a harder, trancier direction. Truly mindbending. Markie
wrapped it up for us and was also fantastic. Bass therapy at 5:30 am is
just a great experience. Finished up with a killer track which must be
called *Joy* that left everybody clapping and wishing for more. Really
looking forward to hearing him at Connection Earth this sunday  :)

Sound:
Okay, I'm gonna sound conceited here, but if I'm wrong, I couldn't tell it
from anyone I spoke to there... Sound was amazing; loud as shit but crystal
clear with *no distortion* no ringing ears, nothing, just power! Better
sound than Basics, Vision, Groove Kitchen, any party I've been to
recently... We used my system for monitors and JK provided the rest: six
stacks of the Community VBS 415 /RS 880 combination. 24,000 watts total :)

Visuals:
Synergy did a great job on two screens right over the dance floor.
Left/right mirrored computer/video psychosis all night. Lots of
compliments on their work. Howard from Liquid Sircus Delight also did
agreat job on one and occasionally two screens. He really needs a big
screen like at the first Come Unity to do him justice. But his liquid,
mineral, radial treats were really nice. Towards the end, he started
projecting onto the dance floor which was this neat shower of twirling
shifting light, almost like beams of pre dawn sunlight anticipating the
coming day...

Water:
lots of it and free :)


negatives:
Well I live in the Mission district and quite honestly, aside from having
great burritos, I can do without the local culture. Alcohol just figures
way to prominently in the Mission's definition of how to have fun. Resident
gangs etc. force Cesars Latin palace and by turn us to Take security rather
seriuosly. This resulted in up front security that frisked everyone fully
and weren't the most friendly at times. They did however keep out twenty
gang members in colors that showed up, and thank goddess, there was no
violence during the night. My apologies to anyone that they offended; they
came with the space; very little i could do about it except repeatedly ask
them to be as pleasant as possible.

Luckily, most of the drunk locals seemed to pass out in the corners and the
vibe didn't take too much of a hit from them...It really is a good space,
too bad about the neighborhood...

What's next?
Well, I'm viewing this as a great start to something that will keep getting
better. I have to break even on the next one though, or I'm going to have a
hard time selling my wife on the concept. Bottom line is: we just can't
afford to lose the money  :( 

so our next party is going to be a little less of a big production and try
and focus on the basics: music, sound, dance, vibe. We're looking at the
weekend of October 23 for a smaller party in a non-mission SF, 18+ space.
We'd like to feature two members of UVC: Jon D and Jeff Taylor (don't worry
Jon I'll mail you about this) and two visiting members of the UK's DIY sound
system, plus a special guest or two  :)

One again, thanks for the support; I had a fucking great time!
love ya
ethan and mark
--

Sean reports:
>Then Jon Williams came on. I've never heard
> him spin before. Holy shit! 

He really blew us away.  He set was the peak of the evening for us.
 
> Visuals - *Really* groovy visuals. Some of the best I've ever seen.

Synergy rules!  
 
> Sound - Perfect. Whoever set up the sound should give lessons. 

I'd have to say that it was the best sound system I've experienced in
recent memory.  The complete lack of distortion allowed the volume to
be cranked without pain, completely taking over my body & mind.  At one
pojnt Simon played some trancy religious-sounding stuff that made
me feel like I was floating in space.  
 
Ethan and company did a fantastic great job putting together this party.
It's too bad more people didn't come out for it.  Like 16th & Harrison, 
Ceasar's doesn't have a very good reputation for house parties.  Perhaps a 
lot of people just weren't willing to risk $15 for an unknown production 
at an iffy location.  Too bad.  But Ethan, if you're reading this, don't 
be discouraged.  It might take some time to build a following.  Word will 
get around that Home rocks.
  
> The Bad - The only bad thing I can say about Home is that the security
> presence was excessive. They were circulating among the people,
> constantly checking the bathrooms, etc., obviously looking for drugs.

I know someone who got thrown out that night for attempting to eat a small
piece of paper.  Actually, he succeeded in eating it, but only after
wrestling with the security goon over it who then became so enraged that
he pinched my friend's jaw open and tried to retrieve the paper from his
mouth with his hand.  Is that sick, or what?  After being thrown out, my
friend tried to salvage his evening by visiting the MESS party and ended
up in the middle of the gang violence that ensued there.  Nice trip :-(

But anyway, we know that Home had no say in the security situation, so
I just want to end this post on a positive note: Ethan & Mark, thanks;
you guys really put your heart into it, and it showed.  The free water,
good air circulation, great DJs, incredible sound & visuals - it was
better than any *home* I've been in, more like raver heaven!

- leg of eel

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 13:56:39 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20661; Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:56:39 PDT
Received: from orca.es.com (ES.COM) by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20654; Mon, 27 Sep 93 13:56:35 PDT
Received: from slack ([130.187.198.23]) by orca.es.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04360; Mon, 27 Sep 93 14:56:00 MDT
Received: by slack (4.1/E&S_client-ver1.5/SMI-4.1)
	id AA27268; Mon, 27 Sep 93 14:56:12 MDT
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9309272056.AA27268@slack>
Subject: Subterranean
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Mon, 27 Sep 1993 14:56:11 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 14115     
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

We had planned to use the basement of the same building we used for "Sea
Monkey Love Castle".  The basement was huge, and we had blocked most of it off
when we used it before.  This time we thought we would use the whole thing and
go for the theme of "Subterranean".

After a lot of work, I managed to secure a date to fly in Garth and Carlos.  I
was especially excited to see and hear Carlos work after the buzz that has
been given him on SFRAVES, and Garth is immensely popular here, due to his CD
being played at parties with no DJ.

We finally splurged on color flyers, and were they ever gorgeous!  In
association with Dave Scruton, I spent a large part of two weeks designing
this thing.  Dave did the rendering of the front, which looked like an
underground cavern with stalagtites, stalagmites, and a glowing crystal with a
TASTE logo flying over it.  The back was done with Photoshop and a newly
purchased copy of "Kai's Power Tools" which does the funkiest psychedelic
effects around.  Even on my employer's (after hours) Mac Quadra 900, it
seemingly took FOREVER to get things right.  Even after I was satisfied with
both sides, John had to spend five hours getting the color corrected (at his
work) and the separations done.  Then he was able to swing a deal for 3000
cardstock copies for $500.  The color correction cost $300.  Expensive and
time consuming, but was it ever pleasurable to see people's faces explode when
they saw them.  Even when I went out to San Francisco with our friend Grant,
we got a big reaction handing them to people at a smallish rave we went to.
Nothing like this had even come close in Salt Lake City, but we raised the
standard again, and now everyone is at least getting their flyers litho'd.

Because we had 3000 flyers, we went a bit aboveground and distributed them in
record and clothing shops.  Along with the flyers, we had tickets printed up,
so we sold those in advance.  However, there wasn't much incentive to buy them
in advance, since the price would not change from $10.  Tickets did sell
gradually, and things were simplified in a major way when it came time to take
them at the door.  Very little door sales were done at all, because we
insisted on having people buy their tickets at the map point.

The basement of the building ended up not being available, so we scrambled for
another site.  We looked at roller rinks, and a couple of unsuitable
warehouses.  In the end, we decided to use the same "cat box" warehouse that
we had used for "Rites of Spring".  When we arrived to inspect the building in
advanced, we were happy to see that it contained roughly half the amount of
cardboard that it did before.  Since we were expecting around 800 people to
show up, we decided to expand the dancefloor into where the chill area was
before.  There was enough cardboard to make a large partitioning wall between
a reduced size chill area, bathrooms, and smart bar.

I ordered four eight foot weather balloons, and one sixteen foot weather
balloon.  We blew up two of the red eight foot size, and they looked great
hanging from the ceiling.  I started to fill the sixteen foot when John locked
himself out of the warehouse, I didn't want the barely inflated balloon to
touch the floor where it could collect dirt, so I ran with it to the door.  It
snagged on suspended box pallette and tore a hole in it.  John patched it with
duct tape and I continued to fill it up.  When it got to be about ten feet in
size, it exploded.  Our beautiful $70 weather balloon was a useless pile of
latex.  I felt like a kid who's first balloon just got popped.

Most of the setup was done again by John and myself.  Lots of people always
want to help and we're glad to oblige, but when it comes down to it, they very
rarely show up for extended periods.  We did have a lot of help from Grant of
course, and Todd who was a manager for a local clothing store, but that was
about it.

I was approached by a friend who wanted to do an ambient room.  This was when
I thought we had the basement, so I told him it would be great if he could do
so.  He requested someone to spell him, so I found another guy who is
enthusiastic about the ambient music I play.  When I had to tell them that I
couldn't use them after all, it was bitching and whining to hell and back.
Both of these guys had never spun before and all of a sudden they felt like
they were doing me a favor.  The second guy asked if he could close the rave
instead and I just had to laugh at him.  The lesson learned here is that you
shouldn't tell people they can do something until you are absolutely sure you
can accomodate them.  I ended up giving them free tickets and the second guy
was a big help at one point in getting things setup.

Carlos called me the night before to tell me how psyched he was to be doing
the show.  He said he was getting lots of rest on Friday so he could give us
the best possible performance that he could do.  Needless to say, his energy
over the phone was invigorating.  I picked Carlos and Garth up from the
airport the evening before, and Carlos insisted on going to Sizzler.  A point
that many people here couldn't understand, but I didn't mind.  I bought them
both dinner and they were very appreciative.  We talked about different DJs,
music, and different bands.  I started to realize that I had recruited the
thickest accents in San Francisco and going from Carlos to Garth to Carlos to
Garth manage to cause a lot of confusion in the conversation.  More than once
I had no clue what they were trying to say to me.

When we returned to the warehouse, Carlos took a look at my pristine tables
and said, "Wow! New needles!"  I told them that they were about six months old
and he laughed and said, "You should see my needles."  There was some previous
debate before they arrived over how high the table should be.  We had to find
a happy medium for the shorter Carlos, and the taller Garth and myself.
Luckily our "guess" was just about right.  Aside from moving the monitors
around, things were very comfy for everyone involved, which relieved me in a
big way after having that junk turntable that Moonpup had problems with.

The door opened at about 11:20, 20 minutes late.  Reid, our video guy had
worked very hard at preparing animations and video to use for this one.  I had
spent some time getting 72 new slides made, but alas, I didn't make it back to
the photo shop in time to pick them up.  I hadn't wanted things to come down
to the wire like this, but I had spent a leisure hour at the Sizzler stuffing
my face, which was a drastic change from the past.  Usually I have a loaf of
french bread underneath the table to feed me from not eating all day.

I kicked things off with a unspectacular set, realizing I was going to be
dwarfed by the things to come.  There was a small panic when I realized the
second CD wasn't playing, and I frantically watched the time count down on the
first one before I discovered that the "TAPE" button had been pressed on the
NuMark that I had rented on Carlos' request.  I played until 12:30, when he
took the controls.

People stood near the tables slackjawed while he spun up a storm.  I have
*never* seen anything like it.  The amazing amount of energy that flows from
Carlos into the crowd is just spectacular.  When he mixed in Led Zepplin and
another classic rock song that just GROOVED (I can't remember the name),
things just exploded.  What was great is that he was having such a good time
doing it.  Salt Lake was in awe over his skill and ability.

Garth took over two hours later and had things pumping until *blam*.  The
power went out.  This happened FOUR times later, and we finally isolated it to
monitors being cranked too loud.  I pulled one of the monitor speakers off and
even though I was fairly sure that was it, all we had running at that point
was the projection TV and the computers.  All the disco lights, slide
projectors, and the laser were shut off permanently.  What was great about
Garth was his complete calm over the situation.  Even though the power kept
dropping out in mid set, he kept the crowd happy and had his thumb on the
situation.  Things would start up immediately when the power came back on and
it was like it never happened.  By the third blackout, people had almost begun
to expect them, as they started to clap in rhythm before things would kick in
again.  Many cheers were heard once they did.

I got a chance to talk with Carlos while Garth was playing and he was so
charged.  "You MUST bring me back here, I LOVE this place!"  He had met so
many people and picked up such a good vibe that he had really fallen in love
with Salt Lake City.  He was telling me that there was so much more energy at
4:00 AM than he had seen in San Francisco recently.

When I took over at 5:20 from Garth, there were still about a hundred people
left.  Not surprising since Garth had laid down an excellent groove, and it
was hard to quit from that.  I put down my *real* set, playing things that I
had been holding on to for a while, just waiting for the right moment.  It
went over very well, and I was able to keep the crowd there.  When I kicked
into trance at a quarter to six, I was deeply involved in what I was doing
when I noticed what was going on with the video.  Reid had taken a break and
thrown in a film called "Chronos".  Utterly gorgeous images of Egyptian
temples, classical Greek sculpture, and life on this planet.  About thirty
people had gathered around on the floor in front of the fifty foot image and
just watched in silence.  The other half just flowed and moved to the sound.
I left the mixer so I could go up to where they were sitting and I was
surprised to find John sitting there with his eyes wide open.  One of those
precious moments I will not forget.

After I returned and mixed for another fifteen minutes, I turned around to
find a grinning Carlos behind me.  I pointed at the mixer and he nodded
enthusiastically.  I let him take the controls to clear things out.  Garth
showed up as he was doing that and I asked him if he wanted to play at all.
He said he was happy in letting Carlos finish it out.  He asked how long he
should go, and I said another five minutes.  Then he talked to Carlos and
asked for fifteen.  That would have made things stop at 6:30.  I said sure,
but when we got to that point, it wasn't enough.  Garth asked for him to play
for ten more minutes and I readily agreed.  Then I ran into John who said the
sun was almost up and we should probably take things to 7:00.  Garth said,
"Good show!" and we relayed this to Carlos who laughed over it.

For the first time that night, I really saw Garth moving around to the music.
He certainly wasn't as outgoing as Carlos, but he was just as enthusiastic
about our work.  They both were in awe of Reid's video work, which was
astoundingly beautiful.  We ended up paying Reid $300 instead of the $200
originally agreed on.

When things ended at 7:00, John got up on a box and said thanks and thanks to
Garth and Carlos, which got a loud round of unexpected applause from the
remaining fifty people there.

I took them back to my place where they were determined to stay awake until
their flight left at 11:00.  I was not in the same state and crashed
immediately even though Garth was playing a tape on the stereo.  When they
woke me an hour later, they were concerned about their records being in the
sun in the car, and wanted to go to the airport now so I wouldn't have to
worry about them an hour later.  In my groggy state, I was glad to oblige and
took them there.  Carlos emphasized about how he wanted to come back and Garth
thanked me for a good party.  I said goodbye and that was that.

At 2:30 I returned to the warehouse to find John had swept most of it, and
removed the porto-potties from the inside.  Grant was busily coiling cables
and taking down equipment.  We stayed until about 10:00 cleaning up and
hauling equipment out.  This included a break to setup one of the televisions
to watch the premier of Star Trek.

When all the cash was counted, the results turned out to be rather dismal.
Despite the extensive flyering we had done, the crowd had not been any larger
than what we would have had if we had just sent photocopied flyers to the
mailing list.  I think the "curiosity seekers" have left the raves, and all
that is left is about 500 hardcore dancers.  This is good for the scene, but
not good for bigger and better promotions.  When we had spent in excess of
$4000 for putting this on, it ended up with about $240 each for John, myself,
and Todd from the clothing store who had helped sponsor us.  I found out later
that the sound had not been accounted for, and so $190 came out of John's and
my share.  That left us with $330, which all went towards the Meat Beat
Manifesto debt (yes, we still have about $500 left to pay).  Plans for Orb,
and Orbital/Aphex-Twin/Moby have been abandoned.  Plans for scaling back how
often we do these things have been pushed aside as well.  We are doing a
concert with Crash Worship on the 16th of October, and thankfully, that is
relatively cheap to do in comparison.

The small net gain coupled with the fact that someone stole my "Ecco The
Dolphin" cartridge from the Sega videogame that we had setup, along with
someone ripping off my step-mother's three folding tables from outside the
warehouse the next morning (who would be so desperate?), along with a possibly
blown 18" woofer, put a very dark cloud over what was an excellent vibe.  The
future holds scaled back raves for us, and an effort to quit what we are
doing.  The possible sidetrack into concerts looks like a dead end as well.
Although I think we as Taste are the one best teams in the country, and
possibly the planet, a fact that is constantly confirmed by outsiders, I can't
see how much longer I can go on doing something that drains me physically and
financially.  Very frustrating considering the fact that we would be doing
very well in a larger town, but good considering the fact that the audience
here is the only reason that keeps me doing them anyway.

From sfraves-owner  Mon Sep 27 14:05:35 1993
Received: by techno.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA20755; Mon, 27 Sep 93 14:05:35 PDT
