       "Home Review" (Sep 27, 12:07pm)
References: <9309271907.AA23078@netcom3.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (2.0.5 2/14/92)
To: nrg@netcom.com (Ethan I. Miller)
Subject: Re: Home Review
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <93Sep27.162330pdt.14125-2@well.sf.ca.us>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

MAJOR PROPS to Ethan and the krewe for a great party at HOME!

I had a thoroughly enjoyable time.  Only wish the sound had been cranked
up a little louder earlier in the evening -- my pal DRC would've tranced
everyone through the roof -- but perhaps it was just as well to bring it
up steadily.

OK, so here's the checklist:

1.  DJs.  We got 'em.  What a great lineup!  Strongest through and through
    I've seen for months.  I arrived at midnight so missed the earlier
    turns, but DRC was on-spot onna trancey tip (a little rough, I think
    these large events are new for her but she has a great selecter's view
    of things :).  I *finally* got to hear Jon Williams doing a great
    progressive/trance/happy house set similar to the combo he did with
    Phil Smart on their tape 'Kitchen Synch' which is my fave of '93 and
    I would highly recommend (I bought it at Housewares which doesn't
    seem to have copies at the moment, but Ameba has several -- get it
    while you can!).  Simon put through an incredibly powerful, driving
    sound and I can't wait to hear his new tape which just appeared in
    the stores this week.  And our good friend Markie, well what can I
    say except 'mental as everything' :)  During part of his set I sat
    next to the far wall by the stage and got that good South of Market
    bass reverberation thang :) :)

2.  Location.  Cesar's is really a nice place, good wood on the dance floor,
    clean setup, a nice upstairs chill area.  It seemed a bit bright with
    lots of little light strings all over the place (less would have
    highlighted the excellent light show), but really no matter.  

3.  Staff.  A bit on the obtrusive side, but not surprising, and really
    no worse than, say, the Townsend types.

4.  Patronage.  A pretty good mix of into-it types and confused locals.
    A few thuggish types hanging around at the margins trying to look
    tough but really swimming a little out of their element.  I saw a
    few familiar faces on the floor (including Vitamin B, lee, M and
    P-ter and others) and lots of unfamiliar but havin-a-great-time
    ones as well.  And even better, Ethan got to do some *serious*
    shakin' at his own party, which really indicates how well things
    were organized.

5.  Sound and lights.  Oh baby!!!  Props'n'a'half to both crews.  
    I almost had a chance to visit Community's place outside Philly a
    couple weeks ago, wish I'd been there to thank them kindly :)

6.  Extras.  Water, fruit, plenty'o'space . . . and the smiles from
    EVERY one of the DJs after their sets!

I was amazed at how much it costs to rent out these places.  It sure
is easy to lose money fast when that's half of your break-even budget.
And I hope that Ethan and his partners make it all back and then some,
because HOME has set the new standard for parties in San Francisco.

Hey Sean,

I use Doc's myself. . ...attached to construction stilts expandable from
three feetto five feet. I stay on the three foot extension. I must say
that, at times, I find greeting peopleto be a problem. I can also say
that walking above a smoke fog is lonely; but very trance-like in that
I see only a floor of smoke below me, and above exists a sky of light
with bouncing lasers dashing here and there. The best is when you find
yourself in the midst of data flashes and the projection of fractal
graphics and loony tune cartoons. I don't recommend the experience un-
less you wish to turn away from a positive vibe and alienate yourself
from your friends. Also, the stilts take time to move in and don't real-
ly work for outdoor events where the ground is bumpy. Oh well, that's
my greenback for ya.

bye,
victor
(babylon/xenon) at ihc1@utep.bitnet

heard that there will be a, uh, Gathering on the 30th (Sat.), and of course

Monday off!).  There are lots of other things going on as well, but these
two events back to back mean more ugliness to the oz.

On Mon, 27 Sep 1993, Max Enrique Sequeira Garza wrote:

> >
> >     Seriously, does anybody know of any shoes that won't make my feet
> >     complain horribly (and usually blister) when danced in for as
> >     long as a good rave lasts?
> >
> >
>         Well, back in april i was there in SF and discovered what an incredible
> experience is to rave with your Birkenstocks... what can i say... it's like
> dancing on little fluffy clouds!

To solve a blister problem try wearing two pairs of socks (a thin pair,
then a thick (ie Nike) pair. It's a squash players tip.

As for shoe I reckon 70%+ ravers in Britain wear Nikes. (Including me at
moment). I'm sure we must account for a fair percentage of Nike UK's
income :)

To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: What about speaker-power amp combinations?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

OK. I stand corrected on the unsuitability of audiophile style turntables for
DJ use. I apologize to all for speaking out of turn. But actually I was truly
interested in the reasons why Technics were superior. Thanks to all who quickly
pointed out the folly in my suggestion of alternative turntables. BUT.

Now onto something which I do have a wee little bit of knowledge about.

What is your personal preference for power amplification and sound reinforcement
speaker combinations for rave useage? I'll bet this will draw almost as many
opinions as there are people in this group.

My personal preference is Crown PB1 or, if you can find any, Phase Linear A700
power amps coupled to Mr. Hank modified Altec A7 based, horn loaded PA cabinets
equipped with Electro-Voice bass drivers. For midrange, the Electro-Voice 600
series midrange horns, and for treble, JBL multi-cellular tweeter horns 
(I forget the model number).

Mr. Hank is a fellow down in North Miami Florida who makes the most impressive
sounding speaker enclosures I've ever heard. My band used to use a PA system
designed by him that kicked ass. It used Phase Linear active crossovers and
Phase Linear A700's. Clean and LOUD!

Anyway, I also like Klipsch La Scala's and the original Klipschorns too. They
are my second choice for speakers. But with them you need bunches of them to
soak up all the power of the amp racks. They're a little too efficient.

Oh well enough bandwidth wasted.

Bye.

John Turman
john@makesys.com

There are no "internet rules" beyond "don't break the Internet".
The closest thing that comes that way is a prohibition against
chain email letters, which isn't actually network-wide policy but
every individual site seems to have accepted as local policy.

If someone is doing something of interest to the raving community,
be it smart drugs or organizing a rave or music, it is appropriate
for the list.

-george

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9309290053.AA07946@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Addition to Promotion..
In-Reply-To: <9309282131.AA13350@karl.tapir.Caltech.EDU>
References: <9309282102.AA02867@netcom2.netcom.com>
	<9309282131.AA13350@karl.tapir.Caltech.EDU>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


There aren't any Internet rules per-se, except perhaps don't mess up
other people's routing, don't use someone else's IP (i.e. register
with the NIC), etc. The Internet is a big mishmash conglomeration of
nets (you are in a maze of twisty networks, all different). They
usually have their own rules.  The NSF net, for example, is supposed
to be noncommercial and mission-specific, but it's only enforced for
severe cases of abuse. And even then there's really nothing to be done
if something comes from a net where it is permitted. Milnet
is obviously only for military traffic. When everyone can IP from
their ISDN hookup, there may be few rules at all, except don't screw
up the net. (Perhaps by then, Congress will start making laws about
junk email, etc.)

I don't mind people advertising rave (or even non-rave) related stuff
on here unless they get repetitive about it. I think it helps out the
community as people can often get things for far less than in stores
(like the crazy Eddie Twitch sale (yay!)).

Sean

Wrong!

This may have been the case a few years ago, but it isn't now. There are
plenty of companies that are doing business over the internet, or have
plans to do business over the internet. (e.g. my present employer, EIT).
"Business" use of the internet also includes advertising products for sale.

Take a look at the sorts of projects that are exciting our VP Al Gore
nowadays, and they're all basically for "doing business over the internet".
Take for example our (EIT & Smart Valley's) "CommerceNet" proposal, which
is finding strong support at both a state and federal level.  See below for
a relevant overview/excerpt on CommerceNet.

Now it may be against this list's policy to talk about items for sale, but
there is no way of enforcing the rules from a "legal" standpoing. However,
from a social standpoint, certain lists could develop working policies that
ask users not to post certain kinds of information to the list. However,
please consider the following: on these rave lists, Chris has talked about
many topical things, holds the unique perspective of having been around
during the birth of the SF rave scene, and he also happens to sell "smart
drugs" that are quite topical to the rave scene. So give him some slack...

I don't see you complaining when someone reviews a new CD/LP on the
internet. Hell, if someone does a record review on the internet, one might
construe it as advertisement for the label/artist/individual responsible
for producing the record. Where do you draw the line?

You don't.  At least not yet.

In the future, we may start seeing more instances of unsavoury things like
"internet junk mail" and free offers that attempt to generate marketing
lists and so on. Unlike the television industry, we will more easily be
able to evolve towards technological solutions that can help us filter out
unwanted e-mail. Internet junk mail may eventually drive people towards
passing laws that limit the kinds of commercialization that may be
possible.

The internet is already paid for. We all paid for it with our tax dollars
(like it or not), and we all have a vote/voice (supposedly) on how it will
be used. So it may be possible to make "advertising" over the internet
illegal, but given the current political climate, the exact opposite is
happening. And I'm glad to see it happen -- I see such massive futuristic
government funded "public works projects" as the only way to get this
country out of the recession without having to resort to this nation's
other favorite means of economic stimulus -- WAR.

Consider the "data superhighway" in analogy to the US Interstate highway
system. Taxes are levied for use of the highways; paid out of vehicle
registration fees, gas taxes, etc. So who is going to support the
interstate equivalent of the internet? We all will, but hopefully the brunt
of the costs will be done as useage taxes for commercial users. Hopefully,
the free flavor of the internet will be maintained for individuals,
universities, and researchers.  However, there's no guarantee that it will.

Also, given the current growth of the internet, and the proliferation of
high-bandwidth data services (MBONE, World Wide Web), we're going to need
the tax base of commercial internet users to help pay for the higher-speed
networking infrastructure...

--------------------

<an example of future uses of the internet, excerpted from W.W.W.
http://www.eit.com/blurbs/smartval.html>

          COMMERCENET: SMART VALLEY'S ELECTRONIC COMMERCE INITIATIVE
                                       
  JAY M. TENENBAUM
  
   Smart Valley is sponsoring a TRP initiative on  electronic commerce.  The
   project will create  CommerceNet, an information highway linking  companies
   to customers, suppliers, and development  partners over the Internet.  It
   will also populate the  highway with innovative services by soliciting grass
   roots proposals and supporting them with matching  funds, technical
   assistance, and software.
   
   CommerceNet will start by linking companies that  comprise the Valley's
   electronics food chain: IC and  component manufacturers, distributors, PC
   board  assemblers, subsystem producers (e.g., disk drives,  power supplies),
   and computer system companies.  Initially, catalogs and product literature
   will be  available on the net. On-line ordering, product data  exchange,
   delivery scheduling, collaborative  engineering and other services will then
   be added  incrementally until every business function is  supported.  If the
   electronics industry pilot proves  successful, CommerceNet will be expanded
   to other  industries and geographic regions, and the  underlying information
   highway opened to other  sectors such as healthcare, education and

Anticipated Benefits

   CommerceNet will enhance competitiveness by  eliminating the delays, costs,
   and errors associated  with paper-based transactions. It will also
   significantly reduce inventory and excess capacity  by encouraging
   coordination of production  schedules and outsourcing.  By serving
   businesses in  both the commercial and defense sectors,  CommerceNet will
   accelerate the transition to a  single, unified industrial base.
   
   CommerceNet will open new business opportunities  by creating an electronic
   marketplace and  distribution channel for information services that are
   international in scope, virtually instantaneous, and  free. In the
   electronics industry, for example,  CommerceNet is expected to spawn
   information  businesses selling on-line access to CAD and  software
   libraries, supercomputer simulation, part  locating and order aggregating
   services, etc.   Finally, as a regional prototype of the proposed  National
   Information Infrastructure (NII),  CommerceNet will prepare the Valley's
   businesses  and other institutions to lead in the exploitation of
   electronic markets and information services.
   
   Many large companies already benefit from the  efficiencies of electronic
   data interchange (EDI)  with their major trading partners.  However, EDI is
   generally not cost effective for small companies or  occasional transactions
   because each relationship  entails expensive and time consuming private
   arrangements. A major goal of CommerceNet is to  make EDI widespread and
   spontaneous by  transacting business in open electronic markets on  public
   networks.
   
What's needed

   Four things are needed to make CommerceNet  successful.  First, JVSV's
   industry working groups  must join with trade associations (e.g., AEA, EIDX)
    to standardize business practices and certify  suppliers that adhere to
   them. E-commerce will not  take off as long as every company has
   idiosyncratic  trade agreements, vendor qualification processes,  part
   descriptions and the like.
   
   Second, a majority of the Valley's companies must  get on the Internet.
   Economical dial-up access to  the Internet is now available from a variety
   of local  services such as Netcom, Portal, and the Well.  For  more
   demanding applications, BARRNet is  collaborating with Pac Bell and other
   carriers to  create a new high-speed dial-up IP service that is an  order of
   magnitude more cost-effective than that  currently available using leased
   lines. The planned  service will exploit new technologies, such as ISDN,
   and economies of scale, such as centralized network  management services.
   
   Third, the Internet must be enhanced to support e- commerce. Essential
   services include privacy- enhanced multimedia mail, directories of people
   and  services, format translation, and remittance. More  advanced services
   include information retrieval,  real-time collaboration, and software
   interoperation.  Software is also needed that makes it easy for  developers
   to offer new services over the net and for  clients to use them.
   
   Finally, the marketplace must be primed with  services. We will start by
   persuading existing large  EDI trading partners to transact business on
   CommerceNet. We are pleased to report that the  EDI directors of several of
   the Valley's major  computer and semiconductor companies are eager to
   participate in CommerceNet, and to enlist their  suppliers and distributors.
   
   We will then focus on smaller companies and  individuals, helping them to
   develop innovative  services that expand their businesses or simplify  their
   interfaces with customers and suppliers. Many  such services can be
   delivered effectively via e- mail, and are thus candidates for early
   deployment.  We will lubricate this nascent marketplace by  establishing a
   directory of regional email addressees  and encouraging participants to
   adopt standard mail  boxes at their sites for services such as "info",
   "catalog", "support", "orders", etc. Momentum will  build rapidly, as
   companies sign on to take  advantage of the ever-growing spectrum of
   services,  then begin offering services of their own.
   
Next Steps

   A 5-year TRP proposal is being prepared for  submission on July 23, 1993.
   The funds are needed  to develop the enhanced Internet services and
   software, and to subsidize participation by small  businesses. Thereafter,
   CommerceNet will be self- supporting.  The required matching funds will come
   from the in-kind contributions of recipients of  development grants, as
   well as vendor-supplied  subsidies for purchasing network services, hardware
   and software.
   
   ...

--------------------

 A few months ago I ran a similar posting to the one I just mailed through
the net,and basically nobody complained except the administrator of one
list,which I pointedly left out of this posting.As Niel pointed out,as far
as I know,there has been a policy shift vis a vis commercial traffic on
the net.Still,I can sympathize to a certain extent with the Caltech
persons concerns.Ive seen lists when they get mired in commercial
traffic,and its not something I like either.But I don't think this has
happened yet on sfraves..and I hope it never does.I'm sorry to have
contributed to the noise level. Still,I'd rather read about tapes,or
nutritional supplements,or interesting deals on CD's than some other
things..like flame wars. Pick your poison.. Still.. I havn't unsubscribed
yet!!

new,better product soon.(a single serving product,and I'll leave it at that)
If they dont..well,I'm already looking for another job!!
Big Hugs to Everyone!

> From: hogg@tapir.caltech.edu (David Hogg)
> >    I understand that it is a violation of internet rules to advertise
> > products for sale.  Please desist lest the internet become like the
> > television industry.
> 
> Wrong!
> 
....

> There are plenty of companies that are doing business over the
> internet ...

I wouldn't be connected to the internet, if I didn't have a business
justification.  My life is mostly written in my charge slips; commerce
strengthens the internet.

The internet will not become like television, the internet will
destroy television, and with it the concept of valueless broadcast
advertising passively watched.  However, laying just under television
in the dustbin of history will be the sterile internet coteries that
couldn't tolerate any discussion so real it might involve money.  The
thing I like about the rave lists is that they relate to SOMETHING
THAT IS ACTUALLY HAPPENING IN THE ACTUAL WORLD, as opposed to
alt.intelectual.pointless.  I'm not particularly interested in Chris's
products, so I skip over his messages, but what he is doing is not as
big a problem as people who say, "In my day, we didn't do that on the
Internet."  Refuse to use pens with logos on them, refuse to use the
rubber dividers at the checkout line if they have ads on them, refuse
to read free magazines with ads in them, then tell me that commerce
has no place on the internet.


BTW, EIT is doing some very cool stuff.  EIT is one of the companies
that want to make the Internet available to as many people as
possible, and have, I hear, been working with well-known privacy
advocates Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility (CPSR).
I have a lot more respect for EIT and Jay Tenenbaum than I do for
those who want to make the Internet into some sort of electronic
gentleman's club.


I hope none of you are offended by my companie's new official SIG
line.  While it doesn't mention our products (Software for electronics
manufacturing), it could still be construed as advertising.

As long as the for-sale stuff relates to the rave scene, it's no less
appropriate than posting CD's for sale to rec.music.marketplace (which 
I recently did, and had a LOT of success with).  

        Brian

        sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
In-Reply-To: Mark Guthrie's message of Tue, 28 Sep 93 16:21:14 PDT <9309282321.AA09229@cassy.lurnix.com>
Subject: Re: Addition to Promotion..
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



  Mark> Is it a violation of rules or breach of ettiquette?  There's a difference.


Well, much of the traffic on this list is going to and from US
academic sites.  That means it will traverse the NSFnet backbone and
several of the regional mid-level networks.  These networks are funded
out of public money, and they are governed by a set of rules known as
"Acceptable Use Policy", or AUP.

In the case of NSFnet, AUP dictates that the network is only used for
traffic in direct support of education and reseach activities.  In
practice, this is interpreted in a pretty lax manner, and pretty much
any non-commercial traffic is tollerated.  And of course, some
commercial traffic satisfies the AUP -- eg a university comminicating
with a commercial vendor in order to get information about products
for academic use.

So the answer is, technically, yes, it's a breach of AUP.  In
practice, as long as it doesn't become excessive, no one will care.

But remember, the US government is paying for it.....

Hope this answers the question....


	Cosmic Roy

	<9309282321.AA09229@cassy.lurnix.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

 > Well, much of the traffic on this list is going to and from US
 > academic sites.  That means it will traverse the NSFnet backbone and
 > several of the regional mid-level networks.  These networks are funded
 > out of public money, and they are governed by a set of rules known as
 > "Acceptable Use Policy", or AUP.
 > 
 > In the case of NSFnet, AUP dictates that the network is only used for
 > traffic in direct support of education and reseach activities.  In
 > practice, this is interpreted in a pretty lax manner, and pretty much
 > any non-commercial traffic is tollerated.  And of course, some
 > commercial traffic satisfies the AUP -- eg a university comminicating
 > with a commercial vendor in order to get information about products
 > for academic use.

I talked to Stephen Wolff (director of the NSF) a while back when I
was working at the University of Kentucky. It is a long story, but I
was in the middle of a funding battle for the University's T3 line.
The official answer is that the policy is not enforced for things like
personal sales, etc. Where one draws the line is largely interpreted
by system administrators, and their opinion on whether the violation
will affect their NSF funding :).

Outside  traffic that passes through the NSF doesn't make the sender
liable for the AUP. It makes the actual NSF site liable.

In any case, there is zero chance that Chris' sale announcement is
going to blow any official gaskets anywhere. The only objections here
are personal, not official, and I don't think the sfravers as a group
have a problem with it or any of the other announcements that are tied
to money.

Sean

From: Roy Badami <roy@harlequin.co.uk>
Date: Wed, 29 Sep 93 18:17:16 BST
Message-Id: <8709.9309291717@wundt.harlequin.co.uk>
To: csc@pilot.njin.net
Cc: ccat@netcom.com, hogg%tapir.caltech.edu%uunet@uunet.uu.net,
        sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU, socal-raves@ucsd.edu, winston@lurnix.com
In-Reply-To: Sean Casey's message of Wed, 29 Sep 93 12:50:51 EDT <9309291650.AA03936@pilot.njin.net>
Subject: Re: Addition to Promotion..
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU



  Sean> Outside  traffic that passes through the NSF doesn't make the sender
  Sean> liable for the AUP. It makes the actual NSF site liable.

Yep, that soudns right.  But when you say NSF site, you mean any site
that's registered with the NSFnet as having "fully connected status",
which includes a large proportion of all internet sites.  There are
very few sites directly on the NSFnet network (most connect via a
mid-level net).

eg harlequin.co.uk is registered with NSFnet as being fully connected,
which means that our IP packets will be forwarded by their routers.
In order to get fully connected status, of course, we had to agree to
be bound by the AUP.  Without fully connected status, NSFnet will just
drop your packets, so you'll be unable to ftp to most edu sites, for
instance....

  Sean> In any case, there is zero chance that Chris' sale announcement is
  Sean> going to blow any official gaskets anywhere. 

Yep, I think I said that.  I have no objections at all to Chris's
announcement, and I doubt anyone else would either.

I just didn't like to see lots of dangerous misinformation proclaiming
that the internet has no rules, only etiquette.  That may be true of
cooperative networks like UUCPnet, but it's certainly not true for the
large centrally run backbones that make up the internet.


	Cosmic Roy

From: Joachim Vance (The Underdog) <jvance@einstein.oac.uci.edu>
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


  As most of this topic is not related to these lists, I want to leave
you with a few things to think about (that are by no means the last
word on the subject) and then ask that this topic be taken to private
email (or the individual groups if the discussion is "appropriate posts
to foo-raves").

  1.  AUPs (Acceptable Use Policies) are in conflict everywhere.
      Every network and site have AUPs that vary from "you can do
      anything that's not illegal" to "you can't do anything unless
      it's related to school/research."   This conflict is quite a
      hindrance to the growth of the internet and quite a few people
      think that most AUPs should be thrown out the window.

  2.  Due to the "seamless" nature of the internet and the existence
      of  commercial and other net backbones, it is not always
      obvious whether or not a piece of traffic will pass through the
      NSFnet backbone.  This makes AUPs rather difficult to enforce.

  3.  The "rave" mailing lists are arguably not "acceptable use" of
      most university/research sites.  At UCI a short time ago, they
      determined that USENET and email to off campus sites were not
      acceptable use of UCI's instructional computers (funded in part
      by the NSF).  Luckily some students and faculty who felt that
      these were important learning tools managed to overturn that
      policy.   

  4.  I think that since Usenet and email lists cross so many
      boundaries that it should be up to the local communities to
      determine acceptable uses of each area.  Some newsgroups/lists
      go the moderated route to enforce this.  Other's are less
      stringent. 

   If you feel that a particular type of post threatens your net access
then take it up with the poster or the list administrator.  More
often than not, that should be a job for the NFS or site admin to deal
with.   Or, if as a group each lists decides that "commercial" posts
are not appropriate then I'm sure that the members will be happy not
to make commercial type posts.

   Personally I feel that the only posts to SoCal-Raves (and the other
mailing lists for that matter)that are inappropriate are those that
are off topic. 

Joachim

The book is called:
Internet Starter Kit for Macinotsh by Adam C. Engst (Publisher of TidBITS)
ISBN: 1-56830-064-6 List price $29.95

Should be available shortly at all the cool bookstores. It indead comes with MacTCP 2.02
(a $59 value). It also comes with the latest versions of freeware: Fetch (FTP), Eudora (Email)
InterSLIP (SLIP under MacTCP), TurboGopher, and Stuffit Expander.

Also if modem's are  too slow, (warning commercial comming up :-) you can
use our ISDN to the Internet service which currently has a POP in Menlo
Park and soon in San Francisco, South Bay and East Bay. FTP to internex.net for
more info...

Joachim Vance (The Underdog) writes:

 >   3.  The "rave" mailing lists are arguably not "acceptable use" of
 >       most university/research sites.  At UCI a short time ago, they
 >       determined that USENET and email to off campus sites were not
 >       acceptable use of UCI's instructional computers (funded in part
 >       by the NSF).  Luckily some students and faculty who felt that
 >       these were important learning tools managed to overturn that
 >       policy.   

Universities have been deciding things arbitrarily and censoring
things based on content for far too long. Recently, students have been
battling it in court, and they have been winning.

Would a modern dance mailing list be acceptable?
Would one oriented towards the school's football team?
How about a math club list?

If any of these are acceptable, then a rave list is acceptable.
Especially at a public university:

    It is illegal for a public university to censor a public forum or
    a limited public forum (such as a mailing list) on the basis of
    content.

This isn't my opinion; it's legal precedent and case history. If a
public university does this, it's a violation of 1st amendment rights
(and IMHO, poor academia).  Most students aren't aware of the
legalities.

Unfortunately, the sfraves list is being run from a private
university, so we don't enjoy those constitutional protections.

Sean

Subject: S.F. Panel Backs Easing of Cabaret Curfew Laws
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

[SF Chronicle, 9/29/93]

by Dan Levy  [name sounds familiar.... -brian]

        In a victory for all-night dancers and party-goers, a San
Francisco supervisors' committee voted yesterday to amend the police
code to make it legal for people aged 18 to 21 to enter and be inside
dance halls and cabarets after 2 a.m.

        By a 2-to-1 vote, the Board of Supervisors' Health and Public
Safety Committee changed the rarely enforced police code section,
which currently allows only those over the age of 21 to be inside
"after hours" establishments after 2 a.m.  The motion now goes before
the full 11-member board.

	The hearing drew about 100 club-world denizens to the
supervisors' chambers for the second time in two weeks.  After a few
of them testified against the current law, Supervisor Terence
Hallinan, the author of the proposed amendment, asked to see a show of
support.  Like a classroom full of dutiful pupils, a mass of hands
went up.

	"I can vote, I can buy stock, but interestingly enough, I
can't dance," said Susan Kameny, a 21-year-old student who was
presumably speaking for her younger friends.  Referring to police
concerns that a change in the code would lead to more crime, Kameny
said, "I don't think it's fair to use young adults as scapegoats."

[GO SUSIE!  FEED THEM THOSE SOUND BYTES BABY!]

	San Francisco police Lieutenant Barry Johnson told the
supervisors that he saw "no social redeeming value" to dancing after 2
a.m.  He implied that officers from the department's Southern Station,
which handles the South of Market nightclub district, have a difficult
time dealing with "300 to 400 people roaming the streets, going from
club to club."

	In an interview after the hearing, Johnson said a large part
of the police concern stems from the station's own staffing problems.
South of Market has the city's highest concentration of cabarets and
nightclubs, but Southern Station does not have the officers to beef up
patrols on weekends and popular club nights, Johnson said.

	"We don't have enough people," he said.

	"If we're going to cover the area the way we're going to have
to now, we'll need more people."

[sheeya, right.]

I haven't really been out this week, so I didn't find any flyers
for Friday...if anyone gets anything, post it.  Otherwise, check out
Corduroy City or Mission Rock; I think Zanzibar has stopped (I was
there at 1:30 two Fridays ago and no Josh).  Saturday, Mr.Floppy is
back with an intriguing lineup including several live acts.

And Sunday, everyone come out to Golden Gate Park, as SFR brings back
the "Rave in the Park"!  Thanks to Leg of Eel for doing a lot of the
organizing (and permit-retrieving) for this, and other SFR members for
contributing DJ talents, sound, moola, and other goodies.  It oughta
be a fantastic afternoon, and hopefully we can move it in the evening!

i wanted to let you guys know a little more about what is happening inside
city hall...well first of all i want to point out that clubs in this city
are sponcering the lawyers to help move this along...clubs by there nature
of making moola have decided to use this is an attempt to be anti-rave
(i.e. outdoor renegade) ...an amendment to an amendment changed it so that
this new curfew law only applies to places that are "permitted and
opperated as a cabaret"...now in one respect this is cool...cuz then 18-21
year olds can dance after 2...but it could *possibly* be interpreted as
any place that is not permitted could be shut down....so this is kinda of
a bitter sweet battle...(hell they even got the general manager from live
105 to give a speech (and i don't think he really was briefed well i think
he was being used as comming from a bussiness organization) i will be
posting phone and fax numbers..and there is a meeting on monday when it
goes before the board...i will keep you all posted...partyon...susie (:

p.s. supervisor leal has it all wrong!!! she is being manipulated by the
mission district merchants (big bussiness) so that she can deny what i see
as a constitutional right...also she doesn't realize that this law is
currently not being enforced and so the result of this law being amended
will be exactly like now...dahhhhh!

From sfraves-owner  Thu Sep 30 16:01:36 1993

 Last year , I made a post about the dissappearance of Auricular Records ,
one of the few sources of recordings by Big City Orchestre , Nux Vomica ,
and other experimental bands. 

 Well , Auricular Records is still in business. I picked up a mail order
catalog at the WORKS gallery in San Jose ( Nux Vomica had just made a
live performance there ). In the catalog are offered recordings by the 
artists I've mentioned above , as well as Curium and Chemical Toybox ,
and some solo efforts.

The address is:
 
	Auricular Records
  	2434 21st Avenue
  	San Francisco , CA 94116
  
 Business Phone [ call between 12 noon and 5PM ] (415) 664-6302
 
Looking at the size of the catalog , I'm sure two 1st Class stamps would
pay for postage.
 
 
 					Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From: Gioni Pasquinelli <pasque@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: FMR
To: The Ravin' Peoples <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.07.9309301621.A28223-b100000@hamlet.ucdavis.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU


	Well it was a pretty terrible night...here goes

	Gregor, Rob and I drove to the site on San Antonio from Davis
arriving about 2:30.  Right when we pulled up we heard rumors of cops and
another site.  
	We got directions to go back over the bay to Fremont along 
Paseo Padre.  As we were pulling in we passed a parked cop who most likely
wondered why so many cars were passing by his way.  We parked got out
and meandered around for about ten minutes till a cop rolled up.
	Upon seeing the hundreds of people he kicked back and waited for the
backups to arrive.  The FMR crew went down to talk to them and see if they
would allow us to set up.  By 3:30 everyone came back and said that do to
the possibility of gang violence we were to move to another site.  I
figured thats all right cause at least the cops were gonna let us do our
thing just somewhere else.
	So we followed the van further south in Fremont to a wetlands spot
were they started setting up.  I was pretty happy at this point and
couldn't figure out why we hadn't come here first.  It was a perfect site.
But of course it didn't last!  They had almost finished setting up when a
cop rolled up and over the bull horn shouted.  Get in your cars and go
home, you are creating a fire hazard and must leave.
	I couldn't believe it!  We were on solid dirt surrounded by marsh
yet we were a fire hazard.  Yeah right?!  By then it was around 5 or later
and so we went home.  I didn't feel like waiting around for another site
to be picked so we left for the two hour drive home.  
	It was a pretty bad night, but maybe YSH can make up for it!

	Did anything happen after that?

Peace out,
G

Gioni Pasquinelli pasque@hamlet.ucdavis.edu

Everything is looking good for Connection Earth, just some final points:

1. If Ethan needs help in the morning hauling equipment, I'll be
contacting the volunteers directly.  We'll definately need people in the
evening.  I'm sure I can recruit when that time comes.

2. I'll be bringing garbage bags.  I'll need help bagging and disposing. I
figure the I can take 4 or 5 bags in my car.  If a few people can take a
bag or two home with them, we should be OK.

3. Vibe Enhancers: Those who haven't contributed can relieve themselves of
the overwhelming guilt by bringing fruit, drinks, bubbles, toys, 
luv phasers... whatever will put smiles on faces.  No guns ;-) 

4. I anyone has a cellular phone they could bring, for an emergency, that
would be great.  I don't think GG Park is gang turf, but it'll be nice to
be prepared for anything. 

So far, it looks like the weather will cooperate.  I'm looking forward to
connecting with those that I know, and those that I don't.  Come early, we
might actually be able to start the music at 12, and if not, Marx Meadows
is a real nice place to hang out anyway.

Thanks again to everyone for your encouragement & support!

An addendum to my Auricular Records posting:

 For those who went to Richard Sun's IMAGINATION rave at 177 Townsend , one
of the memorable things there was the free-form improvised music/noise 
ambient room . Called SENSE/NET , it was a sonic performance by members of 
Iao Core , BCO , Nux Vomica , and others. This nine-hour performance was 
reduced to a one hour cassette , available from Auricular Records.

 I've ordered it , and I'll let you folks know what I think of it after
I take a listen.

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

In-Reply-To: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing)
       "FMR?  Where'd it go?" (Sep 30,  3:05pm)
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: red@net.bio.net (Ben Wing), sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re: FMR?  Where'd it go?
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU

The FMR story....

Site #1: Cops arrived about a half-hour after the first people showed up,
apparently tipped off by a security device in the park itself [we're 
watching you!].  The sound truck and such hadn't even arrived yet.  Geoff
and I started giving cars directions to the second possible site.

Site #2: Arrived on the tail end of the caravan to see a night watchman 
standing at the entrance to the recreation area.  Damn.  Within minutes
4 police cars had entered the parking lot and with their bullhorns asked
people to leave.  I remembered the flyers I made up for directions to a
backup site back in may, in case the May FMR in palo Alto had been a
bust.  didn't use them then, so I pulled them out and used them now.
Within 10 minutes everyone was back on the road to site #3 - many people
went back to the first site, where more directions to site #3 were given.

Site #3: Almost everyone was here by the time the police got wise.  The
area was fairly much in the open, unfortunately - I had thought it would
make a good backup site as it was easy to access from the highway and 
the dance floor was a paved cul-de-sac.  6 more police cars showed up,
and a member of the FMM went to talk to the cops.  They talked for a long
time, while everyone else hung out by their cars and were generally pretty
mellow.  They came very close to granting permission to having it, and 
then the captain came out and said there had been a gang shooting there
a week early (I doubt the truth of this, as it's in the middle of nowhere)
so it was no go.  Someone in the crowd piped up about a site a few miles 
north; this time people didn't even bother with complex directions, they 
simply formed a caravan out, directed by cops with flares in the ground
and airplane-landing-attendant-style hand-held direction lights.  

Site #4: Better than any of the other three, site of a previous smaller
renegade party, with plenty of parking.  Unfortunately the long stream
of cars caught the eye of a security guard at a building the cars passed
by, who called the Newark police, who stopped one of the cars and 
discovered it was the same group of people from site #3 (evidently word
gets around fast inpolice departments at 4 in the morning).  As it turned
out even though the route went through Newark, the actual site was in
Fremont, the same jurisdiction as the previous site, so the same cops came
down and asked us to leave, jokingly suggesting we should have gone there
first.  It was decided that 4 tries was enough for one night, and that maybe
another party would be attempted the next night, tonight.

So, I dunno if anything actually is happening, I'm here at school with a
project due tomorrow... anyone go?  It is/was probably somewhere quite
safe, like bonny Doon.  

Anyways, referring to it as a "fiasco" or "disaster" is probably NOT the 
best choice of words.  it implies ignorance and intentional mistreatment
by those who were throwing the party, and I can assure you no one wanted
it to happen at those places than us.  Maybe the sites could have used
some more thought and scouting, but all of them at least had the potential
for a rocking party, and it was simply a series of misfortunes that
caused the party to not take place.

Well, the Fremont cops wished us better luck next time, so we'll see....

        Brian

Subject: orb and sensenet
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Date: Fri, 1 Oct 1993 10:43:32 -0700 (PDT)

to avoid panic i will post the orb tickets as soon as they arrive at
ameba on this here computer gismo. i was called on tuesday by orb
woman voice and asked if she could bring them friday. so we will
be  strung in anticipation untill further notice. 

Larry has wisdom in his long memorie of sense net and the auricular
thing. Allan & jenny of auricular are sound sculpters of the old
school 1st wave of "industrial" which i believe mix heavy into rave/
underground dance music roots. disco, is the popular force, which
brought the vinyl out of the nerdy record private school, and into
group pleasure. Rave is weird electric sound with rythym, 
but it has sparked a new intrest in more abstract, non rythymic sound
but many have a short memmory and due to the negative image of the
testosterone wax trax "industrial" the people who really can deliver
the most awesome "ambient " sound come from the old school(steven stapleton
cab voltaire members etc.) I do not like my ambient room to sound like
a cancer therapy healing new age flute harp synth mush. i like the music to
be mentally engaging and viceral swirling trippy witty beautiful....not
just a cliche of what a few eno records gave birth to.
 
I am so happy that the park is happening, this music and our bodies
need daytime outdoor )F\ffM!s v<,?o                                       
                  salutations

                              allen@ameba

Here is a survey from the Seattle's XLR8R zine. (reprinted it wo permission)  

They are offering prizes:

	You could win a free gift!!! If you fill this poll out completely
	and turn it in not only will you help to change this magazine for 
	the better but you will be placed in a drawing in which the winner
	may choose from the following:
		a) Shitty Rave CDs
		   -LA Style (incl "Im Raving" and "James Brown is Dead")
		   -Rave 'Til Dawn comp (The Movement, 2 Unlimited...)
		   -Smart E's "Sesamee's Treet" 	
		    (who can forget this kiddie classic?)
		b) Vinyl from Tribal America
		   -4 new 12"s from a rather lovely label
		c) Techno Treat
		   -Tressor Comps 1&2 on CD

It says you can bring the poll in to:
	Reactor - Seattle, 1st ave
	Basic - Seattle, Broadway
	XLR8R - Seattle, U-district
	Turntable Mary's - Portland
	HouseWares - San Francisco

or mail it to XLR8R, 1314 NE 43rd Suite 208, Seattle, WA 98105

but since the editor of XLR8R has an email acct, you can flood his mbox:
	bollock@u.washington.edu    here's a message from to nw-raves:

>Hello dearest ravers,
>My name is Andrew Smith, I run this crap magazine called XLR8R out of
>Seattle. It is a dance music mag, covering mostly raves. Anyway, I have
>been meaning to send you all a message so that I might begin to get
>information from you people.
>Andrew
 
or send it to me, and i'll get it to him.
	plui@iossvr.gm.hac.com

1) Where do you call home?

	b. Between the Cascades and the Rockies
	c. Vancouver, BC
	d. Oregon (specify)
	e. San Francisco
	f. Elsewhere in CA (specify)
	g. East coast
	f. Elswhere (specify)

	a. -18
	b. 18-20
	c. 21-25
	d. 26-35
	e. 36-45
	f. 46+

	a. Female
	b. Male
	c. Undecided

	a. Upper Food Chain
	b. Lower Food Chain
	c. Extraterrestrial

	a. Homosexual
	b. Heterosexual
	c. Bisexual
	d. Boring

	___ times a month, or
	___ times a week

	a. House	h. Techno	l. Tribal
	b. Trance	i. Rave		m. Acid Jazz

	d. Hip Hop	k. Ambient	
	e. I have no idea
	f. I hate dance music
	g. Others ___________

	b. Guarantee of good time	i. Non-presription drugs
	c. Alcohol			j. Sex

	e. Education/enlightenment 	l. Posing
	f. Drooling

	b. no

	b. no

	a. yes
	b. no

	c. 15-50 miles		e. 50-200 miles

	c. There are no good clubs

	a. Vinyl	c. CDs
	b. Tapes	d. Food

	b. $10-20	f. $20-50
	c. $50-100	g. $100-250
	d. More? ______

	b. no

	a. yes
	b. no

<forwards deleted>

>
>---------------------------- o f f i c i a l
>
>                           i n v i t a t i o n ------------------------------
>
>
>                    The Goal & Objectives of P-funk online 
>
>    To bring together, not necessarily unite, people of all kinds to dance-
>                         "THE DANCE" at "THE PARTY"
>
>    The pre-PARTY preparation consists of establishing the "P-funk Network"
> 
>p-funk online is set up to help us network with others in areas we feel most
>comfortable. This will help us discuss issues, express feelings, share ideas
>                  and basically get to know each other before
>                                 THE PARTY.
> 
>I am the system operator (sysop) of p-funk online (pfo). pfo is a computer 
>bulletin board system (bbs) dedicated to the funk. What is funk? I think 
>funk is a way of thinking. A whole attitude and outlook on life and the way
>one handles things. I started this bbs so the funky folx would have a place
>to compute.(There are funky computer people).  WE ARE THOSE PARTY PEOPLE!
>
>pfo will be the backbone of a worldwide club of funky folx dedicated to one
>thing: THE DANCE. A bunch of folx on the same beat ain't nothing but a party.
>To find that rhythm, all we have to do is know each other. I'm not talking
>about uniting the world, just getting to know some of the people in it. 
>
>I see alot of people trying to stop racism, save trees, halt injustice. 
>Not us. We're all about a real good time. Up for the for the downstroke.
>We ain't try'n to change the world, just play in it. You with me?
>
>If you can help with THE PARTY or need more info, rsvp to pfo. 
>You'll wanna be down with this. Come funk with us.
>
>
>
>
>---------------------------- o f f i c i a l
>
>                           e n l i s t m e n t ------------------------------
>
>                            Wut da'funk is up?
>                                        
>                          
>                        Welcome to p-funk online.
>                                     
> PFO is in pre-PARTY-prep stage 1", "infunktry enlistment". The infunktry is
>made up mostly of dancefloor guerillas, our frontline funkers. The first come
>funky of this group will be selected Regional Beat Keepers. RBKs will be re-
>sponsible for the region's off-line infunktry enlistment and rhythm main-
>tenance. RBKs will keep their region's infunktry on the ONE. The ONE is our
>universal beat. Are you with me out there? I don't think y'all hear me. 
>
>This ain't nuttin but a party. Let's get this party started right. 
>Check out the questionaire. Answer how ya'like. 
>And if ya'like, add wutcha'like. OK?

Greetings from the Fluid Grooves posse!

We're in the first throes of putting together Liquid Air for October,
and we need some help.  I wanted to put this out to the list to solicit
any assistance you can offer.  We also need help with some specifics.
Please send me some return email if you can help.  We definitely need:

1.  3 people to load, 3 people to unload
2.  People to personally hand out flyers at the major parties, the hotspots
    on Haight, the hotspots in Berkeley, the east bay, the peninsula, and
    san jose.  We could also use some help in getting the word out to
    your friends.
3.  People to oversee the parking area
4.  People to help collect donations and greet folks

If you can help somewhere else, let me know, too.  Any and all assistance
is greatly appreciated!
-- 
Bryce Ryan -- AMBIANCE --------- brycer@netcom.com------------
Sound surrounds you like Liquid Air ------- Every Month ------
